
------------------------@1-------------------------
Welcome to Piazza!
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
<br/>


<ol style="margin:0;padding:0;list-style-position:inside;"> <li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Ask questions!</strong><br/><br/>The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"><strong>Edit questions and answers wiki-style.</strong><br/><br/>Think of Piazza as a Q&amp;A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single <strong>students' answer</strong> that students can edit collectively (and a single <strong>instructors’ answer</strong> for instructors).<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Add a followup to comment or ask further questions.</strong><br/><br/>To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a <strong>followup discussion</strong>. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&amp;A above.<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Go anonymous.</strong><br/><br/>Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Tag your posts.</strong><br/><br/>It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>Format code and equations.</strong><br/><br/>Adding a code snippet? Click the <strong>pre</strong> or <strong>tt</strong> button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. <br/>Mathematical equation? Click the <strong>Fx</strong> button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.<br/><br/></li><li style="margin:0;padding:0"> <strong>View and download class details and resources.</strong> </li></ol>


<br/>
Click the
<strong>Course Page</strong>
 button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at
<strong>team@piazza.com</strong>
. We love feedback!

Tips & Tricks for a successful class

------------------------@3-------------------------

------------------------@6-------------------------
Welcome and Important Info Below!
<p>Welcome to the Piazza page for EECS 280!  Please read this post thoroughly to not miss any important information.</p>


<p></p>


<p>This is a space for you to <strong>ask (and answer!) questions</strong> about technical material in the course and about course projects.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Piazza is intended as a resource for <strong>current EECS 280</strong> students. We ask that students not currently enrolled in the course refrain from participating (either asking or answering questions).</p>


<p></p>


<p>As always, <strong>be kind</strong> to your fellow students and instructors!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Please <strong>don't post your code publicly</strong> on Piazza. Doing so is a violation of the Honor Code. If you need help, either go to office hours or make a <strong>private post</strong> (visible only to you and the instructors).</p>


<p></p>


<p>All course information and links can be found at our <strong>website</strong>. <a href="http://eecs280.org/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">http://eecs280.org/</a></p>


<p>(alternate link: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/eecs280.org/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/eecs280.org/</a>)</p>


<p></p>


<p>A few more things...</p>


<p></p>


<p>1) To help answer your question we sometimes look things up, which often requires a uniqname. To save time, and thus allow us to answer your questions more quickly,<br/><strong>please make a small setup change to Piazza</strong>. Go to the upper right corner, next to your name, and click on the gear there. Select Account/Email settings. On the screen that appears, after your "Full Name", add your uniqname in parentheses as shown below.<br/><img height="186" src="https://lh6.googleusercontent.com/1cmiArfD6g7GuTptRVgTmDohU8jlmx67hQz4C2F89r1gbmAFF19Fe_QRGR1PtW5YT-w2zPonivUUXBUT2nHX1bRTkI4d_u-Do4YGMB0N3HlPe5gOmR9OX3_J20--HKe79WLD4u-v" width="479"/></p>


<p><br/>2) Please make use of Piazza's search bar before posting a new question. You will save everybody's time that way! If you see a question that has been asked before, feel free to link to it using "@". For example, we will link to this post by means of <a href="/class/ksoz9z684qy18u?cid=6" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><a data-pats="post_ref" href="6" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('6');">@6</a>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Note: If you are posting a screenshot of an error, please also include some searchable test in the post to describe your error. Ex: "X Code error Command usr/bin/make/ failed with exit code 2"</p>


<p></p>


<p>3) Find all dates and times for office hours, discussions, and due dates at our course calendar on our website linked above<strong>.</strong> Any super-mega-important changes (like a change in a due date) will be emailed to everyone, and any not-as-important changes (like rescheduling office hours) may be reflected on the calendar. See the calendar for all lectures, labs, and office hours for the week.<br/><br/>4) Every project will have an FAQ post to save time with asking and answering questions<strong>.</strong> Please refer to that post before asking any questions related to projects. If you notice a question as been asked multiple times, you can suggest something be added to that particular post.<br/><br/>5) It's sometimes difficult to identify a compiler error based on a written description. If you have a compiler error, please post the full output. This includes the command you used to compile as well as the error messages. If you have to scroll to see all of your errors, post the ones that appear first and indicate it goes beyond that. Also, a snippet of the lines of code that are causing this error is helpful.<br/><br/>Stay tuned for more announcements/tutorials/links from your fellow instructors!<br/><br/>#pintroduction</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@7-------------------------
tutorial
<p>In the tutorial, I am confused about what exactly they mean by "On Windows, it’s “Bash on Ubuntu on Windows”. This is right after I checked my tools on Ubuntu. (I am using windows 10 pro on hp)</p>


<h2>Starter files<a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup.html#starter-files" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a></h2>


<p>In this section, we’ll download the starter files and get our project to compile by adding function stubs.</p>


<p>Open your shell for this step. On macOS and Linux, that’s the Terminal application. On Windows, it’s “Bash on Ubuntu on Windows”.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Likely, that's referring to using Windows Subsystem for Linux on Windows</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It just means to use Ubuntu, which I assume you downloaded following <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_wsl.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this</a></p>

Because of this, it only ever shows me the first step of the debugging section of the tutorial.</p>

------------------------@10-------------------------
C++ Environment Not Available for Debugging
<p>Hello,</p>


<p>When I try to set up the debugger, the C++ or GDB/LLDB environment does not show up in the options for a debugging environment. I have already installed the C++ extension, so I don't know why it won't show up.</p>


<p><img alt="" height="144" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy2v236ihf38t%2F2ad012ae0cf38a76d4055968864f650f93fba185c48108292a0f0c1549435df6%2Fdebugging.png" width="567"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Looks like there may be an issue in the latest version of either VS Code or the C/C++ extension where it doesn't give the proper options in that dropdown list. Sorry about the inconvenience! We'll work on updating our tutorial to compensate.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For now, you can just go ahead and hit enter in that dropdown without choosing any debugger configuration and it will create an empty launch.json file. That's fine, since in a few steps our tutorial will have you copy in the proper contents for that file anyway, replacing whatever is there.</p>

------------------------@15-------------------------
C++ not G++ compiler
<p>I am on the compiling part of the VS Code tutorial on mac, however, my compiler is c++ not g++. Not sure what to do.</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="102" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyntjtu1l910h%2F4719f81225cd2dccc33b4e6657bd9a4e03171721ee0c9dc270bd066a5bd041e5%2FScreen_Shot_2022-08-29_at_8.40.27_AM.png" width="1904"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe that `c++` often just represents whatever compiler you have on your system. That could very well be g++. You could maybe try taking a look at the first line of your Makefile (`CXX`) and see if you can change that from `c++` to `g++</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think that should be fine. Does stats_tests.exe exist in your directory after running that?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>My Makefile says CXX ?= g++. I do not think I changed it from c++, but I might have. Either way I am still compiling with c++.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The ?= assignment will only assign the value if CXX isn't already set, which it probably is. If you want the command to use g++, change it to "CXX = g++".</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>'git &lt;command&gt; [&lt;revision&gt;...] -- [&lt;file&gt;...]'</p>

------------------------@21-------------------------

------------------------@22-------------------------
Setup and P1 FAQ
<p>Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding the setup tutorial and Project 1.  The setup tutorial itself is linked on the eecs280 website.  Project 1 is due Wednesday, September 14 at <strong>8pm</strong>.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q:</strong> <strong>I get this error when trying to run VSCode on WSL (error starting the pipe progam):</strong>  </p>


<p><img alt="" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=attach%2Fk4iv85stjw02kh%2Fj725978q5tm3m4%2Fk5havdqexrvb%2Fdownload.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: Try changing:</p>


<p></p>


<pre>"pipeProgram": "c:\windows\sysnative\bash.exe",</pre>
<p>to</p>


<p></p>


<pre>"pipeProgram": "/mnt/c/Windows/System32/bash.exe",</pre>
<p>in the launch.json</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: I’m trying to debug my project with VSCode on Mac, but it’s skipping all my breakpoints. What do I do?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: This is a known bug in the Microsoft C/C++ extension. Try installing the `CodeLLDB` extension with the following steps:</p>


<p></p>


<ol><li>
<p>In VSCode, go to the Extensions tab and search for “CodeLLDB”</p>
<p></p>
</li><li>
<p>Set your `launch.json` configuration to the following:</p>
<p></p>
</li></ol>


<pre>{ <span class="hljs-string">"name"</span>: <span class="hljs-string">"(lldb) Launch"</span>,
<span class="hljs-string">"type"</span>: <span class="hljs-string">"lldb"</span>,
<span class="hljs-string">"request"</span>: <span class="hljs-string">"launch"</span>,
<span class="hljs-string">"program"</span>: <span class="hljs-string">"<span class="hljs-subst">${workspaceFolder}</span>/stats_tests.exe"</span>,
<span class="hljs-string">"args"</span>: [],
<span class="hljs-string">"cwd"</span>: <span class="hljs-string">"<span class="hljs-subst">${workspaceFolder}</span>"</span>,
}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p><strong>Q: I’m getting an error in CAEN when I try to compile my code that looks like</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p><code>/usr/bin/ld: cannot find /usr/lib64/libasan.so.0.0.0</code></p>


<p></p>


<p><code>collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status</code></p>


<p></p>


<p><code>make: *** [stats_tests.exe] Error 1</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: Try changing the gcc version by running the following command:</p>


<p></p>


<pre>module load gcc/7.1.0</pre>
<p>You can add the following command to automatically change the gcc version every time you log in:</p>


<p></p>


<pre>echo "module load gcc/7.1.0" &gt;&gt; ~/.bash_profile</pre>
<p><strong>Q: Why am I unable to view console output in macOS vsCode?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: For Mac users on VSCode, install the “codeLLDB” extension instead of the “C/C++” extension and then set externalConsole to “true”. Now when you run the visual debugger, it will open a new “Terminal” window</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: I’m getting the error that “call of overloaded abs(double) is ambiguous” when I’m trying to compare floating points as used in Appendix F of the spec.</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: Try adding <code>#include &lt;cmath&gt;</code> to the top of the file.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: I haven't worked with vectors before - are there any recommended resources?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: You can find a number of vector tutorials online that give a decent introduction. Additionally, here are some links to the ENGR 101 Runestone materials with an introduction to vectors in C++. (These links are to a development server that isn't terribly reliable, but it avoids you having to make a Runestone account. If it doesn't load immediately, try refreshing the page a few times until it does.)</p>


<p></p>


<p>Vectors in C++: <a href="http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/vectors_in_cpp/main.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/vectors_in_cpp/main.html</a></p>


<div>Vectors of Vectors, relevant for <kbd>summarize()</kbd>: <a href="http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/more_data_structures/main.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">http://lobster.eecs.umich.edu:8000/more_data_structures/main.html</a></div>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: When I ssh into CAEN, I get put in the root folder (/) instead of my home directory (/home/uniqname/)</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: For some reason, your home directory was not created automatically. You can request for one to be created for you at the <a href="https://ifsprovisioning.its.umich.edu/ifs_storage/request" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">IFS storage request page</a>. </p>


<p></p>


<p>EDIT (jjuett), #unpinittowinit</p>

<div>

<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-07_at_10.41.27_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt20fvkyirb5kc%2Fa6b7ac605a2dbd95866f6373f5912b7dc37310228e5d48960f610c58b62740a9%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-07_at_10.41.27_PM.png"/></p>


<p>Anything you can think of that could cause this?</p>


<p>Thanks!</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>That's the expected behavior. As discussed in lecture "assert(/*something*/)" will crash the program if /*something*/ evaluates to false. Once you add implementations for all the functions (including "sum"), you must remove the "assert(false)" statements.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok i'm glad that was expected however I thought my compiler was supposed to successfully compile.  </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It is compiling and running. What you are seeing is the output from running your program.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>no output...</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>"Assertion failed: (false)..." is the output of your program.</p>

<p></p>


<p>This is the full output </p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I understand. The text in blue is the output of your program. It means that your program compiled and is running as expected. Try replacing "assert(false)" on line 14 with "cout &lt;&lt; "hello" &lt;&lt; endl;" and you should see that printing out.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Did you compile the files? When you make clean, it deletes the exe files, so running the debugger will result in it not finding the stats_test.exe file. Try running make test so that it will compile your desired file. Note that if you have a compiler error, then there is no way to enter debugging mode as the exe file fails to be built.</p>

Issue with percentage formula
<p>The formula for percentage goes:</p>

<p>Say that P = 100. Then, k = N and we are trying to access $v_{N+1}$ in the 1-indexed system, which is out of bounds. Do we treat 100 percentile as 99 percentile?</p>

------------------------@41-------------------------
test cases
<p>Will we be expected to deal with the scenario in which an empty vector is passed into our functions in stats.cpp? Should we return some sort of default value or use assert to reject empty vectors?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you look at the requires clause for the functions, (almost) all of them say:</p>


<p>"REQUIRES: v is not empty", this means that you don't have to test or consider the case where the vector is empty. </p>

<p>when you are running the code, do you press step into or step over? If you are pressing step into, the highlight will move to some of the preprogrammed compiler code. The reason the code stopped running is because it failed the assertion in stats.cpp line 14. That means the data you are passing is incorrect or the assertion is incorrect.</p>

<p>I'm a bit confused....are you saying it goes straight into the highlighting threads? The code will only stop at a specific line if it has a breakpoint (aka a red dot next to the line numbers). Double check to make sure there is no break point there. Then check your launch.json and make sure you have it set to the stats_tests.exe.  Add a break point into the stats_tests.cpp and click run while still in that file. It should start the highlight at the line with the breakpoint.</p>

------------------------@47-------------------------
Synchronizing deleted files
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_12.07.48_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0tvomb6mz1vb%2F1c1a277d597e7eb888c831a4c0ff24203abff1fbf42a78856effb38203daea60%2FScreen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_12.07.48_PM.png"/></p>


<p>I am trying to synchronize deleted files using rsync -rtv --delete --exclude '.git*' ../p1-stats/ sydneyfi@login.engin.umich.edu:p1-stats-copy/, and it keeps saying failed no such file or directory. What does this mean? Should I be concerned?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The 'no such file or directory' error means either p1-stats does not exist or in caen you don't have a p1-stats-copy folder. If you have them named different things, then make sure you change the command to be the right folder name. If you need to add the project to caen, see <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html</a>. To get into caen and see what the files name is / if it exists, type ssh uniqname@login.engin.umich.edu.</p>


<p></p>


<p>This error could also be because your terminal is in the wrong directory. Try running "ls" in the terminal. You should be in your p1-stats folder so ls should print out all the file names in p1-stats. If you are not in the right directory, cd into your p1-stats folder.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@52-------------------------
Autograder Compilation Warnings Failure stats_tests.cpp
<p>I was submitting to Autograder to make sure there weren't any setup errors, and I got a Compilation Warning for stats_tests.cpp.</p>


<p>I am using Visual Studio Code on Mac Air with a M1 Chip, if that is helpful information. I have no idea why this is happening.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Actual Output:</p>


<p><code>g++ --std=c++11 -Wall -pedantic -g -Wno-sign-compare -Wno-comment -S -Werror stats_tests.cpp -o stats_tests-warning-check.s<br/>2 public.mk:59: recipe for target 'stats_tests-warning-check.s' failure</code></p>


<p>Expected Output:</p>


<p><code>n file included from /usr/include/c++/5/cassert:43:0,<br/>2                  from stats_tests.cpp:21:<br/>3 stats_tests.cpp: In function 'void test_mean()':<br/>4 stats_tests.cpp:79:43: error: call of overloaded 'abs(double)' is ambiguous<br/>5    assert(abs(mean(uglyMeanData) - 2.283857) &lt; epsilon);<br/>6                                            ^<br/>7 In file included from /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:72:0,<br/>8                  from /usr/include/c++/5/ext/string_conversions.h:41,<br/>9                  from /usr/include/c++/5/bits/basic_string.h:5249,<br/>10                  from /usr/include/c++/5/string:52,<br/>11                  from p1_library.h:13,<br/>12                  from stats_tests.cpp:19:<br/>13 /usr/include/stdlib.h:774:12: note: candidate: int abs(int)<br/>14  extern int abs (int __x) __THROW __attribute__ ((__const__)) __wur;<br/>15             ^<br/>16 In file included from /usr/include/c++/5/ext/string_conversions.h:41:0,<br/>17                  from /usr/include/c++/5/bits/basic_string.h:5249,<br/>18                  from /usr/include/c++/5/string:52,<br/>19                  from p1_library.h:13,<br/>20                  from stats_tests.cpp:19:<br/>21 /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:174:3: note: candidate: long long int std::abs(long long int)<br/>22    abs(long long __x) { return __builtin_llabs (__x); }<br/>23    ^<br/>24 /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:166:3: note: candidate: long int std::abs(long int)<br/>25    abs(long __i) { return __builtin_labs(__i); }<br/>26    ^<br/>27 In file included from /usr/include/c++/5/cassert:43:0,<br/>28                  from stats_tests.cpp:21:<br/>29 stats_tests.cpp: In function 'void test_median()':<br/>30 stats_tests.cpp:90:37: error: call of overloaded 'abs(double)' is ambiguous<br/>31    assert(abs(median(data) - -1.46675) &lt; epsilon);<br/>32                                      ^<br/>33 In file included from /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:72:0,<br/>34                  from /usr/include/c++/5/ext/string_conversions.h:41,<br/>35                  from /usr/include/c++/5/bits/basic_string.h:5249,<br/>36                  from /usr/include/c++/5/string:52,<br/>37                  from p1_library.h:13,<br/>38                  from stats_tests.cpp:19:<br/>39 /usr/include/stdlib.h:774:12: note: candidate: int abs(int)<br/>40  extern int abs (int __x) __THROW __attribute__ ((__const__)) __wur;<br/>41             ^<br/>42 In file included from /usr/include/c++/5/ext/string_conversions.h:41:0,<br/>43                  from /usr/include/c++/5/bits/basic_string.h:5249,<br/>44                  from /usr/include/c++/5/string:52,<br/>45                  from p1_library.h:13,<br/>46                  from stats_tests.cpp:19:<br/>47 /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:174:3: note: candidate: long long int std::abs(long long int)<br/>48    abs(long long __x) { return __builtin_llabs (__x); }<br/>49    ^<br/>50 /usr/include/c++/5/cstdlib:166:3: note: candidate: long int std::abs(long int)<br/>51    abs(long __i) { return __builtin_labs(__i); }<br/>52    ^<br/>53 make: *** [stats_tests-warning-check.s] Error 1</code></p>


<p><code></code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The default <code>abs</code> function in C++11 only handles integers and similar types like long and long long. The error output is saying that the function which only handles integer types is being used with doubles.</p>
<p>The <code>abs</code> function in <code>&lt;cmath&gt;</code>, however, allows for using doubles. So put <code>#include &lt;cmath&gt;</code> at the top of your <code>stats_tests.cpp</code> file.</p>
<p>Additionally, to test if compilation will be successful before submitting to the autograder, be sure to test your code on CAEN.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@54-------------------------
Error with checking is vector is empty
<p>Hi I don't know if this is a dumb question but why is there an error here for return -1? </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw3s00pegt2cu%2F7d29e7492bd63d6e6bc26cc09b2e7681076bff31f341e058b454e214d538034c%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw3s00pegt2cu%2F0076d4904d6f2a5b421ea10b1507ab15402713d62333253e01186cbdad61f1c2%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Remember that the return value must match the type that the function specifies. Here we can see that the function requires a 2d vector as a return value so returning -1 (an int) will throw a conversion error.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So should I be calling an exit function or abort instead? </p>


<p></p>


<p>Also another question sorry, is the count function just supposed to find the size of the vector??</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>in this case, you want to use an assert. This will stop your code from running, which is what we want. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Yes the count function is suppose to find the size of the vector.</p>

------------------------@56-------------------------
stdev for formula
<p>Hi, I am working on stdev function, but I saw two stdev formula online, one use N as denominator, the other use n-1. I wonder do we need to consider the difference between population and sample or just use n-1 for this project? Thx.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should use the sample standard deviation formula, which uses n-1.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: As a more direct answer, the RME for standard deviation asks specifically for the “corrected sample standard deviation”, which is given here in the wiki page:</p>


<p><img alt="" height="187" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fjljit6h1ewo5tn%2F0b0f97c1eda2872433af71f728bf068756a2582b5dec3f0b87ac811605568027%2Fdev.PNG" width="1553"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@57-------------------------
how to use csvstream
<p>I see the constructor requires delimiter and strict, I was wondering what they are. I'm working on main.cpp, and I'm trying to read in files. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The <code>p1_library.h</code> has an <code>std::vector&lt;double&gt; extract_column(std::string filename, std::string column_name)</code> function that does this for you. Putting <code>#include &lt;csvstream&gt;</code> into any of your submitted files will cause the autograder to automatically reject your submission, so don’t try to implement it yourself. Make sure to check the section that shows the libraries you’re allowed to use for this project.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For reading in from files, you can use cin &gt;&gt; variable name. You don't need to declare a csvstream object. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>As the student answer says, the provided <code>sort</code> function sorts the vector in ascending order. You should <code>#include "p1_library.h"</code> to use the function. Remember the only libraries you may use are given here: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions</a></p></div>

------------------------@62-------------------------
Number of sigfigs to extend the functions to?
<p>For some of the functions, particularly the percentage and standard deviation function, the outputs can result in some pretty long numbers. How many significant figures should our functions and test cases extend to in order to be accurate to the autograder?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As long as you are using the typical C++ `double` type for decimal numbers, your precision should not be an issue autograder-wise. Do note, however, this part of the spec for testing equality of decimals: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons</a> (you do not need to do <code>cout.precision()</code> or anything like that)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When we are writing test cases are we just supposed to assert everything? Wouldn't we have to have a certain precision and do the cout.precision() thing if we are asserting certain stdev and percentile numbers? </p>


<p></p>


<p>Unless we aren't supposed to assert everything sry I've never written test cases before lol</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>See the Floating Point Comparisons part of the spec (https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons) to learn how to assert stdev and other decimal outputs.</p></div>

------------------------@64-------------------------
Brew disappears when terminal is killed
<p>When I install brew it is able to install correctly. Yet, after I kill the terminal and check if it is still there it says "brew not found". Here is what I am doing. </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_10.11.50_PM.pngNaN" height="623" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkthuyfeq1of768%2F6110d4f485ed1c3f431ef4a72fed9fe2f5ef284aa4934ec4ce5510ca393f7e14%2FScreen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_10.11.50_PM.png" width="858"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_10.12.42_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkthuyfeq1of768%2F03f0df83504dc0e70a68f0cdbc58331e05582f570e01371183dcbaf2bebba35d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-08-30_at_10.12.42_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Are you running this on M1/M2? I would try running</p>


<pre><code>export PATH="/opt/homebrew/bin:$PATH"</code></pre>
<p><code></code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try this</p>


<p><code>echo "export PATH=/opt/homebrew/bin:$PATH" &gt;&gt; ~/.bash_profile &amp;&amp; source ~/.bash_profile</code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p></p>


<p>Thank you. It works only if I copy that before I search for which brew. Is there a way to fix this issue? And it is M1. </p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-08-31_at_2.51.37_PM.pngNaN" height="340" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkthuyfeq1of768%2Fd381c852985f179915b60f17fd7da2c37eebaaaec269eed5c047491e649c1f06%2FScreen_Shot_2022-08-31_at_2.51.37_PM.png" width="1039"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You might need to create a .zshrc file in your home directory.</p>


<p></p>


<p>1. Check if the file exists: If it anything shows up, press q to exit from the screen.</p>


<pre><code>less ~/.zshrc</code></pre>
<p>2. Assuming the file is not created, create the file: (SKIP if the file already exists)</p>


<pre><code>touch ~/.zshrc</code></pre>
<p>3. Open the file in vim for editing (or another editor you prefer):</p>


<pre><code>vim ~/.zshrc</code></pre>
<p>4. Press the 'i' key to enter insert mode. Use the arrows to move down to the end of the last line and press enter to make a new line. Add this line to the end of the file:</p>


<pre>export PATH=/opt/homebrew/bin:$PATH</pre>
<p>5. Press the esc key, and then :wq This will save and close the file. Finally, make available</p>


<pre><code>source ~/.zshrc</code></pre>
<p>from <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66666134/how-to-install-homebrew-on-m1-mac" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/66666134/how-to-install-homebrew-on-m1-mac</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this works!</p>

------------------------@66-------------------------
Error unpacking files on Ubuntu
<p>I've downloaded the starter files, but when I try to unpack them I keep running into this error. Notes: I am on a Windows and the .1 on the file name is because I tried to download the files again assuming I had done that part incorrectly.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="782" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7cayzdezjk6cv%2Fbea64e1ef3ccc64329cde744f1a9c878221cd6a918432805c5bcba4c65552a6a%2FUbantu_Error.PNG" width="1525"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Resolved in follow ups</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I had the same issue, my friend, from CS with IT background helped me. </p>


<p></p>


<p>0. Enable Windows Virtual Machine Platform in Windows Features<br/>0.5. Enable virtualization in BIOS (usually called VT-x on Intel systems)<br/>1. Go into Powershell<br/>2. Run the command `wsl -l -v` and verify that the Ubuntu distro is on version 1<br/>3. Run the command `wsl --set-version Ubuntu 2` and wait for completion<br/>4. Restart your WSL instances, if opened</p>


<p></p>


<p>The issue is that most computer uses WSL by default which is a knock-off version of Linux, so you need to Enable Windows Virtual Machine Platform in Windows Features to use WSL 1 (actual Linux program). This is my basic understanding of it. Hope it helps. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>BE VERY CAREFULL, THIS INVOLVES MESSING WITH CORE HARDWARE STUFF1! so do it around with someone who understands. GOOD LUCK!</p>


<p>I found this video: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOuTxfzCvMY&amp;ab_channel=Triple-ATechSolutions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">(413) How to enable Virtualization (VT-x) in Bios Windows 10 *** NEW *** - YouTube</a></p>

------------------------@68-------------------------
Cannot download WSL
<p>I cannot download WSL to my laptop. I started trying last night by following the given instructions, but it did not work. I went to office hours today, but we could not figure out the issue. Every time I input a --install command, it tells me I need a system reboot, and any other line I input returns a long list of information without doing anything. There is an example of both of those situations in the photo attached. I have tried restarting PowerShell, restarting my laptop, googling to find similar issues, but nothing has helped.</p>


<p><img alt="Screenshot_(1).pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fku7hv89ouie354%2F6654de75262af5f5654f27a5559aa44e30ebca945bc2b950089153436a6a9549%2FScreenshot_%281%29.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Been seeing this issue in a few places. First make sure you install Ubuntu from the Windows store.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Attempt to open Ubuntu. This should fail.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Then open Windows Powershell as administrator and type in <code>wsl -l - v</code> which should return “Windows subsystem for Linux has no installed distributions”.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Then type in <code>wsl --list --online</code> which should give you a list of distros you can install. You want to install “Ubuntu” with <code>wsl --install -d Ubuntu</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>You know it worked when you type in <code>wsl -l -v</code> and you get</p>


<p><br/>NAME       STATE         VERSION<br/>Ubuntu     Stopped     1</p>


<p></p>


<p>Restart your computer and launch Ubuntu and it should load.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This hasn't worked either. I did have Ubuntu downloaded and it was failing like you said, but when I put in the line you told me the same big response from the picture in the original post comes up. Any other ways to make this work?</p>

------------------------@69-------------------------
p1_library.cpp
<p>I'm using VSC and it shows there are 7 bugs in the p1library cpp code. Should I just ignore the bugs?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>p1_library.cpp should not have any bugs in it, I've been able to get it to compile properly. Since p1_library needs to be referenced, you'll probably want to check to make sure you've installed (and are using) the right versions of C++. The autograder will use their version of p1_library.cpp, so you can't just modify the library code to stop it from erroring (as your version will not be used). It's also helpful to stop compile errors from occurring when you try to submit to the autograder.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7dza5tu96s3r2%2Fc0263c69d3abed92bb68748bf8509a58e74a7f6d52d3fb72e392a5807f67217b%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>Why do the include statements show up as bugs.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>make sure you have C++ selected at the bottom-right as the language you’re using and that your settings are correct (and show the right version) in <code>.vscode/c_cpp_properties.json</code>. you can also hover over the text for more info about why a compile error is being raised.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@74-------------------------
Functions calling other functions in stats.cpp

-------------------------------------------------
<p>yeah you can</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I have the same concern. May I ask something more. </p>


<p></p>


<p>In the effects of mode, the hint says to use sort, nested loop. It somehow indicates that we should write a function from scratch. </p>


<p></p>


<p>If we use the summarize function in mode, things become easier. Since we have the frequency listed, we just need to find the number with the largest frequency and avoid tons of complicated stuff. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Therefore, it looks like a shortcut. Is it allowed?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can, but most people end up writing the mode function before summarize and the double vector situation can get confusing. You can do whichever is better/easier for you.</p>

------------------------@79-------------------------
I think the standard deviation in the p1-stats tutorial might be wrong
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>The problem I am encountering is as follows.</p>
<p>I implemented the <code>stdev</code> function in <code>stats.cpp</code> as described in the link in <code>stats.h</code> (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_deviation#Corrected_sample_standard_deviation). I used the formula directly below the linked header “Corrected sample standard deviation”.</p>
<p>With the data from the p1-stats tutorial (<code>[6, 7, 8, 9, 10]</code>), I got <code>1.41421</code>. The tutorial states that the standard deviation should be <code>1.58114</code>.</p>
<p>It just so happens that my TI-84 says that the <em>sample</em> standard deviation is also <code>1.58114</code> (rounded). The TI-84 also says that the <em>population</em> standard deviation is <code>1.41421</code> (rounded).
The <code>stats.h</code> file does say that <code>stdev</code> should return the “corrected sample standard deviation”.</p>
<p><strong>So, I think that either the wrong formula is linked or the wrong thing is written in <code>stats.h</code>.</strong> Either that or I implemented <code>stdev</code> wrong and got a coincidentally similar number.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Thanks. For anyone that comes to this thread later:</p>
<p><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/df695c81f11c7d0d27209a42c72c20d2ad4e1fd2"/></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm having the same problem as above where I am getting 1.41421. How did you fix this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@87-------------------------
#include vector, iostream, header files -- all showing up as errors in VS Code

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>I would also make sure you have your language in the bottom-right set to C++ with the proper environment selected. Additionally, make sure your <code>/.vscode/c_cpp_properties.json</code> is setup correctly (make sure cStandard is <code>c11</code> and cppStandard is set to <code>c++11</code>). You can also learn more about the error by hovering over the squiggly lines (which can tell you why the error is happening).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I’ve experienced this a few times. The first time it was because I didn’t open vscode with <code>code .</code> and instead opened it manually. The second time I just required a vscode update. Try reopening with <code>code .</code> and looking for updates, and post a followup if that doesn’t solve it.</p></div>

------------------------@88-------------------------
homebrew installation
<p>hi, i'm trying to install homebrew and am getting past the password option, but when it says installment in progress, it isn't doing anything else. if i exit the terminal, it does not save. is this something that takes a long time to download or am i doing something wrong?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>it can take a minute or two (or even longer if you have a bad connection) to install but if it’s taking more than 10 minutes then something’s probably going wrong. if it keeps taking too long, try <code>rm -rf ~/Library/Caches/Homebrew/</code>. If you’re on an M1 Mac, try <code>rm -rf /opt/hombrew/</code>. if you’re on an Intel-based mac, try <code>rm -rf /usr/local/Homebrew/</code>. this should remove all of your Homebrew files and let you redo the installation entirely.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@89-------------------------
Memory Model
<p>Hello, I was just wondering what parameters look like in the memory model. In the stack frame with the function with parameters, are there simply slots of memory allotted for the parameters (treating them like local variables)? I would appreciate any help. Thanks :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Correct, they’re allocated memory for that new stack frame and are treated like local variables, <strong>assuming</strong> they are passed by value and not by reference.</p></div>

------------------------@97-------------------------
Is input data always sorted?
<p>Can we assume that the data inputed by the user in main will always be sorted in ascending order or is that just the case in the provided sample?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The data is not guaranteed to be sorted, but there is a sort function for you to use included in the starter files.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Adding onto the student answer: You cannot assume anything regarding the input to a function that’s not specified in the Requires clauses. Since no function has “is sorted” as a requirement, the input need not be sorted.</p></div>

------------------------@101-------------------------
What to do when the “requires” is not fulfilled
I am trying to make some edge test cases to make sure that everything in P1 works. However, as I skipped eecs 183, I am not quite familiar with the details of rules for reading descriptions for functions.
<div><br/></div>
<div>In main.cpp, when an input does not meet requires of a functions in stats.cpp, should I simply make it so to simply not call the function or return None?</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Thanks!</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If it doesn't meet the requirements, you don't really have to worry about it-at least for project 1. Although not necessary, a good practice is to start using assert statements to make sure an input meets the requirements. For example, if a vector is required not to be empty, you can use an assert function to verify this at the start of the function. The #include &lt;cassert&gt; library allows you to use these statements. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
As the student response and follow-ups say, you can assume that the autograder will never test input that directly breaks the Requires clause of a function. The only place you need assert statements is in stats_tests.cpp, but you can assert the requires clauses in stats.cpp as a sanity check that you're not testing any invalid input.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Note, however, that each stats function must be able to work on its own independent of the main function. So if, for example, the requires clauses does not disallow empty vectors, that's a valid test input if the autograder tests that function individually.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
Hi! So, basically what I need to do is to “catch” the “exception” with an assert functions to test the requirement, which will return “False” if it doesn’t meet the requirement? I am wondering this since it seems like that the auto grader is strict on the format of ouputs.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm pretty confident for project 1 they dont make you use assert statements and, if, for example, a vector is required to be empty in the required description, the autograder wouldn't give you an empty vector, so you dont have to worry about it. You can if you want though.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Hi! Thanks for letting know.
<div><br/></div>
<div>I was just wondering this since some of the functions have incoherent requirements. stdev requires at least 2 elements in v, count doesn’t require anything, and all rest require v to not be empty. Hence, I am wondering if the hidden test cases in the autograder will contain empty vectors to see if we’ve accounted for this.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The autograder will not have any test cases that violate the requires clauses.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Professor Beaumont. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>Thank you for your clarification. I was just unsure if the autograder tests cases through main.cpp and calls all functions unifiedly or tests them one by one. It seems like that the latter would be the case.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Correct. From the spec: "The functions in stats.cpp must still work when compiled with a different main function."</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I see. So when the autograder is testing through main.cpp, it will use cases that satisfy ALL function, but not necessarily so when testing individually through stats.cpp.
<div><br/></div>
<div>By the chance, what would the autograder do about the stats_tests.cpp? Would there be a staff grader manually handling them when calculating the final grade based on the quality of our custom test cases or it’s no matter so long it passes the autograder?</div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@102-------------------------
Make clean not working in Makefile setup
<p>In the Makefile setup when i enter the "make clean" it says this instead of saying remove stats_test.exe like it should.</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_10.32.48_AM.pngNaN" height="182" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky330it8gsm70t%2Fcfc7eda9bd25396ff2896e530424637a81f1b22788ebe736645bea1e345b7905%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_10.32.48_AM.png" width="349"/></p>


<p>Then when I get to the command: </p>


<p>"g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe"</p>


<p></p>


<p>This should appear under "stats_tests.exe: stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp" in the middle of Makefile. For me it just says</p>


<p>" $(CXX) $(CXXFLAGS) stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe"</p>


<p></p>


<p>What did I do wrong in my Makefile set up?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks.<br/> </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The "make clean" command removes automatically generated files, including all files ending with ".exe". </p>


<p></p>


<p>In regards to the make command for compiling: " $(CXX) $(CXXFLAGS) stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe",</p>


<p>think of the $(CXX) and $(CXXFLAGS) as Makefile variables. You should see that these variables are defined at the top of your Makefile and when they are substituted in, the expression evaluates to the same thing: "g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe".</p>


<p></p>


<p>Both of these seem in line with the intended Makefile setup, so you should be good!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>I am having the same problem. were you able to figure out what it was?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I fixed a similar problem by adding “stats.cpp”, the file with the actual implementations, as part of the flag-</p>


<p></p>


<p>Before:<br/><code>g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>After:<br/><code>g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp p1_library.cpp stats.cpp -o stats_tests.exe</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>Doing so let me create the executable with no errors.</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@107-------------------------
Mode- case with two or more mode
<p>In a case in which the data has more than one mode (for example, 1 1 2 2 3 4), should the program return both modes? If not, what would be the correct number to return?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You return the lowest value mode. In your case, it would be 1.

------------------------@108-------------------------
Summary function
<p>On the project specs, the summary function is formatted as (value: frequency) but on the rme in stats.h, it is formatted as (value, frequency). Does it matter if we use ':' or ',' to separate the value and frequency?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The “: “ format should be part of your print statement in your driver program. The comma format is how your vector of vectors should look for each value in the given vector.

------------------------@111-------------------------
Problems with Division
<p>Hello, I was working on project 1 and I came across a problem with division. As it is shown in the screenshots, I typed 5/2 and expected the program to return 2.5. Instead, it returns 2 for this value. I was able to work around this problem in project 1, but I was wondering why the program is not giving me the expected response or if I am doing something wrong.</p>


<p><img alt="" height="226" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy2v236ihf38t%2F9a27e1ea3adb5670ebff48baf77286d4db991338155487f98f8507cd7da04b6b%2Fdivision.png" width="352"/><img alt="" height="260" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy2v236ihf38t%2F67208eb716ad7232bedf1e820dd9146e30155eab763a351e76b7a510badbbf6a%2Fdivision_terminal.png" width="533"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>So on line 260, <code>double h = (5 / 2)</code> is going to be set to 2.0 instead of 2.5 because 5 and 2 are interpreted as <code>int</code> instead of <code>double</code>. This means the <code>/</code> operator will do integer division instead of floating point division - you want the latter. \</p>
<p>To fix this, write <code>double h = (5.0 / 2.0)</code> instead. You can do something similar on line 262 to fix that line of output.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@112-------------------------
Percentile Function
<p>I am somewhat confused about how the percentile function is supposed to work. Is the p input the desired percentile, and then the function would return the value in the vector that is at that percentile? If not, then what does the p input refer to?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>in the wiki page it says P/100 but that's what the p in our function is, we just input a decimal instead of dividing a number by 100</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Question about this as well: should we return the percentile of number after calculation, which may  not exist in the vector, or only the one that exists in the vector?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think that the number returned can include values that do not exist in the vector because in the percentile example, the function returns a value that was not in the given vector.</p>

<p></p>

<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>&lt; enter a filename </em></p>


<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>&lt; enter a column name </em></p>


<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>---</em></p>


<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>&gt; enter a filename</em></p>


<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>&gt; enter a column name</em></p>


<p style="padding-left:40px"><em>make: *** [test] Error 1</em></p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>That looks like whitespace differences. The autograder may or may not throw an error in this case, I’m not 100% sure. You can either run the <code>diff</code> with <code>--ignore-space</code> or fix the spacing issues in your code.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How would you go about clearing the whitespace issue?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>You can do <code>cat -te</code> on both the correct file and your own output to see whitespace. Read here for more details: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23313764/how-can-i-use-diff-to-see-whitespace-changes" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23313764/how-can-i-use-diff-to-see-whitespace-changes</a></p></div>

------------------------@121-------------------------
Stats_tests.exe Compiling
<p>I compiled the stats_tests.exe executable as per the VS Code tutorial and my output is the exact same except for an added in -Wno-sign-compare and -Wno-comment. Will that be a problem and should I change anything? thanks</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>That probably means the CXXFLAGS in your Makefile is different, perhaps because there’s a part of the tutorial that asks you to change it and you might’ve changed it in a slightly different way. Ultimately, if it compiles, that difference in output shouldn’t be an issue.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So, what to do next?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>You shouldn’t have to do anything if your project still compiles.</p></div>

------------------------@123-------------------------
modf not working
<p>Hi, When I try to use modf to split a double into its int and decimal parts It is giving me an error. Im having this problem on lobster and VScode.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Lobster says,</p>


<p>"iden.not_found: Name lookup was unable to find "modf" in this scope."</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Lobster does not support <code>modf</code>, among many other standard library functions. The way you used <code>modf</code> in Lobster was correct, but in VSCode, you passed an <code>int</code> as the second parameter, whereas it <a href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/math/modf" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">expects</a> a <code>float*</code> or <code>double*</code> as the second parameter, which represents the location where it should place the integer part of the first parameter. One way to fix this is to change the type of <code>d</code> to <code>double</code> and write <code>modf(n, &amp;d)</code> instead.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="" height="289" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyqill5z7v24a%2Fde5ed6c543e69cc05b2337117a3d07f2019d9da6e2d16c69a65c5ad0ff6aaf21%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_8.02.19_PM.png" width="559"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
Could you show the error you’re running into on VS Code?
<div><br/></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="" height="314" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyqill5z7v24a%2Fd42a077e7018bcbf2b6d887ba8e2ae333cca70e93e965e52df2468b772a4f5c7%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_9.27.11_PM.png" width="393"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Honestly, I would just use "number - floor(number)" to get the decimals to avoid the hassle.</p>

------------------------@124-------------------------
Question about summarize()
<p>I'm a little confused about what exactly should go in the summarize function in stats.cpp. Is all the information below supposed to be in the output of summarize()? If so, how is summarize() supposed to return a vector?</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_8.24.53_PM.pngNaN" height="699" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt02oritrda2cu%2Fdc93ce4e93c5a1c458345c0759b49551e0486d584cd351d141710c4647c14e45%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-01_at_8.24.53_PM.png" width="940"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
Summarize returns a vector of vectors. All of the statistics functions are separate. Think of your vector of vectors as such:
<div>• outside vector -&gt; contains many individual vectors.</div>
<div>• inside vector -&gt; contains a pair  -&gt; {number, how many times it occurs}</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Note: the outer vector should be sorted as well!</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Hope this helps!</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am still confused about this question. Where do all of the ones come from? Where is this data come from? I know it is reading in from a file input by the user, but I do not understand where the ones come from?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The 1s just represent the frequency the number on the left occurs.

------------------------@129-------------------------
Are we supposed to round stdev?
<p>For the stdev function, I know it is returning the proper value as I used cout to print the value, however I do not know how that is rounded. It printed 1.58114, however I know that is not the exact value as I tried to use the assert() function with that value and t threw a false. How am I supposed to round this number, and if I can't, how do I write a test case for it?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
If you see Appendix F from the project spec, it contains information regarding floating point comparisons. You should be able to use the information provided to help you write tests for functions such as stdev.

-------------------------------------------------
Why would you need to compare?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm guessing you are asking about the comparison method described in the spec- floating point numbers possess limited accuracy. Values we expect to be exactly the same may differ from one another slightly at a later decimal place. As a result, a comparison with some tolerance for our values to differ from one another is necessary instead of an exact comparison. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hi, Elaine.</p>


<p></p>


<p>No, I am wondering why would you need to compare floating points to test stdev? Why not print out the result of the function from your test case to simply see if it's correct win comparison with a calculator?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The point of writing test functions is to programmatically be able to assert if your function output matches something expected and fail if it doesn't. Sure, you could verify everything by just printing and comparing to an external calculator, but I think you want to use assertions to fail the program.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Last question, should I account for floating point "inaccuracy" for autograder?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In case you weren't able to find your answer elsewhere, your testcases that you write should account for these rounding errors in the output of your functions. But you actual implementations of functions (for example, mode), should trust that the values coming in are exactly correct.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@130-------------------------
Error in exciting main.exe local: malloc: nano zero abandoned
<p>When I execute the main.exe file, it keeps showing this error. But it seems that it does not prevent the program form running.<img alt="__2022-09-02_11.33.33.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7cqw0ansll47d%2F57cdbc08f551f744493fb8e0f20f24c093dad3c45181c4eaf3b93c4a300399e2%2F__2022-09-02_11.33.33.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Are you using a Mac? This error seems to be related to macOS's memory allocation implementation (not related to EECS 280, but you can read about it more <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/64126942/malloc-nano-zone-abandoned-due-to-inability-to-preallocate-reserved-vm-space" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>). As far as I can tell, this shouldn't affect your program's behavior, but if you want to get rid of this message, try setting the MallocNanoZone environment variable to 0 as so in your terminal: <code>export MallocNanoZone=0</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>If you're worried about this affecting your program's correctness, you can always try running it on CAEN!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>From the screenshots, it doesn't look like VS Code is running in WSL mode. <p></p>


<p>All your C++ tools and compiler are installed on the Linux side (i.e. WSL), so you need VS Code to be in Remote - WSL mode for C++ development.</p>


<p></p>


<p>(Also, if there's no option to do that, you'll need to go to your VS Code Extensions and install the WSL Remote extension.)</p>

------------------------@140-------------------------
summarize(), adding pairs to a vector
<p>How can I add a pair of values to a vector so that they are as recognized as one item instead of two? I have tried push_back(), but it is not letting me add more thing at a time, even when I wrap the pair in {}. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hey I ran into the same problem, I think we need to declare the vector as a vector of pairs, this is what I found online: "To declare a vector of pairs we can use the syntax : <em>vector&lt;pair&lt;string,int&gt;&gt; a;",</em>.  Then double instead of string/int, hope that helps.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks! That did it! </p>

------------------------@141-------------------------
Percentile Formula (Index out of bounds)
<p>Let's say that I have a vector&lt;double&gt; v = {5}.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Since v.size() == 1, how would the Percentile Formula work if I need to use k and k+1 indices?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>All percentile values for some single-element vector <code>{x}</code> are <code>x</code>. In the given percentile formula, <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="0" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D45B TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3D"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> for all possible <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="1" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D443 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>P</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container>, so <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="2" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D458 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3D"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> and <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="3" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D451 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3D"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>d</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container>. This means that <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="4" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-msub><mjx-mi class="mjx-i" noic="true"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D463 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-script style="vertical-align: -0.15em;"><mjx-texatom size="s" texclass="ORD"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D458 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2B"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-texatom></mjx-script></mjx-msub></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> has no influence on any percentile value, so you don’t need to use the index <code>k + 1</code>. You may want to handle this as a special case.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Do we just have to assume that v.size() is always &gt; 1?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>No, do not assume that.</p></div>

------------------------@145-------------------------
Implementing Tests
<p>I finished writing some of the function implementations in stats.cpp as well as the tests in stats_tests.cpp, but when I try to run the program to run the tests, I keep getting thrown exceptions due to the 'assert(false)' that is there in every function that has not been fully written yet. How do I test the functions I have finished writing if I cannot run the program?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
What I did was that I erased the assert(false) in the stats functions, and then in the test functions, I used the asssert() function. Assert basically checks the condition within its parameter, and if it is true, it goes through the assert with no worries. However, if the condition within assert is false, then an error pops up. 
<br/>
<br/>
For example,
<br/>
<br/>
assert(2 == 2) will pass, but assert(2 == 3) will produce an error. You can use these in your test cases to see if your expected results are actually lining up with what your stats functions are returning. Sorry if this doesn't really make sense. If you need more help, I'm more than happy to help later :)
<br/>
<br/>
Another thing you could do is just comment out the lines you don't want for right now and then add them back when you're ready to test those functions

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I had this same issue and fixed it by just passing in vector v rather than giving it v.begin() and v.end().</p>


<p></p>


<p>^^ This fixed the issue!</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yeah I think the <code>p1_library.cpp</code>’s definition of <code>sort</code> accepts the whole vector as a parameter, unlike the <code>std::sort</code>.</p>
<p>Just FYI if anyone needs it, you should use <code>p1_library.cpp</code>’s <code>sort</code> instead of <code>std::sort</code> because you can’t include the <code>&lt;algorithm&gt;</code> header file, which <code>std::sort</code> relies on.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@147-------------------------
Set up help with intel mac ( visual studio code)
For compiling the executables, I followed all the steps but when I type in $make clean it shows extra lines like it is shown in the picture below. Also, after compiling the $make clean, I see that stats_test.exe.dSYM has been disappeared, but when I type in the next step, which is $ make stats_tests.exe, the stats_test.exe.dSYM occurs again in the files and it gives me an error message “ the file is not displayed in the editor because it is either binary or uses an unsupported text encoding” when I click the stats_tests.exe. Please help..!
<div><br/></div>
<div><br/></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>dSYM files are, from what I can tell, “debug symbols files” and are generated automatically by the compiler with some debugging information. The <code>make clean</code> command includes a rule to get rid of dSYM files and other automatically generated files from testing, which is probably the extra lines you’re seeing.</p>
<p>When you click on stats_tests.exe in the editor for VS Code, you’re seeing that message because the editor is trying to open stats_tests.exe as an editable file, but it’s a compiled binary that the editor can’t open. If you’re trying to run stats_tests.exe, open a terminal in VS Code or use the built-in Mac terminal, navigate to the location that file’s saved in, and type ./stats_tests.exe. Running <code>make test</code> in your project folder will run the program too.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>if you could upload files of your terminal, that would help us a lot!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p></p>


<p>Any idea what this message is stating? I've been through the code a bunch, and it runs perfectly on my computer and on the CAEN systems, but just this UB check is failing. Since it's a public check, what is it actually executing? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think it has to do with the percentile function. When you put in 1.0 for double value, it does this error, I think?</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This error does have to do with the bounds of the percentile function. When you run the percentile function, many new variables are created. These variables access elements of the vector directly so they have to be in bounds of the vector size (aka 0 - vector size - 1). I would suggest looking at what the variables you create during the percentile function are when you pass in p = 0 and p = 1. This can find where you may be indexing out of bounds, which in turn causes undefined behavior.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No, the percentile function works as intended even when using 1.0 as the value. Also, this error occurs before the percentile function is called. What exactly is run when doing "UB Check"?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Another thing that's odd is that the standard test for main.exe ran just fine on the autograder. I don't know what's being passed in for the undefined behavior check, but whatever it is I can't see, so I can't really debug it. The only way to check is to resubmit to the autograder three times a day and try random fixes. What does this check run, so I can try it on my machine and debug it there?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am having the same exact issue</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hi! Sorry for the additional follow-up. I found the issue; it is not <em>just </em>in the percentile function, it is also in the summarize function.</p>


<p>For whatever reason, both my Mac and the CAEN computers allow for the evaluation of v[n+1] -- for an array of only n numbers.</p>


<p>This crashes on the auto-grader, because I assume it's set up to <em>actually </em>throw out an error when this happens, as opposed to VSCode which kinda just rolls with it.</p>


<p>(sidenote: why does VSCode do that? Why wouldn't it catch that?)</p>


<p>Issue corrected and fixed - whomever Anonymous Scale is, I hope this helps you too - go back and check out both of those functions in the debugger and check exactly which index it accesses.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hey! How did you fix this error of yours? I just started getting it and im pretty lost as to how to fix it</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hi!</p>


<p>I went through both my percentile function and my summarize function using the step-through debugger, and I found out that in a couple of cases I was trying to access array value 'n' in an array with n elements, which VSCode was accepting but the autograder was rejecting. </p>


<p>Unfortunately, I did end up having to rewrite both of those functions to check for those special cases where it was trying to pull v[n]. In those cases, I actually found it much easier to just write a function that deals with that case specifically, instead of trying to work a solution into the main function. Elegant? No, but it worked.</p>


<p>I don't know how much more detail I can get into it within the honor code rules, but I hope this proved at least somewhat helpful. Good luck!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So Helpful! </p>

To make sure you’re good to go with the tests, be sure you’ve tested your code thoroughly with <code>stats_tests.cpp</code> and have caught any edge cases.</p></div>

------------------------@152-------------------------
Summarize() return type
<p>I'm struggling to return a vector of vectors for the summarize function. My understanding is that we are returning a vector of vectors which are of type double. If that's right then how do you push_back or add a pair of doubles to a vector of type double? Wouldn't the vector need to be of type double, int, or double, double? If not and there's a way to push_back a pair of values into a double type vector then is there a tutorial or any information available online because I've looked everywhere. Thank you to anyone that can help</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Simply add another nested vector into the outer vector and add (not append, otherwise it won't just be two elements in the nested vectors anymore) and update the amount of the nested vectors dynamica</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Here’s an arbitrary example of using a vector of vectors, aka a 2D vector:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-comment">// Returns a 2D vector "w", where the i'th vector in "w" is a triplet of the i'th element in v, the index i itself, and the sum of the element and its index.</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">// Example: indexer({2, 5}) --&gt; {{2, 0, 2}, {5, 1, 6}}</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&gt;&gt; indexer(<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&gt;&amp; v) {
    <span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&gt;&gt; w;
    <span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> (<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> i = <span class="hljs-number">0</span>; i &lt; <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>(v.size()); ++i) {
        <span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&gt; x = {v[i], i, v[i] + v[i]};
        w.push_back(x);
    }
    <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> w;
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>As the student answer says, you would use <code>push_back</code> to insert an “inner” vector into the “outer” vector, just the same as you would insert a regular number into a 1D vector with <code>push_back</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I was thinking each element of the inner had to be of a type pair I forgot the concept of 2d vector being equivalent to that. That answered my question. Thank you Professor and Eddie.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@153-------------------------
