------------------------@158-------------------------
What files to #include in code
<p>When choosing what files to #include at the top of the code for main.cpp and stats_tests.cpp, how am I supposed to access the functions I've written in stats.cpp and the given functions in p1_library.cpp without doing #include "stats.cpp" and #include "p1_library.cpp"? -------------------------------------------------
<p>Whenever I try to run main.cpp with #include "stats.h" and #include "p1_library.h", I get the following error:</p>


<p></p>


<div>

------------------------@159-------------------------
Difference in unit test & system test.

<p>According to the instruction, we are supposed to write all the tests in stats_tests.cpp right? Therefore, when I wrote test functions for each p1 function in tests_tests.cpp, this cpp file looks more like a system test. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Therefore, are we supposed to create a cpp test file for each p1 function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I’m not sure which lecture you’re referring to, but it was most likely an example with only one test being shown. You’ll want to write all of your tests as functions in the stats_tests.cpp file, and the main function in that file should call each test.

------------------------@161-------------------------
alignment of percentile output
<p>Hello!</p>


<p></p>


<p>I just finished programming my main.cpp driver function and was checking the output of my main.exe against main_test.out.correct when I noticed the percentile output is somehow aligned in a way different than just outputting the information. I'm new to C++ and am not really sure how to accomplish output alignment, could I get some guidance? My output is correct, but when compared to main_test.out.correct, the output is not the same because it is aligned differently. </p>

------------------------@162-------------------------
Regarding Lecture 2
**EDIT** I don't seem to see where you can add photos in this class so if you take a look at 44:06 in Beaumont's lecture (1:30pm), you'll see what I'm referring too**
<br/>
I have a question regarding the certain data put on a stack entry. So the following photo has variables being passed into the function min(), but would those certain variables (x, y, z) being passed in be put on top of stack or no?
<br/>
I got the answer right but wanted to double check if they would create another space for the variables or not be because they have already have occupied space within the stack corresponding to those variables.
<br/>
(Sorry if my question is a little confusing as I can clarify where you need help understanding.)

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I think that Beaumont mentioned before that functions normally pass parameters by value, regardless of data type. So it should be that calling a function with three variables x,y,z defined elsewhere will create three new variables on the top of the call stack like you mentioned. If you wanted this to not happen and for them to use the same memory, you would declare the parameters with the ampersand (&amp;) after the data type to indicate to pass by reference:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">void</span> <span class="hljs-title">my_function</span><span class="hljs-params">(<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&amp; a, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&amp; b, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>&amp; c)</span> </span>{
	<span class="hljs-comment">/* function body */</span>
}

<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">void</span> <span class="hljs-title">main</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span> </span>{
	<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> x,y,z;
	my_function(x, y, z);
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('dm9pZCUyMG15X2Z1bmN0aW9uKGludCYlMjBhLCUyMGludCYlMjBiLCUyMGludCYlMjBjKSUyMCU3QiUwQSUwOS8qJTIwZnVuY3Rpb24lMjBib2R5JTIwKi8lMEElN0QlMEElMEF2b2lkJTIwbWFpbigpJTIwJTdCJTBBJTA5aW50JTIweCx5LHo7JTBBJTA5bXlfZnVuY3Rpb24oeCwlMjB5LCUyMHopOyUwQSU3RCUwQQ==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre></div>

------------------------@170-------------------------
Unable to Debug Stats.cpp
<p>When I try to run the "make stats.exe" on Ubuntu WSL, it says I cannot make stats.exe. I even have it in launch.json. How can I step through the function definitions to find out what's wrong? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><code>stats.cpp</code> contains the functions you’re implementing for this project, but to actually run the code, you’ll want to compile <code>make stats_tests.exe</code>, <code>make stats_public_test.exe</code>, or eventually <code>main.exe</code> (when you get to writing your <code>main.cpp</code> file!). Notice how these three files are the ones that have a <code>int main()</code> function, which tells the compiler where to begin executing code. <code>stats.cpp</code> is just a file to host your functions, so there’s actually nothing to “begin” running!</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you’re curious about how these commands work, take a peek at your <code>Makefile</code> - you’ll notice that the three “makeable” files I mentioned above are listed out in our <code>Makefile</code>, hence why it works here.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you! I was asking because I am trying to step through my summarize() function to see what is wrong, but I cannot do so because when I do it in stats_tests.cpp or main.cpp, it takes me to some vector file.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can add a breakpoint to the summarize function so when you run stats_tests.cpp it will stop at the summarize function for you to step through.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I did that, and it still made me step into the debugging vector file.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Did you put the breakpoint at the header of the summarize() function? If so, try putting it a few lines into the function. If that isn't the problem, try heading to office hours to get more one-on-one help so they can look at your code directly.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I figured it out. It works if you step out of the function and step in again. Thank you for the help!

<p>Here are the files for your reference: <a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszctriqgxu71e%2F1b809e40787e5fbe70b8be1f9d99b04ca971d2c76b889c6feb1e6dc956f49905%2Fstats.cpp" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">stats.cpp</a> and <a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszctriqgxu71e%2Fa48524985b60a9e9b67228c3960bba13edd4e0a8da7ac67c10b4f165117ca6e5%2Fmain.cpp" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">main.cpp</a></p>

This error would cause the make to not finish, which is why you get a make error. I would suggest looking at how your percentile function handles the bounds.</p>

<p>Thanks!</p>

<p><img alt="" height="1080" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fks5iojmc4rncc%2Ff3d4020ee4e54c3ee38be37f1771016484e97e6da496ae6a0b9e817b7fb00dc2%2FScreenshot_2022-09-04_185546.png" width="1920"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Any assert statements you have in your code will halt the program if the code inside the assertion evaluates to false. At the beginning of the project, we had assert(false) statements in all functions. Make sure all of those are removed. If you have any other assertions in your code, make sure they are evaluating to true as well.</p>

------------------------@186-------------------------
Debugging main() Function Issue
<p>Hello! Whenever I try to debug main(), it always says "Exception has occurred \nAborted". Is there any reason why this is happening?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
This is the default nature. Exception - aborted usually is indicating “assert(false);” was called. When you first open the project files, every function is defined as this, and calling any of the stats functions will immediately crash with this exception, as it hasn’t yet been coded.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It's a bit hard to identify what the problem might be without seeing your code. Try using your debugger to see what line the exception occurs on and debug from there. You could also submit to autograder so that an IA can see your code.</p>

<p>So if I have p = 100, wouldn't the excel method itself (disregarding c++, just the algorithm itself) go out of bounds? because</p>


<p></p>


<p>((100 * (number_of_elements - 1)) / 100) + 1</p>


<p>= number_of_elements - 1 + 1</p>


<p>= number_of_elements</p>

------------------------@193-------------------------
Question about project 1 tests
<p>Hi, <br/>The instructions say:<br/><strong>"Each function in stats.cpp must have at least one corresponding test function in stats_tests.cpp."</strong></p>


<p>For my tests, I only have 3 functions (for three different data sets), but each function calls every function in stats_tests.cpp. Is this ok, or am I supposed to have several separate test functions for every stats function?</p>


<p>Also, I was wondering how the tests we write are graded, as the autograder doesn't cover that. Are they just graded on completion and then the correctness of our code is evaluated by public and private tests, or do our tests get evaluated separately as well?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This isn't something we enforce with grading, but I would recommend having separate tests for each function. With your organization, if there is something wrong with, say, "sum", and everything else is fine, you may fail every test (which isn't very informative). If you separate them by function, it should be more immediately clear where the problem is because you only fail the tests that call "sum".</p>


<p></p>


<p>But as long as you submit some test for the project that passes on a correct implementation, you will get credit for P1. The later projects will have more stringent requirements that we will discuss later.</p>

------------------------@201-------------------------
Error with summarize()
<p>Could anyone explain this error or a way to go about fixing it?  <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-05_at_4.02.52_PM.png" height="236" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt02oritrda2cu%2F17f698d4c075eb4ceeb5214c09622127fa43203790fd5f91ff9eda605b817fd5%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-05_at_4.02.52_PM.png" width="554"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It sounds like you used a constant, and tried to assign its reference to a non constant variable, which would defeat its purpose. Recall that “const” makes a variable unchangeable, <span style="text-decoration:line-through">so you shouldn’t ever need to pass a reference to a const</span>. The “&amp;” sign denotes this passing by reference. You possibly just want to pass the value instead, or make the variable non-constant.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Passing by const reference is valid. In this case, you avoid making copies of the original object, and "const" forbids you to make changes to the original object. Note that sometimes we pass by reference not because we want to modify the object, but because the object is too big and it costs a lot to make another copy -- We would save some space by avoiding making a copy.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I hadn't used any constants when writing the function so the error confused me. Is there any other reason why it would be giving this error for a vector?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Without sharing code, could you tell me what line 35 does in that file?
<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm adding a vector into the vector of vectors using push_back.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Ah. If I had to guess, you’re adding the vector<double> as a type rather than an object. You can make a vector literal by using curly braces, for example, “{1, 2, 3}” will make a 3 item vector. You can replace 1, 2, 3 with variables if needed. Alternatively, consider declaring the vector<double> you want to push on a separate line.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@202-------------------------
Style Check with Comments
<p>Will single-line comments affect the style checks on your code when you submit the files to the autograder? (e.x.: cout &lt;&lt; "Hello World!" &lt;&lt; endl;           //This is a comment)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/style_guide.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/style_guide.html#comments</a>: "Comments go on their own line(s) unless they are <em>extremely</em> short." Not sure if it'll affect the autograder but it's probably good convention.</p>

------------------------@203-------------------------
Trying to print 2d vector element with colon in middle.
<p>resolved</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You can stack “<<“ and it will concatenate. For example, “cout << a << “ - “ << b << endl;
<div><div>And this will print “[a] - [b]”. Make sure to put anything that isn’t a variable in quotes so that the compiler knows to treat it as text.</div></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@204-------------------------
Test Functions
<p>I'm a little confused about what to do with test functions and what data we use for them. I understand they are our way to make sure our functions are working, but I'm not too sure how to code them. I know that we are suppose to use the assert() function to make sure everything is running properly. I guess what I'm exactly confused about is what kind of data should we use? Do we use the data from main_test_data.tsv? Do we use the data from How Couples Meet and Stay Together study? Can we make our own data just like how in stats_test.cpp gives us a function where they create a vector and push back data into and use it as their test data? Is there a certain amount of test that can be utilized in one test function? Does it even matter what kind of data we use?</p>


<p></p>


<p>I apologize if this is a redundant question. First time taking a EECS class at UOM and really scared of the formatting and grading systems. I hope you understand</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The point of the test functions is to test if the <code>stats.cpp</code> functions you write are giving the outputs you expect them to. Thus, you should create test functions that test whether the function works correctly for datasets you know the answers to. For example, the <code>test_sum_small_data_set()</code> function tests whether the <code>sum</code> function correctly calculates the sum of 1, 2, and 3 to be 6.</p>
<p>It doesn’t really matter what kind of data you use, but to be effective at weeding out bugs, it would be a good idea to think of where your program might fail due to weird data (edge cases). This usually means making your own vectors, and to do this, you can follow the example test function given. Alternatively, instead of pushing back each value individually, you can create a vector like so:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">double</span>&gt; a = {<span class="hljs-number">1</span>,<span class="hljs-number">2</span>,<span class="hljs-number">3</span>};
<span class="hljs-comment">// the above is the same as:</span>
<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">double</span>&gt; a;
a.push_back(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>);
a.push_back(<span class="hljs-number">2</span>);
a.push_back(<span class="hljs-number">3</span>);
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('dmVjdG9yJTNDZG91YmxlJTNFJTIwYSUyMD0lMjAlN0IxLDIsMyU3RDslMEEvLyUyMHRoZSUyMGFib3ZlJTIwaXMlMjB0aGUlMjBzYW1lJTIwYXM6JTBBdmVjdG9yJTNDZG91YmxlJTNFJTIwYTslMEFhLnB1c2hfYmFjaygxKTslMEFhLnB1c2hfYmFjaygyKTslMEFhLnB1c2hfYmFjaygzKTslMEE=');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>As for the number of test cases you can use for each function, you can use as many or as little as you want (but at least one test case per if you want points for test functions).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The students' answer has a lot of good points. You can use whatever data you'd like to test your functions, just make sure you know what the correct output should be (or can easily find it)! Like the students' answer says, be intentional about what data you are using to try and find bugs.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You'll see 'edge cases' talked about a lot. These can mean literal edges, like a function that takes in the numbers 1-10 (inclusive) can be tested with 1 and 10 as inputs. Edge cases can also be weird sets of data that you wouldn't always see, like small sets or sets of all the same number. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Feel free to check out other piazza posts about test cases, the test writing process, and other bugs that students have run into as well! If you search 'test' in the search bar you will find a lot of posts.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@207-------------------------
summarize function

-------------------------------------------------

<p>So I understand why we use to sort function but once the input on column is given how do I extract that column and sort from there</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

------------------------@212-------------------------
Function, memory and efficiency.
<p>Is it good practice or efficient to call functions in my functions? For example, should I call the mean function and the sum function that I wrote and defined earlier in the code in my stdev function or does that even up taking more memory etc?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It won’t end up taking more or less memory, but in terms of clean code, it’s definitely a good idea.  Your code will be much easier to read if you’re able to define it as sum() or mean(), rather than more code. As for memory and efficiency, it should all be roughly the same.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In addition to the student's response, it's generally a good idea to reduce code duplication, and one of the ways you can do this is by utilizing functions you've already written. This will help with debugging as well, so that you don't have to fix errors with the same code in more than one place.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@213-------------------------
Accessing elements of vector pairs in summarize()
<p>In summarize() i created vector pairs with {value, frequency} and I want a way to access and check the specific value in each pair. When I look up online how to do this everything says to use vector_pair_name.first (to access value for example) but this doesn't work in vs code. What is the proper syntax to access individual elements of vector pairs?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
If you’re looking to search for a specific value, you’ll need to write that yourself, but if you’re working off indexes, you can use vector[2][0] to access the row number 3,l key, or vector[2][1] for the value.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Be careful to note the difference between a vector of length 2 and a pair (std::pair). If you are working with a 2D vector where each of the inner vectors has a length of two, the student's answer would be correct that the proper syntax would be vec[&lt;row&gt;][0] for value and vec[&lt;row&gt;][1] for frequency in your example.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Am I declaring my vector pair wrong then? This is how I declared my vector:</p>


<div>
<div>vector&lt;pair&lt;int,int&gt;&gt; vec_name;</div>
<div></div>
</div>


<p>When i try and access my vector using <span style="text-decoration:underline">vec_name[0][0]</span> i get the error:</p>


<p>"no operator "[]" matches these operandsC/C++(349)<br/>stats.cpp(77, 27): operand types are: std::__1::pair&lt;int, int&gt; [ int ]"</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks again. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>My apologies, I should have also specified the syntax for the other case. Since you are using std::pair within the vector, you would access with vec_name[&lt;row&gt;].first and vec_name[&lt;row&gt;].second</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Essentially, you need to use an index into your overall vector to retrieve the pair, and from there you use .first or .second to access the specific elements within that pair.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Oh I see, that syntax worked, thanks so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think what you mentioned is different from the original question. If you are using VS Code, since it is only an editor not an IDE, you have to make a new exe file every time you change the related cpp files. You can also understand this as you are debugging the "exe" file and your computer helps to translate the machine code back to your cpp file so you can read the debugging process. If you use Visual Studio or Xcode, you do not need this step since they are IDEs and you may think that they automatically update the "exe" files.</p>

------------------------@219-------------------------
Floating Point Comparison in Mod
Are we expected to use the method for comparing floating point values within the stats.cpp, like in the mode function? Or is Appendix F more of a discussion for test cases?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>We are supposed to use the epsilon method wherever we compare doubles, so yes we would use it in <code>stats.cpp</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There isn't necessarily a file your supposed to use the epsilon value for floating point comparisons. Instead, think about it like you want to use epsilon in <em>any instance </em>of comparing two doubles. If your comparing doubles in your mode function, then you should use the epsilon value to make sure you're accurately comparing the two numbers. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
I don’t think that you would need to compare when you are writing the function, but only when testing to see if your answer is correct?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p><img alt="Discord_2022-09-06_00-30-28.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7nv0y6f4pf5aa%2Fc74e8a20409ff2ffe92b39af858fe5a96026d6114f0ccef6b082c6725c751635%2FDiscord_2022-09-06_00-30-28.png"/></p>
<p>it was confirmed with the staff on discord</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
Yes, I think they are saying this is why you need to write the tests as so. But you don’t need to compare anything inside the stdev function itself, right? Since that the autograder will get epsilon anyway

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>I don’t think that it matters too much for the <code>stdev</code> function, but I think that it would make a difference in <code>mode()</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
Then, should epsilon always be 5 digits?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo3ooY"><p>It’s what I’m going to use until I’m told a different value, since Alec mentioned that the autograder uses the epsilon method.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Epsilon doesn't have to be 5 digits, just has to be a small value less than 0 so that the doubles will accurately assert equal</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Hi,
<div><br/></div>
<div>What I am wondering is that, will autograder (in private test cases) use any digits beyond 5 digits.</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div> And , I think, it doesn’t matter in mod function. as well so long that the input is the same. We need epsilon for testing because that we are inputing a value manually for comparison. However, no matter what the actual double value is, so long that the input value (in the vector), is the same, they will be equal. For instance, if two 1.3456 is in the vector, they will at least be both 1.34560000001 or something in actuality.</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Please correct me if im wrong</div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@220-------------------------
Should we only care about epsilon when testing?
<p>As title, and do we need epsilon when camparing greater or less instead of equality?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
For the most part, floating point rounding errors only arise when the numbers are mutated. If you plan to change a double’s value and then compare two that you expect to be identical, only then will you want an epsilon. For testing, this makes perfect sense, as we want to compare the mathematically derived output to what we know to be true. Within stats.cpp, it depends on how your code was written, but you more than likely won’t need it.

-------------------------------------------------
Hi, so we do want to compare the full “hidden” digits when comparing INSIDE mode function (meaning, without epsilon) , but only using epsilon when we wanna simply test if the standard deviation is the same for the first five digits?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>That’s correct, in general you should avoid rounding in intermediate steps when computing something like stdev. Epsilon should only be used for testing if your stdev is correct.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@221-------------------------
error checking for functions
<p>For each of the functions listed in "stats.h", there's a part in comments that mentions "REQUIRED: v is not empty". Does this mean that there will be private test cases that will deliberately give functions an empty vector? If I have to implement error handling, what should I actually return? I reread the spec but I don't see a part that describes what to do when issues like this come up.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
In an RME, the Requires means that you can expect the input of the function to strictly follow the Requires clause. You can always double check this with an assert() statement.

-------------------------------------------------
To confirm, there are NO test cases that violate the “Requires” clause. Nothing you could do in that case would be incorrect.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@222-------------------------
VS Code lacking basic C++ functionality
<p>My VS Code does not know what cout or the operator "!=" is. It also is saying my summarize function doesn't have a return type when a) it does, and b) it is commented out (the entire function). My C/C++ extension has been installed, and I am using namespace std. Does anyone know how to fix this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Not sure about !=, but you need to #include the iostream library to get C++ to recognize cout or cin.</p>
<p><br/></p>
<p>New: Make sure you’ve installed the C++ extension in VS Code, this will enable syntax highlighting and some intellisense.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sounds like intellisense is just not refreshing. Try closing and reopening VS Code. If that doesn't fix the issue please make a follow up; otherwise, that's probably just intellisense running like molasses.</p>

<p>(base) myusername p1-stats % g++ stats_tests.cpp -o stats_tests.exe<br/>Undefined symbols for architecture x86_64:<br/>  "sum(std::__1::vector&lt;double, std::__1::allocator&lt;double&gt; &gt;)", referenced from:<br/>      testSum() in stats_tests-773891.o<br/>  "mean(std::__1::vector&lt;double, std::__1::allocator&lt;double&gt; &gt;)", referenced from:<br/>      testMean() in stats_tests-773891.o<br/>  "count(std::__1::vector&lt;double, std::__1::allocator&lt;double&gt; &gt;)", referenced from:<br/>      testCount() in stats_tests-773891.o<br/>ld: symbol(s) not found for architecture x86_64<br/>clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)</p>

------------------------@235-------------------------
sort function giving the message "Expected '(' for function-style cast or type construction"

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Main.exe is the executable compiled by the compiler. It's the code that only the machine should read so it knows how to execute your program. Maybe you mean main.cpp? That's the file you should modify and then when you compile it, the result is stored in main.exe</p>

------------------------@238-------------------------
Edge Cases
<p>I am struggling to come up with edges cases for some of the functions, most notably summarize. Does anyone have any tips or tricks on how to think of them and develop test cases for them? Thanks!</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
One trick that I have is to just think of weird cases that would deviate from the main code in your function and find ways to fix these special cases in your code without breaking the requirement case.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Do we need edge cases for all functions? If so, would that be possible for functions as simple as sum?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You won't be graded on the thoroughness of your test cases, but it is good practice to think of edge cases for all your functions. However, for project 2 and beyond your test cases will be graded</p>

------------------------@239-------------------------
how to test the functions we write
<p>Say I wrote the summarize function in stats.cpp and I wrote a function that tests the summarize function in stats_tests.cpp. How do I actually test that the summarize function works? I tried using "make test" in the terminal but I only see that it creates a bunch of files that I can't read/open in the Explorer. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
So "make test" is the command for a regression test that tests your whole code, not a specific function. It makes sure that the code still works after you've made a change. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>To test a specific function, like summarize(), run stats_tests.cpp and see if the tests are passed or not. Good luck!</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Tip: Use the debugger!</div>

------------------------@241-------------------------
How to call functions inside other functions?
<p>I'm writing my functions and I want to call my functions inside other function but I get this error,</p>


<p><img alt="2022-09-06_(2).png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2F55e48113b02bd2593b99e6561c45c6953b23696b54e435d8421fe721feb4fcdb%2F2022-09-06_%282%29.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you compile your code by running "make main.exe" in the terminal, do you get any errors like those in your screenshot? If not, then you're including the header files correctly, and it's probably an issue with VS Code. Could you share your c_cpp_properties.json file, please? It's in the .vscode folder. Usually, the C/C++ extension looks in your current folder for header files by default, but it may not be configured to do so on your machine...</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I actually continued afterward making this post and found that I don't run into an error if I just use the function instead of trying to save the function's output.</p>


<p>So instead of vector&lt;double&gt; v = sort(v), I just use sort(v)</p>


<p><img alt="2022-09-07_(2).png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2Fc42af268a4f118ca7af28e03a5499afd79fef902856f0468ea324291407d4bc2%2F2022-09-07_%282%29.png"/></p>


<p>I don't understand why this is the case, but I figured out how to get functions inside functions it, thank you for your response.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This works because the sort function takes in a vector by reference. So sort modifies the original vector v that you give it and the sort function doesn't return anything.</p>

------------------------@242-------------------------
Get Return Value With Debugger
<p>How do you get the return value of a non-void function while debugging on VSCode so it shows up in the debugging panel?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Modify the return value to be a variable and then when you're debugging, you'll be able to see the variable in the panel and it's value. Then you can set a breakpoint at the return statement and see what the variable holds right before the return executes.

------------------------@244-------------------------
Rand in Test cases?
<p>Hi, </p>


<p></p>


<p>I was wondering if test cases could make use of the rand function? Or, should every aspect of the test case be known to the programmer for debugging purposes? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The issue with using random data for test cases is: how are you going to know the correct answer for the random data? If you are going to check whether your function calculates the correct mean of a random set of data, you need to know what the correct mean is. If you try to write something to find the mean of this random data programmatically, well then congratulations you’ve written your function again, or a different function that you aren’t sure works 100% of the time.</p>
<p>This isn’t to say that you can’t - for example, you could find a <code>mean</code> function that has been verified to work accurately and use that to test against the random data. But when your function fails, it would be helpful to know the data where it failed so you could study why it failed at that specific case. You would test your function against that data until it works - and voila, you ended up using a static, known test case in the end.</p>
<p>The randomness just helped you find that case by chance - but what if it didn’t find an edge case for you? Your function wouldn’t be completely correct and you wouldn’t know it. It’s better to think through and find your wanted test cases because you may have an intuition of what datasets your function may err on instead of trying to find one by picking at straws.</p>
<p>tl;dr: it’s hard to check your answer on a random dataset and random data probably isn’t the best at finding where your function fails</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@245-------------------------
What floating-point precision value should be used for summarize function?
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Is it expected that we implement something similar to the code in Appendix F for floating point precision in the summarize function? If so, what value should we use for precision?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The epsilon value comparison in Appendix F is definitely necessary to successfully test and compare your functions involving doubles. The value itself in reality can just be any small value less than 0.01 such that two doubles assert to be equal.</p>

------------------------@247-------------------------
9/9 on autograder, but code won't run with real data
<p>Hello!</p>


<p></p>


<p>I submitted my code to the autograder last night and received a 9/9. However, when I tried my code with the real data from HCMST_ver_3.04.tsv, my code failed and I'm not sure why... I'll include screenshots with the error but I am not 100% what is wrong as it seems to be working with my other small data. Any guidance would be appreciated! </p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you!</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7diwffsv70j1%2Ff1d1a6cfe9e58692b6e758766e80e28b8cdc4e9d968d48365053e79fe21caa0d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_11.39.52_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_11.39.52_PM.png</a></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7diwffsv70j1%2F62e21708647528d49df2f9e39349099911545a28fe8781aa6db841932b63216b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_11.40.08_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-06_at_11.40.08_PM.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you're getting a heap buffer overflow on line 20 of main.cpp. Don't worry if you've never heard of this error before; it basically means you're indexing outside of some memory buffer (array, vector, etc.). I looked up your submission in the autograder, and it looks like you might have a problematic for-loop on line 19 of main.cpp:</p>


<p></p>


<p><code>for (size_t i = 0; i &lt; v.size(); i++){<br/>    vector&lt;double&gt; data = summary[i];<br/>    cout &lt;&lt; data[0] &lt;&lt; ": " &lt;&lt; data[1] &lt;&lt; endl;<br/>  }</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>Notice how you're looping from 0 to v.size(), and then you're indexing into the summary vector. Is summary guaranteed to be at least as big as v? If not, you'll walk off the end of summary, causing this error. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@248-------------------------
Test cases and comments
<p>1) Since there is an RME for each function in stats.h, do I have to recopy those comments and put them above the functions that are in stats.cpp? Do I have to add an RME for the main function that's in main.cpp and my test functions that are in stats_tests.cpp?</p>


<p></p>


<p>2) Additionally, my second question is when creating test cases, can I make vectors like this</p>


<p>vector&lt;double&gt; = {1, 2, 3} </p>


<p>or do I have to make the vectors using the push_back function? (So for example, push_back(1), push_back(2), etc...)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>1) You don't have to but could do this if you like! Personally, I like to have my header files on the right side of my VS Code window and the .cpp files on the left side. It makes it really easy to see both and makes it so that you don't have to duplicate those function RMEs. You can do this by right-clicking on a file in VS Code (I'm not sure about other IDEs). No, you don't have to create an RME for the main function in main.cpp. You also don't need to have RMEs for your tests in stats_tests.cpp, but I think it's a good idea to write a short description of what the test is doing or something about the datasets that you are trying. Just a few words will work so that when you revisit these tests, you can quickly understand what is going on and you can avoid writing multiple of the same tests.</p>


<p></p>


<p>2) Either way should work!</p>


<p></p>


<p>This was a good question! Feel free to make it public or ask these kinds of questions as public next time if you'd like!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@249-------------------------
P1 Overview Session
<p>Hi everyone! Hope you all had a great long weekend!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Staff will be hosting a <strong>P1 Overview Session over Zoom tonight from 7-8PM EST</strong>. We'll go over the basics of the different components of this project, as well as some general tips on getting started. <p>Hey guys, I finished with the stats and main cpp and I was trying to run the code, but the system shows</p>


<p></p>


<p>"fatal error: p1_library.h: No such file or directory". </p>


<p></p>


<p>However, I did include the header file #include &lt;p1_library.h&gt;</p>


<p></p>


<p>Can anyone help me with that problem? Many thanks!</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try #include “p1_library.h” with quotes instead of &lt;&gt;</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you're curious as to why the student's answer is correct, using quotes tells the compiler to look for the file in your current directory. Using angle brackets tells the compiler to look in a set of special directories that includes the standard library.</p>

------------------------@258-------------------------
style checking message meaning / putting test cases in functions
<p>1) When I run the oclint to check for style, I get a message saying "non-aggregate<br/>    type 'vector&lt;double&gt;' cannot be initialized with an initializer list". Can someone explain to me what that means? I would appreciate it.</p>


<p>    I did try the "make style" command and it said "EECS 280 style checks PASS" though (I'm just mentioning this in case it's important).</p>


<p>2) There's a part of the spec under the "testing" section that says this: "Your tests should be written as separate functions".</p>


<p>     So if I have a function called test_sum() to test my sum function, and I want to use 3 different vectors as test cases, does this mean I can write ONE test_sum() function</p>


<p>     and have 3 assert statements (one for each test case), or do i have to write THREE separate functions, one for each test case?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<ol><li>An initializer list  is something like "vector&lt;double&gt; v = {1,2,3};", which should be supported. OClint might not be using the correct version of C++? That might be worth checking with someone in OH where we can see how you're running it.</li><li>This is a bit of a judgement call. You want to avoid having too bloated test cases. It makes it harder to narrow down what the problem is if something goes wrong. Sometimes two assert statements are very related to each other, so it make sense to pair them in one test case. I would say the common tendency for newer programmers is to put too much in one test case. Remember that you can write and call helper functions if want to have similar setup in each test with separate values.</li></ol>


<p>Great questions! Since you didn't post any code, would you mind marking your question as public, in case other students have similar questions? You can mark yourself as anonymous if you'd prefer.</p>

------------------------@262-------------------------
Floating Point Clarification
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo4ooY"><p>I just went to Prof. Beaumont’s Office Hours today to get a clear answer on floating point errors and handling throughout the project. Here is what he said:</p>
<ul><li>You will need to use the epsilon method in testing your own code because of floating point errors. The epsilon value is the <strong>same</strong> as in the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">appendix</a> on the project spec. That is:</li></ul>
<pre><code>const double epsilon = 0.00001;
</code></pre><ul><li>You will not need to use the epsilon method in the <code>mode()</code> function or any of your code in the <code>stats.cpp</code> file.</li><li>You will not have to change your math to compensate for floating point errors in any functions in the <code>stats.cpp</code> file.</li></ul></div>

-------------------------------------------------
"You will not need to use the epsilon method in the mode() function or any of your code in the stats.cpp file."
<br/>
Then the mode function will give an incorrect value for any repeated double?
<br/>
I.e. mode{2.0, 2.0, 2.0, 1.0} = 1.0?
<br/>
Do rounding errors only occur when a double (or floating point) value is calculated?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>TL;DR: Because of how we represent decimals in memory, rounding errors only affect the <code>mode</code> function’s behavior when you feed the result of arithmetic operations on floats into it.</p>
<p>The root cause of rounding errors is the way computers store floating-point numbers. There are infinitely many floating-point numbers within any interval, but there is only a finite number of permutations of 1’s and 0’s that computers can use to represent them. In this context, we use the <a href="https://www.h-schmidt.net/FloatConverter/IEEE754.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">IEEE-754</a> standard to represent floating-point numbers. Intuitively, it’s like representing base-10 decimals using base-2 decimals of limited length (along with <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="0" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-cD7"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-msup><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c32"></mjx-c></mjx-mn><mjx-script style="vertical-align: 0.363em;"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i" size="s"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D45B TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-script></mjx-msup></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></msup></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container>).</p>
<p>While all possible IEEE-754 encoded values can be represented in a finite number of base-10 digits, most base-10 decimals can’t be represented in up to 32 or 64 binary digits. Try putting 2.0 and 1.0 in the IEEE-754 converter linked above—you’ll see that they are represented exactly and accurately in binary. However, try putting 3.3 in the converter—you’ll see that the number stored is not exactly 3.3, but slightly less than it. This is as close as IEEE-754 floats can get to 3.3.</p>
<p>Now, imagine the comparison <code>3.3 == 3.3</code>. Since the compiler encodes both decimals in the same way, they end up being equal to each other, i.e., slightly off from 3.3 in the exact same way. Therefore, even if you did <code>mode({3.3, 3.3, 3.3, 1.0})</code>, the answer without accounting for <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="1" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D716 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>ϵ</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> would still be 3.3.</p>
<p>However, rounding errors start becoming problematic for us when we start performing arithmetic on terms that already have rounding error. For the sum <code>1.1f + 2.2f</code>, and assuming they are stored as floats, the computer actually calculates 1.10000002384185791015625 + 2.2000000476837158203125. The result would be slightly above 3.3, but recall that when you put in 3.3, the exact number stored is slightly below 3.3 because that’s the closest possible number in our float encoding. Therefore, the result of <code>1.1f + 2.2f</code> is different (bitwise) compared to <code>3.3f</code> because the sum compounds the rounding errors of the operands. However, their difference is tiny and should be below your <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="2" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D716 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>ϵ</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> value, in which case you would treat them as equal.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@263-------------------------
out of range error for multiple stats functions
<p>This is my code for the summarize function. It prints out as should in the terminal except for the last line. This seems like an easy bug to fix although for the life of me I can't figure out where or why it is going out of range. I figure it must be from the outer while loop since this is code that repeats in the sum and mean functions which report the same error.<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyucejru3j3rk%2F848680a0da8851c3f756e25ad8d2537c0ee9368f8c4257a613e5415ae153bc4f%2F2022-09-07.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">2022-09-07.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Since you're sharing a snippet of your code, I converted your post to private. In the future, please post privately if you're sharing code -- we don't want anyone stealing your ideas! ;)</p>


<p></p>


<p>I recommend stepping through some examples on paper to find this bug. In particular, what if v contains only duplicate elements? For example, what if v = [1, 1, 1]? I think your inner loop will cause an issue in this case; since (currentnum == rightnum) is always true, what will happen with y? Replacing these while loops with for loops might help, since you have to specify a terminating condition for them.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, it looks like you're doing all the printing in summarize(), and returning an empty vector of vectors to satisfy the compiler. I recommend checking out the documentation for this function in stats.h:</p>


<p></p>


<p><code>//REQUIRES: v is not empty<br/>//EFFECTS: returns a summary of the dataset as (value, frequency) pairs<br/>//  In the returned vector-of-vectors, the inner vector is a (value, frequency)<br/>//  pair.  The outer vector contains many of these pairs.  The pairs should be<br/>//  sorted by value.<br/>//  {<br/>//    {1, 2},<br/>//    {2, 3},<br/>//    {17, 1}<br/>//   }<br/>//<br/>// This means that the value 1 occurred twice, the value 2 occurred 3 times,<br/>// and the value 17 occurred once</code></p>


<p><code></code></p>


<p>You may want to change your implementation to fill the vector with summary information, return that vector, and then handle the printing outside of the summary() function. Feel free to stop by office hours if you need help getting started with this!</p>

------------------------@264-------------------------
Duplicate symbol '_main' error in Mac os
<p>Hi, I found one error message showed that there are two duplicate symbol in my two files, can anyone help me with this issue? Thank you guys in advance.</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7glu6ytdvc2qd%2Fd9f4b965d5ed34574d09334b6c06f2901e0be1c9e069182bf9355995e28ded7a%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The error is essentially stating:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Duplicate symbol “main” in the “stats_tests” and “stats” object files.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Therefore, a main function is defined in both <code>stats_tests.cpp</code> and <code>stats.cpp</code>, which confuses the linker. Which main function would <code>stats_tests.exe</code> run? It has two options and can’t decide.</p>
<p>In project 1’s context, <code>stats.cpp</code> is <em>just a library</em>—it only provides some functions that other programs can use. It is not a self-sustaining program, so don’t write a main function in <code>stats.cpp</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@270-------------------------
Call of overloaded 'abs(double)' is ambiguous issue in Autograder
<p>Hi, on an M1 Mac here (if relevant). I've been creating test cases in stats_tests.cpp that test pointer comparisons, and so far my code has been compiling and running as expected. However, when I submit my code to the autograder, this issue shows up. Does anybody know how to fix this? </p>


<p><img alt="" height="1448" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky4mhdwocbw5l0%2Fc468d7d4fea4dffcbf0ce4163b95e7dd46924a7fb3679dd100ac60117bcf7203%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-07_at_8.26.31_PM.png" width="2200"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm guessing you are not including the appropriate library in your C++ file (I think it's "stdlib.h"?). Your IDE might be including it automatically, but the autograder will not.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hi, I added #include "stdlib.h" to the stats_tests.cpp file and I am still getting that error. Could it be another issue? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sorry, it should be &lt;cmath&gt; not stdlib.h</p>

------------------------@271-------------------------
Segmentation error
<p style="text-align:left">Hello I'm having a bit of trouble trying to run some test cases, I tried to use my function in the int main but its giving me a segmentation error</p>

<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I just copy pasted the sort function from the p1 library and made sure to match the vectors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You copied the function header (aka “def sort(…..)”)? If so, there is no need to do that, having the function header in your stats.cpp file might even cause issues, I’m not sure. Just call it by having a line that says “sort(v);”, where v is your vector’s name. You said you wrote “#include “p1_library.h”” at the top already, which is good, that will mean you don’t need to copy over anything from that file.

------------------------@275-------------------------
Epsilon Testing
When testing using epsilon, is it okay that we do not use the assert statement? In the example on the instructions, the assert statement was not used.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In the p1_stats tutorial, it shows how epsilon should be used. For most of the test cases, usually we would do assert(mode(v) == 2) or something like that, but we cannot do that when comparing float numbers because they are not entirely precise. So your assert argument has to be something similar to what the floating number comparison tutorial did. Sorry if my answer was somewhat confusing; leave a question below if you are still confused :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When writing your test cases in stats_tests.cpp, you should use an assert statement in each test case.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>Hello,</p>

I have a .exe file for stats_tests.exe, I created a launch.json file, and started the debugging section of the setup. My problem comes with the debugging itself. I cannot get it to run through my program. Every time I try to debug, a new file comes up and my terminal shows all sorts of funky stuff I don't understand. Above all the bytes, it gives a summary saying "AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow." I don't know how to fix this.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-07_at_10.39.30_PM.pngNaN" height="266" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7kniuridzg9u%2Ff1af15f3b0009e13db47d608d575ec83ded72eab5c46dd9446f0d715c812c2b4%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-07_at_10.39.30_PM.png" width="414"/></p>

<p>The AddressSanitizer error means your program is likely accessing memory that hasn't been allocated yet (for example, going off the end of a vector). I would reccommend setting a breakpoint at the start of main, then stepping through your program to see which line of code is causing the error. Follow up if you have any more questions!</p>

I believe that it means you are indexing outside of the bounds of a vector. I believe I got the same error many times.

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm not sure if that's the issue because I was going outside of bounds and it was different. Also it happens for all of my functions and I can continue stepping in and it takes me to various .h files.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ohh I'm very sorry, I misled you before. I didn't even check to see if there was an error being thrown - there isn't. What's happening is that you are always "stepping in" from the little debugging control panel, right? Instead, I would almost always use "step over". For what it's worth, when I was accidentally indexing outside of a vector, it was bringing me to the vector.cpp file that you have shown above, but again, nothing is broken with your code, just use step over (if you use step in, it will bring you to all the granular stuff that the functions we use all the time are build off of).</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I thought when debugging we were supposed to step into the function we write? When I step over the function, it just shows what the result of my function was not how everything is happening. Thank you for your help I really appreciate it!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is true, normally we step into functions when we want to see what's happening, but it looks like you're stepping into a function in vector.cpp. It's going to be difficult to understand what's happening in vector.cpp since it's from the standard library (you include this when you do #include &lt;vector&gt;) and you can guarantee there are no bugs in the standard library, so I would just step over to the next line.</p>

------------------------@279-------------------------
Ubuntu Commands
<p>I am a transfer student so this is my first time using a command line in order to compile and run code. I was a little confused going through the setup and project information about the different types of commands. If I want to run the whole program do I run the "make test" command in my Ubuntu application? For testing individual files, do I just put the .exe file name at the end of the command? Are there any other commands I should be using for testing and debugging?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There's basically two steps to running your program: compiling the executable, then running the executable. The compilation commands are the ones that start with g++ or c++, and basically bind all of your source code together into the executable. For stats_tests.exe, it might look something like</p>


<p></p>


<p>g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe</p>


<p></p>


<p>This command creates the stats_tests.exe file.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Then to run stats_tests, you would type</p>


<p></p>


<p>./stats_tests.exe</p>


<p></p>


<p>Makefile commands make it easier to compile your code without have to write the full compilation command. I would reccomend looking at the Makefile to see what commands it supports, because each do different things! For example, "make stats_tests.exe" will run "g++ -Wall -Werror -pedantic -g --std=c++11 stats_tests.cpp stats.cpp p1_library.cpp -o stats_tests.exe". However, "make test" will compile each of the test files AND run them. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Please follow up if you have any questions!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@281-------------------------
Standard Deviation Test failing
<p>Hello. While using caen, my standard deviation test is failing but the output of both elements is the same. I'm lost as to why they're failing and how I implement the precision and epsilon tips in my code. Images are attached<img alt="" height="550" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxzjz9knc269v%2Fdc81dd1b0a490bd1b1c6b0180320c0b9041d81385eeeeda4e9531388e6ddd01c%2Fstdev_test.png" width="693"/><img alt="" height="118" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxzjz9knc269v%2Fbcf80ff8191720ed50331908ed4fdb0e5ed88005adc8c4c7c8345490f7138cca%2Fcaen.png" width="1291"/><img alt="" height="544" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxzjz9knc269v%2F1fa4992f40dc03f9f7d38c557528655143b0d1485a6683ecd7e1d0db304f726d%2Fstdev_function.png" width="696"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So the reason the test case specifically is failing is because you aren't using the epsilon comparison value properly. If you refer back to appendix F, you'll see that while the first few digits of the decimal are the same, maybe 10 digits later they will differ, so thus they aren't equal. In order to fix this, simply take the absolute value of the difference and compare it to be less than a small epsilon value (0.01 or lesser) (see Appendix F for syntax). </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So in this case, would I be using the Epsilon comparison value in my test case function? </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@282-------------------------
assert()Function
<p>Is it nessacery for full points to use the assert function for our tests or can we use cout </p>

-------------------------------------------------
Tests aren’t graded for p1 so you don’t have to worry about it

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Assert is specifying the cases which we do not consider "valid" which should trigger abortion as you may see from your compiler. For grading, yes we do not grade on your test cases on p1, but try to use assert since it is very helpful for debugging and help you to distinguish "edge cases" from "invalid cases" (Some students may be confused about these two ideas).</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Assert is just really useful for test cases, and I think it make test cases a lot more simple to see where bugs where. But yeah, test cases are not being graded in project 1, but I think they will be graded starting from project 2. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@285-------------------------
debugger problem
<p>does anyone know what this means?<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_11.15.13_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky3b7g1m2u57o6%2F31a0b1094f368dbbf4898473928132633b124ece1a26d6ca241ff1a829ad64e8%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_11.15.13_AM.png"/></p>

------------------------@286-------------------------
Confused on the summarize function
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkejgw934y4m2le%2F54d42d0fe0b9a725db3b64699c99e538ace25c099fcaf861141d1513af3f98a7%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>I've been stuck on the summarize function for quite a while now, but this is what I've been trying to implement. I looked on the internet for a way to create a pair, and I used the index that I'm at followed by a number which tracks how many times it shows up. I also looked up a way to push those back into a vector, which is what the emplace back is for, however, I feel like I'm completely off track. Any pointers?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The return type of summarize is a 2D vector -- this means you should create a vector that holds vectors (the declaration will match the function signature). The inner vectors look like pairs, but they are actually just vectors with two elements in them. Each "pair" (vector of size 2) holds the number you are summarizing in the first index and then the frequency in the second index. Let me know if you have any more questions!</p>

------------------------@288-------------------------
Console issue
<p>I have been running my code on my terminal and its been passing all of my tests that I wrote and running perfectly fine on there. However, I tried running my code on my IDE and when it got to my percentage function, this error message came up. What does this mean?</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_3.35.56_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0tvomb6mz1vb%2F34fa1741637166cf5610b58d7d2890769ac4388714e5ba5ba6218d0add57b3bb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_3.35.56_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>An invalid read typically indicates that you are attempting to access something at an index that is out-of-bounds on your vector/array. I would suggest reviewing your percentile function and looking out for possible edge cases where the index you are accessing may be outside the allocated size of your vector.</p>

------------------------@291-------------------------
Segmentation fault error when testing on HCMST file
<p>Hi, I was testing my code using the HCMST_ver_3.04.tsv file and I ran into this problem with segmentation fault. Has anyone else seen this or have suggestions on how to fix it? Everything works fine when I run it using the main_test_data.tsv and I have the sanitiser line in my makefile, so I'm confused. Thanks!</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_8.37.40_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkegpb635x7o4rj%2F7bf368dbc23efec68198cbf6f1fe0386e114fa369e4315d3f7fc0731d43cc05d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_8.37.40_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Segmentation faults can mean a lot of things (typically with accessing outside of a bound) so you would have to dig into your code and see what might be wrong. I recommend making a private post or coming to office hours. That being said, for this project, typically segmentation faults could occur if you are accessing outside the space of a vector. So I suggest you make sure you are accessing elements that exist within the vector objects you are creating (keep track of the running size of the vector to verify this).</p>

------------------------@292-------------------------
What to return for percentile.
<p>Hi, for the percentile function I was wondering if we are asking the user for a specific percentile and printing that or if we are just printing 0,25,50,75,100 like in the example, thanks.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Your main function should use those set percentiles, but your percentile function should be able to handle any given percentile. For this project, we are basically submitting the functions in stats.cpp, so the autograder will input vectors and percentiles and test the output. In other words, no cout or cin needed.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So the function takes "v" and "p" as input, so if we are not asking the user for the percentile what would our input for p be then?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The percentile function should be able to handle any value p, but for the purposes of this project you only need to test p = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0 from main (you don't need to ask the user to input a percentile). </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@293-------------------------
P1 Mode Function
If all values in a vector are different, what would the mode be?

-------------------------------------------------
The lowest number

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Adding on to the student answer, you can find the details on how we expect the functions to work in the stats.h file</p>

------------------------@294-------------------------
Output wouldn't print from main.cpp
My output is printing only to a certain extent and after that, I don't see anything on the terminal. I don't understand why this is happening.
<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_10.18.52_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxulg2ctoq5h1%2F53e90ec167a768e29a27677db20bd9debc0ed1b8e56256b8ad4e710e839fa14b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-08_at_10.18.52_PM.png"/>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like your code never completes running. So somewhere between lines 26 and 29 it is getting "stuck", and never makes it to line 30, which is why we don't see that output at the terminal. You could try setting a breakpoint at line 26 and using the debugger to see where in the code the program is getting stuck.</p>

------------------------@298-------------------------
Autograder, private tests and undefined behavior
<p>Hi! </p>

<p></p>


<ul><li><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk9ud4ux46t53yf%2Fb5718788132a49aba429527b7bec96a57a6c1bfe7b48e85680c81eaa35bf94d1%2Fimage.png"/></li></ul>


<p></p>


<ul><li>In other piazza posts, I read that we are not supposed to know which private tests to write. Does it, therefore, mean, that the private test section will stay greyed out even if I write the correct tests? </li><li>What would be tips to make sure I can get all points for the private tests?</li></ul>


<p></p>


<ul><li>When it says that there are 2 mean test cases I should have written (stats test mean 1, stats test mean 2), does one of the two include the the assert function stubs that were provided at the beginning? Therefore, I would technically only have 2 test mean functions, if my second one is correct.</li></ul>


<p>Thank you so much for your help!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Addressing bullets 3,4, and 5, instructor should correct me if I’m wrong, but in project 1, they are not testing our test cases, there are just certain tests that will be performed on our functions.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Like, if you had an add function, they might test it by giving it 1 and 6 to get 7, and then another with 4 and -1, to test if the function can handle this. You do not *need* to write test cases specifically (for this project, again, instructor should correct me if I’m wrong), you *should* write them to help convince yourself that your function will pass any test the autograder forces it through. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>The list of private tests on the autograder I believe is a heads up to us as students about how many ways they will be testing our functions, and their titles give you a hint on how vulnerable certain functions are (for instance, a more complex function will have more vulnerability to error, most of the time, so there will be more tests of it, because there are more possible bugs).</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Use these titled tests to help assure yourself that you have covered all your bases. These grayed out boxes, however, will not highlight until after the final due date for the project.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Just to be clear, the tests you write are for your sake. You can easily create test cases and run them on your computer to make sure your code performs correctly.</p>
<p>The greyed out boxes are private test cases. We will run them against your code after the deadline as a way to grade how accurately your code performs.</p>
<p>All of the blue boxes are public test cases. They’re there to help you see how well your code performs on the autograder while developing your code. They will also contribute to your score, as you may have already seen.</p>
<p>Hope this was clear, feel free to follow up with any uncertainties!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

<p dir="ltr">If you already have the windows version of VScode installed, once you remove the debian file and run $code . it should open the windows vscode version and on the bottom left you'll see "WSL: Ubuntu" in the green box. ------------------------@301-------------------------
bad_alloc error on summarize function [w/ image]
<p>This is my stats_tests.cpp file which has the test_summarize function.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_11.08.58_AM.pngNaN" height="896" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswhs7lnsj31vn%2F3a6bb101eaa01fe9f3753126f8f4a956d317d03589da62ed161e3f10cb76b8d4%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_11.08.58_AM.png" width="1394"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>This is my implementation of the summarize function in stats.cpp. This screenshot also has the error that I get after trying to run stats_tests.</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_11.11.58_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswhs7lnsj31vn%2F16f489da7824995173d6855641758c4b827aee004465a2bedb8457196447ea06%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_11.11.58_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Hmm okay. Looking at <code>summarize</code> in <code>stats.cpp</code>, you’re probably getting that specific issue on line 23 or line 28. <code>bigv[1]</code> refers to the second element of <code>bigv</code>, but <code>bigv</code> only has one element (one vector) in it on the first iteration of the for loop.</p>
<p>I <em>think</em> (and I could be wrong) that you might be mixing things up with your vector indexes. If so, this might help. We provide an example in <code>stats.h</code> of an output summarize vector like so:</p>
<pre><code>{
    {1, 2},
    {2, 3},
    {17, 1}
}
</code></pre><p>The entire object is of type <code>vector&lt;vector&lt;double&gt;&gt;</code>. There are three <code>vector&lt;double&gt;</code> objects in here: <code>{1, 2}</code>, <code>{2, 3}</code>, <code>{17, 1}</code>. If we call our outer vector of vectors <code>v</code>, then we could access the second vector with <code>v[1]</code>. We can then index into the vector at <code>v[1]</code> with additional square brackets: <code>v[1][0] == 2</code> (first element of <code>v[1]</code>) and <code>v[1][1] == 3</code> (second element of <code>v[2]</code>). Going back a bit, <code>v[0]</code> accesses the first vector, `v[2] accesses the third vector.</p>
<p>I may have misdiagnosed the issue, so please follow up (or hop on office hours!) if this isn’t clear and/or you’d like more assistance.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok I think I understand what you mean somewhat about indexing into the vectors. Also I would go to office hours but I have class during that time today :( I'm still somewhat unsure on my approach but that aside, I don't understand why there is an error on lines 24/25. It says "expression must have class type but it has type "double"C/C++(153)" but I feel like since I am indexing into the vector of doubles and then into the double cell itself, I should be able to push back a double. Why wouldn't this work? <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_12.19.01_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswhs7lnsj31vn%2Fea6449e8fa3507e579cb9f5767dfcae1a12fed12e03a5a136a89b010e85ceec6%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-09_at_12.19.01_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You have the right idea on line 18 where you push a vector into your bigV. You're going to want to mirror that on lines 24-25. The reason its giving you an error is because bigV is a vector of vectors so it will only allow you to push another vector into it, not individual double values. </p>

------------------------@304-------------------------
Summarize Tests
<p>I'm a bit confused on how to actually test summarize as assert is only for one value? Are we supposed to split up the tests or see if the 2D vectors match? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Assert can be used for vector equality, though I believe you might have to declare them before putting them in the statement:</p>



<div>vector&lt;vector&lt;int&gt;&gt; example = {{1,2},{3,1}};</div>


<div>assert(summary(data) == example);</div>



<div>Assert is a function that tests if the internal statement is true or false, so you can test whatever you want in it.</div>

<p>Hi! This is a great question. On the autograder, your test functions are tested against other buggy code to see if you catch errors. Unfortunately, getting all of the test points on autograder doesn't mean your code actually passes them. You'd have to run your stats_tests.cpp locally to test your code. </p>


<p></p>

<p></p>

My code passes all my private stats tests and the public ones through the auto grader but the two it fails are because of out of bounds indexes. Particularly, you're going to want to look at each time you call v[something] check that in all cases that something is going to be strictly less than the size of your vector. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Am I not accounting for that already though? In my current percentile function, I made if statements and else if statements to account for when v[something] has a negative number or something out of bounds.<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxzjz9knc269v%2F1f00a9cd595a380821f5650c7e38629e9e469f8c0709c92215e9d8f6f97bee76%2F1.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">1.png</a></p>

You have if statements to check if intpart is equal to 0 or equal to 1. But think about the errors you're getting. It's saying you're trying to index 3th element in a size of 3 vector which is out of bounds. When would your intpart be large enough to be the size of the vector?

------------------------@306-------------------------
Percentage requirements
<p>The percentage function only has the requirement that v is not empty, but I am not sure if I am reading / implementing percentage wrong from the Wikipedia, but it seems to me to need 2 elements to give a percentage? I am just making sure so I can find all the edge cases based on what is given</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes you will need both values that are passed in as parameters for the function. The requires clause in the RME is not detailing what the function takes in to operate, but rather prerequisites of the values to ensure that the function works correctly. For example, in this case, it is simply telling you that the function should only work given that the vector v that is passed in is not empty. Think about how you can use an assert statement to ensure that the requires clause is being met. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@313-------------------------
Mode function
<p>I'm trying to use the summarize function in my mode function. Is there a way I can access the variables in the summarize function within the mode function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Not as far as I am aware, the variables within the summary function are not in the scope of the mode function. Personally would recommend just writing a mode function independent of summary.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Alternatively, you could just copy the stuff you have in summary into mode, instead of calling the summary function. Would be just as fast.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
