------------------------@316-------------------------
Error for summarize function
<p>Hi! I'm getting this error in my summarize function when I create a new vector of doubles and set it equal to {current num in for loop, count} and I'm not sure how to fix it.<br/> "message": "Non-aggregate type 'vector&lt;double&gt;' cannot be initialized with an initializer list".</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Did you initialize the vector outside of the loop? I recognize that error from when someone tried doing <code>assert(summary(data) == {{1,1},{2,1}});</code>, and the solution was to initialize this double vector outside of the assert statement. I would recommend creating a 1D vector outside of the loop, pushing back to a 2D vector and then overwriting it, rather than initializing it each time within the loop, if that is what you are doing. My guess is that that is where the error is coming from. If it wasn’t that, maybe these: did you type <code>vector&lt;double&gt; = {current_num, count};</code>, or <code>vector&lt;double&gt; example_name = {current_num, count};</code> (<code>int</code> vs <code>double</code> not relevant here)? Maybe try initializing it with an actual number then use your variables. Hope this helps!!! 😃</p></div>

------------------------@318-------------------------

------------------------@319-------------------------
Caen Help
<p>Hi, </p>


<p></p>


<p>I was wondering whether installing CAEN Linux was necessary for project 1. I submitted to the autograder and got full points without using CAEN.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I also am confused as to how to login to CAEN and how it is used with a Mac. If someone could help explain the purpose of CAEN also that would be really helpful. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The reason we use CAEN is because the autograder runs on an environment very similar to CAEN. There are times where a program may work on your local machine but won't work on the autograder and CAEN. It exposes certain other issues with code like undefined behavior. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>I just want to clarify that even though you got full points on the public cases on the Autograder, does not mean your code is working perfectly. You should definitely write your own test cases and run your code in CAEN to ensure that you don't have any bugs. The test cases on the autograder are very basic and do not encompass all edge cases. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>There's a CAEN tutorial on the eecs 280 website that will be helpful for how to navigate CAEN on mac! </div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@323-------------------------
auto grader problem

-------------------------------------------------
This is a white space issue. You should not be printing spaces after the highlighted statements.

-------------------------------------------------
There's an option on the autograder to show white space and you can see exactly where there should be a space (denoted by a dot) and where there should be a new line (denoted by an arrow)

<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>Could someone please help me understand what it means? For extra context as to what the count() function in this instance is see this article: <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/count/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/count/</a> </p>


<p></p>

<p></p>

<div>I would recommend implementing the summarize function manually. </div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@325-------------------------
Error with the stats_public_test
<p>When I turn in my files to autograder, it gives me an error for the stats_public_test "error: attempt to subscript container with out-of-bounds index 3, but container only holds 3 elements". It's saying this in reference to my count function where I am returning "count3" which it says is wrong. I don't understand why that's wrong because the vector for the public test is {1,2,3} so the count function should return 3. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
We know that vectors are 0 indexed containers meaning that the first index starts at 0 not 1. Although a size of a vector is 3 indicating that there are 3 elements. The largest index in that vector is actually 2. 
<div>For example for the vector you have listed, the size would be 3 and the respective indices in the vector would be 0, 1, and 2. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>This fault is saying you're trying to access a 4th element at index 3. </div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Does autograder give any indication of where that issue occurs? Because I can output the correct public test and main tests to my terminal but autograder says it's wrong. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
Its likely because you're not writing a test that catches the out of bound indexing. Write some more test cases using extreme numbers. Additionally, you're going to want to look at every time you use v[something] and identify whether that something value could ever be as big as the size of the vector with how your code is set up. Also if you want to see what functions to look inside, check your autograder output and see where your code faults. It will likely be in the function that your code stops printing at.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@326-------------------------
error when I run main.cpp
<p>I have not written anything in main.cpp yet, but when I attempt to run it I am getting an error. I am using VScode on a mac. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_10.32.50_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fke8vfrggki21lh%2Ffe50062b0464a24a13cccd24d2cc6db8a9e77d8bbad32d95e674eefef358e796%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_10.32.50_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
There is likely a missing or extra curly brace } somewhere in your stats.cpp. 
<div>There are a lot of extensions you can install on VScode marketplace that can help with color coding brackets so its easy to match them. The most common being Bracket Pair Colorizer. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Also, did you declare a main function in your stats.cpp? </div>

-------------------------------------------------
Huh, so you overwrote your cpp file with your compiled code. 1. In the future, please use the make commands (they are pre written so that you can save time and avoid this mistake), so this doesn’t happen again, or learn to write your own (it’s not so bad, just read the make file and it should make sense). 2. -------------------------------------------------
<p>So I would paste this in the terminal to run stats_tests.exe?</p>


<div>

</div>

-------------------------------------------------
So to run an executable, something that we have compiled, you type “./stats_test.exe”. You don’t need to copy and paste anything from the makefile. To use the makefile type the word make and a keyword. The 280 setup tutorial gives more information on how to use it.

------------------------@328-------------------------
main public test (UB Checks)
<p>The only issue I am having right now is with main public test (UB Checks), no code is printing for the 100th percentile even though it is printing on main public tests and when I run my code on VS Code. <p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_1.07.45_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyse1j3l155xs%2Fac5dcaefb43f57da5544caeceb864108f5b5f348fbbcc06039273d5bcc35a64a%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_1.07.45_PM.png"/></p>

The error for your output is showing that your are indexing out of bounds, specifically, trying to access the 5th element of a vector of only size 5. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>Try taking a look in your percentile function at any point that you use v[some_value] and ensure that in all cases (particularly the most extreme like 100th percentile) that the some_value is strictly less than the size of your vector </div>

------------------------@331-------------------------
Sum, median, and stddev function return when v is empty
<p>Just to double-check, should sum, median, and stddev just return 0 if the vector v is empty? Or are they guaranteed to not be empty? Thanks in advance</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The RME specifies that the vector passed in is not empty.
<div>Good practice is to include an assert statement that ensures that v is not empty in the beginning of your function </div>

------------------------@335-------------------------

------------------------@336-------------------------
pthread_kill
<p>Everytime I run my debugger a pthread_kill tab pops up. Is this normal or something I should be worried about? <img alt="" height="914" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk8laf9dvza6pf%2F20fd33bd5d4d6f597cce14cd2bfb96bc979b6b29367e76a6ac73240dae0174de%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_3.13.48_PM.png" width="2292"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The debugger is stepping into behind-the-scenes C++ code which is not always a problem. But I believe that pthread_kill is called to stop your program after an unhandled exception/error is found, so there's likely a bug somewhere in the code. Use the debugger to go line by line and see where the problematic line is.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@337-------------------------
Printing output
<p>I finished writing all of my functions and calling them in main, however, I'm stuck on something that I feel like should be so simple. I'm trying to figure out how to place the colon in between the output, and when I try putting in the loop I get something like 6 1:, 7 1:, and so on. I feel like I'm forgetting something so simple but I just can't figure out what it is. <img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkejgw934y4m2le%2F2bd05ac67ab3058bb85dea38f6edf2b4bb280b7e20bfc6b6c71cf4b231240bff%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
This can get tricky if you use a nested for loop. Since you know the size of the inner vector (num, freq), think about how you can eliminate the inner loop. This should make it easier to add the :

------------------------@339-------------------------
Cout in stats.cpp
I tried to print out something by writing cout at the end of the function, but I don’t know how to run and compile the stats.cpp it self. I included <iostream> to use cout and in the terminal I typed make stats.exe then typed ./stats.exe to run the file. But it’s shows “no such file or directory”. What should I do to print out somethings from stats.cpp, not from stats_test.cpp?

-------------------------------------------------
You actually cannot run stats.cpp on its own. The file simply holds a collection of functions so that they can be utilized in files like main or stats tests. 
<div>You can put cout statements in your functions for testing purposes but in order to see output from specific functions, you would set up a test and call the function in your stats tests file and run stats tests. That will allow you to run the function and see what it outputs. Alternatively, instead of cout statements in your functions, the debugger is a great tool to see what values in your function look like while it is executing</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Oh, my bad! I would suggest you test the function before you implement it and then do it one after another. In that way, you will know more about the function’s behavior before implementing it. Furthermore, there are also two pro-tips on the p1 spec:
<img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt103pdags15va%2Faffc1c4d499db5f1962e5acabe46b40166a036f361d162574ac9f9ec66bc6227%2Fimage.png"/></p></div>

<p><img alt="" height="796" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7f5230f9wl7a0%2Fb1c5925ed3745f1a8f7f899213e6f7273c1f089fbc1ba15c516e6052c802e4ff%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-10_at_10.13.48_PM.png" width="2160"/></p>

------------------------@354-------------------------
CAEN test error message
<p>I got this error message when I ran my stats test cases on CAEN. Can anyone guide me what this message means and how to rectify?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszyrecl6a16iv%2F2b78036dd5eb68c7e4c329cea1132bf582b9109b0b08fd7457f443b176649e85%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
This error means you are trying to access out of bounds in a vector. In this case it's saying you have a vector of length 1 and are trying to index into the 1th place which does not exist (because containers are 0 indexed) 
<div><br/></div>
<div>To resolve this, look at every time you try to index in your percentile function. wherever you call v[some_value] ensure that some_value will always be less than the length of your vector. Pay attention to edge cases like very low and very high numbers </div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@355-------------------------
Why size_t?
<p>The specification mentions that "v.size() returns a size_t type, which is an alias for an unsigned integer type". This makes me curious. Why not just use the unsigned integer to represent "unsigned integer", which is more intuitive? What is the point of "size_t"? Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Here's a good stackoverflow post that asks that exact question. The answers provide some nice insight and links to other resources if you're interested. </p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/131803/unsigned-int-vs-size-t" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/131803/unsigned-int-vs-size-t</a></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@356-------------------------
SSH keys Gitlab - permission denied
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>I have been following the steps on the <a href="https://gitlab.eecs.umich.edu/help/user/ssh.md" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">GitLab SSH page</a> to set up SSH keys, but when trying to connect to the server, it has denied my requests:</p>
<pre><code>$ ssh -T waning@gitlab.eecs.umich.edu
waning@gitlab.eecs.umich.edu: Permission denied (publickey,password).
</code></pre><p>I have added</p>
<pre><code>Host gitlab.eecs.umich.edu
  PreferredAuthentications publickey
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
</code></pre><p>to my <code>~/.ssh/config file</code> (using WSL Ubuntu). What am I doing wrong here?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>so uh you don’t use your uniqname when trying to ssh, it should be</p>
<pre><code>ssh -T git@gitlab.eecs.umich.edu
</code></pre><p>instead. great to figure out minutes after posting the question</p></div>

I can either drop them in, or click this button that opens up file explorer. Both cases need me to open file explorer.</p>


<p></p>


<p>So I guess my question is "How do I navigate to my WSL files (my stats.cpp, ect) in the local file explorer?" I have searched around and have not found the answer</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>In WSL, the windows file system is located under <code>/mnt/</code>. To move your files to the C drive, you could set the destination folder as <code>/mnt/c</code>. If you want to move your entire project setup to your windows filesystem (which will likely help with convenience), you can run the following commands starting <strong>in your project directory</strong>:</p>
<pre><code>$ cd ..
$ mv p1-stats /mnt/c/Users/[your username]/Desktop
</code></pre><p>of course replacing <code>[your username]</code> with your windows username and then you should be able to see it in file explorer under your desktop folder or on the windows desktop. Then you can move it wherever you want through Windows, this path was just an example so you can find it easily.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
As a shortcut, if you are in the directory inside your WSL terminal, you can type “explorer.exe .” and it will open the file explorer in that directory.

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>


<p>Hello! In stats_tests.cpp, I just wanted to know what the purpose of line 7 is doing. If anyone could elaborate, that would be great!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
This is a function stub. Essentially it allows us to be able to call a function before we implement it, basically telling the compiler that this function exists and not to throw an error because it can't find it yet

------------------------@364-------------------------
main.cpp weird error
<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-11_at_1.23.21_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxulg2ctoq5h1%2Fabd521071282502a1df360fca5573d320871338fc58e5889e7f12cf6725aaf18%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-11_at_1.23.21_PM.png"/>
<br/>
 I don't understand why I am getting this error.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The address sanitizer error tells us that you are likely trying to perform a read on memory that does not exist. One reason this may happen is indexing out of bounds in a vector. The next lines tell us it's hitting the error on the call of summarize on main.cpp line 27, specifically, on line 31 of stats.cpp in summarize. I would recommend taking a look at the lines that the error mentions.</p>


<p></p>


<p>A way you can figure out what is happening is setting a breakpoint in main.cpp before line 27 and stepping into the function causing the error before the error occurs to see what might be going on.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Please let us know if you have any other questions!</p>

summarize test

<br/>
  ~~~~ ^  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
<br/>
<br/>
How do I go about fixing this?
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
This error also occurred when I tried calling summarize() in main.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The return type of summarize is a 2-D vector. In order to cout the elements of summarize's return value, you will have to iterate through each element of the returned vector and print each element.</p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I suggest you follow the tutorial to use the <code>make</code> command to compile your code. See <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_make.html#compile-with-make" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_make.html#compile-with-make</a>, because it is preconfigured and you don’t need to type the long command.</p>
<p>The reason your assert function fails is because <code>count(v) == 3 </code> is false, which means that <code>count(v)</code> returns a value that is not equal to 3. That’s how you catch bugs by writing test functions. To go from here, check your <code>count()</code> function more carefully. I took a look at your code on Autograder, and the <code>count()</code> function always returns zero (so are the other functions in <code>stats.cpp</code>. You only <code>cout</code> the values, but you need to return them). I’m not sure if you have fixed that, but that’s the cause of the problem in the screenshot.</p></div>

------------------------@372-------------------------
UB Checks graded?
<p>Are we graded on UB checks? </p>


<p>I got a 9/9 on auntograder so I passed the public tests but am confused on the UB checks. There's no points associated with it on autograder, but I am getting a similar error for both main and stats_tests. What is happening in the UB checks</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Though there are no points associated with it, the UB checks throw errors when there is undefined behavior possible. If you aren't passing the UB checks, that means your code reaches undefined behavior and that your code is viable to errors. The private tests are designed to find all edge cases and areas of undefined behavior. So even though there are no points associated with the UB checks, it may lead to lost points in the private tests.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p><img alt="" height="457" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1svhk7y782nd%2Fc17ef78d0465a309bccbc04680ed731bda631fe3ae57f5c8425c1324078bf2e5%2Fimage.png" width="751"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
Did you make the executable? Like did you run “make stats_tests.exe”

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like your project is in the "p1-stats" folder, but your debugger isn't looking for the executable in this folder. What does your launch.json file look like? Try updating the program path in launch.json to "C:\Users\north\Downloads\eecs280\p1-stats\stats_tests.exe".</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you get the same error with the updated path, try re-running "make stats_tests.exe"</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I assume this is what you mean by changing the program path. Also, I have run make stats_tests.exe</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="521" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1svhk7y782nd%2Fead0461fdb5e1126a814896fbdd13486f6a5dbf552929fb7d418ed9955fb2754%2FScreenshot_2022-09-11_170128.png" width="1050"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try removing the "${}" from your "program" value. In other words, try copying and pasting this in:</p>


<p></p>


<p>"program": "C:\Users\north\Downloads\EECS280\p1-stats\stats_tests.exe"</p>


<p></p>


<p>If that doesn't work, please share the error message. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This was the output.</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="515" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1svhk7y782nd%2Fc6b0fe04aafe69f42699047983c08de8e8b72549cd6bae5dcbf00c2e3f30d0a6%2Fimage.png" width="958"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hmm, could you confirm for me that you have GDB installed? You can do this by running "gdb --version" in the VS Code terminal. If you get an error like "command not found," you can install GDB by running "sudo apt-get install gdb" (assuming you're using Ubuntu with WSL).</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you already have GDB installed, or if you install it and still get this error, try running "which gdb" in the terminal; this should give you the path to where GDB is installed. The output will probably be something like "usr/bin/gdb." Copy this value, and add a new entry to your launch.json like so:</p>


<p>"miDebuggerPath": "your/path/to/gdb"</p>


<p></p>


<p>One more thing: If you do all this and get an error about your program path being invalid (I'm not sure how well Windows and Linux paths mix in VS Code with WSL), try changing it to this:</p>


<p>"program": "${fileDirname}/stats_tests.exe"</p>


<p></p>


<p>Then, once you're ready to debug, open stats_tests.cpp, and start debugging from the Debug sidebar. This way, VS Code should automatically infer the program path. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@380-------------------------

------------------------@386-------------------------
sizeof operator
<p>How does this work?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyzwx70ptf4ut%2F1f85be71dabe3623c70b7755dcc912448c22cb7c4e819c0491a4cc568ef496de%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
I agree, that’s an unclear explanation. Sizeof returns the amount of memory an object is consuming. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>So an int is 4 bytes. If you have an array with 8 ints, the array should be 32 bytes big. In this example, sizeof(array) is 32. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Keep in mind an array is actually represented as a pointer to its first element. So doing *array, grabs array[0]. </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Therefore sizeof(array) / sizeof(*array) = 32/4 = 8 in this example.</div>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>Use the cout to write to a file and cin to read from a file</p>

------------------------@388-------------------------
max function failing its assertion?
<p>My max test function keeps failing its assertion... why? I included my test file and max function.</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F585644994062db544e14dfce112993f3d0ac55e9c2c1b6f82493c4664a74c614%2Fstats_tests.cpp" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">stats_tests.cpp</a></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F38f4e65c7ddb7fa892693a74815c02d7921268d93ed349115f655b006d6de883%2Fmax_function.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">max_function.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
You assigned maxval as zero for each loop, which somehow isn’t even the problem you have here. I would evaluate what that would do, for starters.
<div>It might be a problem with your for loop, I think I know why you declared i as size_t, but that is not necessary and likely the source of your problem. To avoid this, I would suggest sorting the vector and then indexing the end.</div>
<div>To be sure, go ahead and cout the result of your max function call (cout &lt;&lt; max(data)).</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Nvm it’s definitely what the instructor said, sorry I missed that.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you did not initialize i = 0 in your for loop. Unfortunately, computers don't default values to 0 (and instead something random). Remember that any value you initalize in a for loop is deleted at the end of the loop and then reinitialized at the starting value when the next iterations of the loop comes, so think about if you want to declare maxval instead or outside the for loop. Also remember that each variable you create must have a declaration type (like int, string, double). </p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
Take a closer look at your inner loop in your printing

-------------------------------------------------
<p>is it not supposed to be j&lt;1</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>i see the problem is data[j] but i don't know how to access the frequency column</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Here's a hint for indexing into the frequency column:</p>


<p>Let's say you have a vector of type int called x. Indexing into x will return an integer. For example, x[i] returns the integer at index i.</p>


<p>Now in your case, summary(data) returns a vector of vector of doubles. Let's call this vector summarized_data. If you index into summarized_data, i.e. summarized_data[i], you'll get a vector of doubles. This vector of doubles should be a (value: frequency) pair. How can you index these two values and print them out?</p>


<p>Here's another hint: You can do this with just one for-loop, rather than two. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>thank you i tried to assign summarize(data) into a new vector of vectors so I could index into it but I got errors that I think said the types were incompatible. and I also cant use two brackets like this [i][0].</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I would double-check the type of the new vector you created against the return type of the summarize() function. For example, here's the method signature of summarize() from stats.h:</p>


<p>std::vector&lt;std::vector&lt;double&gt; &gt; summarize(std::vector&lt;double&gt; v);</p>


<p>So the new vector's type should be vector&lt;vector&lt;double&gt; &gt;. Once you've done that, the two-bracket syntax (i.e. [i][0]) should work.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>yes thank you earlier for some reason it wasn't working but now it does</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@392-------------------------
Mode Function
<p>I'm looking at the hints for the mode functions under stats.h, and I'm confused as to why you would need to sort the vector to find the mode. could I create a code without sorting it, since its just calculating the most frequent number.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It is more convenient to sort it first. It should be possible without it, but it would be quite a bit more work.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Why does sorting it first make it more convenient since we're calculating the frequency? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
With sorting and then finding the mode, first you sort, then you can have the code iterate through the vector and keep track of the largest pack of numbers it has seen so far. You can overwrite variables every time this happens.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Without sort, you would have to keep track of every number the loop saw. Imagine that there was a vector a million entries long, each entry unique, except for one repeat. How would you remember that you’d even seen this one number twice?</div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@393-------------------------
Error message
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-11_at_8.01.02_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt023jdfwj0ui%2Fe4a9dd3ddd50957674708bec6077738d4095fc7041c3720d5ee74fb6e8e27d9a%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-11_at_8.01.02_PM.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>I keep getting this long error message, how do I turn this off?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You go into your makefile and delete some of the tags that you added during the setup (should be line 2 of the makefile). But getting rid of this doesn't fix your bugs...</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="210" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw74v59av4w2bg%2F48c160a8b620908162516efda70043f3b6f0f9cae890660014330150463c357c%2Fimage.png" width="789"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This long error message comes from the Address Sanitizer, which looks for memory errors and undefined behavior in your code. To disable this, remove the compiler flags mentioned <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#sanitizers" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a> in the setup tutorial from your Makefile, and re-compile your code.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Now, as for the error itself, it looks like you might be indexing a vector out of bounds. Check out line 16 of stats.cpp; if you're looping over a vector, make sure the upper bound of the loop isn't larger than the vector you're indexing into. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@394-------------------------
main.cpp
<p>I am working on main.cpp right now and I am at the part where I print out the statistics that I wrote. However, I am a bit confused on how to do this. For example:</p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; count(x) &lt;&lt; endl;</p>


<p>Do I need to create a vector for x? What gets read into there? Any help is appreciated!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So you need to read in the data. You need to write a little bit of code to read in the data. You need to cout something asking the user for a file name. Then, cin a file name, saving it as a string (then also ask for a column name). Then use the extract column function (syntax here):</p>


<div>
<div>vector&lt;double&gt; column = extract_column(filename, columnname);</div>
</div>



<p>And then that column vector is your x vector.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You should get the data from the <code>extract_column</code> function, then pass the resulting vector into all the stats functions you’ve created appropriately.</p></div>

missing last vector for summarize()

------------------------@403-------------------------
autograder having issue with find function
<p>Hello, this question is in regards to the summarize function.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I am using a function known as find in an if statement to check if the value from the original vector parameter is in the vector of values that I am creating as a way to record what numbers are in the vector. IE{1,1,2,2,2,4,4,4,4,3 } -&gt; {1,2,3,4}</p>


<p></p>


<p>Here is a link to documentation regarding how this function works: <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/find/" target="_blank">https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/find/</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>However, the autograder is complaining about this function, here are the errors in question: </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

<p></p>


<p>Could someone please explain what it is exactly saying?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The message is saying that the <code>find</code> function isn’t found - did you put <code>#include &lt;algorithm&gt;</code> at the start of your file? However, this isn’t something you should keep using, as <code>&lt;algorithm&gt;</code> is not a library we are allowed to use in p1. The list of allowed libraries is found <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here in the spec</a>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Compilers are funny like that. Sometimes they will make assumptions based on the code and other times they will throw an error. If you ever want to know for sure, submit to the autograder or run your code on CAEN. These two will always catch these types of errors.</p>

main.cpp

-------------------------------------------------
You should design functions in stats.cpp which perform your statistics operations, and then your main.cpp should be a driver program which calls these functions and prints them out. Hope this helps!

Gertrude sounds nice. I think non-descriptive names are fine for P1, but going into P2 and later projects/CS classes, you want to get into the habit of using descriptive names for your variables.

------------------------@414-------------------------
Mode test failing

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>When you reset <code>currnum</code> and <code>occ</code>, <code>occ</code> should be set to 1 instead of zero because you have seen this number for one time now.</p>

------------------------@415-------------------------
Summary Testing
<p>I'm trying to test summarize and I'm using the summarize(data) == answer_key format, yet it is still not passing my test. I iterated through the values to check and I'm getting exactly what I'm expecting in the answer key. Am I going about testing summarize correctly? Is there another way to test summarize?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The compiler doesn't understand how to compare vectors so you can't directly compare the results of your summarize function to a correct vector using ==. You're on the right track though! Looping through the values to check is the best way to go about this, so you can just use individual assert statements to check each of the values in your vector of vectors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@416-------------------------
stdev slightly off
<p>Hi!</p>


<p></p>


<p>I'm using the real life datasets from the p1 spec, but my stdev function is returning values that are slightly different from the ones that are specified in the spec:</p>


<p></p>


<p>My values      Spec Values</p>


<p>0.426247        0.4263</p>


<p>0.431925        0.431979</p>


<p></p>


<p>Are these differences ignorable? Or should I address them somehow - the formula that I used is the same as <a data-pats="post_ref" href="79" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('79');">@79</a>. uniqname: runy</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>hi! try using the formula that is in the comments of @79's post. there are three different formulas listed in the wikipedia and the one we are supposed to use is the last one that is listed. you might have used the first or second formula?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>yes, I did use the one from @79's followup, and that's the one that's giving me the slightly off answer</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>My understanding is that the epsilon value used by the autograder is <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="0" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c2E"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.00001</mn></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container>, meaning that the difference in your case is not ignorable. The formula, if implemented correctly, returns differences that are far less than <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="1" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-cD7"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-msup space="3"><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c30"></mjx-c></mjx-mn><mjx-script style="vertical-align: 0.393em;"><mjx-texatom size="s" texclass="ORD"><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2212"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c36"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-texatom></mjx-script></mjx-msup></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> from the true value. This means that, if you are getting the wrong values, the formula is not implemented correctly.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I took the liberty of determining the population standard deviation—which is incorrect, as we want the sample standard deviation—for both columns, and they are <kbd>0.426247</kbd> and <kbd>0.431925</kbd>. Therefore, your program actually uses the population standard deviation formula, not the sample standard deviation formula. The original students' answer is correct.</p>


<p> </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@417-------------------------
percentile in stats_tests.cpp
<p>while writing the test case for the percentile function in stats_tests.cpp, one of the cases i used were percentile(data, 0.40) and when i do assert(percentile(data, 0.40) == 2.4), the code stops compiling and says its false. But when printing percentile(data, 0.40), it prints out 2.4. im confused as to what is going on and why the assertion is false when it gives the same output. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It could be that the output of the <code>percentile</code> function is not actually 2.4 and a number infinitesimally close due to floating point errors. See <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this appendix</a> and <a data-pats="post_ref" href="262" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('262');">@262</a> for more info, but to compensate for this, you would check if the output of the function and the output you are expecting are within <code>0.00001</code> of each other.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@418-------------------------
percentile rounding
<p>I've read a lot of piazza posts relating to the percentile function but I'm still confused as to how we should be rounding the return value. I tried using ceil which worked for testing integers but for doubles I would need a different system.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You should not be rounding the return value of the funciton - instead you should be comparing the return value of the function to the correct answer in your test cases with a margin of error, namely <code>0.00001</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@420-------------------------
Unsure of how to fix scope error.
<p>I've been able to implement all my function on the stats.cpp and have tested them using my test functions. But, everything I try to check if my code compiles using CAEN and testing stats_public_test I receive this error message. I'me been trying to fix it but still not found a solution. Please Advise! <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_10.30.34_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkym64wau1sv1t5%2F2b74d613483fb9fd2c1d369ac83401983c0a4b4d851c5eda3edf3a0bf453a023%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_10.30.34_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
You are not using the correct syntax for the sort function defined in p1_library.cpp. Please check that for how to use it.
<div><br/></div>
<div>FYI, the proper syntax is just the following:</div>
<div>sort(v);</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Where v is your vector.</div>
<div>Also be sure to use the following at the top of stats.cpp:</div>
<div>#include “p1_library.h”</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I see you're also using std::for_each() in stats.cpp. This requires the &lt;algorithm&gt; header, which isn't allowed for Project 1. Please only use <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#tips-tricks-and-restrictions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">these libraries</a> in your implementation; there's definitely a clean way to implement sum() without for_each. Feel free to follow-up or join us in office hours if you need help with this!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@421-------------------------
Main.cpp
<p>I'm not sure how to run my main.cpp file. Right now I have only been running my stats_tests. How can I switch the file that runs?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you’re using VSCode, in your <code>launch.json</code> file you can change</p>
<pre><code>            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/stats_tests.exe",
</code></pre><p>to</p>
<pre><code>            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/main.exe",
</code></pre><p>and the debugger should instead look for main. Alternatively, you can manually build and run it by running</p>
<pre><code>$ make main.exe
$ ./main.exe
</code></pre><p>in your shell.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you how can I do that for xcode?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can follow <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#compile-with-xcode" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this</a> part of the setup tutorial, just switch stats_tests.exe with main.exe</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Marking as resolved</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@423-------------------------
median
<p>For median() are we just returning the middle value, or do we also need to have if conditions for tie values and negative numbers?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The functions should be implemented as specified in their header comments, which for <code>median</code> links to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median#The_sample_median" target="_blank">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median#The_sample_median</a>. So yes, you are returning the middle value - for an even number of values you return the mean of the two middle values.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@424-------------------------
Help with Autograder
<p>Hi,</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>For standard deviation, make sure you’re accessing the vector elements correctly, especially when considering that the value is not necessarily evenly divisible so we need the modf function. Try running through the failing vector by hand and then once again with your debugger and seeing if the values are being calculated correctly.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@442-------------------------
About reference type.
<p>What will happen if we declare a reference type and assign nothing to it?</p>


<p>i.e. int &amp;a;</p>


<p>Since if we declare a normal int type and assign nothing to it, what's in it will just be some memory junks. Reference types are aliases. So what will happen if it is not assigned to anything? Thanks.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A reference must be initialized when it is created, so you can't declare</p>


<pre>int &amp;y;</pre>
<p>without initializing it, i.e.</p>


<pre>int x = 100;
int &amp;y = x;</pre>
<p>However, you can declare an uninitialized reference when it's used as a function parameter (pass by reference), i.e.</p>


<pre>void foo(int &amp;x) { ... }</pre>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@443-------------------------
Arraying indexing
<p>What will do if the compiler meets arr[2] is that, it will convert it directly into *(arr+2)? So actually arr[2] is just an abstract thing and lives upon pointer arithmetic?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, brackets in c++ are what we call syntax sugarcoating. This is an important distinction to make when dealing with arrays in project two. Brackets always will always conduct pointer arithmetic and then dereference the pointer.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@444-------------------------
Confused about "Write your statistics program in main.cpp"
<p>Hi,</p>


<p>I was confused about the description provided in the instructions, which says "Put all of your statistics functions in <code>stats.cpp</code> and all statistics function tests in <code>stats_tests.cpp</code>. Write your statistics program in <code>main.cpp</code>." What is a statistics program? Is my main.cpp in good shape? Thank you!</p>


<p>(I chose that this post as only available to instructors, so it should be fine to upload my code?)</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="457" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gf6b5atwp6a0%2F6ce2748e929be19f4ab7743f251e1540f4fdf354bbec73b0bd53ef3dbc9d37db%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_17.44.23.png" width="488"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, what you did is correct! It just means to put your "driver" program in main.cpp (like user input, calling each of the stats functions, printing output — this is the main program that will be run) while stats.cpp contains the actual implementation for each of those functions (code for calculating sum of values in vector, mean, median, etc)</p>

Thanks so much. <img alt="Screenshot_2022-09-12_at_18.09.19.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1wuq2ofmh5tt%2Fcd9a669878dc59b0735b1d922cd9896f35aae1804612ea08dfed1789288e7aa1%2FScreenshot_2022-09-12_at_18.09.19.png"/></p>

------------------------@446-------------------------
Errors met while doing "make test"
<p>Hi,</p>


<p>I generated such errors while running the "make test", will that be a problem? I faced similar issues during set up(malloc: nano zone...) and was solved by an instructor, but it reappeared such errors again today.</p>


<p>Also, is there any errors apart from the "malloc" ? Thank you!</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_18.29.29.pngNaN" height="742" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gf6b5atwp6a0%2F7814cf756c0db1baf5b7457cecf2997397e79b417c2d56fa60f7bde24fcbe8fb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_18.29.29.png" width="751"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Looks like you encountered the same error as <a data-pats="post_ref" href="130" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('130');">@130</a>. In short, this error is just a kernel optimization failure, and shouldn't affect the correctness of your program. Fortunately, you can disable this message permanently by adding the MallocNanoZone environment variable to your shell profile.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Your Mac is probably using zsh, so you'll want to open "~/.zprofile" in a text editor, and add "export MallocNanoZone=0" to the end of the file. If your Mac is using bash, add this to "~/.bash_profile". You might need to restart your terminal for this to take effect, but if the variable is set correctly, you should never see this error again. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@450-------------------------
Assertion False failed
<p>Hello, I've been trying for a few hours to figure out why my debugger stops almost instantly when I try to run any of my test cases, It keeps telling me assertion false failed and takes me to like 17 of my stats.cpp and i've even removed the code that it took me too and no matter what I do it takes me back to line 17 in stats.cpp. Could someone let me know what's wrong with my code that it's doing that.</p>


<p><img alt="" height="326" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk45otymxgq74m%2F6e1fbba76fb0683709b13714eae70bf95bbe1d06f470d084bcdc628d3e0cde0a%2FScreenshot_2022-09-12_191006.png" width="583"/></p>


<p><img alt="" height="352" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk45otymxgq74m%2F6881e2372820543f0016e1a8199f4bd2c49f621350975b593de6a495662d7f72%2FScreenshot_2022-09-12_191027.png" width="586"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Usually, the problem is that the student hasn’t rebuilt the executable. In this order:</p>
<pre><code>make clean
make all
</code></pre><p>then run the debugger.
Let me know if this doesn’t work : )</p></div>

<p>I dont know if you saw what i sent above all the red and white code but here is my make file<img alt="" height="651" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk45otymxgq74m%2F2023e19d8e6b508156e72016ff37dc8c05d05adcb979417dcea238bc6f982377%2FScreenshot_2022-09-12_192912.png" width="742"/></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="378" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk45otymxgq74m%2F14f37e2c80dd426938bace9b74e1ee883c48dc9a3607f2db6dfd11dd34177b02%2Fimage.png" width="460"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Those red and white messages are compiler errors:</p>


<p>- For the first one, it looks like you aren't returning anything from summarize(). If you haven't finished implementing summarize() and would like to test your other stats functions first, you can comment it out in stats.cpp. Same thing in your percentile() function.</p>


<p>- For all the "i &lt; v.size()" errors in your for-loops, it's because you're comparing an integer variable to the vector's size type, which is usually some unsigned integer type (don't worry about the details of size_type for now). You can easily fix these errors by trying some of the suggested fixes in the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#signed-and-unsigned-integer-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">spec</a>.</p>


<p>- For the code "medEVEN = medEVEN--", if you just want to decrement medEVEN, then "medEVEN--;" should do the trick. The "--" operator is shorthand for "medEVEN = medEVEN - 1".</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@451-------------------------
Do not know how to resolve this error. Can somebody help?
<p>When I submit to the autograder, for the main public test (UB Checks) section, I am getting this error. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_7.16.59_PM.pngNaN" height="98" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt3entvs4ey1up%2F13f8ed6af9ec98b2eb0500fcddef49c57d7f378dfdd3db72c8bb61e72d2bacd9%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-12_at_7.16.59_PM.png" width="496"/></p>


<p>When the expected output is compared to the student output, it says I am missing the 100th percentile line. However, when I run the file, that line shows up every time. Why is it not working when I submit it and how do I fix this error?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Do you have the Address Sanitizer enabled on your local machine? It may not be enabled and your code is just continuing with the undefined behavior associated with indexing out of bounds. You should use the debugger and see what your code does step-by-step when the 100th percentile is calculated.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ditto the student answer. These out-of-bounds errors are common when using a for-loop to iterate over a vector, so I would double-check your loops' terminating conditions. For example, make sure "i" is never greater than or equal to the vector's size, or you'll go off the end!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@452-------------------------
print summary error
<p>I set vector&lt;double&gt; v and set it as the result from exact_column, and vector&lt;vector&lt;double&gt;&gt; v1 as summarize(v). I use for loop to print elements of v1, like cout&lt;&lt; v1[i] but it shows a complier error. Isn't each vector an element in v1? How should I print it?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Each entry in v1 is also an element and will have to be iterated through. I would suggest the following:
<div>cout &lt;&lt; v1[i][0] &lt;&lt; v1[i][1];</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>With some added syntax for it to come out looking nice.</div>

------------------------@457-------------------------
Test cases
<p>If I am passing all test cases on Autograder, even the undefined checks, could there still be a chance that I lose points on the private tests? Do I still need to write more test cases?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yes, there is a very good chance that there are bugs remaining, more test cases should be written :)

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To add onto the students' answer, you should be thinking of possible edge cases that you may not have tested previously. Even if the tests you have run / the autograder public tests have not exposed a bug in your code, it is possible that a more specific test case (and perhaps one of the private tests) will.</p>

------------------------@462-------------------------
What is the domain of the values that we can expect our code will be tested with?
<p>Do I need to account for negatives and zeros for all my functions?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I would test it to be safe, though an instructor said earlier that they would be giving us reasonable values only.
<a data-pats="post_ref" href="284" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('284');">@284</a>

-------------------------------------------------
Unless the REQUIRES clause for a function says that certain values are not allowed, then you should assume that we will test them.
<div><br/></div>
<div>The “reasonable values” referred to in the student answer means we won’t test really really large numbers, because computer hardware can only represent numbers so large. Anything besides that is fair game.</div>

------------------------@464-------------------------
Trying to check answers
<p dir="ltr">Hello I am just trying to check the output if my median function on lobster but I can't get the answer as 6.5 it keeps stopping at 6. Does this possibly mean my code is incorrect or did I initialize something wrong?</p>


<p dir="ltr"><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky11a69k1rc6qq%2F16edd47aab7632a4b7dbaeecdc1f825ed12f7a8c095150a38189038c8f24b769%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If the operands in division are integers, then the result of that division is also going to be an integer (i.e. rounded down). You'll want to make sure either the numerator or the denominator are doubles.</p>

------------------------@468-------------------------
summarize
<p>my summarize function return everything in row 0 but is it suppose to have different rows / does it need to?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The output of the summarize function should look like this:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">double</span>&gt;&gt; expected = {
	{number, frequency},
	{number, frequency},
	{number, frequency},
	...
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('dmVjdG9yJTNDdmVjdG9yJTNDZG91YmxlJTNFJTNFJTIwZXhwZWN0ZWQlMjA9JTIwJTdCJTBBJTA5JTdCbnVtYmVyLCUyMGZyZXF1ZW5jeSU3RCwlMEElMDklN0JudW1iZXIsJTIwZnJlcXVlbmN5JTdELCUwQSUwOSU3Qm51bWJlciwlMjBmcmVxdWVuY3klN0QsJTBBJTA5Li4uJTBBJTdEJTBB');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>where the <code>{number, frequency}</code> vectors are size 2. So it should have different rows, unless there is only one unique value in your input data.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>how do we pushback to the double array making a new row?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>First make a vector and fill it with the values you want. Then use .push_back to add this vector to vector of vectors. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

summarize function

------------------------@474-------------------------
summarize
<p>so the vector we return in summarize should have multiple rows of 2 values. How do u pushback to a double array to add a new row? right now all my elements are in row[0][i]... ect. i dont know how to add new elements to a new row.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You should have a vector:
<div><br/></div>
<div>vector&lt;double&gt; temporary = {0,0};</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>And you overwrite this each time in a for loop with your count and number. In each iteration of the for loop, push this temp vector back to the 2D vector.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>what function do we use to overwite it?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/vector/vector/push_back/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">push_back</a> adds an element to the back of an array.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You just manually overwrite it,
<div><br/></div>
<div>initialize temp vector;</div>
<div>For loop stuff{</div>
<div>temp = {number, count};</div>
<div>big_vec.push_back(temp);</div>
<div>}</div>
<p></p>

<p>./main.exe</p>


<p>Let me know if this helps!</p>

------------------------@479-------------------------
CAEN not outputting correctly
When I put my code through the autograder it gets full points and when I run it normally through the terminal it pasts all the tests I put for it. But when I put my code through the CAEN option the only thing that is outputted is the original code (so main.exe prints out “this is main” etc.) and I’m not sure how to test it otherwise. I followed the CAEN tutorial again and recopied the files over, but I’m not sure if I made a mistake there.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Should I be concerned about this/How do I make the CAEN output my updated code?</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>That sounds like you probably aren't running the correct version of your code (the only reason running main.exe would print "this is main" is if you have a statement explicitly printing that in your code). Try running "make clean" on CAEN, and then run "cat main.cpp", which will print out that file. Is it the version you are expecting? If so, re-run "make" and try running again. If it's not the right version of the file, then we would need to see the output when you sync files over to see what's going wrong.</p>

------------------------@481-------------------------

<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.33_AM.jpg" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk0ihpovjtv3y9%2Fa270f738b922f4642f79e3563cf06722b40eb554c0cae7961eadea2df4ac5db1%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.33_AM.jpg"/>
<br/>
<br/>
When trying to run my main program, I am getting this error, how would I fix a segmentation fault?

-------------------------------------------------
a segmentation fault means you are indexing out of bounds somewhere. You should start by stepping through with your debugger to see where your program faults. You can then examine that line for where you index out of bounds. 
<div><br/></div>
<div>It's likely the first function you call after reading in the column. Or it is within any code after where you called the extract columb function</div>

-------------------------------------------------
I resolved this, the issue was with creating the 2D vector in int main()

------------------------@490-------------------------
summarize function not iterating through the last element
<p>Hey, so I'm trying to write my summarize function and it doesn't add the last element into my vector&lt;double&gt; (which then is added to the vector of vectors).</p>


<p></p>


<p>startPos and EndPos helps determine the frequency of a number (both starts at 0, with endPos taking the value of j and startPos taking the value of j after the number and its frequency are added into the vector.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7dhivtufkl2or%2F283c1849ff2506f3e74f9f5b7c96cb1bd5409cdbcb4bd5346b80b329934a1f10%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I've tried including an or operator in the if statement to check if endPos is equal to the size of vector v minus 1. It basically checks if endPos is the last index in vector v.</p>


<p></p>


<p>When I try to debug it, at the last iteration (v.size() is 14, j is 13, endPos is 13, startPos is 11, and currentNum is 10), the program did go through the if statement, but it returned false and exited the for loop. Wouldn't the if statement be true because endPos is equal to v.size() - 1?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try tracing through this example input: v = [1, 2, 2, 2]. After your code inserts the value:frequency pair for "1" into pairsInAVector, endPos is 1, currentNum is 2, and j is 1. Now, there is no other element in the vector that isn't 2, so (currentNum != v[j]) will never be true. Will (endPos  == (v.size() - 1)) ever be true, since you don't update endPos anywhere outside the if statement? Perhaps you should update that condition to check something other than endPos. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
Runtime Error When Compiling Main

<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_11.23.58_AM.pngNaN" height="211" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkeiopqgjp1r785%2Fd4d34293b591f37485bdd9647f850c27469bad829ef9f48489363a0a8df9851b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_11.23.58_AM.png" width="384"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I haven't seen this error from anyone else on piazza, any idea why this might be occurring? I compile using make main.exe through my terminal, and when I do my main.cpp executes until it reads out the file name and the column, and then this runtime error occurs. Not sure why. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Reading the error message, it says UndefinedBehavior. This is usually caused by out of bounds accesses. It looks like it originates from the summarize function line 16 in your code (also taken from the error message). The summarize function call came from main line 21. I would suggest looking at the data you were running and think about how it could access out of bounds in the summarize function.</p>

------------------------@495-------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There is no max amount of test cases for this project and you will not lose points for having too many, as your test files are not submitted to the autograder (this time around). </p>

------------------------@496-------------------------
Way to avoid putting test vectors into each individual function?
<p>Is there a place to put all the test vectors in Project 1 that work with each test function rather than having to put the vectors in each individual test function? Main.cpp didn't work. When I call vectors from main.cpp, it says undeclared identifier.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You could write a helper function that returns a specific vector. E.g.:</p>


<p></p>


<pre><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-built_in">vector</span>&lt;<span class="hljs-keyword">double</span>&gt; <span class="hljs-title">get_special_vector</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span> </span>{
 <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> <span class="hljs-comment">/* some vector */</span>;
}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('dmVjdG9yJTNDZG91YmxlJTNFJTIwZ2V0X3NwZWNpYWxfdmVjdG9yKCklMjAlN0IlMEElMjByZXR1cm4lMjAvKiUyMHNvbWUlMjB2ZWN0b3IlMjAqLzslMEElN0Q=');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p></p>


<p>although if you are using long enough vectors that reusing them is a pain, it might be worth rethinking your test cases. Remember that the small scope hypothesis says we should be able to expose any meaningful bug with a small test case (for this project, I don't think you should ever need more than 5 elements). Also remember that you can concisely initialize a vector using curly braces, e.g.:</p>


<p></p>


<pre>vector&lt;int&gt; v = {1,2,3};</pre>

------------------------@503-------------------------
epsilon rounding
<p>I'm unsure on how the autograder will check private tests- for functions like sum or stdev, where the output could be a decimal value, how should I go about implementing floating number comparisons? I understand how the logic works, and can implement it in my own test program, but how do i know what this epsilon value that autograder uses will be? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe the epsilon value cited <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">in the spec</a> should be adequate for the autograder. So epsilon = 0.00001 should be fine!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks, how exactly does autograder test my cases? Does it directly compare the value from my function to it's expected value? Like, does it do the epsilon comparison by itself? Would the only place that I would need to implement it be on my own test cases? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For Project 1, I think the autograder is just checking to see your tests exist. However, if we were grading for test correctness, the autograder would run your tests against a correct solution. If any of your tests fail against this solution, then we know that test is malformed -- or that there is a bug in our solution, but we test it thoroughly to ensure this is unlikely. If we were to grade your tests for their effectiveness (which future EECS classes like 281 do), the autograder would run your tests against solutions with known bugs, and count the number of bugs exposed by your tests.</p>


<p></p>


<p>In short, you don't need to worry about epsilon changing between your machine and the autograder. Epsilon is there only to account for any imprecision in floating-point calculations. Without using epsilon in your test cases, a test may mistakenly fail due to some minuscule imprecision; by adding some room for error into your tests, you remove these false positives. The epsilon value we give you is large enough to remove false positives, but small enough to not introduce false negatives -- that is, if the error is larger than epsilon, then there's probably a logic error in the implementation. The autograder's correct solution should not make floating-point errors bigger than epsilon. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@504-------------------------
NOTE REGARDING AUTOGRADER
<p>The autograder is very specific about the main.cpp output being exactly like the expected output down to the whitespace. So if the autograder is marking you down for a certain test and it seems like the program output and the expected output match exactly, turn on show whitespace. It will show you the differences in the spacing of the outputs and you need both to match exactly! </p>


<p></p>


<p>See <a data-pats="post_ref" href="502" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('502');">@502</a> for an example of this. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@517-------------------------
If, else statements
<p>Is it possible to have an if statement with 2 elses underneath it?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can only have one <code>else</code> statement in a conditional block, but you can handle as many conditions as you want using <code>else if</code>:<br/><br/></p>


<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (my_first_boolean_expression) {
    ...
} <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (my_second_boolean_expression) {
    ...
} <span class="hljs-keyword">else</span> {
    ...
}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('aWYlMjAobXlfZmlyc3RfYm9vbGVhbl9leHByZXNzaW9uKSUyMCU3QiUwQSVDMiVBMCUyMCVDMiVBMCUyMC4uLiUwQSU3RCUyMGVsc2UlMjBpZiUyMChteV9zZWNvbmRfYm9vbGVhbl9leHByZXNzaW9uKSUyMCU3QiUwQSVDMiVBMCUyMCVDMiVBMCUyMC4uLiUwQSU3RCUyMGVsc2UlMjAlN0IlMEElQzIlQTAlMjAlQzIlQTAlMjAuLi4lMEElN0Q=');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>

------------------------@518-------------------------
cout with summarize in main

------------------------@520-------------------------

<p>Using C-out instead of vectors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You will need to use vectors in your summarize function implementation (in stats.cpp) as you have to return a vector of vectors and populate it with the summarizing data. In main.cpp, you will cout the data in this vector in the format of "&lt;value&gt; : &lt;frequency".</p>

------------------------@521-------------------------

------------------------@522-------------------------
cannot cout summary
<p>I can call the summarize function, but if I try to cout, I get a compile error</p>

-------------------------------------------------
That’s because you cannot cout what summarize makes. You need to iterate through the double vector produced by summarize, cout-ing as you go.

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>


<p>summarize();</p>


<p></p>


<p>by itself, as if it were supposed to be a void function, I am really confused, I guess given the thead above the returning of a double vector is correct, but why is this the case? should summarize be returning the vector AND C-outing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Our stats_public_tests doesn't actually test summarize, it just makes sure that it runs. All summarize should be doing is returning the double vector.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p> You can write your own functions, just make sure to declare them as static!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thats great to hear I think... apologies but may ask what that means? I googled what a static function is in C++ and it says the following "A static function is <b>a member function of a class that can be called even when an object of the class is not initialized</b>. A static function cannot access any variable of its class except for static variables. The 'this' pointer points to the object that invokes the function." I don't completely understand what that means, is this saying that the function will not make any changes to the the input or?  Also are the functions that are required also static functions?</p>


<p></p>

<p>All I mean by that is put the word static in front of the return type. For example:</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@529-------------------------
summarize (issue with running the test!)
<p>What is the issue here  ? (This is in stats_tests_cpp). *data* is a vector&lt;double&gt;. Just trying to cout to see what the resulting output would be. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_7.56.13_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2Fefc5860f0249eac54b61684d0bcf4b9d2441e93fdd92e71bec582af98cbb35a2%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_7.56.13_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
You can’t ask cout to output a 2D vector, you have to iterate through it. It doesn’t know what you want it to do so it’s sad.

-------------------------------------------------
summarize returns a vector of vectors. C++ does not know how to print that out. You have to write a for loop manually printing the values in the vector of vectors returned by summarize!

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@530-------------------------
What does this mean? Median test function gives error
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky3tze2m3v25q0%2Ffedff83f49517853e4e634896332dbac3a70d046e308433450b7300add5add0a%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>My median test has a vector with 5 elements, the error says that its out of bounds but i dont get why</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So, to be clear, indexing the 5th position of a size 5 vector is out of bounds because it is zero indexed, so the valid indices for a size 5 vector are 0,1,2,3, and 4. In your median function, you are at some point indexing out of bounds. I experienced the same problem, essentially, the solution was to put the last iteration outside of the loop, though I don't think I can say more than that.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@532-------------------------
Summarize question
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.32_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2F17aa9f5ee7c064398e3d61d1d32a3d753b11660cb4371c3142c8a47928c77ebb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.32_PM.png"/>Hello, I'm unsure of why the terminal printed the last number with random decimals at the end. I would like to change to int, however the spec does say that summarize is supposed to return a double. *edit: every time I run it, the last number changes from 1.3, to 3.7, to 7.9, etc... (without even touching the code in between).<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.44_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2F0f5c4f3d38d0c8d5fecd5ee56d6e6b7d6045fae8a1a31919ed090229c829167b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_8.43.44_PM.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The frequency of the last number in the IDE is actually 1.31 x 10 ^ -310, which is its best approximation of the number 0 as a double. This is similar to issue outlined in the spec with the IDE having limited <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/#floating-point-comparisons" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">floating point precision</a>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You can consider this number to be 0, and if you wanted to assert it equals 0 you will have to follow the spec section linked above with setting an epsilon threshold.</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you just want it to print out to a certain number of decimal places, you can use:    std::cout &lt;&lt; std::fixed &lt;&lt; std::setprecision(2) &lt;&lt; decimal;</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
The private tests. Aside from that, style and test cases are *not* graded on this project.

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
You don’t see them until after the deadline, so make sure you test all possible edge cases

-------------------------------------------------
You won’t need main for it, autograder will just test your stats.cpp functions.

------------------------@543-------------------------
make test error on CAEN
<p><img alt="" height="150" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkfv8zzuo24e4ll%2F383e8f163d662f01e93a9d37a512fa40935b4135b294937ec7e01e1106b0af4c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_10.21.12_PM.png" width="1160"/></p>

<p>chmod u+x stats_public_test.exe</p>
