------------------------@544-------------------------
Floating Point Precision with the Summary Function
<p>Suppose you have two numbers 2.2453242431 and 2.2453240980. These two numbers are identical up to the fifth decimal place (the fifth decimal place is the same and the sixth is not). They are basically the same number; however, technically, there is a very, very small difference between the two. When writing test cases for summarize, should we count these two numbers as the same number or two separate numbers? I ask this because if one does need to consider them the same number, then one would need to introduce the epsilon stuff into the summarize function and also make sure that the number is displayed only to the fifth decimal place in the summary. Any thoughts on this would be helpful. Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As per <a data-pats="post_ref" href="262" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('262');">@262</a>, you do not need to consider values within an epsilon to be the same in your <code>stats.cpp</code> file, only when comparing to your test cases.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@545-------------------------
My autograder for the stats_public_test (UB Check) keeps being wrong. How do I fix it?
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gdbkjbt1x5wg%2Fc6c9d53595f103975e1c3f65363b00280c49633363f9096d6fd67059ed0aba7e%2Fimage.png"/><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gdbkjbt1x5wg%2Fc7c589ea3f167cfcd097816b35627bb23794eb80bb7693989d06daac79aaa0f0%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
You’re indexing out of bounds for these things. To fix these errors, look at the for loops that you wrote in stats.cpp. It seems like the errors are in summary and somewhere else - this second bug location is not clear to me. Anyways, take a look at your functions with for loops, and write some cases that will highlight the failures that are there.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Check out the answer on <a href="/328" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><a data-pats="post_ref" href="328" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('328');">@328</a>. Basically, you're indexing out of bounds somewhere (accessing index 3 of a vector of size 3).</p>

<p>*since I am discussing my implementation, I made sure to make this post private.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For the min() and max() functions, my implementation was to call the sort function on the given vector, and to find the MIN, I simply returned vector[0], and for MAX, I returned vector[vector.size() - 1].</p>


<p>Can I create an implementation like this that always assumes that the given sort() function will work correctly?</p>

------------------------@547-------------------------

------------------------@548-------------------------

<p><img alt="" height="1587" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxfxo1r1f877a%2F16c5bd4989de93cda39ed94e03dbdf53699277868fa93877b5c7815a7acbe125%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-13_at_11.16.11_PM.png" width="2880"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
I don’t really know what your code is like, but when you call extract_column, the result needs to be stored in a new vector: for example, you can create a new vector— vector<double> extract;
<div><br/></div>
<div>Then store the extract_column:</div>
<div>extract = extract_column(___,___);</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>Then you can summarize on the extracted column.</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>If that’s what you meant to ask about, hooray. </div>
<div>Otherwise, it would seem that you may have indexed out of bounds…</div>
<div><br/></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you solved this problem, but to make your life a little easier you can combine two lines in your code instead of having the for loop that I'm seeing on the autograder.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You can do something like: vector&lt;double&gt;v = extract_column(___,___)</p>

------------------------@555-------------------------
Question about Autograder
<p>This is my first time ever using the autograder and it said I received 9/9 for my submission. Does that mean I'm finished with the project? Is there anything else I need to add?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks for any advice!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You have received full points on the public tests. The majority of points are private, meaning they will be evaluated after 8:00 this evening, after the project is due. To ensure that your code is robust, test it with your own test cases, to see where the bugs are. You can keep submitting even past your 3 graded submits, since you already have 9/9, the feedback provided by these 3 submissions are not valuable to you, so they might as well not be there at all (to be clear, I just mean that you should submit at long as you think you have worked out another bug). The autograder will use the best result that you ever submitted, regardless of if you submitted broken ones afterwards. It's possible that your code is great, and there are no issues. It is more likely that there are bugs, so keep working on unit tests until you are satisfied with your code's performance. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>&gt;You can keep submitting even past your 3 graded submits, since you already have 9/9, the feedback provided by these 3 submissions are not valuable to you, so they might as well not be there at all (to be clear, I just mean that you should submit at long as you think you have worked out another bug)<br/><br/>Doe this mean that we have unlimited submits but only will get feedback for 3? <p>You only get 3 submissions, period. You will not receive credit for any submissions after that.</p>

Edge cases

-------------------------------------------------
Those would count as edge cases, but it’s not that literal, it’s just times when a function is given something that is not normal, like if a vector only had one entry, or something like that.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Is their any specific way were supposed to go about making sure those pass?</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@569-------------------------
Buffer Overflow / Bounds - Question
<p>Hey instructors - </p>


<p>I'm gonna attach a screenshot of my summarize function. I've been struggling with it for a couple of days and have gotten it to the point where I believe it would be extremely efficient, if it wasn't for one thing.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I believe that right now it's skipping over the last element in the vector. I'm trying to solve this by changing "k &lt; v.size()" to "k &lt;= v.size()" but the second I do that, it causes a buffer overflow. Would anybody be able to explain to me why this happens and what I can do about it?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks guys.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.13.22_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkta6k05vbph5wy%2F7c3878579b84a5db57b320b01d9a83bb997cc5721b32ad656d2e3fdf2bb2cc5b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.13.22_PM.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Recall that vectors (and arrays, for that matter) are indexed starting from 0 in C/C++. So if you have a vector v with five elements in it, v.size() returns 5, and you can access indices 0 through 4. In the last iteration of your for-loop, k is equal to v.size(), which is one position after the last index, hence the buffer overflow.</p>


<p>I see what you mean about your code skipping the last entry in the summary. Consider tracing this example: v = [1, 2, 3]. In the last iteration of your for-loop, you add the summary for 2, but you never get the chance to for 3. Maybe you need some logic outside the loop? Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@570-------------------------
Issue with sort.
<p>I'm currently working on the summarize function and im getting this error message "no matching function for call to 'sort'".  I included p1_library.h so I really have no idea why this is happening.</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksw56m2js1i4es%2F04b84b12f71ac1911af8fa5069fea1f5c6bdb6f00df68315e6bfdbc8b9c0663c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.27.00_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.27.00_PM.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you're passing in a variable of type vector&lt;vector&lt;double&gt;&gt; into sort(), but the sort() function in p1_library.h expects a variable of type vector&lt;double&gt;. Also, you may want to double-check your definition of summarize() against the one in stats.h: Recall that summarize() is also supposed to take a vector&lt;double&gt; as input, and return a vector&lt;vector&lt;double&gt;&gt;. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@572-------------------------
Problem with summarize
<p>I'm working on summarize and I've hit a wall.  I know that the function is meant to take in a vector of doubles and I know its meant to return a vector of vectors of doubles.  I first tried to have the same vector, v, be the input and the output but I found that you can't convert the type it holds.  So then I tried inputting a vector of doubles, v, and then creating and returning a different vector, vfinal, which is declared as a vector of vectors of doubles.  But now its giving me an error saying that I can't redefine v and that it's expecting it to be a vector of vectors of doubles.  I really don't know where to go from here.<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksw56m2js1i4es%2F48792e1323b54425cc4bbac36459c60a02f39ee260b3f22ef2fddd17ec95b92a%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.51.52_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_12.51.52_PM.png</a></p>

So, get rid of line 13. As for the second error, <code>vsmall</code> is being used without any type declaration. You might’ve meant to put <code>double</code> before it.</p></div>

------------------------@575-------------------------
My functions aren't looping until the end
<p>Hello, my uniqname cristi. I'm not sure how to fix my percentile and mode functions so they iterate until the end of the vector.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In your mode function, it looks like you're making this comparison:</p>


<pre>if (v[i] &lt; v[i + 2]) ...</pre>
<p dir="ltr">Your limits of i in your for loop are from 1 to v.size(). When i = v.size() - 2, this comparison becomes:</p>


<pre>if (v[v.size() - 2] &lt; v[v.size()]) ...</pre>
<p>The index v.size() is out-of-bounds, so you get an error before the loop ends. You'll have to modify your code a bit to avoid this out-of-bounds indexing. </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>In your percentile function, I'm not sure what you mean when you say you're not iterating through the whole vector because I don't see any loops that iterate through the vector. Could you elaborate?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
In autograder, my percentile function didn't give the 100th percentile in main.cpp.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You need to make a special case in your percentile function when p = 1, otherwise you will index out of bounds later. Think of what the 100th percentile always is, no matter what numbers are in the vector.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@578-------------------------
Trouble indexing out of bounds for summarize
<p>I'm think my summarize function is ready to go except I'm getting an error message that I believe is saying im indexing out of bounds.  My loop seems to stop at the right stop though so I don't know what could be causing this.<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksw56m2js1i4es%2F8c6f3d06ddf43c7289bc5e5add6421c9c0f098a731b24cf27dbd857d9c75212c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_1.37.05_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_1.37.05_PM.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Say we have a vector with 5 elements: _ _ _ _ _</p>


<p></p>


<p>The size here is 5. Since vectors are 0-indexed, we never want to access the element at index 5, because this would be going out of bounds: <span style="text-decoration:underline">0</span>  <span style="text-decoration:underline">1 </span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">2 </span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">3 </span> <span style="text-decoration:underline">4</span></p>


<p><span style="text-decoration:underline"></span></p>


<p>In your summarize function, do you see anywhere you might be trying to access the element past the end of the vector? (i.e. an element that does not exist?)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok in my for loop I realized I needed to have v.size()-1 but its still giving the same error so now I'm really confused</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Quick clarification: Your original terminating condition for the loop, i &lt; v.size(), should be fine. If v.size() is 5, then the loop will evaluate for i=0 through i =4; once i=5, the loop will terminate.</p>


<p>So the problem doesn't seem to be in the for-loop's terminating condition... I would double-check the places you index into v in the for-loop's body to see if you can find any situations where you could go out of bounds.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@579-------------------------
9/9 on autograder but orange main public test
<p>Hi instructors - </p>


<p></p>


<p>I got a 9/9 on the autograder but the main public tests are orange. They give me the points, and my output is exactly the same as what is expected, but I would just like to see if anybody could tell me if there's a specific function that's triggering it to be orange. I'm kind of betting it's my percentile function.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!</p>


<p></p>


<p>uniqname is wjrob</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your output looks great, but your program is exiting with code 1. This is because your main function in main.cpp is returning 1. As a convention, programs return an exit code of 0 if they run without error, and return a non-zero exit code if they encounter an error. So even though your program is running just fine, it's tricking the autograder into thinking there's an error by returning 1.</p>


<p>This has an easy fix: If your program makes it all the way to the end without error, it should return 0. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You shouldn’t need to include limits since this only includes constants for the higher and lowest numbers in a data type and not much else. -------------------------------------------------
<p>yes add #include &lt;cmath&gt; to stats_tests.cpp -- as for the autograder question, vscode might be overlooking the fact cmath wasn't included and automatically recognizing the function but autograder does not. one way to check this is by running the project on CAEN, as it uses the same environment as autograder</p>

------------------------@588-------------------------
Autograder Expected Output Incorrect?
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk041nyivcau3xy%2F3fa856a814921119209c5a4901646cbb5b1641cf5d31c18a70ee54c270ba8aaa%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>When I tried to solve this manually by hand, using the data set of &lt;6, 7, 8, 9, 10&gt;, I got a variance of 2, which means the standard deviation should be the sqrt of 2, which is 1.41421. Why should it be 1.58114?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You may be using the wrong standard deviation formula. The formula for p1 is</p>
<p><mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="0" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-msqrt><mjx-sqrt><mjx-surd><mjx-mo class="mjx-s3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c221A TEX-S3"></mjx-c></mjx-mo></mjx-surd><mjx-box style="padding-top: 0.089em;"><mjx-mstyle><mjx-mfrac><mjx-frac type="d"><mjx-num><mjx-nstrut type="d"></mjx-nstrut><mjx-mrow><mjx-mo class="mjx-sop"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2211 TEX-S1"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c28"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D465 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2212"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-texatom space="3" texclass="ORD"><mjx-mover><mjx-over style="padding-bottom: 0.06em; padding-left: 0.064em; margin-bottom: -0.544em;"><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-cAF"></mjx-c></mjx-mo></mjx-over><mjx-base><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D465 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-base></mjx-mover></mjx-texatom><mjx-msup><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c29"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-script style="vertical-align: 0.289em;"><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" size="s"><mjx-c class="mjx-c32"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-script></mjx-msup></mjx-mrow></mjx-num><mjx-dbox><mjx-dtable><mjx-line type="d"></mjx-line><mjx-row><mjx-den><mjx-dstrut type="d"></mjx-dstrut><mjx-mrow><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D441 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2212"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-mrow></mjx-den></mjx-row></mjx-dtable></mjx-dbox></mjx-frac></mjx-mfrac></mjx-mstyle></mjx-box></mjx-sqrt></mjx-msqrt></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msqrt><mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0"><mfrac><mrow><mo data-mjx-texclass="OP">∑</mo><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mrow><mover><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></msqrt></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container></p>
<p>where <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="1" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-texatom texclass="ORD"><mjx-mover><mjx-over style="padding-bottom: 0.06em; padding-left: 0.064em; margin-bottom: -0.544em;"><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-cAF"></mjx-c></mjx-mo></mjx-over><mjx-base><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D465 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-base></mjx-mover></mjx-texatom></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mover><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover></mrow></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> is the mean, and <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="2" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D465 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> is each value in the vector, and <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="3" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D441 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>N</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> is the size of the vector.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So it seems that we're using the sample stdev formula instead of the population stdev formula. Why is that?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo5ooY"><p>I don’t really know but it’s what’s linked in the header comment of the function.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In this project we're analyzing data from a study, which means we're dealing with sample data, not population data.</p>

<p></p>


<p>Element = {CurrentValue, Count};</p>

-------------------------------------------------
For your summarize function think about where you are when indexing through pairs. For example, there are j elements in pairs. And there are only ever 2 objects in element. You’re very close with your current code for printing summarize!
<p></p>
<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I don't quite get the point though, do you mean if Pairs[j] gives me the element I want,  then i should cout &lt;&lt; element[0] &lt;&lt; element[1] ???</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Well if you have two objects in element[j] and you want to print them, then you have the choice between either accessing the 0th element in j or the 1st element in j. Does this make more sense?
<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>like cout &lt;&lt; pair[j][0] &lt;&lt; pair[j][1]??? because j is our row ???</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I really don't know when we do push back, how would the vector look like, is it like j rows 2 columns or 2 rows j columns???</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Or the element itself is a vector holding two objects?? so I can do element[j][0] and element[j][1]</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
Try running what you typed out :)

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is one way of visualizing a 2D vector:</p>


<p></p>


<p><code>{</code><br/><code>   {1, 2},</code></p>


<p><code>   {3, 4},</code></p>


<p><code>   {5, 6}</code></p>


<p><code>}</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>When you are using the first index, you are choosing one of the "inner" vectors within the outer one. So, if I have a 2D vector called x, then x[0] would yield the first inner vector:<br/><br/></p>


<p><code>{</code><br/><code>   <em><strong>{1, 2}</strong></em>,</code></p>


<p><code>   {3, 4},</code></p>


<p><code>   {5, 6}</code></p>


<p><code>}</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>The second index will choose an integer within my inner vector, just like normal. So x[0][1] would give me the 2nd integer within the inner vector, which in this case is 2:</p>


<p></p>


<p><code>{</code><br/><code>   {1, <strong><em>2</em></strong>},</code></p>


<p><code>   {3, 4},</code></p>


<p><code>   {5, 6}</code></p>


<p><code>}</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>In the case of summarize, the inner vectors always have a size of 2. So you can use one loop with a counter <code>j</code> and print out the elements using <code>element[j][0]</code> and <code>element[j][1]</code> like you mentioned previously.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@601-------------------------
out of bounds
<p>I referenced <a data-pats="post_ref" href="328" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('328');">@328</a> for the out of bounds error I'm getting, It is the same one as <a data-pats="post_ref" href="455" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('455');">@455</a></p>


<p>but this is my percentile function and I am accounting for for extreme circumstances Im not sure what I'm doing wrong I've added my percentile function as well to reference- this is the only error I have left in my last submission if anyone can guide me in the right way please let me know! Thank you! </p>


<p></p>


<p><b>double</b> percentile(vector&lt;<b>double</b>&gt; v, <b>double</b> p) {</p>


<p>    assert(!v.empty());</p>


<p>    sort(v);</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> rank;</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> k = 0;</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> d = 0;</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> perc;</p>


<p>    rank = (p * (v.size() - 1)) + 1;</p>


<p>    k = modf(rank, &amp;d);</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> a = v[d-1];</p>


<p>    <b>double</b> b = v[d];</p>


<p>    <b>if</b> (d == v.size()) {</p>


<p>        perc = v[v.size()-1];</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>    <b>else</b>{</p>


<p>        <b>double</b> c = b - a;</p>


<p>        perc = a + k * (c);</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>    <b>return</b> perc;</p>


<p>}</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The index out of bounds error is going to happen anywhere that you're indexing into v. That means it's either happening where you're initializing a, initializing b, or initializing perc. Your error message should be able to tell you which line here is causing the index problem. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>My error is only on the autograder it doesn't happen when i run my program individually on the terminal, I honestly don't know another way to approach this</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>"</p>


<table><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>/usr/include/c++/5/debug/vector:409:error: attempt to subscript container</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>with out-of-bounds index 5, but container only holds 5 elements.</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>Objects involved in the operation:</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>sequence "this" @ 0x0x7fff6df75310 {</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td>type = NSt7__debug6vectorIdSaIdEEE;</td></tr><tr><td>7</td><td>}"</td></tr></tbody></table>

------------------------@605-------------------------
percentile - overindexing and starting from index 0
<p>Hi, what specifically in the percentile formula is causing it to index from 1? Is it the +1 in rank? I am trying to figure out how to avoid overindexing. thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>These posts should help you with this: <a data-pats="post_ref" href="523" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('523');">@523</a> <a data-pats="post_ref" href="519" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('519');">@519</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>The reason why you have to deal with overindexing is because the formula uses the value of <code>k+1</code> (consider whether there is an input that will yield a value <code>k</code> that lets you go out-of-bounds).</p>

------------------------@612-------------------------
About summarize
<p>My summarize function can't print the last pair of data( i mean the number and it's corresponding frequency), and for the first pair of data, the frequency will automatically adding 1 itself.....<img alt="" height="1096" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxfxo1r1f877a%2Fc6c2f2e04463f4f083447ee60ee20214d9c2661d35e30df7c35ab374f2895acf%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-14_at_7.18.11_PM.png" width="1484"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><ul><li>My summarize function can’t print the last pair of data</li></ul>
<p>The last element is not being pushed to the vector.</p>
<ul><li>for the first pair of data, the frequency will automatically adding 1 itself</li></ul>
<p>You initialize count to 1 and begin the for loop at the first element. So you basically compare the first element with itself so <code>count</code> will always be incremented by 1 at the beginning.</p>
<p>I strongly recommend you use the debugger to go through your code.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

You are going out of bound, you have to check to make sure your loop doesn’t count to the index that equals to the size or even larger

------------------------@619-------------------------

------------------------@620-------------------------
Project 2 FAQ
<p>Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding Project 2. Project 2 is due <strong>Wednesday</strong><strong>, September 28th at 8pm</strong>.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Spec is <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>. </p>


<p><br/>Resize GUI repository (you can use this to easily try your resize code on other images!): <a href="https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI</a><a href="https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a></p>


<p><br/>Write clear code! This is especially important for this project, remember:<br/><strong>Matrix width = # of columns</strong><br/><strong>Matrix height = # of rows</strong><br/>Instead of using variables like "i" and "j" in your for-loops, consider using "row" and "col" so you don't get confused!<br/><br/><strong>Q: Am I required to use traversal by pointer?</strong><br/>A: <strong>No.</strong> You are allowed to, but not required to use traversal by pointer in this project. You should choose to traverse by index/pointer based on what makes sense to you logically.<br/><br/><strong>Q: My program takes a couple minutes or more to run. Is this expected? </strong><br/>A: Yes, but not too long - your program should run in under 30 seconds. Double check that you're not looping unnecessarily or calling an inefficient function within a loop. Perf is also a helpful tool for improving efficiency! <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#appendix-b-perf-tutorial" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#appendix-b-perf-tutorial</a><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#appendix-b-perf-tutorial" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><br/><br/><strong>Q: Rotate left is failing, even though it was provided. Is there an error in the provided function?</strong> <br/>A: Rotate left calls several student implemented image functions, which can cause errors in rotate left.<br/><br/><strong>Q: Why do I have to write functions like Matrix_width? Couldn't I just use matrix-&gt;width directly?</strong><br/>A: Unless you're implementing a Matrix function, this is generally considered really poor design! We actually consider this incorrect behavior, even if you get the right results, so please make sure you use the right function. Even if it's just Matrix_width and Matrix_height, whenever you're not writing Matrix functions, go through the interface - the same goes for Image as well.<br/><br/><strong>Q: Do I have to respect the interface when writing tests?</strong><br/>A: Yes, tests should always respect the interface! In the real world, this means you can reuse tests when changing the implementation to make sure that you haven't also changed the interface, such that you can avoid updating the code everywhere the interface is used!<br/><br/><strong>Q: How can I test Matrix_at without breaking the interface?</strong><br/>A: When thinking of unit testing, you should think in units as behavior instead of units as functions, because it is common to have functions like Matrix_at that solely rely on the underlying implementation. When testing Matrix_at, we really want to test the behavior of setting and retrieving independent values reliably from our matrix. For example, you could test that setting a value at (0,1) doesn't modify the value at (1,0) or other similar variations of this.<br/><br/><strong>Q: What does it mean for the column start to be inclusive and the column end to be exclusive?</strong> <br/>A: This means that when looking for the min value, you should consider the column start but not column end. For example, if my column start was 2 and my column end was 5, I would consider columns 2,3, and 4, but not 5. <br/><br/><strong>Q: Why am I failing crabster but passing dog and horses?</strong><br/>A: Crabster tends to catch more edge cases. Be sure that in all cases you're checking the correct columns when you compute the energy, cost, and seam.</p>


<p><br/><strong>Q: One of my processing test is failing, but when I print out the output it matches the correct file.</strong> <br/>A: Double check your image init. If you read in the correct image incorrectly, then Image_equal will fail even if you've processed the image correctly.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: I am missing some test cases. What other tests should I write to catch the test cases?</strong></p>


<p>A: Sorry! We don't share what test cases the AG is looking for. The best advice we can give it to brainstorm more edge cases. </p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: I'm trying to run processing_public_test.cpp/resize.cpp on XCode, and Xcode is saying that it's unable to open dog.ppm/crabster.ppm/horses.ppm.</strong></p>


<p>A: You need to update XCode's custom working directory: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run</a></p>


<p><br/>Happy coding!</p>

Official Grading Statistics Thread
<p dir="ltr">This thread contains the grading statistics for class assignments. We will keep it up to date throughout the remainder of the semester.</p>

<p dir="ltr">A: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/eecs280.org/syllabus.html#grades" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/eecs280.org/syllabus.html#grades</a></p>

<p dir="ltr">A: The number of assignments submitted for grading</p>

------------------------@629-------------------------
Array decay
<p style="text-align:left">In the array decay lecture, there is one slide page mentions that</p>


<p style="text-align:left"><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gbxa2boas4b6%2F240d8846ce4b8811e5634e8fb9f37b1fe0de63bf9c9f2aa949094d62c0f16270%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p style="text-align:left">What does it mean by "Doesn't happen if you use * or []" and "Doesn't apply if array appears to the left of ="? What specific situations are these two sentences referring to?</p>


<p style="text-align:left">Moreover, I am really confused about array decay. Why is it even exists? It seems that there is no such thing in other languages like Java or Python. And in what situations will array decay occurs?</p>


<p style="text-align:left">Thanks so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In regards to those "Doesn't" bullets, they're referencing the fact that the array will not decay to a pointer that is pointing at the first element if the array is dereferenced using the * operator or if a specific element of the array is being accessed. The "=" one I believe is in reference to initializing an array.</p>


<p></p>


<p>C++ is a lower level language than Python or Java, and by using the array, we can access its elements using pointer arithmetic, which I'm guessing isn't possible in other languages.</p>


<p></p>


<p>As stated in the lecture, array decay will occur when the name of the array is used without any * or [] operator. For instance:</p>


<p></p>


<p>int arr[3] = {1, 2, 3};</p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; arr;</p>


<p></p>


<p>would print the pointer of the first element of the array.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Part 1, which is most of what you asked about:</p>
<p>Let’s say we have array <code>a</code> at location 0x0000:</p>
<pre><code>int a[5];
for (int i = 0; i &lt; 5; ++i)
{
    a[i]  = i;
}
</code></pre><p>The second bullet point is saying that we don’t decay to pointer if we index using <code>[]</code> (e.g. <code>a[2]</code> returns 2) or dereference with <code>*</code> (e.g. <code>*a</code> returns 0 - as a rule, dereferencing returns the first element). We do decay to pointer if we just read <code>a</code> by itself: <code>int* start = a</code> will set <code>start</code> to <code>0x0000</code>. Any time we read <code>a</code> without using either the <code>*</code> or <code>[]</code> operators, pointer decay will occur and <code>a</code> will be interpreted as a pointer.</p>
<hr/>
<p>Part 2, specifically “why?”</p>
<p>Why does this exist? Great question! I went down a bit of a rabbit hole answering this, but the question really boils down to why should you use pointers at all. As far as I know, part of it is computer science history and part of it is the contrast between C / C++ and some other languages. I would say that 90% of the time when you’re coding “in real life”, you don’t need to worry about pointers; however, in the other 10%, you <strong>really really</strong> need to know what you’re doing with pointers. Take what I say with a grain of salt because I am a student and don’t really know that much more either.</p>
<p>First, the history. Wikipedia says that pointers were first introduced as an idea in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and were independently discovered in the 1960s in the west. Computer science at this time was a lot more annoying - take a look at some FORTRAN or Lisp code if you want an idea - and one of the annoying things was that you had to deal with memory a lot more directly. For example, on the Wikipedia example of a FORTRAN II program, the first line of code reads from an actual physical tape roll of data. This was I think pretty typical - you had to manually read and write data from some input instead of the nicer way we have through the terminal today. The introduction of pointers meant that instead of reading / writing every time you want to manipulate something in memory, you can just keep a pointer to the same address and dereference whenever you want to read / write. I <em>think</em> this basically makes the pointer a nice little “wrapper” for everything you might want to do with a memory address, including reading / writing to that specific address. As computers and programming languages became more advanced, we’ve tried to do even more abstraction; this is why you don’t see explicit pointer types in Python and Java, for example.</p>
<p>The reason this is still important, and a big part of what keeps C / C++ in use despite its age, is that having easy access to lower-level stuff allows for a lot more optimization than a “nicer” language like Java or Python. For example, the Tiger engine used in the video games for the <em>Halo</em> franchise goes crazy with optimization, because there’s so much going on in a video game and not a lot of power on a console to work with (Halo Combat Evolved had to fit in I think 32 MB of RAM - for reference most computers nowadays have 256-512 times that much). Careful memory management with pointers becomes a fundamental part of your optimization toolkit. I won’t say too much about what those optimizations are because this answer is long enough, but it basically boils down to the fact that adding more abstraction to make it easier to work with the language comes with a performance cost (e.g. <a href="https://benchmarksgame-team.pages.debian.net/benchmarksgame/performance/mandelbrot.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">see this website here running a benchmark in different languages</a> and compare C++'s performance with Java or Python 3). A consequence of all this is that a lot of “old code” you might still have to interact with today (say, operating system-level code on Unix or Windows) will be using pointers, meaning that pointers will still be a valuable part of your toolkit.</p>
<p><img alt="" src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Barplot_language_speeds_%28Benchmarks_Game_Mandelbrot%29.svg/1024px-Barplot_language_speeds_%28Benchmarks_Game_Mandelbrot%29.svg.png"/></p>
<p>Now when you’re operating at this level, <strong>array decay specifically is a convenient way to pass around sequential data as pointers</strong>. If there wasn’t anything like array decay, then you’d basically have to implement it yourself if you wanted to do anything with arrays - which is asking for weird and subtle errors to occur (on top of the other weird and subtle errors that already occur at this level).</p>
<p>Would be interested in other staff members’ thoughts on “what’s the point of pointers”!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@633-------------------------
Autograder result

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I noticed you didn't have any test cases for sum() in your submitted code. Although it might seem like some functions are trivial, bugs can be very subtle and the only way to be sure they work as expected is to test them with a variety of input.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I would recommend writing a few diverse test cases and see if you can replicated the bug on your end. As a hint, I believe your function will produce the correct output for a vector like {2,-1,0}. What are other types of values you can try passing in? Think about the data type being passed in.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For count, you are missing an edge case. Hint: take a look at the RME for count. What is different compared to most of the other functions?</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@636-------------------------
How to read in ppm file from istream in Project 2
<p>I've been working on Project 2 and am stuck on the Image_init function that reads a PPM file from istream. I read the write-up, but I don't understand how to use &gt;&gt; to read-in the file. Are we supposed to use specific functions like getLine from the istream? I have ideas about how to process the file, but I'm just really confused on how to actually obtain it from istream. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you imagine the <code>istream</code> to just be <code>cin</code>, it acts in the same way as though you were reading the file from user input. Does that answer your question?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So each time you use is&gt;&gt;string_variable or is&gt;&gt;int_variable, the value stored in the variable would be the next string or int separated by a whitespace? Or does it read more than that?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Yep! Just like <code>cin</code></p></div>

------------------------@637-------------------------
P2 Allowed to use "using namespace std"?
<p>Are we allowed to include "using namespace std" at the top of our Matrix.cpp file? Or should I just do std:: next to everything (for example, std::cout)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>youre allowed to use that everywhere</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To augment the student answer, it's considered bad practice to include "using namespace &lt;anything&gt;" in a .h file (since then if someone down the road includes your library, you are forcing them to use that namespace which could cause naming conflicts). Other than that, you should feel free to to include that statement in any .cpp file.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@639-------------------------
variable length array
<p>I wrote in void Matrix_init():</p>


<div>
<div>  const int size = width * height;</div>
<div>  int data[size] = {0};</div>
</div>


<p></p>


<p>but when I tried to compile it, there is an error says:</p>


<p>error: ISO C++ forbids variable length array ‘data’ [-Werror=vla]</p>


<p></p>


<p>What can I do?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Since width and height can change depending on user input, the value of size can change from run to run. C++ forbids this. In order to make an array, you must have a constant int size that’s the same for every run of the program.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How is it possible to use a seam array, as its length would depend on the input image's height? Do you have to dynamically allocate memory?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You don't have to dynamically allocate memory, in this case, you can declare a seam array that is dependent on the height. In the case of data[] though, since it is part of a struct object, the size of data[] has to be the same for all matrices.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am getting this same problem, and I am not sure that these posts helped me understand what is going on,</p>


<p></p>


<p>writing in my  seam carve width method</p>


<div>
<div></div>
<div>  const int b = Image_height(img);</div>
<div>  int arr[b];</div>
</div>



<div>I get yelled at with "ISO C++ forbids variable length array"</div>



<div>What is going on here? I made b a constant! shouldn't this be fine? </div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Use MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT as the size for the array. It guarantees that the seam will always be long enough for the image.</p>

------------------------@645-------------------------
Question regarding setup for project 2
<p>I'm looking at the project 2 spec and at the Setup section ("Commit and submit" specifically), it says to "submit the code you have to the autograder. It's best to find out early if there’s a mismatch between the autograder and your local development environment". </p>


<p></p>


<p>When I submit to the autograder and get the results, what exactly am I trying to look for? Whether the code compiles? What would I see if there was a mismatch?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What this part of the spec is referring to is that some development environments may overlook certain issues that CAEN / the autograder will flag as problematic. For instance, your IDE may not warn you if you are having memory errors but submitting to the autograder certainly will. Essentially we are just promoting the idea of submitting early so that if something looks right on your local computer but has problems in the autograder, you catch this early.</p>

------------------------@646-------------------------
testing matrix.cpp
<p>I am little confused as to how to design my tests in Matrix_tests.cpp. Could someone explain the TEST(&lt;method name&gt;) syntax and how all of the test methods defined in this way are automatically ran without being explicitly called when compiling and running Matrix_tests.cpp?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, could someone describe the purpose of the unit_tests_framework.h file? Any help would be appreciated, thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There is a tutorial page that describes what the unit tests do and what you can do within them here: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/unit_test_framework/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/unit_test_framework/</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>unit_tests_framework.h is a header file for the framework of the unit tests I believe, as in you need this header file to be able to do the TEST(&lt;method name&gt;), ASSERT_EQUAL(first, second), etc. which you must use for your tests in Matrix_tests.cpp.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hello! </p>


<p></p>


<p>Referring to slides 15 and 16 in lab 3 (<a href="https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/13a7U67orAdlr05_EtFnOpkdutj-HqEBr_1swx9OTB7s/edit?usp=sharing" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/13a7U67orAdlr05_EtFnOpkdutj-HqEBr_1swx9OTB7s/edit?usp=sharing</a>) will be helpful!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Mentally, you can view TEST(&lt;method name&gt;) as a function named &lt;method name&gt;. Against this backdrop, each TEST(&lt;method name&gt;) you write corresponds to a function named &lt;method name&gt;.</p>


<p></p>


<p>When you write TEST_MAIN() in the test file, you can view it as an int main function that calls all the functions corresponding to TEST functions. </p>


<p></p>


<p>You need to ensure you import unit_tests_framework.h as a header file to be able to use TEST(&lt;method name&gt;) as the students' answer suggests : )</p>

------------------------@649-------------------------
Somewhat lost on Image_init(Image* img, std::istream& is)
<p>I am unfortunately almost completely lost on this implementation. How should we read an image in ppm? Would anyone give a hint?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Recall the format of a ppm file: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#ppm-format" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#ppm-format</a></p>
<p>Pretend that <code>is</code> is just typical user input like <code>cin</code>, and use it in that way.</p>
<p>To get the “P3” at the top, you can do <code>is &gt;&gt; blah;</code> where <code>blah</code> is some string variable. Then, you can continue reading in everything else (skipping whitespace) with <code>is &gt;&gt; </code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Given that the maximum color value of 255 is already given in image.h, does that mean we should also skip over the 255 present in the PPM format?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Also wouldn't assigning P3 to a random string variable give a compiler error? The string variable will be unused. Not sure if this will give an issue or not.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>When it comes to reading in variables, the compiler won’t complain about it being unused. It will only complain if you declare a variable and do nothing else with it, like <code>int x = 5;</code>.</p>
<p>The max color value will always be 255, so yes, you can just read that in as a junk value as well.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@651-------------------------
How do we use the ostream?
<p>Do we have to use Matrix_print to write to a file? Is it enough to just print the result to the console?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Given an ostream <code>os</code>, you can use it in the same way that you would use <code>cout</code> or <code>ofstream</code>. So to print to an <code>ostream</code> called <code>os</code>, you just do something like</p>
<pre><code>os &lt;&lt; "this is printed to the ostream";
</code></pre></div>

------------------------@654-------------------------
Output of &a+1
<p>If a is an array, &amp;a+1 will point to the next object, and we don't need to worry about whether the address is in the half way. But is it true for all other object? </p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>See instructor response in followup.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you so much! That's a really good explanation! I am sorry I didn't express it clearly for 'the address is halfway'. Here is what I meant.</p>


<p>If a is an integer located in 0x1010, and b is the next object located in 0x1014. What's the code like if:</p>


<p>1) go to the next object after a, which is b?</p>


<p>2) go to the next address of a, which is 0x1011? </p>


<p></p>


<p>I am not sure whether '&amp;a+1' will returns the second output, and '&amp;(a+1）gives the first output. </p>


<p>Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>These are really good questions actually, </p>


<p></p>


<p>First, we cannot put the '&amp;' operator in front of 'a', since a is already an address because it is a pointer. (I assume the compiler wouldn't allow it or there would be strange behavior).</p>


<p></p>


<p>Second, If a is an integer located in 0x1010, and b is the next object located in 0x1014. What's the code like if:</p>


<p>1) go to the next object after a, which is b?</p>


<p>- By doing a + 1, we would be moving the pointer from a to b (from 0x1010 to 0x1014)</p>


<p></p>


<p>2) go to the next address of a, which is 0x1011? </p>


<p>- If a is an array of integers, then this is not possible, since integers are 4 bytes, we can only move from 0x1010 to 0x1014 to 0x1018 etc.</p>


<p>- Now if a was an array of chars (with a char being 1 byte), then doing a + 1 would take us from 0x1010 to 0x1011</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you want some more info, I would highly suggest trying some code in <a href="https://lobster.eecs.umich.edu/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://lobster.eecs.umich.edu/</a> , this way you can easily visualize memory and where your pointers are going :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/07_ADTs_in_C.html#streams-in-c" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/07_ADTs_in_C.html#streams-in-c</a></p>


<p>The section on string streams might be helpful for some background reading behind the theory of string streams and the syntax for using them! Let us know if you have any questions after this : )</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yep that works perfectly, thanks for the help!</p>

------------------------@656-------------------------
Issues compiling
<p>My Xcode project fails to build and gives me 2 errors: "error build: 50 duplicate symbols for architecture arm64" and "warning build: no rule to process file '/Users/sofiavalb/Desktop/eecs280/p2-cv/Makefile' of type 'sourcecode.make' for architecture 'arm64'". What could I do to fix this?<br/><br/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Typically duplicate symbols occur when your compile sources are not configured correctly to run in XCode or you have unnecessary #includes. To fix this, I would first refer to <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#compile-with-xcode" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this</a> section of the setup guide which walks through how you configured compile sources in P1. Depending on what file you are trying to run, you just have to add the necessary files!<br/><br/>As for the Makefile warning, this is likely also caused by your compile sources not being configured correctly. Following the same steps as before, double check that your Makefile is not listed as a compile source.</p>

------------------------@658-------------------------

I think you're on WSL based on your filepath (correct me if I'm wrong though), so you'll want <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#windowswsl-launchjson" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this one.</a> You'll want to copy this into .vscode/launch.json in your Lab 3 folder.</p>

<p>3. Now, in a remote WSL window of VS Code, try running the debugger.</p>

------------------------@659-------------------------
Matrix row question
<p>How are we supposed to do this function if we are not allowed to use a loop? The spec says these functions (row and col) should not use a loop. </p>


<p></p>


<p>also what if there is more than one number in the array. ex: two 5s in different rows. what would we return then</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Instead of using a loop to find the index, think about how we have a pointer as a parameter in the function which we can use to help find the index (pointer arithmetic). A good example of this in use would be slide 10 on the lab 3 slides. This finds the index.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Then, you must figure out which row it may be in. Something else you may need to help understand which row or column it should be in is the example 5x3 array in the spec. Specifically how the indexes fit with the rows and columns those elements are in. Since it is a 1-D array, the rows and columns are all fit into one array.</p>

<p>I found this easier to find when I wrote Matrix_column before Matrix_row.</p>

------------------------@661-------------------------
Project 2 setup
Do we have to edit the launch.json argument line before we start project 2?

<p>You don't *need* to edit launch.json before you can start writing/compiling/running P2, but if you want to debug P2, you'll need to update the "program" argument in launch.json to point to the right executable.</p>

------------------------@662-------------------------
XCode Arguments
<p>I'm currently following the part of the project 2 setup where you edit the arguments and options, and I'm confused on what arguments we're supposed to add here: <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-17_at_9.15.44_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt03b21o5gb43b%2Fc07ecd8ae650b38d0b2becae9cab3bedde2dba0a0ebe50595befb690930fdb07%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-17_at_9.15.44_PM.png"/></p>

------------------------@664-------------------------
Private test grading
Before the deadline my score was 9/9 and all the functions passed the test on my computer. But I got marked down with some of my functions in the private test for the final grade. So, I want to know how us the private test section graded and what to look for in order to get full points for my private tests for the future projects. Does it mean that my test cases weren’t able to expose some of the bugs?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We test a wide array of inputs in order to see how resilient your program is and if it works as promised. In order to pass the private test cases you will need to think creatively about what valid edge cases might be able to break the types of functions or programs you are implementing and writing tests that handle those cases. If you are not passing all the privates it means that your test cases were likely not able to expose those bugs (since they were found in your program).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@665-------------------------

------------------------@671-------------------------
SSH Keys setup
<p>Hello, I wanted to generate SSH keys, but the outcome is different comparing to the tutorial. It starts with SHA256 instead of <code>ssh-rsa</code>, <code>ssh-dss</code>, <code>ecdsa-sha2-nistp256</code>, <code>ecdsa-sha2-nistp384</code>, <code>ecdsa-sha2-nistp521</code>, <code>ssh-ed25519</code>, <code>sk-ecdsa-sha2-nistp256@openssh.com</code>, or <code>sk-ssh-ed25519@openssh.com</code>. What should I do next? By the way, it says "Publicly visible private SSH keys can compromise your system." What does this mean and do I need to make any changes?<img alt="" height="214" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7hywh90dp86nx%2F62785fe5f7d447d7eb18a552a680e75f41b5e486d436a29cfbd674719c0b0ceb%2F20220918001742.png" width="835"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The sequence of characters following "SHA256" is your key's fingerprint, which is different than the key itself. If you want to see the actual key, <code>cd</code> into your .ssh directory, and run the command <code>cat id_ed25519.pub</code>. Just make sure you don't share your private key and you should be fine</p>

------------------------@673-------------------------
How to check the matrix is a valid matrix
<p>In the requirement, it says mat points to a valid Matrix. I know that it is good to write assert to check the requirement. But how can we check that? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hello! </p>


<p></p>


<p>You're right! Using assert statements to check the conditions in the REQUIRES clause is a great practice. However, some conditions like whether mat points to a valid matrix cannot be checked using assert statements : )</p>


<p></p>


<p>I have attached a line from the "Assertions" subsection of the "Matrix Module" in the specification (<a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#assertions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#assertions</a>):</p>


<p></p>


<p>" Of course, you can’t assert every single thing in the REQUIRES clause. Some of them can’t possibly be checked. For example, you can’t check that a pointer points to a valid <code>Matrix</code> (i.e. one that has been initialized). "</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@674-------------------------
How to use mat in the Matrix_ init function
<p>My partner and I are having trouble understanding how to use the mat variable in the Matrix_init function. We tried to make a matrix using an array, but we don't know how to make mat point to that matrix. Some guidance would be appreciated. Here is our code:</p>


<div>
<div></div>
<div>     </div>
</div>


<p><img alt="" height="247" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt69yjnrzjd4x7%2F0754cd3bcff0b3135cdf657dd0ec75bbf559e3de2b50a80ccad5b41fdf945bb7%2FScreenshot_2022-09-18_115059.png" width="636"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I would suggest taking another look at how the Matrix struct is defined in <code>Matrix.h</code>. Here, you can see that there are three member variables (<code>width</code>, <code>heigh</code>t &amp; <code>data</code>) where <code>data</code> is a 2D array already allocated to <code>MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH</code> by <code>MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT</code> dimensions. In <code>Matrix_init</code>, you are passed a pointer to a Matrix where your job is to “Initialize *mat as a Matrix with the given width and height.” Given that <code>data</code> is already initialized, you just have to handle the other member variables.</p>
<p>Feel free to follow-up with clarifications!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So would I have to access the width and height member variables within the struct and change their values to whatever the input is?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>That would make sense to me! Then you would have access to the actual width &amp; height of that matrix moving forward.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok, this is starting to make more sense to me now. However, I have one more question. The initializer function isn't supposed to create a 2D matrix, it just sets a width, height, and size to be used later on by the other functions correct?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>Yes! - if you refer to the Matrix.h file, data is already pre-allocated with the maximum matrix dimensions.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok, I understand now. Thank you very much for your help!</p>

------------------------@677-------------------------
Long to int warning
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_3.30.37_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkss10t2wxtr739%2F192f35deab7c15bf08d29b19e4c2200eca8d903388547177240575bce0496449%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_3.30.37_PM.png"/></p>

<p>Why is there a warning popping up on my Matrix_row and Matrix_column functions? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The warning is occuring because when you do the pointer arithmetic, that operation returns a long, and you're assigning that value to an integer variable.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@681-------------------------
For Matrix_init(), are we supposed to resize mat->data as well?
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Hi, so I was wondering if we were supposed to change the actual size of the underlying array as well, which has a size of 500*500 by default. My initial guess says yes, but I wasn’t sure because the public test cases weren’t testing for them.</p>
<p>Thank you!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you look at the EFFECTS clause of Matrix_init() in the Matrix.h file, it says</p>


<p>"Initializes *mat as a Matrix with the given width and height."</p>


<p>This is all you need to do : )</p>


<p></p>


<p>Every matrix created will have an underlying unchanging data array of size 500*500</p>

------------------------@682-------------------------
Git pull not working
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_4.11.34_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkxwilzlr6ce4kd%2Fde833272b5d7fd3fb77a1d77af05234a662ed252c9259f8298218e27ddb4047b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_4.11.34_PM.png"/></p>


<p>I am getting this error whenever I try to git pull and I don't know how to fix it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This means your branch is no longer directly based off of the branch you're trying to merge it into - e.g. another commit was added to the destination branch that isn't in your branch. You'll have to merge your changes with the incoming changes.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Disclaimer</strong>: these commands will bring changes from the remote branch into yours.</p>


<p>Try <code>git pull --rebase</code></p>


<p></p>


<p>If that doesn't work, try:</p>


<p><code>git pull origin &lt;branch&gt; --rebase</code></p>


<p> </p>

------------------------@683-------------------------
Matrix_row() and Matrix_column()
<p>For these two functions are we allowed to assume that the pointer points to the beginning of the row or column, or will it sometimes point to an element partway through.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The pointer will point to any valid datum in the Matrix, you cannot make any assumptions on where it will be. Hopefully this image helps!</p>

<p>You can use the interface with VSCode to make commits if you like. We just teach the git commands for normal terminal use since they will work regardless of your operating system, whereas the interface with VSCode is IDE specific. </p>

------------------------@689-------------------------
How to access for the 2D-array through mat pointer
If I want to access for the element in row p and column q, can I use mat->data[p * q] or use mat->data[p*width+q] to access for it?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can consider a 3x2 matrix.</p>


<table border="1px" cellpadding="6px" cellspacing="0"><tbody><tr><td>0, 0</td><td>0, 1</td></tr><tr><td>1, 0</td><td>1, 1</td></tr><tr><td>2, 0</td><td>2, 1</td></tr></tbody></table>


<p></p>


<p>Turning it into a 1D array</p>


<p>    0        1         2        3       4        5</p>


<table border="1px" cellpadding="6px" cellspacing="0"><tbody><tr><td>0, 0</td><td>0, 1</td><td>1, 0</td><td>1, 1</td><td>2, 0</td><td>2, 1</td></tr></tbody></table>


<p></p>


<p>If you want to access the (1, 1) matrix data (i.e. p=1, q=1), you should get 3 as your position. Using this you can find the pattern.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@690-------------------------
matrix_at clarification
<p>When the function is called, do we assume that the row/column start at zero or one? I.e. should matrix_at(mat, 1, 1) return the value in the 1st row and column? Or is it the 1st index (which would technically be the value of the second column/row)</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Matrix is 0 indexed, and matrix_at(mat, 1, 1) would return a pointer to the value at row_index 1, column_index 1</p>

------------------------@694-------------------------
matrix
<p>in matrix_init do we change data?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You initialize the matrix with the default value of 0 for all entries.

-------------------------------------------------
You only need to change the height and width of the matrix object in this function. You *can* initialize everything to 0, but the values you're working with will likely be overwritten when you get real data.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>but that also means changing data bc it is apart of the structure</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@695-------------------------
what does std::ostream& os do?

------------------------@696-------------------------
how do we print an element of matrix?
<p>is there a command or function that helps?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am not entirely sure if I get your question. But, there is the Matrix_print() function that needs to be implemented and then you may call that function whenever required. </p>


<p></p>


<p>To print the matrix, you would need to access each element in the matrix and print it out.</p>
<p><br/></p>
<p>[EDIT: Add on by Adviti Mishra] : I’m not entirely sure of the reason you want to print an individual element. If you are asking this question because you want to print out a particular value in the matrix for debugging purposes, I would encourage you to use the visual debugger : ) </p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>like can i say os &lt;&lt; mat[row][col]?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No that won't work. (Sorry if im wrong about anything) but my understanding is that mat is a pointer to a struct with 3 members: width, height, and the data array. You shouldn't look at mat itself as a matrix but instead that it has members containing information <em>about</em> a matrix. To get the matrix we have to find a way to convert the 1-dimension "data" array within mat into a 2-dimension matrix (there is info about this in the spec).</p>


<p>To get access to the elements of the data array you need to dereference the pointer mat and point to the data array, then you can index into whatever value you need from the data array. there's multiple ways to do this but it can be done with the -&gt; operator. i.e. mat-&gt;data(i) would get the ith index of the data array. Remember since data is a 1-d array you can't index into [row][col] like a matrix. I hope this helps</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>That’s correct, check out the instructor solution in case this is for debugging purposes. If not, another way would be to use the Matrix_at function that you may have implemented.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div>
<div></div>
</div>




<div></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am trying to implement the second part of anonymous calc's answer about dereferencing the pointer mat and then make a pointer to the data array. I am trying to do this in my Matrix_at function, however, I am confused on how to derefence mat. I was thinking something like:</p>


<p></p>


<div>
<div>Matrix dereference = *mat;</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>*mat would dereference mat but you inevitably would need to access one of its members, you can do this in two different ways. they both do the same thing.</p>


<p></p>


<p>(*mat).data[i]</p>


<p>This one first dereferences mat (see *mat), which you can now treat like a struct. You use the dot operator "." to access its members - in this example I used data (.data) . And since data is an array you might want to index into it which you do by using the square brackets. ([i])</p>


<p></p>


<p>mat-&gt;data[i]</p>


<p>does the exact same thing as above, but substituting the * and . operators for the arrow operator "-&gt;" this dereferences mat and accesses a member.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@699-------------------------

------------------------@700-------------------------
what does data do? i dont get its purpose or function

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you are referring to the member called "data" in the Matrix struct, it is an array storing the integers in a Matrix.</p>


<p></p>


<p>The data array is the underlying implementation of how integers are stored in the Matrix object, while the 2D Matrix is the interface that users of the Matrix see.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For example, the Matrix represented below to the left has an underlying "data" array as shown below to the right.</p>


<p></p>


<p>[1, 2, 3,</p>


<p>4, 5, 6,        -----&gt;     [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]</p>


<p>7, 8, 9] </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@704-------------------------
How to initialize seam array for Project 2 Processing.cpp
<p>I've been working on Processing.cpp for Project 2, but I am stuck on the seam_carve_width function because it will not compile, due to my array initialization for seam. For some reason, I cannot put in a variable length, but I don't understand how else I can generate the size for the seam. </p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7fig8ilv8x9v%2F331dea8d74b289cc01e4e3ff316a37b93a03ebb9d8a0fd458934db48f0450094%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7fig8ilv8x9v%2Fe40fd33e9cf15fefbb6fd4bee1d0ec22abb6b3df45e3fadd753f7a6ec2d9ba69%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As a rule in c++, you cannot initialize arrays with variable as length. This is because the compiler needs to allocate the correct amount of memory at compile time (before any of the code is run). You’ll have to pick a constant to initialize your array length, something large enough that any array we try will fit.
Check the spec to see what the largest valid array length can be for this project.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@705-------------------------

------------------------@706-------------------------
Question regarding computer memory
<p>Am I allowed to assume all computers will allocate 4 bytes of memory for each int object when writing Matrix_row and Matrix_column, or is there another way?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_9.32.28_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7diwffsv70j1%2Fa0aa9dbdc578ccdbe22f3344c9c127d0414a2c70965fe2cbc816ac33ce5071d1%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_9.32.28_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is a great consideration! However, C++ is smart enough to recognize the type of pointer that is being used (in this case an int *), and will consider the size of the specified type when doing pointer arithmetic. In other words, you wouldn't have to divide by 4 as it is taken into account when performing "ptr - (mat-&gt;data)"</p>


<p></p>


<p>So if ptr is at address 1000 and you run ptr++, if the ptr is an int ptr it will go to address 1004, not 1001. Again, good thought but sometimes C++ will do the hard work for us.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Oops I think line 64 has an error, and it should be return i % Matrix_width(mat); which I think should correctly return the column number</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@707-------------------------
Matrix_Print
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY">Rendering markdown...</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I had a similar issue. instead, you should try int *ptr = &amp;(m-&gt;data); This should get the address you're looking for. I think this is because when you use the -&gt; operator you dereference the m into a struct and then access the data array. Although since you don't actually access the array it should theoretically just give you the address of the first element in the array. Not sure why but adding the ampersand worked for me. Hopefully an instructor will clarify</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>in this case, m is a "pointer to const", meaning that whatever m is pointing to cannot be modified (including the data array). You could declare it as a <code>const int *</code> to fix this. What the student suggested actually shouldn't work, because <code>&amp;(m-&gt;data)</code> will give you a pointer to the whole data array, and dereferencing this pointer will give you the array, which decays to the <em>address</em> of the first element.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY">Rendering markdown...</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY">Rendering markdown...</div>

------------------------@709-------------------------
Matrix_init help
<p>From my understanding, *mat is an object/pointer. I am confused on how to modify *mat. Also I am unsure how to initialize the matrix without using variable length arrays. <img alt="" height="1438" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyntjtu1l910h%2F4934af7b50d6c3916cac4231aed0c5e169151acd12bc813e6fd57474eb10e6b3%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-18_at_11.24.16_PM.png" width="2504"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Remember that you can use the arrow operator (-&gt;) on "mat" to access any of the Matrix functions or member variables. For instance, if there was a name variable on Matrix, you could set the name in matrix_init by writing "mat-&gt;name = "Joe".</p>

------------------------@710-------------------------
How to test Image_print()
<p>I'm trying to test my Matrix_print function in the test file by declaring and initializing a Matrix. I respected the interface by using Matrix_init(), but how can I efficiently fill the matrix with random numbers I create without doing "Matrix testMatrix = {2, 2, {numbers I want}};" and breaking the interface? Would I have to use the Matrix_at() function for every array value I input? I feel like that's just inefficient.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>One good way to do this would be to use Matrix_at() in a double for loop (one loop for row, one for column). You could then utilize the rand() function in C++ (<a href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/random/rand" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/random/rand</a>) to fill in numbers or you could declare a vector of the matrix you want (in 1D form) and index that vector inside of your double for loop. There are many other options on what type of numbers you could put in your matrix, and I encourage you to think about some of the edge cases.</p>


<p></p>


<p>There's some other ways that I can think of off the top of my head, but they'll all be equally tedious. However, I would keep in mind that a good test case isn't always large and should be testing one singular part of your program/function.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hopefully that clears up some of your confusion.</p>
