------------------------@713-------------------------
Remove vertical seam
After I finished copying every element in the img except for the seam element, how do I resize the img?
<br/>
<br/>
Would it be efficient to do Image_init(img, width-1, height) and then loop through every element to copy it into the resized img?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You will want to make sure that you resize and initialize the image before copying elements into it. Your intuition for using the Image_init function seems reasonable, and you would need to loop through and copy each element as the new image you are copying into is not the same size as the original image before seam removal.</p>


<p></p>


<p>This is a great question, and I think other students could benefit from seeing it. If you feel comfortable, feel free to make it public! You can still choose to keep it anonymous. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I do not understand the instructors’ answer on this question.</p>
<p>The p2 spec explicitly states: Do not attempt to use <code>Image_init</code> to “resize” the original - it doesn’t preserve existing data in an <code>Image</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This line in the spec is making it clear that resizing the original image will not be enough to copy the right data and take out the seam.</p>


<p></p>


<p>When I say "make sure that you resize and initialize the image", this refers to the smaller auxiliary image that you are copying into. You will still need to loop through all of your pixels and copy them from the original image to the smaller image. But to even make an "empty" smaller image, you will need to call Image_init on it with a smaller width before you begin copying pixels into it.</p>

------------------------@714-------------------------
problems "adding Quickstart to README"
<p>Hi, I'm at the "modify README" segment of the git setup tutorial and it isn't accepting my pull requests after following the instructions outlined in the tutorial exactly. It says that the current branch has no upstream branch.  Specifically, I did git fetch -&gt; git status -&gt; git diff README -&gt; git add README -&gt; git commit -m "Added quick start to README" -&gt; git push; it didn't work. This is to implement the main function into README which I'm not sure is necessary for the project, I just wanted to be safe.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try running "git push -u origin main" to set main as the upstream branch for your repository. If this does not work, please respond in the follow ups with screenshots of any further errors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F3033bd226f2f00d58fcf7249569b4fd7b4e1f3505e28558ffeba6b6f72bf7dd1%2Fgiterror.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">This is what came up.</a></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F3033bd226f2f00d58fcf7249569b4fd7b4e1f3505e28558ffeba6b6f72bf7dd1%2Fgiterror.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">giterror.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try following these steps:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1) Run "git pull origin main"</p>


<p>2) If you are met with an error about divergent branches, run "<code>git config pull.rebase false"</code></p>


<p>3) Then, run "git pull origin main --allow-unrelated-histories"</p>


<p>4) Retry running "git push -u origin main"</p>


<p></p>


<p>Please follow up again if these steps do not resolve the error!</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@716-------------------------
const confusion
<p>Hi!</p>


<p></p>


<p>I dont understand why you can't perform the folloiwng code.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyzwx70ptf4ut%2F362c8c058dc90dd88cb0c95d7d902532059bc56e7b8a64c91e384b3313f550f5%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Why is there an error on the last step? ptr1 can be modified</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There is a difference between constant pointer and pointer to const. Pointer to constant is a pointer where the value it points to cannot be changed, while constant pointer is a pointer that you cannot change where it is pointing to. In this case, it is not allowing you to set a non const ptr to a const object because it is afraid that you'll use ptr1 to alter the object it is pointing to which is const </p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkeenlspvu32i1%2F36f44a64ec81166039ec240b135f8e137bfcb3c73e289c952f140d16f2edd485%2Fimage.png"/></p>

------------------------@723-------------------------

<p>Hopefully that helps out a little bit.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So is it like this slide explaining the pointer arithmetic but instead the mat* is our array and I use ptr* as the number that is added to it to get the value? <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-19_at_3.17.43_PM_(2).png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7np2kap5yu6ql%2F4065625ea49b33037ec5be0130af3dbcaf6de62bffbfcd553f7095576d0b6752%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-19_at_3.17.43_PM_%282%29.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yeah I think you get the idea. In this example *ptr is pointing to 0x1010 and *ptr3 is pointing to 0x1018. If you were given *ptr and *ptr3 and knew that *ptr was pointing to the array but had no idea where *ptr3 was pointing to in the array, think about how you would be able to find the location (or distance) of *ptr3 in the array.</p>

------------------------@724-------------------------
For tests, are we allowed to use the -> operator?
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I know in the specs it says this:</p>
<p><strong>In particular, no function other than <code>Matrix_row</code>, <code>Matrix_column</code>, and the two versions of <code>Matrix_at</code> should access the <code>data</code> member directly.</strong></p>
<p>Does this apply to writing tests as well? Or are we allowed to directly compare the output Matrix’s fields to the expected values? In particular, I wanted to take a look at <code>mat-&gt;height</code>, <code>mat-&gt;width</code>, and <code>mat-&gt;data</code>.</p>
<p>Thank you!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This does apply to the tests. Respecting the interface is a very important part of this class in general. However, this isn't a major issue as some of the functions you have implemented will do the same thing! For instance, calling Matrix_height(mat) should return the exact same value as calling mat-&gt;height.</p>

------------------------@733-------------------------
martix_at
<p>no instance of overloaded function "Matrix_at" matches the argument list. Does this mean my actual matrix_at function is wrong or am i calling it into a pointer wrong?</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky11a69k1rc6qq%2Fedcb9722823d00fdc90073f8aa55f3385b2c83105aefafb1eedfef6bee48a91d%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>Matrix_at</code> returns a <code>[const] int *</code> type, whereas since <code>pr</code> is a pointer, <code>*pr</code> is of type <code>int</code>. So it’s a type mismatch.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>so i would initialize my pointer at const int *pr instead?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Since <code>pr</code> is already of type <code>int*</code>, you can just set it to the return value of <code>Matrix_at</code>. The brackets around <code>const</code> just means that it can either return <code>int*</code> or <code>const int*</code></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@736-------------------------
Is it possible to compare two ostringstreams to see if they are equal?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, if you do something like: </p>


<p></p>


<div>
<div>ostringstream correct;</div>
<div>correct &lt;&lt; (print whatever you expect to be printed here);</div>
<div>ostringstream actual;</div>
<div>Matrix_print(mat, actual); //actual will get printed inside print function</div>
<div>ASSERT_EQUAL(correct.str(), actual.str());</div>
</div>

------------------------@739-------------------------
How can we make assign a Matrix with values that are not the same (like 1,2,3,4)?
<p>I want to make a Matrix with values 1,2,3,4 in a 2x2 matrix for my test functions. I tried to assign values using "-&gt;" but this does not respect the Matrix interface. Is there another way to assign these values or initialize Matrix with them?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can use the Matrix_at() function, for exmaple, if you wanted to set the the value at row 0 and column 0 to one, it would be something like:</p>


<p></p>


<div>
<div>*Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0) = 1;</div>
</div>



<div>- Remember that Matrix_at() returns a pointer, so we have to use the dereference operator (*) before we set it to a value</div>

------------------------@741-------------------------
Conceptual issue with for loop
<p>I'm using a for loop in one of the functions for matrix.cpp but I get an error when I try to test it.  </p>


<p></p>


<p><code>function(Matrix * mat, int index, int x){</code></p>


<p><code>for(<span style="text-decoration:underline">index</span>; index &lt; x; ++index){</code><code>//error line</code></p>


<p><code>implementation where y is derived using index</code><code></code></p>


<p><code>  }</code></p>


<p><code>return y</code><code></code></p>


<p><code>}</code><code></code></p>


<p>there isn't a squiggly line anywhere but when I try to compile I get</p>


<p>error: expression result unused [-Werror,-Wunused-value]. The error in the command line shows squiggles under the first "index" in the for loop.</p>


<p>Why doesn't this work? I figured since the index would be declared as an int and given a value when the function is called that the for loop should continue as normal, I played around with it in lobster and this seemed to work. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Try just doing "for(; index &lt; x; ++index)"</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This worked. Could you elaborate more on why? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your original approach is logically correct, but your Makefile passes some parameters (i.e. -Wall, -Werror, -pedantic) to your compiler to make it report more warnings/errors, and to treat all warnings as compilation errors. In the line of code "index;", the value of index isn't being used for anything, and the -Wall parameter enables warnings for unused values; -Werror treats this warning as an error, hence the compilation failure you were getting. Replacing "index;" with just ";" removes the unused value, and still works because index is passed in as a parameter to the function, and thus is in-scope for the entire function body. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@742-------------------------
how to test matrix print using unit testing

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There's an example in Matrix_public_test.cpp (test_matrix_print). Essentially you create an ostringstream for your expected output and then an ostringstream for your actual output (pass this into your Matrix_print function), then compare those two using .str()</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@743-------------------------
Having a hard time to start matrix.cpp
<p>Hi I'm really having a hard time to start this project...I feel like i am so unfamiliar with C++ syntax and pointer that i don't really know where to start....I went to the supplemental tutorial and it made a lot of sense to me...but still...<img alt="" height="1800" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxfxo1r1f877a%2F274a2b076e88e74d418ddefe6804b5576e5fbd9cf97527c2d5f31019d7cc9a54%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-19_at_8.39.26_PM.png" width="2880"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Let's start with the Matrix_init function. This function takes in a pointer to a Matrix object (the first parameter) - this is the Matrix object that we are initializing. We're given a width and a height, and all we want to do in Matrix_init is set mat's width and height. Remember that with pointers, you have to use arrow syntax to access its member variables (ie. mat-&gt;width). Instead of setting width and height to 500, you want to set it to the width and height that are passed into the function. Does that help? </p>


<p></p>


<p>The rest of the functions follow a similar pattern. You're always given "mat," which is a pointer to the object you'll be working with. For example, in Matrix_width, you want to return mat's width. Recall the definition for the Matrix struct (in Matrix.h):</p>


<pre><span class="hljs-class"><span class="hljs-keyword">struct</span> <span class="hljs-title">Matrix</span>{</span>
  <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> width;
  <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> height;
  <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> data[MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT];
};<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('c3RydWN0JTIwTWF0cml4JTdCJTBBJUMyJUEwJTIwaW50JTIwd2lkdGg7JTBBJUMyJUEwJTIwaW50JTIwaGVpZ2h0OyUwQSVDMiVBMCUyMGludCUyMGRhdGElNUJNQVhfTUFUUklYX1dJRFRIJTIwKiUyME1BWF9NQVRSSVhfSEVJR0hUJTVEOyUwQSU3RDs=');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>You can use arrow syntax with the mat pointer to return the width member variable of the Matrix object.</p>


<p></p>


<p>It would also really help to watch/review the lectures on pointers and arrays, and make sure you have a solid understanding of how they work. I would really recommend the Runestone async lectures.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So do I need to use struct Matrix to get a new matrix before Matrix_init?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>All of the functions have a passed in Matrix so you should be using the given mat to access its member variables in all functions.</p>

------------------------@744-------------------------
Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row edge case
<p>Will this function not work for matrices with only one column? One of the requires statements is that column_start &lt; column_end. This implies there must be at least two columns for this function to work. Will we not receive any matrices with only one column or is it a case we should not consider?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Remember that column_end is the column one PAST the one you want to end at (so it's non-inclusive). So column_start could be 0 and column_end could be 1 in a matrix with only one column.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@745-------------------------
Row and column indexing
<p>For the matrix_row and matrix_column functions, do we start indexing the rows and column from 0 or 1? For example if we have a 3x3 matrix</p>


<p>{1, 2, 3</p>


<p>4, 5, 6,</p>


<p>7, 8, 9}</p>


<p>and we have ptr pointing to 8, would matrix_row(ptr) return 3 or 2? Would matrix_column(ptr) return 2 or 1? I have a similar question for matrix_width and matrix_height. If it was a 3x3 matrix would they return 3 and 3 or 2 and 2? In the public tests it seems to be that matrix_row and matrix_column are indexed from 1.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Both rows and columns are always indexed starting from 0. </p>


<p></p>


<p>In your example, Matrix_row would return 2 and Matrix_column would return 1 (for a pointer to the 8).</p>


<p>However, Matrix_width and Matrix_height would both be 3, because there are 3 elements in each row and 3 elements in each column (you actually count these).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

array passed to function

------------------------@752-------------------------
partner push problem: access denied
<p><img alt="image.jpegNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gdbkjbt1x5wg%2F3e06e116b7086d987c659e66a8f4d347ae6b8f7c01d311f9a921fc6be752d4d1%2Fimage.jpeg"/></p>


<p>When my partner tries to git push this shows up in his terminal: how do we fix this? when I try to git pull it won't work and my code won't update.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Have you ensured that your partner has access to the remote repository and is able to read and write from it? (aka make changes, push and pull, etc.) You should be able to set those in the settings tab on GitLab, and configure it so your partner can access it. (You can reference <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_git.html#add-team-members" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this</a> on how to add a team member, since it seems they don’t have access)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@753-------------------------
testing Image_init using dog.ppm etc
<p>Hi,</p>


<p></p>


<p>How can I test Image_init with the various .ppm files? Which stream/syntax would I use for this? Or is this something that will come in processing/resize.cpp and should not be done directly from Image_test.cpp?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Essentially how do I pass a .ppm as a parameter to the istream in Image_init</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You may want to look into creating an <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/fstream/ifstream/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">ifstream</a> object with the name of the .ppm file, and passing it into Image_init. If you don't want to read in an entire file, you can also create an <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/sstream/istringstream/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">istringstream</a> object, and pass in your own made-up PPM data as a string. Hope this helps!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: You should only be using stringstream objects (like istringstream and ostringstream) and not ifstream/ofstream. The autograder may not recognize the files you're trying to read in with fstream, so don't use it in your tests.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I can't figure out how to do this. I tried std::istream dog.ppm and it read an error. How do I do this correctly?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You don't want to create an istream object. Instead, you want to create one of its subtypes. If you're trying to read from a file, you'll want to use an <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/fstream/ifstream/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">ifstream</a>. If you want to read from a string (like we do in Image_public_test.cpp), use an <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/sstream/istringstream/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">istringstream</a>.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@754-------------------------
PPM requires check
<p>I'm a bit confused as to how we can assert whether an image is in ppm format without comments. Or is there no assert and we can naturally assume that this requirement will be true?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In EECS 280, you can assume the requires clause of a function will never be violated -- that is, the autograder won't try any inputs that break the requires clause.</p>


<p>It's still good practice to assert requires clauses, but asserting the PPM format is a bit tricky to do meaningfully. A simple check would be to assert the first line of the file is "P3," to indicate it's a "plain PPM file." You could also check that none of the numerical values are negative, and the color intensities don't exceed the specified maximum (which is always 255). Of course, this doesn't promise the entire file is correctly formatted, but I wouldn't worry about robustly checking this invariant.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@755-------------------------
test cases not deleting previous matrix
<p>I am writing test cases for matrix.cpp, and my test case for matrix_fill_border is failing only because the values I'm not filling are taking data from the matrix i created in my previous test case. I added a "delete matrix;" line at the end of my previous test case but the data in those indexes is still carrying over into my next test case. The matrixes have different names and sizes so I have no clue why its doing that and why the previous matrix isn't deleting. Any ideas would be appreciated!!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hello!</p>


<p></p>


<p>If your new operator has a corresponding delete operator in your previous test case, the previous matrix should be getting deleted! </p>


<p></p>


<p>It is always good practice to set ALL the values in your current test matrix to a certain value to prevent a sort of default initialization of values from taking place.  </p>


<p></p>


<p>After you fill your test matrix with a certain value, you can then proceed to test your matrix_fill_border : )</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hello, I'm having this same issue. I have a delete statement at the end of my previous test cases and I'm still getting junk values in future matrices I declare. Was there ever a solution found to this issue? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe setting the entire matrix to a single value like 0 first might help with the random junk values</p>

------------------------@758-------------------------
Understanding pointer
<p>I am having trouble understanding some stuff about the matrix.</p>


<p>First if we are given const Matrix* mat in a function. How do I pull, I should be able to pull for example the first piece of data by doing mat-&gt;data[0] right? if not how do am i suposed to pull data correctly.</p>


<p>Second in this screenshot am i calling any of the pointer incorrectly?</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky11a69k1rc6qq%2F7d50435f37d01111b203a153456f0c1317591943dbc4c8a47ee215e44418d040%2Fimage.png"/> </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You are correct that mat-&gt;data[index] is how you access the Matrix element stored at a given index in the data array.</p>


<p></p>


<p>The goal of the Matrix_column function is to find this index that ptr points to in the data array, and convert it to a column in the matrix.</p>


<p></p>


<p>The spec urges you not to use any loops to determine the column. Instead, I would think of it in the following steps:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1) Find the index in the data array that corresponds to the element pointed to by ptr</p>


<p>2) Determine a formula to convert from the index in the data array to the corresponding column that element would be in for the matrix</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@759-------------------------
set up for project two
<p>After adding my files to my xcode project, there are "A"'s next to the file names. I've never seen these icons before. What do they mean?<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_1.56.15_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1tcryt3tr6my%2Fea7d2d81cad5b5bc551e0cc76a47b17a156cd54826287cde1fa08a878ed5999c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_1.56.15_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is XCode integrating with the Git version control system that you set up with the project 2 version control tutorials. </p>


<p></p>


<p>"A" next to a file means that the file was added to your version control system and did not exist before. You may also see "M" for modified if you made changes to a file that were not seen by Git, or "C" if there is a conflict between your local file and what exists on GitLab.</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you are interested, here is a list of the possible <a href="https://svnbook.red-bean.com/en/1.2/svn.ref.svn.c.status.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">svn status codes</a> and what they correspond to.</p>

------------------------@764-------------------------

------------------------@766-------------------------
matrix max
<p>Confused on how to approach the matrix_max function. Any tips on how to go about finding the max value?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The data is really a 1D array, iterate through it and keep the biggest value. Then return that. In other words, a for loop with an if statement inside.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should approach the problem as iterating through each element in the 2D Matrix, saving off the max, and returning it. You will want to use the other Matrix functions such as Matrix_height, Matrix_width, and Matrix_at to accomplish this.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Are we allowed to reference values from the 1D array in matrix in this function, or do we need to go through the other matrix functions? The guidelines say that</p>


<p></p>


<p>"<strong>In particular, no function other than <code>Matrix_row</code>, <code>Matrix_column</code>, and the two versions of <code>Matrix_at</code> should access the <code>data</code> member directly – call one of these functions instead."</strong></p>


<p><strong></strong></p>


<p>Can we just find the max value of the array in the matrix directly? (i.e. calling (*mat).data[4] )<br/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Good catch! You should use the other matrix functions to iterate through the 2D matrix and find the max. I would not recommend directly accessing mat-&gt;data.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
You can have as many as you want. Note that in their test public cases they used like 8.

<p></p>


<p>but this returns the following error. Can anyone help?</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_6.25.16_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy86i95wko132%2F502f3ee00ea6301e3e4e52afdccbde3e53a49072b999f7e24fdc96b47eba8399%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_6.25.16_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Just had the same error, tried something online, it worked at first then ended up giving a memory leak. What I'm using now is a line of code provided in the processing_public_tests.cpp file, which initializes the array as int seam[MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT]. Seems to work alright.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I did this and it works. However, the REQUIRES clause for the remove_vertical_seam method which needs to be called after this requires that the size of array equals height of matrix. not that it's &gt;= height of matrix. any idea how to get around this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Right I was worried about this too, I am thinking that was a mistake, I'm not sure how they would even check that. The reality is that there is no way to actually check the size of an array that is passed in:</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#assertions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#assertions</a></p>


<p>"Of course, you can’t assert every single thing in the REQUIRES clause. Some of them can’t possibly be checked. For example, you can’t check that a pointer points to a valid <code>Matrix</code> (i.e. one that has been initialized). You also can’t check that the size of an array parameter is large enough, since it’s actually turned into a pointer parameter by the compiler and doesn’t know its size."</p>


<p></p>


<p>So I want to leave this unresolved so maybe we get an answer to this question, but personally, I'm not gonna do anything about it because I think that its fine. They literally initialized it this way in their public tests, so I don't think its not a big deal if they did it too (don't worry this is starter code it's not breaking rules to post this):</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="657" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw74v59av4w2bg%2Feeb0a5b9863f6bce33261e0eee4edae865d4e1af3b836903fd5f995165739d73%2Fimage.png" width="447"/></p>

------------------------@770-------------------------
mat.size
<p>Would a matrix.size() be allowed or even work</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Well, if you know width and height, then you know the size, don't you?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The only elements of a Matrix struct that are accessible with a . operator are width, height, and the data array.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Since there is no size function defined for the matrix struct, matrix.size() would not work.</p>


<p></p>


<p>As the student follow up suggests, the width and height of a matrix are set in Matrix_init, and should be returned in the Matrix_width and Matrix_height functions respectively.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What about the functions that ask you to return them? I assumed you didn't know those values thus you have to figure it out using functions such as .size().</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No those values are set when you initialize, in Matrix_init, and in those functions, e.g. Matrix_width, you simply access that part of the Matrix struct with -&gt;, does that make sense? I think .size() is a vector specific function, there is nothing going on behind the scenes in our case, we get to set everything ourselves. If you are still wondering where the initial width and height come from, those have to be set by the user or some input.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: Marking as resolved.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@771-------------------------
How do I get breakpoints to run?
<p>I am writing test cases for Image.cpp and I added a breakpoint to one of my functions. It is not hitting the breakpoint when I run the test file. How do I get it to do this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yeah as instructor said, our code won't stop because it isn't really that smart. You need to <strong>set up the launch.json file</strong> and then <strong>specify which executable you want it to debug</strong>, and then include the breakpoint in the code (you could set the breakpoint before doing the other stuff, order doesn't matter). I'm not sure which IDE you are using, but you should go to the setup tutorial for how to use the debugger. I am including a link to the VS code debugger tutorial here: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#debug" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#debug</a></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Breakpoints are for using the debugger! They won't stop your program when you are running it normally.</p>

------------------------@775-------------------------
A weird error from public test
<p>There is a segmentation fault reported to me when I did my matrix test. What is that? </p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl54xl3kzaz8jg%2F16d805c07e2bdf6b6653499aed5c224bd35506e8f3ad7435bf00fdcf0584bfbb%2F_____2022-09-20_194900.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">_____2022-09-20_194900.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It is trying to access something out of bounds, essentially. You said "alright, now go get the ball", but it can't get the ball because the ball is in your neighbor's fenced in backyard. Check for where you might be accidentally indexing out of bounds. Hmm, I don't want this to be misleading, the point isn't that you put the ball in a place it can't get to, you just told it to check out a place it can't look at.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You are right. I write a loop with a wrong index. THX</p>

------------------------@776-------------------------
Public test question
<p>im just trying to run the public tests yall gave us but i had a question, aren't I always gonna fail this since the matrix gets filled with 0's then there is an</p>


<div>
<div> int *ptr = Matrix_at(mat, 2, 3);</div>
<div>  ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_row(mat, ptr), 2);</div>
<div>this would fail always because even though *ptr is set to the last index on the matrix there is also a 0 in the beginning and of course everywhere else. So why would we assert_equal that the row that ptr is in which is every row is correct at row 2. Or is the matrix row and column supposed to return the last row or column that the element is in?</div>
<div>
<div>
<div></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The test you are referring to is asserting that the <code>int *ptr</code> obj is pointing to the second row of the matrix. The Matrix_row function should return the row a ptr is pointing to. See the link below for how a 2d matrix is represented in this project.
<a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#implementation" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#implementation</a></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div>
<div>int *ptr = Matrix_at(mat, 2, 3);</div>
<div>yes this is setting the pointer to point at this value, the value is 0</div>
<div>so if doing<br/><div>
<div>ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_row(mat, ptr), 2)</div>
<div>this would be the same if doing</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_row(mat, 0), 2)</div>
<div>which since all the elements in the matrix are 0 then Matrix_row(mat, ptr) will return the row that has value 0 in it first, which would be the very first row since the whole matrix is 0's.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>ptr is pointing to a specific item in the matrix, not just a value. Yes, the value at 2,3 is 0, but the pointer is talking about that zero specifically. </p>


<p>Those two assert statements would not be doing the same thing.</p>


<p>The Matrix_row function returns what row that specific item is in.</p>

------------------------@777-------------------------
Problem with Image_init and "is >>"
<p>I read the earlier post about using "is &gt;&gt;" for the Image_init function in Image.cpp. I followed the instructions in the spec and the code does make sense to me when I read it. However, when I went to test it with the Image_public_test, it fails.</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_8.08.44_PM.pngNaN" height="180" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7i20wztokn2or%2F33cfbe969c5ffb2f071de9913f543b99262f717dd3f3adbc81acd1e7ea0c8b6c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_8.08.44_PM.png" width="460"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_8.09.14_PM.png" height="146" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7i20wztokn2or%2Faeebb8f1f2f65e5b1f12631be0581db947a1ce414400cf47d22cf721b7f65669%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-20_at_8.09.14_PM.png" width="377"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So you have the right idea with the &gt;&gt; operator, but currently, your implementation only reads a couple words/numbers of the whole ppm. To fix this, consider a way we can implement the I/O iteratively for every number in the PPM file.<br/>As for the -1094795586 value, I'm not sure what cout statement that is corresponding to, but a quick run with the debugger should solve that issue.</p>

------------------------@779-------------------------
init  function purpose ?
<p>Hey , So with the init function am I trying to just make a blank array that will serve as a blank matrix of the specified dimensions. If so what is the purpose of the pointer.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Or am I making it so that the pointer given is the address of the first element in our blank array therefore matrix that will be constructed using the dimensions provided</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>Or is it something else .</p>


<p></p>


<p>Pls help.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The init function just takes in the <span style="text-decoration:underline">already made</span> matrix and sets its width and height in the matrix struct. That's it, just like 2 lines of code.</p>


<p></p>


<p>In general, what you'll have is some code in a different file altogether that says the following:</p>


<p>Matrix* mat = new Matrix;</p>


<p>int width = 5;</p>


<p>int height = 6;</p>


<p>Matrix_init(mat, width, height);<br/>...</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>delete mat;</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So then what do we do with the pointer ? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The pointer is the address of the matrix. At this address is the home of a matrix, which has the matrix struct. To get all the matrix's stuff to him, you need to follow this address, and then deliver this stuff. That looks like this:</p>


<p></p>


<p>mat-&gt;width = width;</p>


<p></p>


<p>You use the pointer to deliver the information.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Like do we need to pass by pointer and input matrix data when we call the  init function? or are we just calling this function to make a blank matrix of the desired size. Like what doe we need to use mat for ?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No init is very simplistic, really. You don't need to multiply, or prepare cells, or put data in, nothing like that. Nothing even to do with any arrays. Init uses no arrays, anywhere. Init is just used to label the matrix's home with the values of the matrix width and the matrix height.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So we are calculating the width , height , and matrix size using the function inputs and then using the pointers to deliver those values to a struct at that address?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There won't be any calculations necessary, but that's the idea. Imagine the init function as a delivery person, it just takes the prepared information of matrix width &amp; height from someone, and it delivers it to the matrix object that was created, so now the matrix knows the integer value of width &amp; height. It is quite simply just the following (with an analogous line for height that is almost exactly the same, if I wrote that part here I would literally be sharing the entire Matrix_init function, without the assertions):</p>


<p>mat-&gt;width = width;</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Also, if it helps, calling "Matrix *mat = new Matrix;" does not specify the width and height of the array, it only initializes the structure and it's members. That's where the Matrix_init() function comes into play; setting specifically what the members of "mat" are.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@780-------------------------
-> pointers
Can someone kind of explain how we use -> with pointers?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>That's how you input something into a struct that you only have the address for (the pointer for).</p>


<p><a href="https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cplusplus/cpp_member_operators.htm" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://www.tutorialspoint.com/cplusplus/cpp_member_operators.htm</a></p>


<p>This link gives examples, but in p2 terms, this is how:</p>


<p>int width = 5;</p>


<p>mat-&gt;width = width;</p>


<p></p>


<p>Where mat is a Matrix type object, which has the member "width".</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can think of the <kbd>-&gt;</kbd> operator as equivalent to dereferencing a pointer and then using the <kbd>.</kbd> operator to access a member of the object being pointed to.</p>


<p></p>


<p>In other words, <kbd>ptr-&gt;x</kbd> is equivalent to <kbd>(*ptr).x</kbd></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@781-------------------------
completely lost on image_init
<p>I can't figure out how to use an istream passed in through image_init and read it, the instructors said somewhere else to create a separate istream object with the same name but I don't know how that even works. How do I even get all the individual numbers using cin? I tried looking through the lecture notes but it just prints out each individual word I don't know where it's stored.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So, you don't want to cin anything, I actually don't know what they were talking about with a separate istream object, that doesn't sound like it belongs inside our Image_init implementation. Anyways, it's just a little trick that they hinted at in the specs:</p>


<div>
<div>is &gt;&gt; filetype &gt;&gt; width &gt;&gt; height &gt;&gt; max;</div>
<div>Read in stuff just like this. The "is" is the input stream passed into the function, so you can literally just type this line into your code and it will work. You'll need to declare the variables before this line, so something like std::string filetype; and be sure to #include &lt;string&gt; at the top. Also, for the reading in of the pixel data, use the following in a for loop (you'll also need to declare these):</div>
<div>
<div>is &gt;&gt; red &gt;&gt; green &gt;&gt; blue;</div>
<div>And then pass each thing into img. This trick is somewhat hard to find on your own, so I wanted to just share it outright. I don't think it counts as dishonesty, may the instructors strike it down if they think it is. You also won't need cout here, if you were considering that.</div>
<div>The reason the trick works is that the arrows will essentially skip past white space, tabs, and new lines, meaning they just collect the information that is useful, like words and stuff. It's like magic!</div>
</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As the student response mentions, you can essentially treat an <code>istream</code> object like it is a <code>cin</code> and read in input using the <code>&gt;&gt;</code> operator. Instead of getting input from the user from the standard input device (like a keyboard), <code>istream</code> takes information from an existing file and feeds it into your program, as if it was coming in via <code>cin</code>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>And it is pretty magical! You don’t really have to worry about spacing, new lines, etc. - your program will know where you last left off in reading in info, so you can pick right off the next time you use <code>&gt;&gt;</code>.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
why do we need to declare the variables before this line, so something like std::string filetype??
<br/>
Why can not I  use like below?
<br/>
is >> width >> height;

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Well... you need the variables used for width and height; or else, where will you store the information?</p>


<p></p>


<p>As for string type, the first line in the example PPM file in the specs has "P3" which is a string type.</p>


<p></p>


<p>How can you collect this info and store it in a string variable?</p>


<p></p>


<p>The same way:</p>


<p></p>


<p>string file_type;</p>


<p>is &gt;&gt; file_type:</p>


<p></p>


<p>**wonder if we can use namespace std</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you use this line , "is &gt;&gt; red &gt;&gt; green &gt;&gt; blue;" the variables cannot be pixels because the complier does not allow this, so would it just be ints? And if it is, how would you put the ints into the get pixel function considering it only takes Pixels?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I have this same question! I tried creating a temporary Pixel variable, reading in red, green, and blue as ints, and then setting each one to tempPixel.r (or .g, or .b) but then how do you indicate the specific color when you call Image_set_pixel?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yeah, red, green and blue are ints. For each of the red/green/blue values, you need to change the values in the respective channels for each color. I don't know how much I can say without this getting flagged for cheating, but use Matrix_at with each of img's channels in a nested for loop. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>That being said I'm sure you can make a tempPixel as someone else said that they did that and it worked. Either way prob works.</p>

------------------------@783-------------------------
Image_init with istream
<p>In the Image_init function where you pass in an istream, are we supposed to be filling the red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel of the Image or are we supposed to be using the Pixel struct for something in this function. A little confused about what this function is asking us to do besides to initialize the image with the given width and height. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
Soo... the answer to this is a little complicated. In this one, you are going to actually read in all of the data and stuff from a .ppm. See
<a data-pats="post_ref" href="781" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('781');">@781</a>
 for some tips for how to do that. In case you want some more hints, here you go:

<ol><li>You will probably want to use a temp Pixel variable</li><li>You will want to use the Image_set_pixel function</li><li>You will want to use the other Image_init function inside of the Image_init function</li><li>You'll want a 2D for loop</li><li>You'll really want to use the tip in <a data-pats="post_ref" href="781" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('781');">@781</a></li></ol>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You're on the right track! As per the RME for Image_init, this function is supposed to initialize an Image based upon the values in the istream, which holds a representation of an image in <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#ppm-format" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">PPM format</a>. Since this PPM file contains preset RGB values for the various pixels of the image, you'll definitely want to make use of these values to initialize your image.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Post 782 is not available, did you mean to reference <a data-pats="post_ref" href="781" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('781');">@781</a>?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes! <a data-pats="post_ref" href="781" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('781');">@781</a> has some very helpful information.</p>

------------------------@785-------------------------
What is matrix_print supposed to print exactly?
<p>I am very confused by the rme of matrix_print. I get the first line, but the second line makes no sense to me. What does "print the rows of the matrix to os with one row per line. each element is followed by a space and each row is followed by a new line." mean? </p>


<p></p>


<p>The matrix public test did not seem to help me too much. Why does it call matrix_at? I thought someone said to implement the functions in order so how are we supposed to do matrix_print? </p>


<p></p>


<p>I just don't necessarily get what is supposed to be printed out.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So, lets say we had a matrix like this:</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="74" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw74v59av4w2bg%2Faa27b354b71a12aac3e5a00bd5b08cd4453d93e49862dbc0bc45b0c15223659a%2Fimage.png" width="74"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>What do we want to print?</p>


<p>We want to print the following (2 2 is width and height of the matrix):</p>


<p>2 2</p>


<p>1 2 </p>


<p>3 5</p>


<p></p>


<p>Now, it may be unclear where the spaces are, so I'll make it more clear. Here, a "_" means a space:</p>


<p>2_2</p>


<p>1_2_</p>


<p>3_5_</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also I don't know who said to implement them in order, Matrix_at is very useful in this. You'll need a 2D for loop that goes through the row and column dimensions, using Matrix_at to retrieve the value at that entry, then give that to the output stream.</p>

<p>Seems like you might have some undefined behavior. Do you have all the sanitizer warnings enabled? What I mean is that your code could be accessing parts of memory that are not marked as safe, so sometimes they are overwritten, and sometimes they happen to be there when you look at them. It would be the equivalent of getting lucky.</p>

Within this file, they have a load_matrix function that reads in a matrix from a file. Now, I think we could probably steal this from them and put it at the top of matrix.cpp (I actually don't know if that would cause an error or not, we def cannot edit matrix.h because we are not submitting this), or just manually make a matrix and set each entry using *Matrix_at(mat_correct, row, col), but that seems hard. -------------------------------------------------
<p>You are definitely not required to use these functions, you are more than welcome to though if you want. </p>


<p></p>


<p>To use Matrix_equal, you would have to create two Matrices: one that you're testing on and one that has your expected output.</p>


<p></p>


<p>We primarily use Array_equal to test seams for processing. This would probably be the only scenario I would use it in.</p>

------------------------@795-------------------------
Matrix print
<p>May we use loop function on matrix_print?</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_9.31.25_AM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkyjgk5364g37nt%2Fc619abb787aacea335ea50d77825a858aa1e1f591926d014e4d7a5a87b136cf5%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_9.31.25_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Using for loops for something like Matrix_print is perfectly fine! You have to access/print every element of the matrix for this function, so doing it with a for loop makes a lot of sense.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For function like Matrix_at, Matrix_row, Matrix_column, you really only care about a single element of the matrix, so we just want to warn that using a for loop for these functions is not necessary and will potentially cause slow runtime.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@796-------------------------
weird number for red channel initialization only
<p>As a follow up to my previous post, this is private and below is my code for both Matrix_init and Image_init.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="167" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7c84hh3kqv3cf%2Ff8f5a8b4d24545bbfe20aae27b78ff452f4169f2869ea7e01211f6ea0d5e361d%2F1.png" width="574"/><img alt="" height="236" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7c84hh3kqv3cf%2F58066bd71847d915f7eab8624c4a2d84390ee4cdcc17044b544492f4c7107568%2F2.png" width="500"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Looking at your code it seems like you are placing a 0 at the end of the data array and not modifying the rest of it. Remember, arrays are given a size upon initialization (the values inside the array are undefined by default). Take another look at the description for Matrix_init and see if you are doing what is required by the function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But I found that even though its set to zero, why do the green channel and blue channel fill up completely with zeros while only the red channel is the one thats odd?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img src="https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1019786858001088512/1021969287138779169/1.png"/><img src="https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/1019786858001088512/1021969287533035540/1.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I actually wouldn't worry too much about this. All the Matrix_init and <span style="text-decoration:underline">this</span> Image_init functions are asking you to do is initialize the given Matrix/Image with the given width/height (per. the RME for these functions). We don't have any expectations of what the values are in a Matrix data array until they are externally specified (for example via. Matrix_fill, Matrix_at, etc.).</p>


<p></p>


<p>That said, for the other version of Image_init which also takes an input stream as a parameter, you will be initializing the RGB channels with specific values. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@797-------------------------
uncaught exception of type problem
<p>When I try to run my matrix_tests, it shows problems like this. How can I solve this?</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyu583mfo13ie%2F43da4753769fd738e4d464fd57b8837b113361a694557d18d8f5118e2fbecd6f%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think this means you need to have your test names not have any periods in them. If you named your test <code>train_small.csv</code> try naming it <code>train_small_csv</code>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>If that doesn’t work, try making sure your <code>TEST_MAIN()</code> is below all of your tests (the tests must come first).</p>

------------------------@799-------------------------
How do I fix memory leaks that occur in the LeakSanitizer?
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>The UB checks on the autograder say that my code has a memory leak every time I do something like <code>Pixel *pixel = new Pixel;</code> and I’m not sure how to fix that (since I do need to instantiate a new object). Would I need to delete the objects at some point to fix this or what should I do?</p>
<p>Additionally, the leak sanitizer won’t work since my compiler claims it does not support <code>-fsanitize=leak</code>, so how should I go about looking for memory leak issues?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, you need to free dynamically allocated memory. Use the delete operator to do that.</p>


<p></p>


<p>This <a href="https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/new-and-delete-operators-in-cpp-for-dynamic-memory/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">article</a> might be helpful for you.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To clarify: any time you use the `new` keyword, you will need to use the `delete` keyword on the object you allocated once you are done using it, to ensure all memory allocated is deallocated, and nothing is leaked.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Alright, I’ve found some places where I can delete the objects but there are methods I can’t change (in public tests) that call <code>Image_get_pixel</code> but do not delete the pixel afterwards. What should I do to avoid memory leaks here?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I don't believe your Image_get_pixel function should return a pointer to the Pixel struct.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So I get the inclination to use "new" for a new variable of the Pixel type, but that isn't necessary here, just declare it like normal:</p>


<p>Pixel example;</p>


<p></p>


<p>or if you want to define it:</p>


<p>Pixel example = {1, 56, 105};</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!! I got similar errors when I tried to new Array, and then I realized it wasn't necessary.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Yeah, I figured as much considering <code>new Pixel</code> causes it to be stored in dynamic memory. I changed it to initialize the Pixel without using new and it worked fine.</p></div>

------------------------@801-------------------------
matrix max const
<p>currently working on matrix max, iterating thru data 1d array to find the max value. but because the matrix is a const, i can't do it the way i am used to, since i can't assign a variable(max) to a value of data. if i make max (the variable) a const, i can't change it later if i find a higher value. am i missing something simple? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A very common "max" algorithm is to keep track of the largest value you have seen so far:</p>


<div>
<div>    if(example[i]&gt;max){</div>
<div>      max = example[i];</div>
<div>    }</div>
</div>


<div>You'll have to initialize max to some value, typically either a really low value (negative, so like -2000000000), or to the first value of the array, and then subtract one from that value. You won't need to modify the matrix at all, and max can be overwritten (max is not a const).</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yup, this is exactly what I am trying to do. But VS Code is telling me "expression must have class type but it has type "const Matrix *"</p>


<p>Maybe something else is wrong here. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok do you have this line and it causes errors?</p>


<div>
<div>max = mat-&gt;data[i];</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>oh my god i just realized i wrote mat.data and not the arrow. thanks !!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Happy to help! :)</p>

------------------------@804-------------------------
array passed to function
<p><img alt="1663639604817.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7jqibclt6ten%2Ffe5756f8085edf2dc7a690d7419a46420007e958ed2aac3b089a95d986fe6711%2F1663639604817.png"/>When I passed seam[] to the find seam function, it seemed that seam is not passed as an array, and every change I made on other elements of seam array did not work. As is shown in the list of variables, there is only a "*seam".</p>


<p>Even if I assign *seam with 1, the point is, the array seems to lose its size. In the main function, it was assigned with size 500, but when passed into the function, it only shows one space with value 0, and doesn't change anymore. For example, while I'm debugging, in the main function , the seam is shown as an array with size 500:<img alt="1663707785534.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7jqibclt6ten%2Fd3ead30b4abf2e569486a6e1b122d667d1f1ea82846f373cb917fe9d3e0f768c%2F1663707785534.png"/>.When I step into the function, <img alt="1663707816758.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7jqibclt6ten%2F18c43920aeeaf02bc9ee02f94cc823735aa1f5d017a2442690a612ffb23dd2d0%2F1663707816758.png"/>the seam changed.Even when I try to assign"seam[0] = 1;seam[1] = 2;", nothing changed,there still shows"*seam = 0"</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>This should be fine. Basically when you pass the array into the function, you don’t pass in any information to indicate how long it is. Because of that, the debugger cannot assume that your array is of length 500, and so it defaults to just showing the dereference of the first element.</p>
<p>Note that when you pass in the array like this, array decay occurs and you really get an <code>int *</code>. So all the debugger can assume it has in this state is a pointer, not the entire array. Does that make sense?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But when stepping out of this function, the seam[] has not be changed, and the program failed.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Ah that’s different then. Just to make sure is this after compiling the code and running again (just to make sure you’re not running on out-of-date code)? <code>seam[0] = 1</code> should overwrite the value in <code>seam[0]</code>.</p>
<p>It’s a little hard to judge based on only what you’ve provided, so you may want to hop into office hours so someone can take a closer look.</p></div>

os in Matrix_print() Function
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F7f71ff7f9a4929a40be47c915df8a8dca943e3993f3003f6aec6406c09ce2ab6%2Fimage.png"/></p>

<p></p>


<p>Edit: I did some research and since "cout" is an object of "ostream", when we call Matrix_print(), the second parameter of Matrix_print() would be "cout", correct?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><code>ostream</code> works like <code>cout</code> similar to how <code>istream</code> can be a replacement for <code>cin</code> when reading in a file (so you can just print to <code>os</code> like <code>os &lt;&lt; "hello!"</code>. Yes, if you wanted to call <code>Matrix_print()</code> somewhere in your code and print to console, you would pass in <code>cout</code>.</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@811-------------------------
RME in cpp files
<p>Just a quick style question, are we allowed to delete the RME from the cpp files once we finish the functions in order to clean up the code?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We do not recommend doing that since RME is actually good style (rather than messing up the code). Leaving proper explanations of what a function does is helpful for future maintenance.</p>

------------------------@812-------------------------
pointer arithmetic
<p>I think if a pointer which points to the second element of an array subtract a pointer which points to the first element of an array, the result is one.  However, what will happen if both pointers point to first element and subtract each other?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your understanding of the first scenario is correct. For the second scenario, the result would be 0 - any number / any address subtracted by itself is 0.</p></div>

------------------------@817-------------------------
When are we allowed to use mat-> to access the struct directly?
<p>I'm under the impression that within Matrix.cpp we can only use mat-&gt;data in four functions. Namely, Matrix_row, matrix_column and both Matrix_at. Additionally, we should only use mat-&gt;width/height in Matrix_width and Matrix_height. In all other cases we should be calling the previous functions (Matrix_at/width/height) to accomplish the task. Is this correct, or do we have freedom to use mat-&gt; wherever we want within Matrix.cpp?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Oh you can use that whenever, since it is within the matrix module, you are always allowed to use mat-&gt;data and mat-&gt;width and height. It might be considered bad practice, but you can always do that inside of matrix.cpp. Outside of it, you should never use it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For structs, the members are <code>public</code> by default. That means you can always do mat-&gt;width, but this doesn't mean it is good practice trying to get the members directly (later in the class, you will see why we need <code>class</code> which solved this issue to some extent).</p>


<p>I think in your Matrix.cpp whenever you need to get the width, feel free to use either mat-&gt;width or Matrix_width. Outside Matrix.cpp, it is better practice to just use Matrix_width. Same for the height. You may notice whenever you use mat-&gt;width, you have the ability to write the value (the write permission could be dangerous sometimes), but with Matrix_width, you can only read the width but cannot write the value (safer when you only need to read).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@818-------------------------
resolved
<p>resolved</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>marking resolved</p></div>

------------------------@819-------------------------
question of Matrix_column and Matrix_row
<p>when I am doing matrix_coumn and matrix_row, I used "ptr - mat-&gt;data" to calculate the distance between the pointer given and data[0]. But whe I am dubugging, it shows that the distance is a number which is totally far away from the number I want to get. How can I solve this?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyu583mfo13ie%2F171955b0813d89e9c8adc680a29710e7516818bb75e1c563bce7377dd4287113%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Is that the initial value or the value after the line is run? I mean that in the debugger, it will display some random value from what was stored in memory while it highlights the line of code that will reset it. Only once it gets past this line has it set it. As far as your code itself goes, I have the same line and it works, so you can rest assured knowing that your code is fine.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Like the student said, before the variable gets initialized, it just contain whatever lived on that memory address. It could be some junk value left by a previous program.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I also use this same line of code, but am getting the warning that "Implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'long' to 'int.' It still compiles, but should I be concerned about this and how it will run through the autograder?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You shall be good with just  ptr - mat-&gt;data.</p>


<p>The default data type for this is long which is long int, and long has a larger range than int which is why you may get the warning. You can also explicitly transfer the data type by doing something like</p>


<p><code>long a = 10;</code></p>


<p><code>int b = (int) a;</code></p>


<p>In this case, you won't get such warnings for the second line.</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@821-------------------------
Matrix_at type error with const int* and const int
<p>We're getting this error when my partner try to compile Matrix_at</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt02uj5j6zj60n%2F5fcddfcda5fd4275e8856b2f8d51a455e8d86495f66100b67856e842041da396%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>We are dividing a const int* by a const int, and were wondering if it is a problem with the / symbol, or if we just need our types to both be const int or both const int*.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Dividing pointer by integer, I think that is not allowed. I would suggest subtracting another pointer from the first pointer to get an integer difference, if you know what I mean.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Remember that the value of a point is an address, and an address is something like 0xbfdb70f0. Think about why division or multiplication does not make sense for addresses (The start address of an array is not necessarily 0x0, and it can change every time you run your project.), but we can do additions and subtractions (with some limits).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@822-------------------------
about matrix_at
<p>Hi i have a few questions about Matrix_at:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1. which pointer are we looking at? Is it mat? Do i need to create a ptr myself?</p>

I know that i can use row and column and width/height to get the 1d index, but after that what kind of command should i use to get the address of that object and let our ptr point to it?????</p>


<p>3.What's the difference between</p>


<p></p>


<p><b>int</b>* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, <b>int</b> row, <b>int</b> column)</p>


<p></p>


<p>and</p>


<p></p>


<p><b>const</b> <b>int</b>* Matrix_at(<b>const</b> Matrix* mat, <b>int</b> row, <b>int</b> column)</p>


<p></p>


<p>like, what do they mean by pointer-to-const?</p>


<p></p>


<p>I am so unfamilier with c++....Geez this is so hard for me...</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you !!!</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>1. <span style="text-decoration:line-through">The pointer is mat</span><span style="text-decoration:underline">[The pointer that we want to return is not a pointer points to a Matrix]</span> and it is passed in to the function. You will have to return a pointer, <span style="text-decoration:line-through">so just use the &amp; to reference whatever thing it is "at"</span>[<span style="text-decoration:underline">No you don't want to use either reference or dereference operators, it is pointer arithmetics</span>].</p>


<p>2. It sounds like you are really close, here is some pseudo-ish code to help you:</p>


<div>
<div> [<span style="text-decoration:underline">Deleted. The student provided too much details that we want you to figure out by yourself.</span>]</div>
<div>3. Don't worry, we're all new to this. The difference is that the second one can handle times when other functions specify that the matrix will be constant. The first one has the ability to change the matrix, and the second one doesn't, but the implementation is exactly the same. [<span style="text-decoration:underline">Think about why their implementations should be the same</span>]</div>
</div>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: Oops! I didn't mean to provide too much info, I'll be more careful in the future. Anyways, instructor is right about 1, I just didn't realize it, it should just be pointer arithmetic, anything more than that is just redundant code.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>1. From the RME of the function, "mat points to a valid Matrix", "Returns a pointer to the element in the Matrix at the given row and column". So max is given (data type: Matrix *), but what you want to return is a pointer that points to an element in the Matrix (data type: int *).</p>


<p>2. I recommend checking lab 3 again. Remember the elements of an array are stored contiguously in memory. In other words, they are next to each other. So if a pointer points to the first element, what is the thing that the pointer (pointer+1) points to? You may do the math and find the pointer that points to the wanted element.</p>


<p>3. Here is a <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/06_Compound_Objects.html#the-const-keyword" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">link</a> to the note of EECS 280 which explains what const is.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Pointers are definitely difficult (and important). Project 2 is designed to give you a better idea of what are pointers, and how they work, so don't worry too much if you get confused at first sight.</p>

------------------------@824-------------------------
Incompatible integer to pointer conversion
<p>Hi i have an error saying "Incompatible integer to pointer conversion assigning to 'int *' from 'int'", and i am not quite sure what's going on...<img alt="" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxfxo1r1f877a%2F5883c6c7ed0cf21f55636ac8d76f167ace4caa67d526ab40c1b57c494b91a6fa%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_6.39.10_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>row * (mat-&gt;width) + column</code> ends up being an <code>int</code> value, but <code>ptr</code> itself is an <code>int *</code> type. These are not the same - <code>int *</code> is an address while <code>int</code> is just a number.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@826-------------------------
Error in tests
<p>Hi, </p>


<p></p>


<p>Can I have help with the following error. I am working with the function: find_minimal_cost_seam(). It seems to not run because of an out of bounds error. I'm also confused a bit by the spec. Is the seam at a certain row equal to the minimum of the three pixels above or below it?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_6.49.15_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy86i95wko132%2F8d648a23527cf1e71f2fec21205f5136b449fc2ab01cd6ffe88cc729703566a9%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_6.49.15_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>So for find_minimal_vertical_seam you’re working from bottom of the matrix to the top. Seam is an array, so each item in seam corresponds to the minimum cost pixel for that row.</p>
<p>To find the minimum cost pixel at any row <code>i</code>, you choose the minimum index of the 3 values in the row above it, as shown in the diagram. It’s easy to get out of bounds errors here since at each end of the matrix, there will only be 2 values to choose from. You should also consider that there is no row <strong>above</strong> row 0.
<img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkeeutacclj53vw%2Fc8878176eb5b84a334bd152eebb456544537dd766b48594dae54c58258bb206d%2Fimage.png"/></p></div>

------------------------@827-------------------------
Why is char** the same as char*[] ?
<p>Why is char** the same as char*[] ?</p>


<p>How to interpret char**?</p>


<p>Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>char** is a char pointer to a pointer. char *[] can be interpreted as an array of char pointers. Because of array decay, we also get a char pointer to a pointer.</p>

------------------------@830-------------------------
matrix init help
<p>hi, how should we go about initializing the matrix? i'm a bit confused on how we're supposed to do it</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Don't worry it's easy. Just copy the assertions to start, and then set the width and height. That's it. Doing this is not so bad, for instance, this is how you set the width:</p>


<p>mat-&gt;width = width;</p>


<p>Because mat is a pointer to a matrix type variable, it needs the -&gt; to set the width attribute of the struct (instead of the dot, as usual, like mat.width wouldn't work here), and then it uses "width" on the left as the keyword.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: I deleted the example the student listed earlier. It was not wrong, but I don't think it really relates to how you want to handle a pointer or set some attributes of an instance of a struct. It might make things more difficult to understand.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: I should have gone about that differently, I only meant to say that mat-&gt;width=width; is very confusing, and we must do that because the matrix struct has width as one of its attributes:</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="73" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw74v59av4w2bg%2F7c3f0c26b6051c9b4bad132ab1334c347983b2907e86739ae9cf856cfcd5d0f4%2Fimage.png" width="321"/></p>


<p>And we were provided with code that had declaration lines like this:</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="16" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw74v59av4w2bg%2F75baafa929f0a24012721d8860f1012ab4d9cb326178781f160de56e2244cc4c%2Fimage.png" width="275"/></p>


<p>So I thought people might be confused about what the -&gt; operator is doing.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><a data-pats="post_ref" href="779" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('779');">@779</a></p>

------------------------@831-------------------------
What is the point of having the int* and const int* versions of matrix_at?
<p>What is the point of having the int* and const int* versions of matrix_at?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>One is for changing the matrix, the other is for accessing the matrix and it has compatibility with function calls that pass in a constant matrix. It's good practice because it will help prevent us from changing a matrix when we don't want to.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@832-------------------------
"c style string" for resize
<p>In the spec, it says for us to use c-style strings when processing command line arguments. Why is this mentioned as a requirement when automatically, the elements in argv[] are all c-style strings? Am I missing something?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Nope, you're not missing anything. That part in the spec implies that you need to use argv to create the command line prompt for resize.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@833-------------------------
Tips for Test Cases
<p>I've been struggling to expose the bugs for Matrix.cpp and Image.cpp. Is there specific functions where the bugs are, or specific cases I should think about? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When I think about test cases, I think about what could break my implementation. Typically any function that has a loop of some sort (while, for) are broken by out of bounds errors. Look at how you implemented your functions and think about what out of bounds errors could occur. Also think about size of the data. Will a larger number or a larger amount of data impact the results? </p>


<p></p>


<p>This is a great question! I am sure others would find the information useful. If you feel comfortable, would you mind making this post public so other students can read it? You can mark your name as Anonymous if you want!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>
