------------------------@834-------------------------
Confusion with seam_carve_width() function
<p>I am a bit confused on the implementation of the seam_carve_width() function. I followed the exact steps from the spec, but I'm in sort of an awkward position where I'm creating a seam array, then have to pass it to the remove_vertical_seam() function that takes a CONST seam array. Is my implementation completely wrong or am I missing something?</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_9.42.47_PM.pngNaN" height="147" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7i20wztokn2or%2F1dcc1b33e72af88dab4a715647608c3071cde2e767ff35c8c07f911ead7a3faf%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-21_at_9.42.47_PM.png" width="356"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Edit: That is because you cannot initialize the array as something that could change each time you run it. Instead, initialize it with the maximum matrix height, as is done in several of the test files.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Oh shoot I meant to send it to instructors only. How can I delete it?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Here I'll delete it for you :) -- nvm looks like you got it</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>All good now, only a handful of people saw that, and plus its not a big deal (people do it on accident all the time). I haven't ever done a private post but I'm sure you'll find it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So just wondering, does this mean we can violate the requires clause of remove vertical seam?</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="82" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkzhw6s5i2wb5qp%2Fc54b6e91d4089410c284cf55644ba0a2cbba5e862edfb1e08e5d6e1fb5ece4b2%2Fimage.png" width="600"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Not really. Since you need to create an array with a defined size, you have to initialize it to the max matrix width because it is const and doesn't change. However, in your implementation you should only fill in the array up to the width. So if the width was 5, you fill in 5 of the array elements. That's why the requires clause says the size of the seam rather than the size of the array of the seam.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should use the debugger to find where the error starts. There’s a million places it could be, but fortunately, the debugger will let you find it. If you don’t know how to use it yet, right now is the best time to learn!! One second I’ll find the link for it:</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: So here's the link for the vscode debugging method:</p>


<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#run" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_vscode.html#run</a></p>


<p></p>

<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run</a></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>it means that somewhere in your image.cpp you're indexing out of bounds in your matrix (i.e. row is less than 0 or greater than height). would recommend stepping through your code to find exactly where as the student suggested!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks for all the help! I figured out my issue was that I wasn't initializing the 3 different matrices in one of the init functions.</p>

------------------------@841-------------------------
Confused about Matrix_fill
<p>So  for the Matrix fill function , are we supposed to be filling values at the pointer proved for our mat. I am confused about where we get those values from , is that the ppm file? In general for when I am just writing the function should I just be using a ifstream to stream values into my function to fill in an array at the pointer of mat , so that I can actually start using the other matrix functions ?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
No in matrix fill you just fill a provided matrix with all the same value (that is also provided). It is just matrix stuff, it has nothing to do with any external files (no use of any streams or any .ppm). You just iterate through a matrix and set each entry to “value”.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ohhhhh so in the spec when they say "none of these function using nested loop" they just mean column, row, and width function don't need for loop but others actually need....</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yeah! :)

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But why do we need another function specially for the border values though??? this confuses me a lot, I think i can implenmenting the matrix_fill by go through the whole 1d matirx( #of elements calculated with the width and height of the 2d matrix) , why do we need to treat the border elements differently?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Oh it’s not that you need a special function for them, it’s that sometimes the user might want to *just* fill the border values, or in fact, you will want to just fill the border values when writing image.cpp

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks a lot!!! And also,  when they say"border", there are four borders right...they are the first row, the last row, the first column, the last column?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
That’s right!

------------------------@846-------------------------
Matrix Row and Column
<p>For the matrix row and column value that we return in Matrix_row and Matrix_column, are we returning an int value as if we are indexing (starting the rows/column number at 0) or regularly (starting at 1)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Matrix_row and Matrix_column should return row/column values starting at zero. This should match Matrix_at(), which takes zero-based row/column numbers as input.</p>

------------------------@848-------------------------
setprecision()
Does setprecision(20) mean that we’re rounding up the number for twenty decimal places?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>set precision sets the number of decimal places to print for a floating point value, i.e.: </p>


<p></p>


<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">double</span> x = <span class="hljs-number">3.141592</span>;
<span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::setprecision(<span class="hljs-number">2</span>);
<span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; x &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;
<span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::setprecision(<span class="hljs-number">5</span>);
<span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; x &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('ZG91YmxlJTIweCUyMD0lMjAzLjE0MTU5MjslMEFzdGQ6OmNvdXQlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjBzdGQ6OnNldHByZWNpc2lvbigyKTslMjAlMEFzdGQ6OmNvdXQlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjB4JTIwJTNDJTNDJTIwc3RkOjplbmRsOyUwQXN0ZDo6Y291dCUyMCUzQyUzQyUyMHN0ZDo6c2V0cHJlY2lzaW9uKDUpOyUwQXN0ZDo6Y291dCUyMCUzQyUzQyUyMHglMjAlM0MlM0MlMjBzdGQ6OmVuZGw7');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>would print:</p>


<p>3.1</p>


<p>3.1416</p>


<p></p>


<p>does that help?</p>


<p></p>


<p>(<a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/iomanip/setprecision/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://cplusplus.com/reference/iomanip/setprecision/</a>)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@849-------------------------
How to compute "energy" in processing.cpp
<p>So for the function "computer_energy_matrix" in processing.cpp, we need to "Compute the energy for each non-border pixel" <img src="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/images/energy_matrix.svg"/></p>


<p>I can see that for this particular 5x5 image, the energies are the following values. However, how do I find the energies of a fresh image that currently has an empty energy matrix? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As per the spec:</p>
<p>To construct the energy Matrix for the whole image, your function should do the following:</p>
<ol><li>Initialize the energy Matrix with the same size as the Image and fill it with zeros.</li><li>Compute the energy for each non-border pixel, using the formula above.</li><li>Find the maximum energy so far, and use it to fill in the border pixels</li></ol>
<p>So first you initialize the energy matrix and fill it with zeros. Then use this formula to compute the energy for each entry in the matrix:
<code>energy(X) = squared_difference(N, S) + squared_difference(W, E)</code></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@850-------------------------
image get pixel
<p>In image_get_pixel are we supposed to create a new pixel struct by reading the rgb matrix's of img  and then retuning that new pixel or am I missing something?</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Correct! You are creating a new Pixel struct object by reading each of the red, gree, and blue matrices.</p>

------------------------@853-------------------------
WSL won't connect to vs code
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky3tze2m3v25q0%2F966ee0a8cb67569d7a7613ce6a25d57a0251451b3acc96722cf4a05b7b0ca94a%2Fimage.png"/>I'm not sure what to do. It was working fine yesterday</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Got the same thing yesterday, I opened command line (windows key, then cmd) and entered “wsl - -shutdown”, no space between the dashes. And then I restarted my computer, and it was still a little iffy but after restarting vscode once it was ok.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Echoing the command above, you can run `wsl --shutdown` within Powershell for windows (or command line) to restart the WSL service. Then, reopen your Linux distribution you are using (should be Ubuntu from our tutorials) and it should start back up and be fine.</p>

------------------------@855-------------------------
Image_public-test undefined behavior
<p>receiving this error:</p>


<p></p>


<table><tbody><tr><td>ASAN:SIGSEGV</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>=================================================================</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>==123==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x7f7bc84d2308 (pc 0x000000425720 bp 0x7ffe6f799410 sp 0x7ffe6f7993c0 T0)</td></tr><tr><td>4</td><td>#0 0x42571f in Image_set_pixel(Image*, int, int, Pixel) /home/autograder/working_dir/Image.cpp:93</td></tr><tr><td>5</td><td>#1 0x425899 in Image_fill(Image*, Pixel) /home/autograder/working_dir/Image.cpp:116</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td>#2 0x4096eb in test_image_basic /home/autograder/working_dir/Image_public_test.cpp:29</td></tr><tr><td>7</td><td>#3 0x404cc2 in TestCase::run(bool) /home/autograder/working_dir/unit_test_framework.h:420</td></tr><tr><td>8</td><td>#4 0x406599 in TestSuite::run_tests(int, char**) /home/autograder/working_dir/unit_test_framework.h:509</td></tr><tr><td>9</td><td>#5 0x409f81 in main /home/autograder/working_dir/Image_public_test.cpp:57</td></tr><tr><td>10</td><td>#6 0x7f7cd069a82f in __libc_start_main (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0x2082f)</td></tr><tr><td>11</td><td>#7 0x404828 in _start (/home/autograder/working_dir/Image_public_test.exe+0x404828)</td></tr><tr><td>12</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>13</td><td>AddressSanitizer can not provide additional info.</td></tr><tr><td>14</td><td>SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: SEGV /home/autograder/working_dir/Image.cpp:93 Image_set_pixel(Image*, int, int, Pixel)</td></tr><tr><td>15</td><td>==123==ABORTING</td></tr></tbody></table>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you have not already, I believe you have to initialize the rgb channel matrices in the first Image_init function in image.cpp, not just the second Image_init. I only initialized them in the second and I kept getting this error because the red channel had a width and height of like -1000000000 and goes out of bounds when you call Matrix_at in your Image_set_pixel function, and again when you call Image_set_pixel in your Image_fill function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is the Sanitzer's way of telling you that you are running into a segmentation fault. In other words, somewhere in the execution of your program you are attempting to access something at an address you shouldn't (likely an invalid index into a matrix). Thankfully this output does give you some hints for where to look for this error: try looking around Image.cpp line 93 and Image.cpp line 116 and see if anything catches your eye.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@856-------------------------
Multiple assert functions in one test function
<p>If I have multiple assert statements in one TEST() function, will it run through all of them, or just the first one? If so, if it says "PASS" does that indicate that every assert function passed the test?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It will run through all of them, just like it does in the public test case that we all have. When it says pass, that means it got through all of them.

------------------------@858-------------------------
What does "Check respecting Matrix and Image interfaces" on autograder mean?
<p>Hi, just a quick question what </p>


<p>" Check respecting Matrix and Image interfaces in processing.cpp" and similar phrases on autograder really mean. </p>


<p>Would love an explanation on this and how we should implement this?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It means that you don’t do stuff like mat->data in Image.cpp.
<div><br/></div>
<div>It is talking about the “interface”, which is the term used to describe the abstraction of the matrix module, and any module, for that matter.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To add onto the student's answer, there is more detail about what <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#respect-the-interfaces" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">respecting the interfaces</a> should look like in project 2 on the spec. Essentially, you should only be directly accessing member variables of the Image struct within your implementation of Image itself, and same for Matrix, etc. On the outside, you should be making use of the getter functions you write such as <kbd>Matrix_width</kbd> instead of trying to do <kbd>mat-&gt;width</kbd> directly.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@861-------------------------
Error with const matrix_at
<p>I keep getting the error "Cannot initialize a variable of type 'const int *' with an rvalue of type 'long'" when attempting to assign the pointer in the const Matrix_at. What does type 'long' indicate, and how would I go about fixing this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>long</code> is another type of number (like <code>int</code>, <code>short</code>, <code>double</code>, etc.). I’ve seen this a couple of times with students doing pointer arithmetic - this is probably something with your hardware and not because of anything you’re doing incorrectly. What I’ve told students is just do</p>
<p><code>(int)(&lt;your expression that evaluates to a long&gt;)</code></p>
<p>and that should be fine.</p>
<p>In your case I would also say: doing that by itself won’t make your type compatible with <code>const int *</code> because <code>int</code> is not the same as <code>int *</code>. (Depending on what exactly you’re doing the <code>const</code> part should handle itself?)</p></div>

------------------------@866-------------------------
pointers to an array
<p>Hi, I am confused about the pointers to an array. For instance,</p>


<p>int arr[5] = {1,2,3,4,5};</p>


<p>int *ptr = arr;</p>


<p>Will it be a pointer to a pointer, because array is considered as pointer? Also, does the pointer points to a single pointer or a set of pointers? How can I access elements of ptr? Can I use *ptr[0]? I am confused about ptr[0] because I thought that is an expression for arrays. Why pointer can do the same thing? Are arrays the exact same thing as pointers? What is the difference between ptr[0] and *ptr[0]? Is *ptr[I] = arr[I]?  Sorry, I am totally confused with this. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Many thanks!</p>


<p> </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yeah <code>arr</code> in this case decays to an <code>int *</code>, so you can think of it as the same data type as an int pointer. So setting <code>int *ptr = arr;</code> makes ptr point to the same thing as <code>arr</code>.</p>
<p><code>arr[0] = ptr[0]</code>, and you can also do <code>ptr[1], ptr[2], ...</code> assuming there’s space in the array.  Also, printing <code>ptr</code> will have the same output as printing <code>arr</code> since they’re pointing to the same thing!</p>
<p><code>*ptr[0]</code> will likely crash since you’re dereferencing an integer. Does this help?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you so much! That really helps me!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@869-------------------------
special rules for c-string and cout
<p>Hi! I wondered if the special characteristics only for *char, or also for char array, or only for *char when using cout?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Many thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>cout's special behavior only applies to char[] and *char.</p>


<p></p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; char[] <em> &lt;- will output the c-string.</em></p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; *char <em>&lt;- will output the c-string it is pointing to</em></p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; *char[] <em>&lt;- will output the address of the memory location of the first string.</em></p>


<p><em></em></p>


<p>With <em>char[]</em>, <em>*char</em>, and <em>*char[]</em> being a variable of that type.</p>

------------------------@871-------------------------
Memory Leak
<p>My partner and I tried to run our tests for matrix, but it states there's a memory leak, and we can't find the source even after stepping through the debugger. We made sure to delete the matrix in the test function and only initialize once. Here are screenshots of the error:</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_8.32.54_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7akdcii1g5186%2Fe9439e28da68e83f79ff043834335fc87f837d945c510956cd84aad5b23c6a90%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_8.32.54_PM.png"/></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_8.33.30_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7akdcii1g5186%2Fc46675e93f8bc9581665571350ec212b362f5d09ef4e7e591c667ff521fcf0b2%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_8.33.30_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>2 things, both of which you can definitely fix <s>and one which might be a bit weirder:</s></p>
<ol><li>Double-check your pointer arithmetic in <code>Matrix_at</code> (both versions). However, based on your current implementations I think <code>test_fill_basic</code> at least should be passing. <s>Which leads me to the second point:</s></li></ol>
<p><s>2. can you try renaming one of the variables called <code>mat</code> to <code>mat1</code> or something similar? Basically don’t use the same name across different tests. If that works please let us know.</s></p>
<ol start="2"><li>on line 90, you are comparing to the address of the variable declared on line 78. This is not consistent. The way you should use <code>Matrix_row</code> and <code>Matrix_col</code> is to get the address of an element in <code>mat</code>, then pass that into those functions. This is why the second test case is failing - there is an error in how the test is written.</li></ol>
<p><s>Still looking into the memory leak.</s></p>
<p>Think I found the reason for the memory leaks - your tests fail before you <code>delete mat</code>, so that part of the code is never reached and your memory leaks. When I try them out and change the tests so that they pass, I don’t get the leaks. I think what you could do is create a matrix locally (without using <code>new</code>) and pass in the address of that matrix using the <code>&amp;</code> operator.</p></div>

Matrix_width function

------------------------@875-------------------------
const Matrix_at
<p>I seem to be having a lot of trouble with const Matrix_at. I have been trying to initially create a pointer and initialize it to mat-&gt;data. However, it only allows this to work if the pointer is a const. How would I then change this pointer later on using pointer arithmetic if it is a const? I've tried declaring the pointer and doing the pointer arithmetic all in one but then I get a warning indicating that the data types are different, even though I'm using all const pointers in the arithmetic. Is there something I'm missing that would make this easier?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I don’t think you actually need to return a <code>const int*</code> in the <code>const</code> version of <code>Matrix_at</code>. The computer will automatically make the conversion from <code>int*</code> to <code>const int*</code> since it’s an increase in security. Try writing the same definition as your non-const <code>Matrix_at</code>. As long as you aren’t modifying the Matrix itself (which you shouldn’t be), you shouldn’t have any issues.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As the student suggests, if you are just returning an address of your mat-&gt;data array, the compiler will automatically convert this to a const int pointer. If you are directly returning a mat-&gt;data element in your non-const Matrix_at, you will be able to copy the implementation. If you are saving off your pointer and returning a local variable, make sure that local variable that you are returning is a const int *.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>


<p>Another edit: I think I figured it out! I was trying to assign the address itself to an int variable, rather than the value of the element that the pointer was pointing to. Had to dereference it using *. Haven't tested it yet but the errors went away!</p>

------------------------@877-------------------------
Getting a SIGABRT Warning
<p>I'm getting SIGABRT when I'm running my debugger for the cost matrix function for the crabster.ppm file. I passed all the tests for dog.ppm, does anyone know why it isn't working for crabster.ppm? (ss is from public test file) Anyone know what SIGABRT is too?<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_10.21.43_PM.pngNaN" height="191" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7i20wztokn2or%2F44360747cb2e28822ab8f3b8b3efe3f23a8e364cbe8d5158958f8f169e0f979d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-22_at_10.21.43_PM.png" width="1079"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>SIGABRT in this instance means that the assert statement failed. Since assert's goal is effectively to say "This statement <em>must</em> be true", it will stop the program if it isn't. When the statement is false, assert will send a <em><strong>sig</strong></em>nal to <em><strong>ab</strong></em>o<em><strong>rt</strong></em> the program's execution.</p>


<p></p>


<p>It's effectively telling you that the two matrices are not equal, in this instance.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>SIGABRT while debugging for line 150 in your code is most likely just caused by your assertion failing.  I would compare your cost_mat with cost_mat_correct to see why those two matrices are different if this error is caused by the assertion failing.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@879-------------------------
iterate through matrix - matrix_fill
<p>I feel like im overcomplicating iterating through this matrix, but you would do a double for loop but then how would you assign the values this is what I have so far but I get the error "Type 'Matrix' does not provide a subscript operator" </p>


<p>I just realized data gets stored in a 1D array lol nvmid so when i assign to interface do i just assign value to all elements of data?</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><b>void</b> Matrix_fill(Matrix* mat, <b>int</b> value) {</p>


<p>    <b>for</b>(<b>int</b> i = 0; i &lt; mat-&gt;width; i++) {</p>


<p>        <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> j; j &lt; mat-&gt;height; j++) {</p>


<p>            mat[i][j] = value;</p>


<p>        }</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>    </p>


<p>}</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Important thing here is that mat is a pointer to a Matrix object. A matrix object has 3 attributes: width, height, and data. Therefore you need to specify which attribute of your Matrix you're trying to alter. For example, if you want to modify data you would want to do something like (*mat).data or mat-&gt;data to get to your data array. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Since data is a 1D array, you can then loop through and set every element in data. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@880-------------------------

------------------------@881-------------------------
interface
<p>What does interface mean? What's the definition for it? Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>An interface is a way of interacting with a system or object. In the case of this project, the interface is the methods provided in the header files to read or modify parts of the structs. For example, we can read a value in <code>Matrix</code> by using <code>Matrix_at()</code>.</p>
<p>When the spec tells you to “respect the interface”, they want you to only use these functions to read and write to the objects. This means that you would use <code>Matrix_at</code> whenever you want to access a specific value instead of trying to do something like <code>mat-&gt;data[y][x]</code>. This can help if you ever need to change the way the interface works, since you’ll only need to change one place in your codebase.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@882-------------------------
Matrix not deleting
<p>While making test cases for my matrix, I realized that even after I deleted the matrix I used from a previous test through "delete mat;", when I initialized a new matrix on a different test without setting its starting values, I got random values which seemed to have bled over from the original matrix's remains in the memory. I could just fill it up using Matrix_fill() right after it's initialized, but is this expected behavior?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>In computer memory, deleting something doesn’t usually wipe its bits. It just tells whatever’s running the gears that the space that used to be occupied is now available. You can tell from lobster that unitialized variables/memory aren’t all set to 0, they’re just at what arbitrary value they were at before. This is also why experts can sometimes recover files that have been deleted permanently on a system.
At least this is my theory - I wouldn’t know if C++ ran in a different way.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
When you create the new matrix, until you fill it with specific values, it'll put random values inside there. In this case, the values matched your previous Matrix, but this is random and will not always be the case!

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@883-------------------------
unfilled matrix
<p>if you create a matrix with 2 rows and 2 columns, do you have to fill the spots with actual numbers for it to be considered a valid matrix?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I don’t know that you have to fill the values in the Matrix with numerical values, but there isn’t much of a good reason for not filling the matrix with values. In the best case scenario, you can run your functions without an exception being thrown, but they might give you logical bugs like the max function outputting a number higher than any other number you used. In the worst case (and most likely), the compiler or runtime will give you an error when trying to run a function with that Matrix.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@884-------------------------
Significance of std::endl stream flush vs '\n'?
<p>I know that when you insert std::endl in a stream, it "flushes" the stream. Is this fact relevant to us when working with various types of streams for P2?<br/>Is only using newline characters (for Matrix_print() output for example) going to cause any memory issues? Just curious. Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Using either should not make a difference.</p>

------------------------@885-------------------------
strcpy in lecture 6
<p>After the function call, do we have word2 = frog/0d, not frog/0 since it stops substitute characters after the 4th operation. And when we cout array of chars, it stops when it reads an escape sequence?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, word2 would equal "frog\0d" for the reason you listed. And yes, generally when functions operate on C-strings, they will continue to process the C-string until they reach the null character (unless a size is passed in). So when you print word2 using cout, "frog" will be displayed since it stops printing the string after it reaches the null character.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@886-------------------------
type matrix
<p>in p2 overview, why does it uses -&gt; after the name of matrix(mat) instead of using "." ? Isn't "mat" the name of the matrix struct but not a pointer that point to mat?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>They both do the same</p>


<p></p>


<p>Answer below taken from <a data-pats="post_ref" href="696" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('696');">@696</a>:</p>


<p></p>


<p>(*mat).data</p>


<p>This one first dereferences mat (see *mat), which you can now treat like a struct. You use the dot operator "." to access its members - in this example I used data (.data) .</p>


<p></p>


<p>mat-&gt;data</p>


<p>does the exact same thing as above, but substituting the * and . operators for the arrow operator "-&gt;" this dereferences mat and accesses a member.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I understand that . and -&gt; do the same thing. I think we use . after the struct name and -&gt; after a pointer point to that. Here (*mat) means to dereference mat, so mat should be a pointer, but isn't mat the name of the object in struct? Is it like it decay to the address of the beginning of the struct like array? If it decays when we call it, how can we use p.(name) in the lecture slides?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>"but isn't mat the name of the object in struct?"</p>


<p>- No, mat is the name of the pointer to the object. We might not know what the name of the object/matrix is, and that's fine, we can still access the object/matrix through the pointer</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@887-------------------------
matrix_init
<p>1. After declare the array a[][], should I let mat point to a instead of point to mat?</p>


<p>2. Do I got empty matrix from this function or a matrix filled with data from mat? Do I fill with data in mat row by row?</p>


<p>3. I use mat = a; I think it's assign mat point to the first element in a, why it doesn't work?</p>


<p>4. I define a pointer point to a, but I can't let mat point to that pointer neither. there's an error when mat=ptr(array), what is the type of mat? I can't neither assign int* and int**</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you are talking about the matrix_init function in matrix.ccp, all you have to do is access the members of the mat struct and change them to the width and height you are passing into the function. </p>


<p></p>


<p>If you look at matrix.h file, you will see the matrix struct and its members. Your matrix_init function is passing in a matrix struct called mat. To access its members you do the following:</p>


<p>"matrix struct name"-&gt;"member name" </p>


<p></p>


<p>Then you can set the corresponding struct members to the width and height you are passing in.</p>

------------------------@889-------------------------
image->width
<p>Just a quick question, the function image_width appears below the function image_print, and we're supposed to get the width of the image in image_print, but I remember not being able to directly get the width because it was bad practice.. should I change the order of the functions and try to use the width function at all times?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It's ok to directly access an Image's width in Image.cpp since we are still within the Image module. The getter for Image should be utilized in non-Image files to respect the interface. See <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#respect-the-interfaces" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this section</a> of the spec for more explanation.</p>

------------------------@891-------------------------
what do we do about the whitespace character in image_init

-------------------------------------------------
<p>the stream we are passing into image_init() doesn't read whitespace, so you can basically ignore the whitespace character</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>will it read onto the next lime or should we put is &gt;&gt; endl?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>By default, the stream will skip any whitespace character (so any tab, space, or newline character) to get to the next value of the requested type. So you shouldn't need to do anything special.</p>

------------------------@894-------------------------
Seam Size
<p>In the find_minimal_vertical_seam function one of the requires statements says "the size of seam is &gt;= Matrix_height(cost)." Is there a way to assert this? I am not sure how to get the length/size of the seam. I tried "seam.size()" but this does not work since seam is of type int*. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Since seam is a normal array and not a vector, we don't know its size unless it's explicitly passed into the function as a separate parameter, unfortunately. So while you cannot assert this requirement in find_minimal_vertical_seam(), you can make some logical guarantee in the caller function. That is, since you're writing the caller function, you can make sure to initialize seam to be sufficiently large before passing it in. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
How to find the size of an array

<p>I'm trying to assert that the size of seam[] is at least as big as the height of a cost matrix in find_minimal_vertical_seam. Is this necessary? If so, could someone provide an example of how I could find the size of my array? I'm pretty new to C++ and array functions.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank u!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is not necessary! Arrays do not know their own size so you can assume the size of seam will always be long enough.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@895-------------------------
Creating new objects through pointers
<p>For a lot of new object instantiations, I see the examples using pointers like so:</p>


<div><br/>
<div>    Matrix* m = new Matrix;</div>
<div>    Matrix_init(m, 20, 20);</div>
</div>



<div>Can someone remind me what the difference would be if I instead had</div>



<div>
<div>
<div>    Matrix m = new Matrix;</div>
<div>    Matrix_init(m, 20, 20);</div>
</div>
</div>


<div>where m is no longer a pointer but is the Matrix itself? </div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The "new" operator returns a pointer to the newly-created object, so something like "Matrix m = new Matrix;" won't compile due to a type mismatch.</p>


<p>The reason why "new" returns a pointer is because it allocates the new object on the heap, which is typically far away in memory from where the current function's activation record on the stack is. Thus, we need a pointer to that location  on the heap so we can access and modify the object. Don't worry if this doesn't make too much sense yet -- we'll spend a lot of time talking about dynamic allocation later on in lecture!</p>


<p>Quick fun fact: It is possible for the "new" operator to not return a pointer. If the operating system fails to allocate memory for the object at runtime, the "new" operator throws an exception instead. The chance of you encountering this in 280 is exceedingly low. :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You will want to make sure you include Image.h</p>

------------------------@901-------------------------
for void compute_vertical_cost_matrix(const Matrix* energy, Matrix *cost) {
<p>so we need to make if statements for when the column = 0 and = cost-&gt;width - 1. so will the min for when its = 0 be</p>


<div>
<div>min = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, r - 1, c, c + 1);</div>
<div>and when its = cost-&gt;width - 1</div>
<div>
<div>
<div>min = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, r - 1, c - 1, c);</div>
<div>? </div>
<div>i'm rly confused on the bounds? is that right?</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Like you're thinking, you don't want to index out of bounds for our edge cases (col = 0 and col = width - 1). A couple things to keep in mind:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1) when outside matrix.cpp, we want to respect the interface by not directly accessing member variables (e.g. doing cost-&gt;width) . think about how we can use functions we wrote in matrix.cpp to do this</p>


<p></p>


<p>2) Matrix_min_value_in_row() returns the min between column_start inclusive and column_end <em>exclusive </em>. this means we want to input column_end as one past the column we want to check</p>


<p></p>


<p>Let me know if you have more questions</p>

------------------------@903-------------------------
compute_vertical_cost_matrix()
<p>Hello,</p>


<p></p>


<p>Can someone help explain how we fill in the matrix values for the cost matrix? Is it we add the lowest value in each row above that certain pixel plus the energy of the pixel? Any help would be appreciated :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yep! Each matrix value in cost should be the energy of that pixel plus the lowest value of the three pixels in the row directly above.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>can you explain why we need the lowest three values of the pixels above? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We don't want the lowest three values of the pixels, but the lowest energy value of the three pixels that are above, above and to the left, and above and to the right of the pixel we're looking at. I don't understand this part of the spec 100% yet, but we basically want to pick the pixel with the lowest energy value so we know what sort of continuous vertical line of pixels we want to remove when we're resizing the image. Watching the demonstration video linked in the spec might help make this part make more sense, too.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@904-------------------------
Setting values inside Matrix
<p>I am currently working on compute_energy_matrix and have gotten much of the function implementation down, but I wasn't sure if I was able to fill the energy matrix up by calling its data array directly by calling energy-&gt;data  despite not being in the Matrix file itself. Since I there was no prototype for adding an element to the matrix, this seems like it is the only way. Would this method be accepted?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you access data directly, you are not respecting the interface, which will cause problems in the future. We recommend using Matrix_at to set pixels outside of the Matrix.cpp file.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How would you use matrix_at to set pixels outside? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>*Matrix_at(matrix, #, #) = #</p>

------------------------@910-------------------------
shorter way of implementing remove_vertical_seam()?
<p>Hi,</p>


<p></p>


<p>For the function remove_vertical_seam(), the RME hints that you should create a smaller image and later delete it. My function works when implemented this way. However, I believe an alternative way to implement this function would be to modify the original matrix: leave the elements before the column to be removed as is, move the elements beyond that one to the left each, then call Matrix_init() and reduce the height and width of the matrix by 1 each. This would run faster due to fewer loops.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Is the efficiency here that important? Which method would you recommend?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>We recommend the first way. <code>Matrix_init</code> is meant to be called exactly once to initialize a matrix, and doing the second method would break that desired interface. By using the first method, the efficiency won’t change enough for the autograder to complain.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@912-------------------------
col_of_min
<p>So, I think I have a basic idea of how to get the min value i'm just confused now on how to keep track of where it is- do I have to use a pointer to simultaneously keep track of the min memory address as I work through finding the min value itself? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When you are iterating through the matrix, and you find a new min, store its column in a separate variable. When you find a new best min, overwrite your previous min and previous column variables with this new information.</p>

------------------------@915-------------------------
Confused on how to test Image_init with streams
<p>I wrote a test function for Image_init with streams.</p>


<p>I used one of the ppm starter files and printed the output of image_init to a separate txt file.</p>


<p>I was confused on how I could compare the original ppm and the new output txt file and check for differences</p>


<p>I'm also curious on how autograder will try check tests I wrote for image_init</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2F0736ea31818cd50b66767b9c4ebbd38f27520ef311e7da130262e782ba796ee2%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You cannot submit extraneous txt files to the autograder. Instead, you have to use stringstreams for these kinds of tests. You can think of a stringstream as “acting” like standard input/output or file input/output, but instead of the source being the command line or a file, it’s a string.</p>
<p>For example, if you want to simulate reading in a file like this:</p>
<pre><code>P3
1 1
255
42
</code></pre><p>You can declare a string with that content, initialize an input string stream (an <code>istringstream</code>) with that string as the content, and then read it in like a file or standard input.</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-built_in">string</span> s = <span class="hljs-string">"P3\n1 1\n255\n42"</span>;
<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-built_in">istringstream</span> <span class="hljs-title">ss</span><span class="hljs-params">(s)</span></span>;
<span class="hljs-built_in">string</span> junk;
ss &gt;&gt; junk &gt;&gt; ...
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('c3RyaW5nJTIwcyUyMD0lMjAlMjJQMyU1Q24xJTIwMSU1Q24yNTUlNUNuNDIlMjI7JTBBaXN0cmluZ3N0cmVhbSUyMHNzKHMpOyUwQXN0cmluZyUyMGp1bms7JTBBc3MlMjAlM0UlM0UlMjBqdW5rJTIwJTNFJTNFJTIwLi4uJTBB');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>For testing output, you’d do the opposite order. Output to a string stream, then convert the output to a string and compare it with a “test” string if you want to use <code>ASSERT_EQUAL</code> in your tests.</p>
<pre><code>ostringstream ss;
ss &lt;&lt; "Outputing to stream";
string s = ss.str();
</code></pre></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@917-------------------------
Seam array not being overwritten
<p>Hello, I was having issues with the lobster test case for seam_carve and after some debugging I found that my seam array was not changing with each column that gets reduced. This makes sense with the output I am getting because only the left side of the image is changing (see image). ------------------------@920-------------------------
Image_init confused
Hi, my partner and I started setting up the image_init function. We are wondering if our process/thinking is correct. We first initialized int variables for red, green, and blue. Then we read in the integers representing red, green, and blue in PPM format by using istream.
<br/>
<br/>

Or do we add them to the img, and if so how should we go about that? -------------------------------------------------

------------------------@921-------------------------
Test functions
<p>Are we required to test all of the image functions? For example, in the print basic function call it uses image_set_pixel as well as Image_init. If we pass the test, are we allowed to assume that those functions are working, or do we still need to provide test cases for every single one?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your test cases are only graded on their ability to catch bugs in code that are not your code. You should test your own code to make sure you have no bugs, but within the autograder, they are just testing your cases to see if you catch bugs in sample code that is buggy. If you have all of the mutation points, you no longer need to make test cases.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There are no points associated with testing every function in Image.cpp, only with catching the required amount of bugs on the autograder. However, I would recommend testing every function you can in Image.cpp to be more confident in your own implementations for private tests.</p>

------------------------@929-------------------------
image_init question
<p>I'm really confused on how to initialize the first image function with the red, green, and blue variables. I tried just calling the Matrix_init three times with img-&gt;red_channel and the other 2 but it's not letting me do that. I'm just a little confused haha</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Which image_init? The first or the second? If it's the first, that's weird, because that's really all you have to do. If the second, it's asking you to Matrix_init, then read in the whole ppm file and put it into the image. It's not as bad as it sounds, just initialize a temp variable, and use "is &gt;&gt; example1 &gt;&gt; example2 &gt;&gt; example3" your variables in and then use image_set_pixel.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Should I do it with a while loop to iterate through the three values and set the pixel?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sorry for the slow response, but that would probably work (like yeah that seems fine :). Personally, I decided to do the following: Since we must start by reading in the beginning of the file (P3, width, height, max), that means that we know the width and the height of the image. So I did a for loop to iterate through it that way. That way, I could read in all of the info from the ppm, by iterating through it, and also set things easily using Image_set_pixel(img, row, column, color). Using a 2D for loop like this seemed a little more convenient :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I kind of feel confused about how do i use Matrix_init? what parameter should i pass to it???like:</p>


<p>Matrix_init(&lt;#Matrix *mat#&gt;, &lt;#int width#&gt;, &lt;#int height#&gt;); what *mat and width and height should I passed into it???</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You'll be creating three matrices for each of the channels, and the height and width are read in from the ppm file/passed in as parameters. So you can use those when calling Matrix_init!</p>

------------------------@930-------------------------

------------------------@931-------------------------
out of bounds RME
<p>Hi!</p>


<p></p>


<p>If the rows and columns are 0-indexed, then how can column_end be equal to Matrix_width(mat)? Wouldn't that be out of bounds?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="177" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fks5iojmc4rncc%2F0849ef3db64288b70518907ec754ba2411dc9dc3a51212dea89d245f8967bc47%2FbuabuabuaAEHEHWE.png" width="575"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The range of columns excludes <code>column_end</code> (since it says “exclusive” in EFFECTS). So if the matrix width is 5 and you have <code>column_start = 2</code> and <code>column_end = 5</code>, it will look for the minimum value in the specified row in columns 2, 3, and 4 (thus excluding 5).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@932-------------------------
Interface
I see the word “interface” appears a lot in the spec of project 2. But what exactly is an “interface”?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>See <a data-pats="post_ref" href="881" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('881');">@881</a>. An interface is basically the functions you will interact with to read or change an object. For example, <code>Matrix_at</code> is part of the interface for interacting with <code>Matrix</code> functions.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@933-------------------------
Matrix _row and Matrix_column use of mat->data
Is it necessary that we use data in our matrix_row and matrix_column functions? It seems like it would make more sense to just use mat->width when doing our arithmetic.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You're right to use <code>mat-&gt;width</code> in your arithmetic. I found it helpful to be able to use <code>mat-&gt;data</code> to use array decay to find the index of the provided pointer.</p>


<p></p>


<p>After that, it's some simple to convert from an index to a row or column.</p>


<p></p>


<p>However, do remember that the p2 spec says:</p>


<blockquote>
<p><strong>no function other than <code>Matrix_row</code>, <code>Matrix_column</code>, and the two versions of <code>Matrix_at</code> should access the <code>data</code> member directly</strong></p>
</blockquote>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@937-------------------------
C style string and int array
<p>Since C style strings are char arrays actually, why it can be initialized like this:</p>


<p>char *str = "hello";</p>


<p>but int array cannot be initialized like this:</p>


<p>int *arr = {0, 1, 2};</p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Ultimately, this is one of those multitude of ways that C/C++ treats char arrays different than other types of arrays. It was considered a priority to be able to place constant strings off the stack and only keep a small pointer to them on the stack, so that syntax was supported for c-strings.
<div><br/></div>
<div>If we were designing our own language, there’s no reason we couldn’t allow the same thing for other types of arrays.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Will char *str = "hello" generate another char array that str points to? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, that puts the string "hello" in a special region of memory that is not allowed to be modified, and puts the pointer "str" on the stack which points to the string.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@938-------------------------

------------------------@939-------------------------
Help with understanding Image_set_pixel
<p>Right now, I'm currently at a complete halt with project because I'm having a hard time understanding how Image_get_pixel works and to even get it working. From my understanding of it, it is selecting a pixel in the image from a specified row and column and setting it to the color of the RGB values from the pixel struct obtained from the Image_get_pixel. The part I don't understand is how does it set it to that color and how does VS code read it as a color?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>Image_get_pixel()</code> shouldn’t change any values in the <code>Image</code>. That’s what <code>Image_set_pixel()</code> is for. If you look in <code>Image.h</code>, you’ll see that the return type of <code>Image_get_pixel()</code> is <code>Pixel</code>. Your code needs to create a <code>Pixel</code> (you don’t need to use new), set its values to the corresponding values in the red, green, and blue matrices, and then return that <code>Pixel</code>.</p>
<p>To answer the second part of your question, reading color values is super simple because each one is just an <code>int</code>. VS Code doesn’t need to do anything special.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@942-------------------------
Why array decay doesn't happen when we use []?
<p>Let's say there is an array</p>


<p>int arr[3] = {1, 2, 3};</p>


<p>When we use arr[1] to assess its second value, what really happens under the hood to my understanding should be</p>


<p>*(arr+1)</p>


<p>at this time, this arr is already be treated as a pointer and we are doing pointer arithmetic to it, i.e. +1. So why in this case array decay doesn't happen? It doesn't make sense with me.</p>


<p>Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I think that’s a fine way of looking at it. It’s ultimately semantics if we want to distinguish between the cases of “that code results in pointer decay” vs “that code is converted to code that results in pointer decay”.

------------------------@944-------------------------
Compute_energy_matrix
<p>I know that we have to call 'square_difference' in Compute_energy_matrix, however, the parameters for that function are pixels. How do we know the exact pixels that we need to pass in? Also, can someone explain how we find N,S,E,W when we don't know where exactly we are in the image.</p>


<p></p>


<p>THANK YOU</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>To calculate the energy for each non-border pixel X, we use the formula <code>energy(X) = squared\_difference(N, S) + squared\_difference(W, E)</code></p>
<p>The values for N, S, E, and W are simply the adjacent pixels. This is why we only use this method to calculate the energy for non-border pixels. So north is simply <code>row_of_x - 1</code>, east is <code>column_of_x + 1</code>, etc. In a double for loop, you can use those offsets from the current pixel being calculated.</p>
<p>You can also see the explanation in the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#energy-matrix" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">p2 spec</a>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@945-------------------------
Adding ∈ front of the pointer
What does it mean when we put & in front of “p->”? I’m confused here because p-> means we’re dereferencing the parameter but if we put & in front of that what would it mean?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The reason you would use <code>&amp;</code> is because you want a pointer to whatever value you’re getting from p.</p>
<p>For example, in the first <code>Image_init()</code>, you need to initialize the matrices that are in the <code>Image</code> struct using <code>Matrix_init()</code>, which requires a <code>Matrix *</code> pointer. However <code>Image_init()</code> only has an <code>Image *img</code> pointer to work with. By using <code>&amp;(img-&gt;red_channel)</code>, you can get a pointer to the red channel matrix and pass it to <code>Matrix_init()</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@946-------------------------
How to test Matrix_at() while respecting the interface?
<p>When testing Matrix_at(), we must compare the address returned from the function with what we know the true address of the data element to be. However, this isn't a way to get the address of the first element of the data array without directly accessing mat-&gt;data, is there?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Correct. You can access the member variables of Matrix directly here since this function is a core feature of the Matrix object itself. Other functions which utilize Matrix_at should respect the interface, however.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I tried accessing the member variables directly from Matrix but when I ran it through the Autograder it fails the check respecting Matrix interface. We only used mat-&gt;data in Matrix_at tests. How can we fix this are we not allowed to use it in our Matrix_tests.cpp at all.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You cannot use mat-&gt;data at all in your tests. Because of this, you don't have to test Matrix_at by itself. You can use other functions, or use Matrix_at to check your other functions, to catch bugs for Matrix_at.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@947-------------------------
Ok to use other Matrix.cpp functions in our test cases?
<p>For example, is it ok to use Matrix_at() when testing Matrix_row() or Matrix_column()?</p>


<p>Because then I would likewise use Matrix_row() and Matrix_col() when testing Matrix_at().</p>


<p>Theoretically, couldn't this cause an issue if all three implementations are susceptible to the same bug?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes. And the bugs are usually specific to one thing that the program can do (i.e. not something that multiple functions are susceptible to). Even if they are, the test would expose the bug regardless.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@948-------------------------
Use of standard library
<p>Are we allowed to use the c++ standard library? So if I wanted to use std::min() would that be allowed?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>See here for the libraries you are allowed to use: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#requirements-and-restrictions" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#requirements-and-restrictions</a></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@949-------------------------

<p>Hi,</p>

------------------------@951-------------------------
what is red_channel, green channel, blue channel
<p>I know how the PPM and image formed, but I don't know what the red_channel, green channel, and blue channel use for.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>red channel, green channel, blue channel represent the colors that form the image. From red, green, and blue you can form almost all colors so these are used (in combination with each other) to form colors on a screen. In the project your input is given by the values of these three channels (which is why your image struct stores all of them), you then do consistent operations on these channels in order to do seam carving and the other stuff listed in the spec. You need to change all these values (on all the channels) so the output is viewable on a computer in the form of an image.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So what the red_channel, green channel, and blue channel contain? I know the they are matrix. What is their matrix about? For example, in row 0 and col 0, red pixel is 0, so row 0 and col 0 in red channel is also 0? Sorry I am confused about these three new matrices. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_6.19.41_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkyjgk5364g37nt%2F140575c5dbf8967705df44ca672c23485bbc0b02885dc5d195339da208b2f9be%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_6.19.41_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Each channel is a matrix of integers. You can think of an image as 3 matrices stacked on top of each other. You can visualize it like thi:</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="171" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk02pxl7nct07o2%2F87abe6d634703698e0c25fb87fa7a6ad89b96c7d8fae68d49a85692873dec150%2Fimage.png" width="205"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>A pixel is made up of three values: a red value, a green value, and a blue value. </p>


<p></p>


<p>So at index 0,0, you're correct that the red channel is 0. The green channel and blue channels at that index are also 0.</p>


<p></p>


<p>The pixel at 0,0 is {0, 0, 0}. </p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@952-------------------------
About Matrix_at
<p>Hi i have a problem about how to implement matrix_at, I know how to calculate the 1d array index with 2d array index(i.e row and column and width and height), but that will give me the index of that object in 1d array instead of its address, which is a pointer, how can i get the pointer pointing to that object with the index i calculated?</p>


<p></p>


<p> *ptr = row * (mat-&gt;width) + column; I use this expression but i don't think this is correct, cuz when i dereference pointer it gives me a address, but essentially row * (mat-&gt;width) + column give me an index, which is super weird. I am quite unfamiler with c++ syntax, please help!!!</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>row, mat-&gt;width, and column are all numbers, so any calculation with them will give you a number, which we can think of as an index. When declaring pointers, we need to set them to the address of objects, not the object's value. </p>


<p></p>


<p>With that being said, if you've figured out how to calculate the index of an element, then you've already accomplished most of this function. An index is essentially how many elements away you are from the beginning of an array. We also know that arrays are represented as pointers to their first element. We can translate the index of an element into the address of an element using pointer arithmetic. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@953-------------------------
False Positives
<p>Hi, when I put my Matrix_tests.cpp and Matrix.cpp files into the autograder, it says I have false positives in a couple of my tests. I'm a bit confused on how I go about fixing those? What is a false positive too?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A false positive means that your test case failed on a working example. So when we ran your test cases against our correct solutions, some of them reported a bug when they shouldn't have. This could indicate that you have an incorrect understanding of how some functions should behave based on certain inputs. </p>

------------------------@954-------------------------
Some confusion about matrix.cpp
<p>Hi i have some questions about these functions in matrix.cpp. My questions are in the comments.</p>


<p>I don't know why I can't have two pictures here at the same time, so i can only put rest of my questions here:</p>


<p></p>


<p>Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row:</p>


<p></p>


<p>So first, we have multiple rows in 2d array, do we still go through the 1d array finding the least element, then get it's column index in 2d array??? Is this the right idea???</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="1555" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxfxo1r1f877a%2Fb422bbcc1f3af71f95a392ab6fe4bdf23836ab70d0cf9960aa6a5aef88f75278%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_11.36.32_AM.png" width="1478"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><strong>Matrix_fill: </strong></p>


<p>You are given a value as a parameter to the function, you want to fill the entire matrix with this value. </p>


<p></p>


<p>You are given mat, which is a pointer to a Matrix object. Matrix has 3 attributes: data, width, height. You need to specify which data attribute you want to access. This is usually done with the dot operator, but since mat is a pointer you need to dereference it first. For example, to access data you would want something like (*mat).data or mat-&gt;data. </p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Matrix_fill_border: </strong></p>


<p><a data-pats="post_ref" href="841" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('841');">@841</a> - the followups explains why we want to have fill_border vs. just fill </p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Matrix_max:</strong></p>


<p>Wants you to return the value of the maximum element in the data array of the Matrix object that mat points to. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@955-------------------------
P2 spec clarification on Matrix loops
<p>On the Matrix module part of the specs, it says this:</p>


<p></p>


<p>"<em>Your <code>Matrix_at</code> functions will need to perform the appropriate arithmetic to convert from a (row, column) pair to an index in the array, and your <code>Matrix_row</code> and <code>Matrix_column</code> functions will need to go in the other direction. </em><strong><em>None of these functions require a loop, and you’ll find your implementation will be very slow if you use a loop.</em>"</strong></p>


<p><strong></strong></p>


<p>does it mean that only Matrix_at, Matrix_row and Matrix_column don't require a loop or is it talking about all functions in the Matrix module?</p>


<p><strong></strong></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am not sure about other functions but for these three they don't really need a loop.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It only means that those three functions mentioned (Matrix_at, Matrix_row, Matrix_column) shouldn't be completed using loops. You will have to use loops to implement some other functions in Matrix.cpp</p>

------------------------@959-------------------------
resize.cpp Memory leak
<p>Hello,</p>


<p>I have been testing my resize.cpp function to see what it would do if I gave it an invalid input. My file did crash and return the proper error message when I used an invalid input, but it also detected a memory leak because I needed to declare a new *img before I could check its width/height. Since my program exited before deleting the *img, it causes a memory leak. Is there a way to change my code to avoid this memory leak or is it important? I could put delete img in the if statement checking for the invalid input, but I check for multiple errors throughout my code so I was wondering if there was a better way to avoid a memory leak.</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="734" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy2v236ihf38t%2F51ccf007a85a864f9c1822a11a07490c13e2af7846e6e4829b09c56704025998%2Fimage.png" width="643"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should reorganize the code to avoid any memory leaks. This can come in the form of deleting your img on every return, or only creating the img after you check error conditions. How you go about it is up to you, but there should be no memory leaks present in your code.</p>

------------------------@961-------------------------
compute_vertical_cost_matrix
<p>so I get the idea of it and how to use min_value_in_row for it. im struggling to understand how to index using the function though. </p>


<p>because min_value_in_row excludes the column_end value passed into it, i was thinking of passing ((the col value I want) + 1), but won't that cause indexing issues? any help would be appreciated </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Assuming you implemented the min_val_in_row function, you shouldn’t encounter an indexing issue.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Where was the min_val_in_row function? Are you talking about Matrix_min_value_in_row? That does not account for out-of-bounds indexing.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your Matrix_min_value_in_row function should index to (column_end -1).</p>


<p>So if you have a 5x5 matrix for example, and you want to look from column 0 to column 4 (across the entire row), you would pass in column_end as 5. Since you will only index up to 4, this won't cause an out_of_bounds error.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You can also look at the RME to confirm this.</p>


<pre><span class="hljs-comment">// REQUIRES: mat points to a valid Matrix</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Matrix_height(mat)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= column_start &amp;&amp; column_end &lt;= Matrix_width(mat)</span><div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As you point out, index 30 is out of bounds in a 5x5 matrix. You should not worry about what the values that are outside the bounds of your matrix as they could theoretically be anything. I would not assert the value of out of bounds indices as it may not be 42 the next time you run the unit test.</p>

------------------------@967-------------------------
Image get pixel
I’m having a hard time understanding this function. I know that pixel is formed with three integers and the integers represent red, green, and blue and the image get pixel unpacks these and store each of the integer color values(?) to each of the matrix(red_channel, green_channel, blue_channel). And if we look at the parameters of this it contains row and column. But I don’t understand what will happen if we call Matrix_at and put these row and column parameters for each of the color matrices. For instance, if the row is 2 and the column is 3 with the red_channel matrix, does it mean that it will point to an element of row 2 column 3 of the red_channel matrix and return the integer (intensity of the red color)?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your intuition about this function seems correct to me. With row, column parameters of 2 and 3, the Image_get_pixel function should access each of the images channel matrices (red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel) and save their values at row 2, column 3 into a pixel struct which should be returned.</p>

------------------------@968-------------------------
Does autograder give feedback for invalid tests immediately after I submit, or after the deadline?
<p>Hi, as the title, does the Autograder give out feedback for valid/invalid unit tests immediately after I submit, or after the deadline?</p>


<p>Say, I wrote several tests but failed to catch a certain bug, will the autograder let me know immediately? And would the autograder let me know what is the input?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The AG will only tell you how many bugs you're catching, and how many points out of the maximum possible number of points you're getting for your test cases. This output is visible after submitting your test cases, and test case scores are final (meaning the score you see on the AG is the score you will receive for test cases, even after private tests are run)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@969-------------------------
Testing Image_Init
<p>My partner and I are trying to test Image_Init by passing in a ppm file given to us in the project. We want to use ifstream for this but cant figure out a way that the syntax works. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You cannot submit extraneous txt files to the autograder, so you cannot use <code>fstream</code> for your Image tests. Instead, you have to use stringstreams for these kinds of tests. You can think of a stringstream as “acting” like standard input/output or file input/output, but instead of the source being the command line or a file, it’s a string.</p>
<p>For example, if you want to simulate reading in a file like this:</p>
<pre><code>P3
1 1
255
42
</code></pre><p>You can declare a string with that content, initialize an input string stream (an <code>istringstream</code>) with that string as the content, and then read it in like a file or standard input.</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-built_in">string</span> s = <span class="hljs-string">"P3\n1 1\n255\n42"</span>;
<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-built_in">istringstream</span> <span class="hljs-title">ss</span><span class="hljs-params">(s)</span></span>;
<span class="hljs-built_in">string</span> junk;
ss &gt;&gt; junk &gt;&gt; ...
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('c3RyaW5nJTIwcyUyMD0lMjAlMjJQMyU1Q24xJTIwMSU1Q24yNTUlNUNuNDIlMjI7JTBBaXN0cmluZ3N0cmVhbSUyMHNzKHMpOyUwQXN0cmluZyUyMGp1bms7JTBBc3MlMjAlM0UlM0UlMjBqdW5rJTIwJTNFJTNFJTIwLi4uJTBB');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>For testing output, you’d do the opposite order. Output to a string stream, then convert the output to a string and compare it with a “test” string if you want to use <code>ASSERT_EQUAL</code> in your tests.</p>
<pre><code>ostringstream ss;
ss &lt;&lt; "Outputing to stream";
string s = ss.str();
</code></pre></div>

------------------------@975-------------------------
Calling Matrix functions inside Image.cpp
<p>Hello! I see that we need to respect the interface when we script our functions, however, I am just wondering if calling functions from Matrix.cpp in Image.cpp would be disrespecting the interface. Unless calling functions from Matrix.cpp in Image.cpp is unnecessary, does anyone have any ideas or tips?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think you can, and it is even encouraged, to use the matrix.cpp functions in the image.cpp</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You will want to call the functions in Matrix.cpp in Image.cpp. In order to "respect the interface", you should not directly access members of the Matrix struct in Image.cpp (mat-&gt;height, mat-&gt;width, mat-&gt;data).</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F1145b8546067e7bb5ccb216339ecbe1bf87c4e85f694da047d2a001a8976d038%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Hmm, okay. The compiler's giving me this error when I "make" Image_tests.exe. Is there any reason why? I've tried including Matrix.h in Image.cpp, but that doesn't seem to be the problem.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It seems like your row and column variables may be pointers, while the Matrix_at function takes in a pointer to a Matrix, an int for row, and an int for column.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks, I got it fixed now 👍.</p>

------------------------@977-------------------------
compute_energy_matrix matrix initialization
<p>Hi, right now I'm having a hard time trying to initialize the energy matrix that would be used in compute_energy_matrix. I've tried using both the first Image_init and Matrix_init separately but I haven't really been able to get them working. Is there another way to initialize the matrix used here or was it one of the previous options I tried but failed to do correctly?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>energy is a pointer to a Matrix object, so you would want to use Matrix_init and not Image_init. The Effects statement for this function says that the energy matrix needs to be initialized to be the same size as the Image pointed to by img. I would recommend taking a look at the Matrix_init function and making sure you're sending it the correct parameters. </p>
