------------------------@978-------------------------
Confusion with Matrix_at and const Matrix_at
<p>I am not sure how I can test if const Matrix_at is working. I tried setting up the constant pointer, filled the indices into a single value, and modified one of the indices; but when I stepped through the debugger, the Matrix_at function on the second line gets called to the non-const version. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, I'm not sure the difference between dereferencing the constant pointer and the Matrix_at function and why would they return different results?</p>


<p><img alt="" height="166" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszctriqgxu71e%2Fb4e423292f346cc581a98ca1efdbce669867f3049a5214185a583c60702814c0%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_4.07.06_PM.png" width="650"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I would really appreciate any suggestions of how I can test this function. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I changed this post to private - please don't include any code in a public post. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Did you declare mat as a pointer to const as well? If mat is not a pointer to a const matrix, then the other Matrix_at will be called, which I believe is what is happening in this situation. To test the matrix_at that takes a pointer-to-const, you need to send it a pointer to a const matrix in the parameters. </p>


<p></p>


<p>You get an error when you try to dereference stay because stay is declared as a pointer to const, and you're not supposed to be able to alter the value that it points to. You don't get an error at the dereference to matrix_at because, like you pointed out in your post, I believe you're calling the non-const Matrix_at. </p>

------------------------@982-------------------------
Help understanding the implementation of the second Image_init
<p>As per my understanding, the 1st image_init function is used to set the width and the height of the image and the second image_init reads a given ppm file and splits the r,g,b values into their respective channels. Is the pixel struct invovled in any of this? moreover, would we need to use functions like image_set_pixel to achieve this? My intuition tells me some looping system is involved but I'm having trouble visualizing how to implement it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>There are a few ways to implement it, some using Pixel and some not. At its core, the function must:</p>
<ol><li>Read in the width and height to initialize the image and matrices</li><li>Read in each pixel (set of three numbers)</li><li>Assign the three numbers to the red, green, and blue channels respectively (at that specific row/column)</li></ol></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@988-------------------------

------------------------@989-------------------------
Compute_vertical_cost_matrix()
<p>Hello,</p>


<p></p>


<p>I was debugging my code, and when I went to my compute_vertical_cost_matrix function, I realized that I was violating the requires clause of the matrix_min_value_in_row() when I was doing the edge case for when calculating the matrix pixel on the last column. </p>


<p></p>


<p>What I currently have is Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, row - 1, col, col + 2), but when I do col + 2, it goes out of bounds. The only reason I am doing col + 2 is because the RME for matrix_min_value_in_row says that the function is exclusive on the column end part. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Any help would be appreciated :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think I found the problem here. Even when the function is exclusive on the last column, you don't need to do col + 2, just do col + 1 instead. This way, if your for loop has (index &lt; col_end), it will never actually try to index out of bounds. Right now, with your code, it indexes at data[col + 1], which is not possible. So I think changing the +2 to a +1 would fix the problem. </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am having this problem as well, and I'm not sure if I can use the min function since that's in the algorithm library.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>you can it says on the spec</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>algorithm is not allowed. i submitted to AG with it and got a error message saying it is not allowed. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
But min is in the std lib, not algorithm lib

-------------------------------------------------
<p>even then, spec says to use the min function we made</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Sorry sir, it is a stupid question: what’s spec…

------------------------@990-------------------------
Image
Just like Matrix, do we also have to think of Image as a 1D array?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>No, the only abstraction was that the Matrix in real implementation was a 1D array. Outside of the implementation, Matrix is supposed to look and be used like a 2D array. Because Image is using Matrix, you only have to see the abstraction and not the implementation, so you can think of the three red, green, blue matrices as a 2D arrays from the outside.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1004-------------------------
What are Mutation Testing Suites and how are they graded
<p>Where should I start for the "exposed bugs"?</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1005-------------------------
What are Mutation Testing Suites and how are they graded
<p>Where should I start for the "exposed bugs"?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A mutation test suite is a set of unit tests that are run against buggy implementations of code. You get points based on if your test case reveals those bugs (for example, if your test case is run against an incorrect <code>Matrix_fill</code> function, you will get a point if your test case fails, which means it found that bug). You can write test cases as normal just like you did in p1; be sure to think about different edge cases for your <code>Matrix</code> and <code>Image</code> functions!</p>


<p></p>


<p><a data-pats="post_ref" href="921" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('921');">@921</a> includes a helpful explanation as well.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Hi, just to make sure: the Testing Suites are testing whether or not my test cases (unit tests) are robust enough. But how is the autograding testing that? Is it going to offer a buggy version of the functions and see if the test cases catches it by failing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yup, your explanation is correct. You can think of each point on the AG as a different buggy solution.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1011-------------------------
remove_vertical_seam() confusion
<p>I read on an earlier post that I should point the pointer that points to the original image matrix over to the copy matrix, but I don't know how that would work since we delete the copy at the end. It works on the debugger until the debugger exits out of the function, then the original image loses the dimensions of the copy and has its old dimensions again. Would anyone be able to help me with this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The phrasing in your post "point the pointer that points to the original image matrix over to the copy matrix" is a bit misleading, as you are correct in that the final image has to be deleted through that same pointer. Instead, think about it as copying the data inside the pointer from the auxiliary image to the original image. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1012-------------------------
seam[height] compilation warning in Processing.cpp
<p>We are receiving a compilation warning in autograder for our processing.cpp in our seam_carve_width function. It says C++ forbids variable length array 'seam' in int seam[height]... where we wrote int height = Image_height(img) on the line above. We understand that arrays are not allowed to vary in length. But we don't know how to maneuver this compilation warning with the purpose of the function. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Seam doesn't necessarily need to equal the height. It simply needs to be at least as long as the height. This is similar to how <kbd>data</kbd> in <kbd>Matrix</kbd> is the maximum possible length required—not the exact length needed for a specific height and width. With that in mind, consider using a constant variable (that we were given in a .h file) to set <kbd>seam</kbd> to be a length which is always greater than or equal to height.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I tried to initialize the array using int seam[500]; but I got a compile error:</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="113" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkszansx1wf6768%2F7a831388d4cbc70be5ac8ad6954620e3ef0e7c8cd6ff78e76394f2d5c99bbc4f%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_10.01.13_PM.png" width="719"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Have you put <kbd>int seam[500];</kbd> inside of <kbd>find_minimal_vertical_seam</kbd> or inside of <kbd>seam_carve_width</kbd>? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm confused, because for remove_vertical_seam() one of the requirements is that the size of seam must be equal to Image_height(img). Wouldn't using seam[500] violate this requirement? Also, shouldn't seam be initialized outside of those functions?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, seam should be initialized outside of those functions. It should be initialized in a function which has to call a function that has a parameter of <kbd>int seam[]</kbd>... say inside of <kbd>seam_carve_width</kbd>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>As for <kbd>remove_vertical_seam()</kbd>'s requirement that the size of <kbd>seam</kbd> must be equal to <kbd>Image_height(img)</kbd>, I believe this is a small typo in the RME. For <kbd>find_minimal_vertical_seam()</kbd>, the requirement is "the size of <kbd>seam</kbd> is &gt;= <kbd>Matrix_height(cost)</kbd>." (And the height of the cost matrix and the image are the same). If we think about it, there's no reason that seam can't be too long... we just stop reading when we're done reading the information we need, even if it's too long. However, it at least has to be as long as the image. Since we can't set the length dynamically (the problem you encountered when making this post), we have to set it to the fixed maximum length.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Lastly, note that <kbd>int seam[500];</kbd> will work for the purposes of the grade on this project, but you may consider using <kbd>int seam[MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT];</kbd> instead in case you want to change the <kbd>MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT</kbd> later (say, to put your own photos in). This is just good coding practice.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1013-------------------------
compute_vertical_cost_matrix

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Marking as resolved.</p>

------------------------@1014-------------------------
About Rotate test
<p>Hi Guys! I am facing a problem with testing rotate. This is a given function, but I do not know why I failed this test. ------------------------@1015-------------------------
using min value row "backwards"
<p>For the min value function (not the column one), can we use it backwards? For example, can we have column_start be towards the right side of the matrix and column_end be towards the left side and read the range of values from right to left instead of the traditional left to right?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you in advance.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your min_value_in_row function should do what the RME specifies; specifically, column_start needs to be the left boundary, and column_end needs to be one past the right boundary. You can read from right to left or left to right within the function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1016-------------------------
What does it mean to copy an image?
<p>Right now, my code creates an image pointer (Image* aux = new Image) and initializes it according to the project spec. Then in the last line, I am setting img = aux so that it points to aux, but I wonder if it no longer points to aux when the function ends bc aux will be out of scope?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_10.43.49_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7diwffsv70j1%2F5502f7b28cbe7b65353bcf4f9c69d3c210103cad8c53851895a85dad896ec9b3%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-24_at_10.43.49_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Nice to hear that you have solved this.</p>
<p>Think of this <code>*img = *aux</code> as copying the “content” of aux to img, because when you dereferencing the pointer, you will get the actual struct that is pointed by the vector. When you do <code>*img = *aux</code>, you will replace the original struct with the struct that is pointed by aux.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>solved; my code has changed slightly since I first posted this but my last line changed from img = aux to *img = *aux</p>


<p></p>


<p>Can someone explain why dereferencing the pointer here was the correct approach to copying my images? Thank you!</p>

------------------------@1020-------------------------
find_minimal_vertical_seam()
<p>How do you use the min value row function to find the minimum of a whole row if, no matter what, column_end will always be out of bounds?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you in advance!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Per the RME, column_end can be matrix_width in some cases. This would allow the whole row to be considered

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You want to find the minimum value by iterating up to (but not including) column end</p>

------------------------@1027-------------------------
Can we assess Matrix's members in test file?
<p>When we are writing test, let's say that we have initialized a matrix:</p>


<div>
<div></div>
<div>Matrix *mat = new Matrix;</div>
<div>const int width = 3;</div>
<div>const int height = 5;</div>
<div>Matrix_init(mat, 3, 5);</div>
</div>



<div>Are we allowed to use mat-&gt;width to test if the data in mat is correctly? Is this "respect the interface"?</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You may not use any of the Matrix struct's data members (width, height or data[]) outside the matrix file. none of the other files, including test files should access Matrix data members. As you rightly pointed out, this would violate the "Respect the Interface" guideline for this project.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If we cannot use any of the Matrix struct's data members in test file, how to test functions like Matrix_init? Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Use Matrix_width() and Matrix_height() to return an integer that represents the Matrix's width and height respectively :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1028-------------------------
min
<p>If a row of elements have two numbers that both are a minimum, what do we do??</p>


<p>For example, if a row involved [1,2,3,2,1], which column would be considered the min value? The 0th or the 4th?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It is included in the RME.</p>
<pre><code>If multiple elements are minimal, returns the column of the leftmost one.
</code></pre></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1029-------------------------
using operators with const int and int
<p>I'm just curious and want to know the explanation of why the reference operator * lets me able to use the other operators such as &lt;, &gt;, = while comparing these two but without it, I would get an error.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt06e6q4hr415n%2Fd58ff400ebb3d57386c976d00e90cf61ee34a08de2a84d2ef4bca0610b724c26%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If I’m understanding the question correctly, <code>num1</code> is a pointer while <code>num2</code> is an int. You can’t compare these types directly, so you need to dereference <code>num1</code> by using <code>*num1</code> in order to compare it to <code>num2</code>. The const operator does not change this; what matters is the pointer type.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As mentioned in the project spec, the only libraries we can use are:</p>


<p><code>&lt;iostream&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;fstream&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;cstdlib&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;sstream&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;cassert&gt;</code>, <code>&lt;string&gt;</code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What do you need eecs280math.h for?</p>

------------------------@1032-------------------------
Autograder Errors? "check respecting matrix interface in student tests"
<p>Tests run correctly, but getting these error inputs.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_4.41.25_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2Fb4a6faabff3cd0c194c59673bd84ca45f7d2a5370ad142890bdcb41cc15bc289%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_4.41.25_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You should not access any field in the Matrix struct outside of Matrix.cpp using the Matrix pointer.</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Respect the interfaces for the modules you are testing. Do not access member variables of the structs directly.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Check out the spec: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#respect-the-interfaces" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#respect-the-interfaces</a></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Does this imply that you can't use ___-&gt;width in the tests cases for ___?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>only in the implementation, specifically the implementation, and not allowed in the tests of that implementation(?)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Yes, something like this ___-&gt;width is what it means by accessing member variables of the structs directly. If this is a Matrix, you should only do this in Matrix.cpp</p></div>

------------------------@1035-------------------------
Matrix_tests completely failing in autograder
<p>I am a bit confused about the Autograder. My Matrix_tests.cpp compile but the Autograder says that no tests are submitted. They compile on my computer and our functions pass all of the tests. I compared the file to our Image_tests.cpp briefly which did run properly and nothing seems to be very different.</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="279" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxtbzqluv03kh%2F797bd8b847a11c408f1a68a9f96284ca145b7f3617d99ef739ff9e0b46fb5285%2Fimage.png" width="655"/></p>


<p>Let me know if it would be helpful to submit my code and let me know if there is a way to give you guys the whole file instead of just screenshots.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It seems like you guys have solved this problem in your latest submission. Is there any other problem?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I guess another question I have is about the undefined behavior checks. How are our test cases supposed to account for undefined behavior if there is no way to predict it? Wouldn't the program just not compile or throw something completely random?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>As per the spec, you should enable address sanitizer to compile your code. Undefined behaviors usually happen because of bad programming practices. For example, you might have created an object using <code>new</code> but never free, which will lead to memory leaks, and it would just compile without address sanitizer and run successfully.</p>
<p>Check out here: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#undefined-behavior-and-memory-leaks" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#undefined-behavior-and-memory-leaks</a></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1038-------------------------
Matix_at use of mat -> data.
If mat -> data is defined as max_height * max_width (500^2), is there a more useful way to reference this within our matrix_at function? If say I had a height=3 width=4 matrix, wouldn't it be much more useful if mat -> data = 12 than 500^2?
<br/>
Not sure if I'm just misunderstanding the way it's initialized, but any clarification would help.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>mat -&gt; data is an array with size max_height * max_width, not the integer max_height * max_width.</p>


<p></p>


<p>In c++ you can't really have arrays with variable size so the memory is allocated using the maximum size of the array even if the entire array isn't used.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can treat mat-&gt;data as if it only has 12 elements in it even when the actual initialized size is much larger. Our member variables matrix-&gt;height and matrix-&gt;width help us with indexing in bounds of the data</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1039-------------------------
Issue Calling Matrix_init
<p>Would it be okay to use <em>matrix_init</em> within other matrix functions to verify the given "<strong>REQUIRES: mat points to a valid Matrix"</strong>  in each matrix function? My partner and I tried doing so but we keep getting a squiggly error (as shown).<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_11.37.23_AM.pngNaN" height="324" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1p9ldh2mi68c%2F09426a92a2cfc3a0464522cfb4c43e62e719f87334663ce3b6be8ee682624b1e%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_11.37.23_AM.png" width="499"/><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt1p9ldh2mi68c%2Fc6facdc3f4d5c0dcb27e5ce81739574ce0046c4842e371983b4417bb5cee1c1f%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_11.34.16_AM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The <code>mat</code> pointer in Matrix_print is a const, while the <code>mat</code> pointer in Matrix_init is not, so you cannot call Matrix_init with it.</p>
<p>I wouldn’t suggest using Matrix_init to verify the REQUIRES clause since Matrix_init should be only used to initialize a Matrix.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

<div>
<div>void compute_energy_matrix(const Image* img, Matrix* energy) {</div>
<div style="padding-left:40px">Matrix_init(energy, Image_width(img), Image_height(img));</div>
<div style="padding-left:40px">for (int i = 1; i &lt; Image_height(img)-1; i++) {</div>
<div style="padding-left:80px">for (int j = 1; j &lt; Image_width(img)-1; j++) {</div>
<div style="padding-left:120px">int sqDiffNS = squared_difference(Image_get_pixel(img, i+1, j),Image_get_pixel(img, i-1, j));</div>
<div style="padding-left:120px">int sqDiffEW = squared_difference(Image_get_pixel(img, i, j-1),Image_get_pixel(img, i, j+1));</div>
<div style="padding-left:120px">*Matrix_at(energy, i, j) = sqDiffNS + sqDiffEW;</div>
<div style="padding-left:80px">}</div>
<div style="padding-left:40px">}</div>
<div style="padding-left:40px">Matrix_fill_border(energy, Matrix_max(energy));</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>


<div>I'm not sure where else to look to debug this. Any help on this is appreciated, thank you!</div>

<p>When you run the test cases, it should create a file for your dog energy matrix, which you can compare to the correct energy matrix. That might give you some insight into where the errors are happening.</p>

------------------------@1044-------------------------
running all tests in terminal
<p>When I run "make -j" in the terminal, all my test cases pass (yay!) but the last test says </p>


<p></p>


<p>./resize.exe dog.ppm dog_4x5.out.ppm 4 5</p>


<p>diff dog_4x5.out.ppm dog_4x5.correct.ppm</p>


<p></p>


<p>Does the "diff" mean that the correct dog picture is different than the "out" dog picture? I am just not sure how to translate what the terminal is saying. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The <code>diff</code> command checks to see that two files are the same - <a href="https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/diff-command-linux-examples/" target="_blank">https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/diff-command-linux-examples/</a></p>
<p>If you aren’t seeing any lines after, that means that the <code>diff</code> command didn’t find anything different between your out file and the correct file</p></div>

------------------------@1045-------------------------

------------------------@1049-------------------------
Testing processing.cpp
<p>Hello,</p>


<p>I was wondering if anyone knows a good strategy for how to write tests for processing.cpp since the correct energy and cost matrices take a long time to calculate. Also, if we write tests for processing.cpp in a copy of processing_public_tests.cpp, how should we compile the file? Should we add a command to the Makefile?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When testing processing.cpp, I would suggest writing smaller test cases of computing the energy and cost matrix so that it does not take as long to calculate. Smaller test cases (maybe a 7 by 7 ish size) are something you can generate a correct output for. Make sure that these test cases are targeted though! Think about all the bounds and if statements in your function. The test case should attempt to run every single line and if condition in the function.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1056-------------------------
red, green, blue channel
<p>What the red_channel, green channel, and blue channel contain? I know the they are matrix. What is their matrix about? For example, in row 0 and col 0, red pixel is 0, so row 0 and col 0 in red channel is also 0? Sorry I am confused about these three new matrices.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Essentially the red,green, and blue channels are just matrices that are storing the RGB values at each pixel but in separate matrices. For example if I have a 2x2 image, the pixel at row = 0, column = 0 will have one set of RGB values.</p>


<p>The first value in my red_channel will be the R value for that pixel also at row = 0, column = 0. The same applies to the blue and green channels. Also let's say I wanted to access my RGB values at some random pixel in the image, then</p>


<p>I would use my Matrix_at function (because red_channel is a matrix) with the statement "&amp;img-&gt;red_channel" to access that R value. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Basically, each color_channel is another matrix that has the corresponding color values at the same row and column as your image.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this is right and helps</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1057-------------------------
remove_vertical_seam
<p>Currently stuck right now with remove_vertical_seam as I can't get the column in each row stored by seam to be skipped when copying the pixels from img to a temporary img as it seems to read what should be the skipped values. By default, are the values in seam that were obtained in find_minimal_vertical_seam not able to be accessed automatically or do you need to call them in somehow?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should be able to access the values obtained from find_minimal_vertical_seam using seam[r] where r is the row number of the seam column you are trying to access.</p>

------------------------@1058-------------------------
assert not working?
<p>Hi, I have no idea of how to create an assert for a REQUIRES clause. It reads:</p>

</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><a data-pats="post_ref" href="894" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('894');">@894</a> talks about this, but to reiterate, there's no good way to actually assert that the REQUIRES clause is met. You still can guarantee that the REQUIRES clause is met, though, since you are the one writing the code that calls this.</p>

------------------------@1076-------------------------
void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {
<p>why cant i say</p>


<div>
<div>*Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;blue_channel, row, column) = color-&gt;b ?</div>
<div>the color-&gt;b underline as incorrect but works when i do color.b. why?</div>
<div></div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>-&gt; is the same as “dereferencing” or getting the actual object associated with a pointer and then using <code>.</code> , for example <code>img-&gt;blue_channel</code> is equivalent to <code>(*img).blue_channel</code></p>
<p><code>Pixel color</code> is a struct object, not a pointer to an object. So you want to access the attribute in the struct with a <code>.</code> , there is nothing to dereference</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1080-------------------------
Matrix_public_test.cpp question
<p>My partner I have been getting a weird error when trying to use the public test for Matrix. In a private test that we wrote, we had <kbd>Matrix_at working fine (and I believe the test is not faulty), but in the public test, we get an error that says</kbd></p>


<p></p>


<p>Matrix_public_test.exe: Matrix.cpp:89: int* Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int): Assertion `0 &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Matrix_width(mat)' failed.<br/>Aborted (core dumped)</p>


<p></p>


<p>and we are not sure why.</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<div>
<div>int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int row, int column) {</div>
</div>


<div>
<div>  assert(0 &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Matrix_height(mat));</div>
<div>  assert(0 &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Matrix_width(mat));</div>
<br/>
<div>  int index = mat-&gt;width*row;</div>
<div>  int* ptr1 = &amp;mat-&gt;data[index];</div>
<div>  int* element_ptr = ptr1 + column;</div>
<div>  return element_ptr;</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>



<div>This is what our Matrix_at function looks like, but the public test makes it seem like we are going out of the bounds we set for the function with assert(). Any assistance would be greatly appreciated, thank you.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If your assert statement is causing the function to fail, this would likely be a result of the function calling Matrix_at, not Matrix_at itself. Double check the parameters you're passing into Matrix_at for the function call at Matrix_public_test.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The parameters in the public test are within the bounds (matrix_at 2 and 3 within matrix_init 5 x 5). We are met with the same error on autograder. We were not the ones who wrote the test, so we shouldn't need to adjust the test. It might be an issue with our actual matrix_at function, but we are not too sure what it may be. The only thing that I can imagine is that it's an issue with the line that has an &amp; (and in result, the line thereafter as well).</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I managed to fix it!</p>

------------------------@1081-------------------------
processing_public_test horses
<p>processing_public_tests passes for all dog and crabster tests but when it tries to run horse it times out. I'm pretty sure the issue is my algorithm for compute_vertical_cost_matrix is doing overlapping calculations but I didn't understand the specs explanation for how to avoid that<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_7.30.11_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl80ayzdhfv3r8%2Fdc576abd454813d0be7e89adef60b919aa1ce1efe7680adb260c007749e02821%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-25_at_7.30.11_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Could you clarify what you don't understand about these instructions?</p>


<p></p>


<p>1. Initialize the cost matrix</p>


<p></p>


<p>2. Fill in the index 0 row with its energy values (It is the first row so there are no previous energy values to add to the cost)</p>


<p></p>


<p>3. Loop through the matrix starting from row index 1, the cost for each pixel is the min value of the adjacent columns of the cost row that you filled in the previous iteration + the energy of the pixel itself. You can find this using the Matrix_min_value_in_row on the previous row of the cost matrix and adding that to the Matrix_at of the current pixel in the energy matrix. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1082-------------------------
do i need to use std while in resize.cpp main function to read in input

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I’m a little confused by what you mean here, are you asking if you need to use a while loop?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Also please add your uniqname as per <a data-pats="post_ref" href="6" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('6');">@6</a></p></div>

------------------------@1083-------------------------
what functions do we want to call in main?
<p>i made if statements for the errors but what am i supposed to do after thta?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Assuming you are referencing the main in resize.cpp:</p>


<p></p>


<p>you want to input the contents of the file (using ifstream) specified by the command line argument into a new image (and initialize it using the width and height at the start of the file) and then call your seam carving function on this image using the width/height specified by the command line arguments. You then want to use your Image_print function to output the resized image to a file (using ofstream) with the filename specified by the command line argument. Don't forget to delete the image you created to avoid memory leaks.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1085-------------------------
problem with Matrix row function
<p>I wrote a test case for my Matrix row function, but the test keeps failing and I am not sure why.</p>


<p></p>


<div>
<div>int Matrix_row(const Matrix* mat, const int* ptr) {</div>
<div>int width = mat -&gt; width;</div>
<div>int height = mat -&gt; height;</div>
<br/>
<div>for(int row = 0; row &lt; height; row++) {</div>
<div>for(int col = 0; col &lt; width; col++) {</div>
<div>if(ptr == Matrix_at(mat, row, col)) {</div>
<div>return row;</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>return 0;</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>



<div>
<div>
<div>TEST(test_row_col) {</div>
<div>Matrix *mat = new Matrix;</div>
<div>Matrix_init(mat, 3, 3);</div>
<div>int value = 6;</div>
<div>const int *ptr = &amp;value;</div>
<br/>
<div>Matrix_fill(mat, 0);</div>
<div>*Matrix_at(mat, 2, 2) = 6;</div>
<br/>
<div>ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_row(mat, ptr), 2);</div>
<div>ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_column(mat, ptr), 2);</div>
<br/>
<div>delete mat;</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>
</div>



<div>output: 0 != 2</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>ptr</code> is pointing to <code>value</code>, not pointing to any element in the matrix, that’s why <code>Matrix_row</code> will always return zero.</p></div>

------------------------@1086-------------------------
Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row pointer
<div>
<div>For this code, I have a problem where I use '&amp;' to take the address of the starting value and values to replace it. It gives there error 'a value of 'const int *' cannot be used to initialize an entity of type 'int *'. I believe we covered something like this in lecture, but I'm still confused.</div>
<div></div>
<div>int Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(const Matrix* mat, int row,</div>
<div>int column_start, int column_end) {</div>
<div>assert((0 &lt;= row) &amp;&amp; (row &lt; Matrix_height(mat)));</div>
<div>assert((0 &lt;= column_start) &amp;&amp; (column_end &lt; Matrix_width(mat)));</div>
<div>assert(column_start &lt; column_end);</div>
<br/>
<div>int min = mat-&gt;data[(row*(mat-&gt;width))+column_start];</div>
<div>int* ptr = &amp;(mat-&gt;data[(row*(mat-&gt;width))+column_start]);</div>
<br/>
<div>for (int i = (row*(mat-&gt;width))+column_start; i &lt; (row*(mat-&gt;width))+column_end; i++)</div>
<div>{</div>
<div>if (mat-&gt;data[i] &lt; min)</div>
<div>{</div>
<div>min = mat-&gt;data[i];</div>
<div>ptr = &amp;(mat-&gt;data[i]);</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>}</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There is a type mismatch on the line you pointed out: int* ptr = &amp;(mat-&gt;data[(row*(mat-&gt;width))+column_start]);</p>


<p></p>


<p>This is because the definition on the left is of type int* and the expression on the right evaluates to a const int*. You could change the definition to be a const int*, but then you may run into issues with changing this const value.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You can, and should, use the other functions in Matrix.cpp to access the pointers and traverse for the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row function. This will take care of the arithmetic and pointer accesses you are attempting in this code snippet, and should greatly simplify the implementation.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1092-------------------------
Mutation Testing Suites Error
Hi, in my mutation testing suites, I have some test functions that say they give false positives and some that are valid; however they are for the same function and are implemented the same. Is there any explanation for that?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you’re saying that two tests are exactly the same but one gives a false positive, I think that this is impossible. I would recommend running through with your debugger to see if the inputs to your test are any different.</p>
<p>If you’re saying that there are two tests testing the same function but one is giving a false positive, then that means your asserts in one test is incorrect, or in other words your asserts are invalid when tested against a correct implementation.</p>
<p>An example of a false positive:
vec = {10,20,30}
ASSERT_TRUE(sum(vec) == 3); // this is not valid, the answer should be 60</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1104-------------------------
matrix_init in img
<p>I'm trying to initialize a Matrix in the img_init function but for some reason my parameter for the *mat isn't matching up- in the first parameter for the matrix_init function is it not just img?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you look at the image struct in Image.h, there are 3 different matrices for each image representing each of the red, green, and blue color channels. In the Image_init function, you must initialize each of these three matrices using the Matrix_init function. You can access the channel matrices using the -&gt; operator on the image. Don't forget the Matrix_init function takes an address as the first parameter.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1108-------------------------
I have no idea why this is failing the testing dog cost...
<div>
<div>void compute_vertical_cost_matrix(const Matrix* energy, Matrix *cost) {</div>
<br/>
<div>int width_NRG = Matrix_width(energy);</div>
<div>int height_NRG = Matrix_height(energy);</div>
<div>int min;</div>
<div>int width_cost = Matrix_width(cost);</div>
<div>int height_cost = Matrix_height(cost);</div>
<br/>
<div>//intilizes cost matrix to the width and height of NRG</div>
<div>Matrix_init(cost, width_NRG, height_NRG);</div>
<div>//fills first row of the cost matrix to corresponding energy</div>
<div>for(int c = 0; c &lt; width_NRG; c++) {</div>
<div>*Matrix_at(cost, 0, c) = *Matrix_at(energy, 0, c);</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>for(int row = 1; row &lt; height_cost; row++) {</div>
<div>for(int col = 0; col &lt; width_cost; col++) {</div>
<div>//if the column is = 0,</div>
<div>//then cannot go leftward to find the min cost</div>
<div>if (col == 0) {</div>
<div>min = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, row - 1, col, col + 2);</div>
<div>*Matrix_at(cost, row, col) = *Matrix_at(energy, row, col) + min;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>//if the column is the last one</div>
<div>//then cannot go rightward to find the min cost</div>
<div>else if (col == width_cost - 1) {</div>
<div>min = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, row - 1, col - 1, col + 1);</div>
<div>*Matrix_at(cost, row, col) = *Matrix_at(energy, row, col) + min;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>//if the column is not an edge column,</div>
<div>//calculate the cost with the given equation</div>
<div>else {</div>
<div>min = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, row - 1, col - 1, col + 2);</div>
<div>*Matrix_at(cost, row, col) = (*Matrix_at(energy, row, col) + min);</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>return;</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>i fixed it nvm</p>

------------------------@1113-------------------------
why does this fail test dog find seam. i tried multiple things but cannot find error
<div>
<div>void find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]) {</div>
<div>int cost_width = Matrix_width(cost);</div>
<div>int cost_height = Matrix_height(cost);</div>
<div>int min_cost_index;</div>
<br/>
<div>//start with bottom row of cost</div>
<div>for (int row = cost_height - 1; row &gt;= 0; row--) {</div>
<div>//find the column of the min cost of the bottom row</div>
<div>if (row == cost_height - 1) {</div>
<div>min_cost_index = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, row,</div>
<div>0, cost_width);</div>
<div>//add the column # of the min value to the end of seam</div>
<div>seam[row] = min_cost_index;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>//if the previous row's min column was = 0</div>
<div>//then make sure to not look leftward of it</div>
<div>if (seam[row + 1] == 0) {</div>
<div>min_cost_index = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, row,</div>
<div>seam[row + 1], seam[row + 1] + 2);</div>
<div>seam[row] = min_cost_index;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>//if the previous row's min column was the last column</div>
<div>//then make sure to not look rightward of it</div>
<div>else if (seam[row + 1] == (cost_width - 1)) {</div>
<div>min_cost_index = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, row,</div>
<div>seam[row + 1] - 1, seam[row + 1] + 1);</div>
<div>seam[row] = min_cost_index;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>//if no out of bounds exceptions will occur,</div>
<div>//look to the left and right of the row to find min cost</div>
<div>else {</div>
<div>min_cost_index = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, row,</div>
<div>seam[row + 1] - 1, seam[row + 1] + 2);</div>
<div>seam[row] = min_cost_index;</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>return;</div>
<div>}</div>

<p>b w</p>


<p></p>

<p>r g</p>


<p></p>


<p>and then <br/>b w<br/>b w</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1128-------------------------
Matrix false positive test cases
<p>My test functions for matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row and matrix_min_value_in_row are both getting detected as false positives and I'm not sure why. I've checked my test cases multiple times and I'm not sure why they're false positives.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From pulling up your autograder solution, here's your matrix:</p>


<p>[1, 2, 3]</p>


<p>[3, 16, 9]</p>


<p>[5, 11, 4]</p>


<p>[6, 13, 17]</p>


<p>[7, 12, 2]</p>


<p></p>


<p>For your first assertion:</p>


<p>ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_min_value_in_row(mat, 1, 1, 2), 9);</p>


<p>This looks for the min value in row 1 between column 1 (inclusive) &amp; column 2 (exclusive). Really, we are just returning whatever is in row 1, column 1, so we would expect the value to be 16, not 9.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I would pay attention to the RME for Matrix_min_value_in_row and Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row since column end is <span style="text-decoration:underline">exclusive</span>, and update your implementation accordingly! </p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1130-------------------------
Testing resize.cpp
<p>Is there a way to test resize.cpp?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can run it using the given files (horses.ppm etc) and compare your output to the correct output files using the command diff like so:</p>


<p></p>


<p>diff horses.out.ppm horses.correct.ppm</p>


<p></p>


<p>If there is no output to this command, the two files are the same and your program works.</p>


<p></p>


<p>for compile, don’t forget to type make ./resize.cpp </p>

-------------------------------------------------
I would also encourage you to look at some of the error checks in your resize.cpp and check if an error message is displaying if a certain condition is not met ( for eg: the number of arguments you pass in isn’t what it’s supposed to be)   :)

-------------------------------------------------
testing resize.cpp

<p>how do you actually test resize.cpp? </p>

------------------------@1131-------------------------
What are some differences between running tests in the CAEN environment vs the autograder?
<p>Right now, when I run processing_public_tests.exe on the CAEN environment, my code runs perfectly with no issues. However, when I submit my code to the autograder, it shows that I my energy matrix is different from the computer matrix. I also want to note that I don't fail any other test cases other than the public_processing test cases, specifically the energy matrix. What are some reasons that could cause this difference in CAEN vs autograder? My uniqname is johnxie is any instructor wants to check the autograder for me.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Make sure to fill your energy matrix with zeros before you begin your calculation. The compiler will fill it with junk values which can mess up the call to Matrix_max at the very end.</p>

------------------------@1132-------------------------
deep nesting
<p>Hi,</p>


<p>I wonder what is the standard of function being considered as deep nesting?</p>


<p>I have a function that has a structure like this:</p>


<p>for(...)</p>


<p>{</p>


<p>    for(...)</p>


<p>    {</p>


<p>        if</p>


<p>        else if</p>


<p>        else if</p>


<p>        else</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>}.</p>


<p>would this be considered by the autograder as deep nesting?</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This not considered deep nesting. It has to be &gt; 4 layers deep to cause an error on the autograder.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>this is fine!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>that’s ok since the maximum of nested layers in your code is 4, which equals to the maximum on Autograder.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1133-------------------------

------------------------@1137-------------------------
XCode debugging resize.cpp
<p>Is there a way to use the debugger in XCode for resize.cpp (adding breakpoints and stepping through)? I only know how to run it in terminal and I can't get the debugger to work with terminal.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you click to the left of any line number it will create a breakpoint there for you (should look like the picture). Clicking it again will disable the breakpoint (and you can right-click to delete it fully). Just run the program as you usually do and it will stop at the break point.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="102" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7axr4htifj405%2Fdf576bc886b3ef8420f7beb9672dee3536974679fea9b362108c8746d2ec3c9f%2Fimage.png" width="42"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thanks for your response. For me breakpoints only work when running in XCode but not when running in terminal. It's only possible to run resize.cpp in terminal right?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sorry, forgot about the arguments. The XCode tutorial shows you how to do it (they use resize.cpp as an example too):</p>


<p></p>


<p>https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#arguments-and-options</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you're still having problems with debugging, you can try using GDB. It's a command-line tool. This website helped me to get started with it: <a href="https://www.srcmake.com/home/cpp-debug-gdb" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://www.srcmake.com/home/cpp-debug-gdb</a></p>


<p>You can call the setup with "file [code.exe]".</p>


<p>Once you've got it set up, you can type "break [function_name]" to add breakpoints, then type "run" and it will break on your breakpoints. If you want to view stackframes, you can type "up" or "down", and "p [variable]" will show you the value of a variable. "continue" will move to next breakpoint, and "next" will go line-by-line.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>


<p>./resize.exe horses.ppm horses_400x250.ppm 400 250 --debug</p>


<p></p>


<p>and I have a breakpoint set in resize.cpp but it's not stopping there.</p>

------------------------@1138-------------------------
Compue_energy_matrix problems
<p>Hi, I am trying to implement what I have written so far in the compute_energy_matrix function by running it through the processing public tests. Any advice about this error or my code in general is greatly appreciated. </p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_10.01.37_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0h8pe7gr356m%2F37746fdb6307bd76f11158c311360de7ae4ee2e45afe61872dc9978ea99e5845%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_10.01.37_AM.png"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_9.56.09_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0h8pe7gr356m%2F5c56ca0cf09e58bb7781cd10cd19efb7ed9fa136e6b923ec5ded989c6d070986%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_9.56.09_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Well if you think about it, j's maximum value is going to be the index of the last column in the matrix. However, line 101 increments j to be 1 more than the last column, which is why you're getting your assertion error. Keep in mind line 99 has a similar problem, but with the row. </p>

------------------------@1139-------------------------
Image_init errors
<p>I'm pretty stuck on my second Image_init function, and I don't know how to resolve the errors I have. Also for tempPixel, I'm not sure how to index the height and width so that it returns the location of the pixel. I just need general guidance and a new perspective for how to finish this function.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F4a1bbbeadcb95cd7906f2dd6dec34daa92589a4c103835ddcb887feaf6347b4f%2Fimageinit.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">imageinit.png</a></p>


<p>I'm also having a similar issue with my image_print function.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F53a0348f9294019f7a93f7923282b87e14c5acd4745a970cee58407b09ee8454%2Fimageprint.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">imageprint.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you are trying to reference img-&gt;height[num] and img-&gt;width[num]. This is throwing an error because height and width is just an integer. The [] only work on arrays and vectors. You can find more information on img and it's attributes in the Image.h file.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1141-------------------------
Processing.cpp - issue with remove vertical seam
<p>Our project is failing dog_seam_carve after passing the find seam and remove vertical seam test and our carved image is only slightly different from the correct one, which would make it seem like an off by one error perhaps but we have spent a lot of time debugging it and cannot find anything, everything seems to copy over fine from the image to the smaller image then we use pointers to copy the smaller image to the original image. Here is our code, we're pretty sure the issue is in remove vertical seam, but pretty stuck, could be something big we're doing wrong as well, who knows. Also posted question <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1098" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1098');">@1098</a> which has more information on our test output<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_11.01.29_AM.pngNaN" height="311" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt3sinwk67y3nk%2F7c5c404cb8f3854b673a011cdaf0ec7e0e5660435d2a1f6370526c76561d632d%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_11.01.29_AM.png" width="642"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like the error is originating in your compute_energy_matrix function. Based on the spec, we know that the border must always be 0. Looking at your code on the autograder, we have some undefined behavior. On the first iteration of the for loop, r = 0 and c = 0 so it will fail the first if statement. The computer will then go to the second if statement (Energy &gt; maxEnergy. At this point, energy hasn't been initialized to a value, resulting in undefined behavior. I would suggest creating a better way to fill the border with 0's.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1150-------------------------

------------------------@1152-------------------------
Is a matrix with only one row and one column a valid matrix?
<p>If it is, and Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row requires col_start &lt; col_end, then does that mean this Matrix can't use Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Not necessarily. We can set col_end = 1 and the function shouldn't go out of bounds because it col_end is exclusive.</p>

------------------------@1154-------------------------

<p></p>


<p>void strcpy(char *dst, const char *src){<br/>  <br/>  // WRITE YOUR CODE HERE<br/>  while(*src != '\0) {<br/>    *dst = *str;</p>


<p>     str++;</p>


<p>     dst++;<br/>  }</p>


<p>*dst = '\0'<br/>}</p>


<p></p>


<p>My question is, wouldn't incrementing str and dst through str++ and dst++ change the address of the first element that str and dst are pointing to permanently? or are *dst and *str passed in as copies of the arrays only?<br/><br/>(If so, would having void strcpy(&amp;char *dst, &amp;const char *src) change the addresses permanently?)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
What is str in this code? Did you mean src?
<div>I think you are right about them being passed as copies of the original addresses and I think passing the pointers by reference would permanently change the addresses.</div>

------------------------@1157-------------------------

<pre><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> <span class="hljs-title">main</span><span class="hljs-params">(<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>* argc[], <span class="hljs-keyword">char</span>* argv[])</span></span>{
	Resize.cpp implementation here
}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('aW50JTIwbWFpbihpbnQqJTIwYXJnYyU1QiU1RCwlMjBjaGFyKiUyMGFyZ3YlNUIlNUQpJTdCJTBBJTA5UmVzaXplLmNwcCUyMGltcGxlbWVudGF0aW9uJTIwaGVyZSUwQSU3RA==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>I want argc to store 400 to 0 and 250 to 1 and argv horses.ppm to 0 and horses_400x250.ppm to 1. Why is it not letting me do that?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
argc should be an integer value (not an array) containing the number of command line arguments and argv is an array of cstrings of all the command line arguments themselves. In your example, horses.ppm would be argv[1].

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In that case, how do I handle integer arguments (such as 400 and 250)? I would get an issue that a char* cannot be used to initialize an int</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Like this:</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" height="350" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7axr4htifj405%2F30925764c53d4deb7a24c338e12fea0fe7550829494412ccd62c93be7df77f05%2Fimage.png" width="459"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>So if 400 is the first argument it would be:<br/>int x = atoi(argv[1]);</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The numbers are read as cstrings. To turn them into ints, use the atoi function as described in lecture.

------------------------@1158-------------------------
seam creation?
<p>working on seam carve width. have a good algorithm, but cant seem to figure out how im supposed to create the seam array that gets passed into the funcs. any strategies?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should initialize the seam using the max matrix height. See <a href="https://piazza.com/class/l7548zpfvr8yj?cid=768" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><a data-pats="post_ref" href="768" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('768');">@768</a> for more details</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>for remove vertical seam, the size requirement says it must be the image height. if i pass a large array to find min vertical seam, can i change the size of it later? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Good point. I think I missed that when writing my function. I don't know how to make variable size arrays in C++.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>im trying to make another array that i could copy the larger seam's data into, but the compiler wont let me initialize an array like this "int arr[Image_height(img)]"</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We can dynamically allocate memory for an array in C++ like so: </p>


<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>* L = <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span>[size];
<span class="hljs-keyword">delete</span>[] L;<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('aW50KiUyMEwlMjA9JTIwbmV3JTIwaW50JTVCc2l6ZSU1RDslMjAlMEFkZWxldGUlNUIlNUQlMjBMOw==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>Using Image_height for the size of the seam array in seam_carve_width works for me.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Source: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35532427/how-to-dynamically-allocate-arrays-in-c" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35532427/how-to-dynamically-allocate-arrays-in-c</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>my algo must not be right but u fixed the error, thanks !!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Turns out, I don't think it is necessary to dynamically allocate memory for the seam array. View
<a data-pats="post_ref" href="768" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('768');">@768</a>
 for more details.

------------------------@1172-------------------------
what does this mean and what's wrong with it? is it wrong or another error?
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_4.01.02_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkvzu6bn6plqol%2Fe5430fc3c043847331726b199cdc9dc5925c5e7bb131428a2faf1b421bd93314%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_4.01.02_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Segfaults are caused by a program trying to read or write an illegal memory location. In practice, segfaults are almost always due to trying to read or write a non-existent array element, not properly defining a pointer before using it, or (in C programs) accidentally using a variable's value as an address.</p>


<p>Source: <a href="https://kb.iu.edu/d/aqsj" target="_blank">https://kb.iu.edu/d/aqsj</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>There is likely an edge case where you have an out of bounds error in your loops. </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Somewhere in your program, you are likely indexing out of bounds or trying to access memory you shouldn’t be allowed to access. Try setting up your debugger, adding a few breakpoints, and narrowing down where in your code your program is crashing!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1173-------------------------
class question
<p>Can someone explain why c3.print() can compile since the print function requires const?  </p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksp009ktmfh7kh%2F4f0b470c8da78e3a882ebac6a72115b182faecd5d8d60272ea162616c9a9b929%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The <code>const</code> in the <code>print()</code> function dictates that no matter what happens within the function, the object it’s being called on cannot be modified. Since printing the contents of something shouldn’t modify anything (it just retrieves info and prints it!), this <code>const</code> constraint should still be satisfied.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
Thanks! Also why d can’t compile?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>D doesn’t compile because the <code>addCream()</code> function modifies the object, but <code>c3_r</code> is set as <code>const</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1175-------------------------
Matrix_At function
<p>Why doesn't this work for my matrix_at function?<img alt="image.pngNaN" height="145" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk45otymxgq74m%2Fa136d899cfbdfbe9b01cae29736d343d725410dfab26b981b801a6df22f85d09%2Fimage.png" width="619"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Underneath the hood, a Matrix object is a struct that contains <code>int width; int height;</code> and <code>int data[500]</code>. In other words, all the data is only in a 1D array. Our goal of this project is in <code>Matrix.cpp</code> to make our Matrix look and work as a 2D array with the functions we are implementing.</p>
<p>In this function, with the information you have (width, height, and a 1D array), how can you get the ptr to the right place in the 1D array given a row and column? If this is confusing, I recommend checking the p2 overview slides on eecs280.org, it gives a visual diagram for what we are trying to do</p></div>

You may find it useful to look at the results from your own code and visually compare them to the provided correct outputs when debugging the algorithm."</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>After running processing_public_tests.exe, these files are created in your working directory with the extension .out appended before the .ppm extension. The correct files that you should compare these to have the extension .correct appended.</p>

------------------------@1177-------------------------
Remove vertical seam issues
<p>Hi, below I have pasted my implementation for remove_vertical_seam</p>


<p>The idea was to iterate through the image, and if the index stored in seam is equal to the current column, take the pixel AFTER the skipped one from the original image and add it to the new one. If the index stored in seam is not equal to the current column, just copy and paste the pixel from the original image. It complies and I do not get any indexing assertion error. I do get an assert failure because the correct image and the one produced by the algorithm are not equal. Any advice on what could be going wrong is greatly appreciated. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_4.26.39_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0h8pe7gr356m%2Fdc842a0035bbcb85daa7bdfe301701ed8edc44f7b418c0584f6117d8a5a80c71%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_4.26.39_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Let's say your image is 10x10 and in your current row, you want to skip column 4. Let us now say that j == 7. This means we would want to copy <strong>col 8 of our old image into col 7 of our new image.</strong> In your current code, since 7!=4, would go into the first if statement and copy <strong>col 7 of our old image into col 7 of our new image</strong>. You may want to look into separating your cases into before the removal col, and after the removal column instead.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1179-------------------------
A question about the implementation of rotate_left function.
<p>This is the given implementation of rotate_left function.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" height="401" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7gbxa2boas4b6%2F30954f325a7c98445ba1039bf322643de12ee5ff71b374a0da5b001b7feb76c8%2Fimage.png" width="577"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>In this implementation, a new auxiliary image is created and the new rotated image is stored into it. Then we need to copy data into original.</p>


<p></p>


<p>When copying data back into original, why it is implemented in such way? To my understanding, the memory diagram  should be like, there are two image objects in the dynamic allocated memory. Before copying back, <strong><kbd>img</kbd></strong> is pointed to the original image object and <strong><kbd>aux</kbd></strong> is pointed to the new rotated image. Therefore, we need to first delete the original image object in the dynamic memory, then let <kbd><strong>img</strong></kbd> points to the new rotated image. So to my understanding this implementation should be like this:</p>


<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">delete</span> img; <span class="hljs-comment">// delete the original image object in the dynamic memory</span>
img = aux;  <span class="hljs-comment">//let img points to the new rotated image</span><div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('ZGVsZXRlJTIwaW1nOyUyMC8vJTIwZGVsZXRlJTIwdGhlJTIwb3JpZ2luYWwlMjBpbWFnZSUyMG9iamVjdCUyMGluJTIwdGhlJTIwZHluYW1pYyUyMG1lbW9yeSUwQWltZyUyMD0lMjBhdXg7JTIwJTIwLy9sZXQlMjBpbWclMjBwb2ludHMlMjB0byUyMHRoZSUyMG5ldyUyMHJvdGF0ZWQlMjBpbWFnZQ==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>

------------------------@1181-------------------------
How do we run our own images in resize.cpp
<p>When I do make test everything runs fine and when I run resize.cpp for horse it also works. I know our argument format has to be [file name] [write file] width height. I want to test my own image for resize.cpp. if I have an image named test.ppm and I wanted to resize it to 100x100, what should I trype into the command line, and do I have to make a second file to be my write file?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div>Your program should automatically create the output file.</div>
<div><br/></div>
./resize.cpp test.ppm output.ppm 100 100

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Do you convert a jpg to ppm using an online converter or just by editing the file name.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You have to use an online converter. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Beware, many online converters convert the image to a "P6" .ppm format. This is different than the "P3" format we are using in our program. You can tell the difference because the first line of the file is either "P6" or "P3". I used this online converter to convert the P6 files to P3 files to use with my program:</p>


<p></p>


<p>https://thomasebsmith.github.io/ppm-converter/</p>

------------------------@1182-------------------------
Question from 9/26 Lecture 8
<p><img alt="image.png" height="276" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkygly41gpcw26m%2F3902086d179cedae43b575facc2c8adc05b247b48aafd7b645a32a75b6683480%2Fimage.png" width="220"/></p>


<p>Can someone explain why we need the &amp; when declaring c3_r? Why can't we just do<br/>const Coffee c3_r = c3; </p>


<p>?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The <code>&amp;</code> is not a necessity when declaring a new object (like <code>c3_r</code>) - using it creates a reference (just like how <code>int &amp;y = x</code> makes <code>y</code> a reference to variable <code>x</code>). You can access the same object using either <code>c3_r</code> or <code>c3</code>!</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1183-------------------------
How do we acess input strings using argv?
<p>I'm confused how we access the strings within argv to use them. Can anyone help explain this? How would I retrieve the entire string of the second element in argv?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>argv is an array that stores the command line arguments in the form of c-strings. argv[1] would retrieve the entire string of the second element in argv.</p>

     &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-string">"WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original"</span> &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>I'm just wondering if we should be altering this line in any way, like for example if the error is that they gave the wrong number of arguments, should we still inform them that WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original? Since this is not really the error they're running into.</p>

------------------------@1185-------------------------
Why is autograder giving me this error?
<p>I don't understand why I have this error as there is literally a member variable int width in Image.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_5.33.36_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt02wxxzym346%2F1d3c7e35ab1000bbb8272cf379061be24dcab975ba09f7de112baba6c6b4b536%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_5.33.36_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The error you are receiving here has to do with the fact that you are not respecting the interfaces.</p>


<p>You should not be directly accessing the data held by your image struct using the -&gt; operator in your processing.cpp file. Instead, you should use the functions you wrote to access this data (Image_width, Image_height, Image_get_pixel, etc).</p>


<p></p>


<p>Please read the "Respect the interfaces!" section of the project spec. </p>


<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#interface-1" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#interface-1</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Is there any way to remove the width by one pixel whilst respecting the interfaces? img_width is a const so it doesn't allow changes to it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes! You can create a temporary image, initialize it with width-1, use a for loop to copy all the pixels except the seam from img to the temp, then write *img = *temp to set the previous image equal to the new, smaller image. Don't forget to delete the temp image when you're done with it to avoid memory leaks.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1186-------------------------
respecting interface while copying new_img to img in remove_vertical_seam()
<p>Hi,</p>


<p></p>


<p>for remove_vertical_seam(), after creating and filling up new_img as my new image with the seam removed, I have 2 options for how to copy this new_img back to img:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1:</p>


<div>
<div>Image_init(img, width-1, height);</div>
<br/>
<div>for(int i=0;i&lt;height;i++){</div>
<div>for(int j=0;j&lt;width-1;j++){</div>
<div>Pixel p=Image_get_pixel(new_img, i, j);</div>
<div>Image_set_pixel(img, i, j, p);</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>delete new_img;</div>
<div></div>
</div>


<div>2:
<div>
<div>*img = *new_img;</div>
<div>delete new_img;</div>
<div></div>
</div>
</div>


<div>Both of these seem to work fine. I was just wondering, are both options okay in terms of respecting the interface and address sanitizer (i.e. memory leaks)?</div>



<div>Thanks,</div>


<div>Muskaan.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes they should be fine as long as you're not accessing the members of the structs</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1187-------------------------
test rotate processing public tests
<p>my test rotate function is failing. wasn't rotate a built in function? how is this failing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The rotate functions use student written functions from Image.cpp. If those are not working properly, the rotate function won't work properly as well.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Adding onto the student's response.</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1190-------------------------

<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_5.47.23_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkvzu6bn6plqol%2F5b8bd717db5c638fbdbe83928eb75524c5dffe86d307c8e3ecb9734079889ef6%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_5.47.23_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>i had the same error for my matrix tests. it means you're going out of bounds somewhere in your resize file, for example, in terms of indexing, which is probably the most probable cause for this</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As the student's answer suggests, a segmentation fault is likely the result of attempting to index out-of-bounds on a matrix. Many of the functions you implement in processing.cpp contain edge cases where you will want to be extra careful that you do not attempt to access something at an invalid index.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Are you calling resize without any additional command line arguments eg</p>


<pre>./resize.exe file_in.ppm file_out.ppm 4 5</pre>
<p></p>


<p>You may be indexing out of bounds if you tried to get the filenames (ex: argv[2]) when you just called ./resize.exe since argc == 1. Make sure you check the length of argv before attempting to get any of the filenames or new width/heights</p>

------------------------@1194-------------------------
Problem with Image_print
<div>
<div>void Image_print(const Image* img, std::ostream&amp; os) {</div>
<div>Pixel test;</div>
<div>Pixel test1;</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; "P3" &lt;&lt; std::endl;</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; img-&gt;width &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; img-&gt;height &lt;&lt; std::endl;</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; "255" &lt;&lt; std::endl;</div>
<div>for (int i = 0; i &lt; img-&gt;height; ++i){</div>
<div>  for (int j = 0; j &lt; img-&gt;width; ++j){</div>
<div>   </div>
<div> </div>
<div> </div>
<br/>
<div>    os &lt;&lt; test.r &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; test.g &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; test.b &lt;&lt; " ";</div>
<div> <strong>   if (i == img-&gt;height - 1 &amp;&amp; j == img-&gt;width - 1){</strong></div>
<div>      os &lt;&lt; std::endl;</div>
<div>    }</div>
<div>  }</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
</div>



<div>So this is what we have for our Image_print function (we are trying to match the public test case right now) and we have an idea on how to match the print format needed, but we are struggling with the syntax. The bolded line is the line that is giving us the issue, and is also the line that we are using to print in the proper format. We have looked into modifying lvalues and how it is not possible, but we aren't sure of how to go about writing this in a way that doesn't give us syntax errors. Thank you.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You know when you exit the inner for loop, you have reached the end of a line. What can you then print before the outer for loop iterates? Similarly, after your exit the both for loops, you know you have printed the entire image. What can you print to match the format.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So the format that we are looking for looks something like this:</p>


<div>
<div>"P3\n2 2\n255\n255 0 0 0 255 0 \n0 0 255 255 255 255 \n";</div>
</div>


<p>What we had beforehand is something like this:</p>


<div>
<div>"P3\n2 2\n255\n255 0 0 \n0 255 0 \n0 0 255 \n255 255 255 \n";</div>
</div>


<p></p>


<p>So in ours, we had 2 extra lines, which we are trying to remove. We are trying to print two sets of numbers (so 6 numbers), end the line, and then print another 2 sets of numbers (also 6), then end the line. Sorry, I'm not quite sure if I completely understand the suggestion that you made...</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Look into this --&gt; <a href="https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/cpp-program-to-print-a-2d-array/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/cpp-program-to-print-a-2d-array/</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>It's the same idea except instead of printing one element of a single array, you can print the three pixels like you are now</p>

------------------------@1196-------------------------
Respecting interface in resize.cpp
<p>When I create an image object in resize.cpp, can I just do img.width and img.height? or should I be calling Image_Height(&amp;img) and Image_width(&amp;img)? Do we get graded for respecting the interface in resize.cpp? thanks</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Accessing the image data directly using .width is not respecting the interface. You should be calling Image_width.</p>


<div>I am almost positive we are graded on respecting the interface in resize.cpp.</div>


<div>Regardless, accessing data members directly when outside of the interface is considered very bad practice and you should always call the member functions.</div>
