------------------------@1201-------------------------
Trouble w/ image_set_pixel
<p>I keep getting errors when I index into pixels like this, but why? The objects are pixels so I don't see why there is an issue. How do I fix this and implement the function properly?</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F9b17c0fa4a5fa7061fb23117144ea600802611456ca09022dadc14829e4c63c3%2Fimagesetpixel.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">imagesetpixel.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>First of all, this is a void function. Void functions do not return anything. </p>


<p>In your function, seting red, green, and blue to cred, creen, and crue does nothing because the red, green, and blue variables are never used again.</p>


<p>Also, the Image_get_pixel function returns a pixel, not a *pixel. </p>


<p></p>


<p>For each image, there are three matrixes: red_channel, green_channel, and blue_channel.</p>


<p>I think to implement this function, you should use the Matrix_at function with the given row and column on each of these matrices and set the value of the matrix to the corresponding r g or b value of the color pixel.</p>

------------------------@1210-------------------------
question about assumptions for RME clauses
<p>can we assume that the input will always be in proper PPM format for Image_init?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In the requires clause for Image_init it says "is contains an image in PPM format without comments (any kind of whitespace is ok)"</p>


<p></p>


<p>Does this answer your question?</p>


<p></p>


<p>We will not be tested on input that violates the requires clause.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>so then do all of these count?</p>


<p>regular white space: " "</p>


<p>tab: "\t"</p>


<p>newline: "\n"</p>


<p></p>


<p>are there any I am missing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes this is all valid as part of the input. I can't think of any others you are missing.</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you just treat the input stream for Image_init as if it were cin, the whitespace is skipped automatically.</p>

------------------------@1212-------------------------
VSCode Debugger: Exe File
<p>For the debugger on vscode, do I have to go in manually every time to change the file in the launch.json that I want to debug?</p>


<p>[I am on M processor MacBook]</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You only have to change the file specified in <code>launch.json</code> so that it will call the code you’re trying to debug.</p>
<p>If you are working on <code>Matrix.cpp</code> and are only running <code>Matrix_tests.exe</code>, then you can just leave the file in <code>launch.json</code> set to <code>Matrix_tests.exe</code>. Later on, if you are wrapping up <code>resize.cpp</code> and find a bug in <code>Matrix</code>, then you don’t necessarily have to change the file in <code>launch.json</code> back to <code>Matrix_tests.cpp</code>. You could just leave it set to <code>resize.cpp</code> and use the step in button to get to the <code>Matrix</code> functions.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1221-------------------------
remove_vertical_seam always removing last column
<p>My remove_vertical_seam function is only ever removing the last column of an image. Currently, I have it set up as an if function where if the column number &lt; the seam column number, it copies the pixel from img into the smaller image, and if the column number &gt; the seam column number, it copies the pixel over. Is there an obvious problem in my logic? I've tried debugging and it always appears that it's only copying over the correct values but my _removed.out.ppm shows that it is only removing the last column.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I used this exact same logic in my program and it worked well.</p>


<p>How are you copying the pixels to the smaller image/ the smaller image to the original image at the end of the function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Splitting the pixel copying action logically between col&lt;seam and col&gt;seam seems appropriate, but make sure that when it’s “copying the pixel over”, it puts each input pixel in the output image, but moved to the left by 1—that is, if <code>seam[2] == 3</code>, for example, then the input pixel at row 2, column 5 should be written to row 2, column 4 in the output image.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To copy the original image into the smaller image, I'm doing Image_set_pixel(smallImg, row, column, Image_get_pixel(img, row, column)); where smallImg is the new smaller image. At the end to copy the smaller image back onto the original, I do *img = *smallImg. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is exactly what I did. I am stumped.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Just figured it out, thank you for helping me narrow down the problem. I think the problem was when I was copying over the columns that are greater than the seam column number, I was leaving the column that i was supposed to be skipping blank. For the columns greater than the seam, I had to change the code to  Image_set_pixel(smallImg, row, column - 1, Image_get_pixel(img, row, column));</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Of course! I should have thought to mention that. That was a tricky one for me too.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1226-------------------------
Things about matrix we should know for this project
<p>Hi, I didn't take eecs 183 here. So, I didn't learn about the matrix. So, I found it difficult to start the project. What should I know about matrix in order to do this project? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
go to matrix.h to see. They are not black-boxy at all, they are very direct, and nothing makes them special, they are just a struct.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Matrix.h has comments that describe the Matrix struct more and how we expect the Matrix functions to work. Matrix is just a struct with 3 attributes: width, height, and a data array. We can think of a matrix as an nxm structure, but we implement it in code as a 1D array that would have length nxm. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1227-------------------------
comments for grades?
<p>Hi, I want to ask whether we should write comments in order to get grades? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Comments are not graded

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>

------------------------@1228-------------------------
Get_pixel: unsure how to return a pixel? Set_pixel: confused as to the difference in code?
<p>Hihi, </p>


<p></p>


<p>I've been digging through multiple Piazza posts on the topic and wanted to reach out for specific help. As I'm working on the Image.cpp file, I have encountered an obvious issue where my code for the image_get_pixel and image_set_pixel function are relatively the same. The only difference I understand is having to return a pixel (which I'm struggling to figure out) and returning nothing with the void function. I know the question may seem vague, but I would appreciate some clarification and potential guidance on this. I have attached my code for the two functions below. Thank you!</p>


<p></p>


<pre><span class="hljs-comment">// REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Image_height(img)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Image_width(img)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">// EFFECTS:  Returns the pixel in the Image at the given row and column.</span>
Pixel Image_get_pixel(<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> Image* img, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> row, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> column) {
  assert(img-&gt;width &amp;&amp; img-&gt;height);
  assert(<span class="hljs-number">0</span> &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Image_height(img));
  assert(<span class="hljs-number">0</span> &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Image_width(img)); 

  <span class="hljs-comment">// Creates a new Pixel struct object by reading each of the red, green,</span>
  <span class="hljs-comment">// and blue matrices.</span>
  Pixel color;
  color.r = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;red_channel, row, column);
  color.g = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;green_channel, row, column);
  color.b = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;blue_channel, row, column);

  <span class="hljs-keyword">return</span> (Pixel); <span class="hljs-comment">// not working</span>
}

<span class="hljs-comment">// REQUIRES: img points to a valid Image</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Image_height(img)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Image_width(img)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">// MODIFIES: *img</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">// EFFECTS:  Sets the pixel in the Image at the given row and column</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           to the given color.</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">void</span> Image_set_pixel(Image* img, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> row, <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> column, Pixel color) {
  assert(img-&gt;width &amp;&amp; img-&gt;height);
  assert(<span class="hljs-number">0</span> &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Image_height(img));
  assert(<span class="hljs-number">0</span> &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Image_width(img));
  
  <span class="hljs-comment">// Accesses the struct object and sets the pixel to the given color</span>
  <span class="hljs-comment">// by reading each of the red, green, and blue matrices.</span>
  Pixel color = Image_get_pixel(img, row, column);

  color.r = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;red_channel, row, column);
  color.g = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;green_channel, row, column);
  color.b = *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;blue_channel, row, column);
}<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>Might be easier to read this way.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyvv749q0l113%2F9d7187a7bac3cdd63e48b1ca4f25b79cfcf2e7755af176126387fe24b4c00681%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You have the right idea in the Image_get_pixel function as it is supposed to just access the Matrix channels of the image and return the values in a Pixel struct. You just have to return the Pixel object you create and not the general "Pixel" data type.</p>


<p></p>


<p>For Image_set_pixel, you do not return anything as the goal is to again index into the Matrix channels of the image, and this time set the three matrices at the given row and column with the given pixel. You do not need to call Image_get_pixel in there as you are given the Pixel you are setting the color channels to via the "Pixel color" parameter. Using this parameter, access the color channel matrices at the given row/col and set each one to the corresponding value of the color parameter.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1231-------------------------
P3 Matrix.cpp Code compiles but fails basic and print tests
<p>What exactly does the segmentation fault error mean for the print function and how can I fix the Basic test to pass.</p>


<p><img alt="" height="603" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt05rt9dco53is%2Ffb688dcdbf845c5eb35a5420dba316589d43cf37f87b4a899df0ce025ac4e998%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-26_at_9.34.23_PM.png" width="2790"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Segfaults are caused by a program trying to read or write an illegal memory location. In practice, segfaults are almost always due to trying to read or write a non-existent array element, not properly defining a pointer before using it, or (in C programs) accidentally using a variable's value as an address.</p>


<p>Source: <a href="https://kb.iu.edu/d/aqsj" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://kb.iu.edu/d/aqsj</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>There is likely an edge case where you have an out of bounds error in your loops. </p>


<p></p>


<p>I suggest using a visual debugger or going to office hours for more help.</p>

------------------------@1238-------------------------
atoi/stoi error for resize on autograder
<p>confused on this error i'm getting from the autograder:</p>


<p></p>


<p>terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::invalid_argument'</p>


<p>what(): stoi</p>


<p></p>


<p>in my resize.cpp function i #included &lt;cstdlib&gt; and only ever used atoi, not stoi, so i don't understand why i'm getting this error.</p>


<p></p>


<p>is there something else i should be including? any help would be appreciated :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It seems like it doesn’t like the argument you’re passing into the function parenthesis. Confirm that you are giving it one c-string. It should be in the format:
int num = std::atoi( argv[#] );</p>
<p>argv[#] is the c-string from the command line, which becomes a number as is given to the num integer.</p>
<p>Hope this helps.</p></div>

------------------------@1243-------------------------
resize.cpp
<p>In resize.cpp after we call argc and argv in the parameters of main, I'm confused on how we write input/out fstreams?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Once you declare your ifstream variable, you can open the file you want to read from using .open(filename) on your ifstream variable where filename is the second command line argument argv[1]. Once you are done reading the file using the ifstream similar to how you would use a cin stream, close the file using .close() on your ifstream variable.</p>


<p></p>


<p>ofstream works the same way as ifstream but for output.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Here is a link to the lecture notes on this topic. Scroll down to "File I/O": <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/05_Strings_Streams_IO.html#strings-streams-io" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/05_Strings_Streams_IO.html#strings-streams-io</a></p>

------------------------@1246-------------------------
no instance of overloaded function "Matrix_at" matches the argument list
<p>My code gives me this error when I pass in channel matrixes to the Matrix_at function in image.cpp. I've tried just giving img-&gt;[color]_channel to the parameter(+ row, column) and declaring a separate const variable that just points at img-&gt;[color]_channel and then pass it onto the parameter, but it still seems to fail with the same reason. What seems to be the issue here?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Matrix_at calls for a Matrix pointer. img-&gt;[color]_channel is just a Matrix. This means you will have to send the address of img-&gt;[color]_channel to the function by using the &amp; operator.</p>

------------------------@1257-------------------------
UB check problem and double free or corruption problem
<p>In autograder, there is a problem shown in autograder called corruption or double free in the matrix_test. We are confused about why this problem occurred. It looks like this: </p>


<p>*** Error in `./Matrix_tests.exe': double free or corruption (out): 0x0000000000c853c0 ***</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, we have another problem in UB check in matrix_test and already delete all the new matrix created. It looks like this: </p>


<p>==91==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow on address 0x7faea0207a48 at pc 0x000000426be6 bp 0x7ffd60cc8780 sp 0x7ffd60cc8770</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you so much for your help and time! </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>heap-buffer-overflow</code> typically means your program is trying to access heap memory beyond the end of a chunk of heap memory that it owns. Take a closer look at the address sanitizer’s error (from the submission timestamped at 9:26 PM)—the first lines include a stack trace taken at the instant the illegal memory access occurred. Line 4 ends in “Matrix.cpp:23”, so it tells you that line 23 in Matrix.cpp caused the illegal memory access. How could that line have led your program to access memory past the end of a chunk it owns?</p>
<p>By comparing the program’s output during the UB check and that during the double-free/corruption test run, you can tell that both errors happened inside the same test case, so they are probably related. By fixing the UB problem, you will probably fix the double-free/corruption error as well.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Could you update your username to include your uniqname so we can look you up on autograder?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sure, my unique name is huayuz. </p>

------------------------@1259-------------------------
Matrix_row problem
<p>For Matrix_row, our thought process behind this was to find the distance between the pointer given and mat-&gt;data. Then, to find the row, we did the distance / mat-&gt;width. We are passing the public tests for Matrix_row, but not our own personal tests, and we can't seem to pinpoint the issue using the debugger. Any thoughts on what could be the issue?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
so by default any number on its own is an integer so when you divide the distance by width, whatever number you get is always rounded down, that number will only work in certain cases and not all, so you need a way to fix that.

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>According to your autograder submission from the time, you mixed up the row and height numbers between <code>Matrix_init</code> and <code>Matrix_at</code> in your test. By calling <code>Matrix_init(mat, 3, 4)</code>, you initialized <code>mat</code> to have a <em>width of 3</em> and a <em>height of 4</em>. This means it has 3 <em>columns</em> and 4 <em>rows</em>, so the valid columns are 0, 1, 2, while the valid rows are 0, 1, 2, 3.</p>
<p>Then, you did <code>Matrix_at(mat, 0, 3)</code>, which takes row 0 and column 3. <code>mat</code> does not have a column 3 (only 0, 1, and 2), so the 3 was out-of-bounds.</p>
<p>Long story short, the ordering of the parameters in <code>Matrix_init</code> and <code>Matrix_at</code> are effectively swapped. For some <code>Matrix_init(mat, x, y)</code>, <code>Matrix_at(mat, a, b)</code> must satisfy <code>a &lt; y</code> and <code>b &lt; x</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Is there a hint? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1260-------------------------
Image print erroring in public test
<p>I'm getting an error in my Image_public_tests in the (test_image_to_and_from). I got the image input from string to work, but when I uncommented the image print section I started getting an error. It says that the width is 0 and the height is negative. Does anyone know why I am getting this error?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Resolved according to your most recent autograder submission. For others: make sure to explicitly read in <code>P3</code>, the width, the height, and <code>255</code> before beginning to load pixels into the image in <code>Image_init(Image* img, std::istream&amp; is)</code>.</p></div>

------------------------@1263-------------------------
Some errors I'm having
<p>I keep getting some errors that happen pretty repeatedly throughout my function. For starters, in my image_fill function, it won't let me manipulate the value of img-&gt;red_channel.data into color.r, renamed red for simplicity. Also, I'm not sure my pointer for loop is working properly, I am aware that I can't use regular ints like width and height, but what do I use instead? Also, do I index the pointer at 0? Thanks.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F9174cd961b02b4fc65690672997f9e6807f987b25392d38b028d39dc193f7ba7%2Fptrerror1.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">ptrerror1.png</a></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F58c054565ec05fc5e82614a03664305db59f11e25966b54bf97c9f1b72a35110%2Fincompints.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">incompints.png</a></p>


<p>Here's my Image.cpp file.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F48da3b9994234cd5279f5ee3b1b55fdb73f84fbf866f7e5bce1b1d656c0504b2%2FImage.cpp" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Image.cpp</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For your pointer for loop, remember that you can use pointer arithemetic to help you here. Your pointer should start by pointing to an address in memory that you want to start looking at, not the value 0. For example, if you wanted to start your loop at index (2, 3), you would have a pointer pointing to that element. </p>


<p>If you wanted your loop to end at index (2, 5), you'd want to go until your pointer is less than the address of that index. More information here: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/04_Arrays.html#array-indexing" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/04_Arrays.html#array-indexing</a> I'd check out the traversal by pointer section!</p>


<p>For your image errors, it looks like you're setting image-&gt;red_channel.data(which is an array of ints) to a single integer, which is where the error comes from. You'll need to set a specific element in the matrix to that value. (I'd reccomend using your matrix_at function!)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1264-------------------------
Error Squiggles
I accidentally turned off the red error squiggles. How do I turn them back on?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Are you using VSCode? Go to settings in the bottom left corner, or do <code>cmd + ,</code>. Search “error squiggles”.
Alternatively, once settings are open, click the icon that looks like this in the top right:</p>
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7e8alqn6rj6u0%2Fd4ef52d5f9ef70882f232fc367c4608f31e891869a5bf5cff903f6bf7ce3c88f%2Fimage.png"/></p>
<p>This will direct you to the json file that vscode uses to store your settings that deviate from the defaults.</p>
<p>Do <code>cmd + f</code> and search squiggles. There should be a line about that. Delete this line to restore that setting to the default (on).</p></div>

------------------------@1266-------------------------
Autograder Feedback
<p>Does this feedback on the Autograder for Student Matrix Tests indicate that our tests are telling us we have an issue in our implementation of a function when we really don't? Just want to make sure my partner and I are understanding this feedback correctly. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Error given:</p>


<p>False positives detected in 1 of your tests. Those tests reported an error when run against a correct implementation.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
This means that the tests you wrote are being run on an implementation that the professors have designated as completely correct. A false positive means that your code is reporting a bug where one does not exist. So far for me that has always meant that my test code had an issue in it.
<br/>
Hope this helps.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1267-------------------------
initializing seam
<p>Working on seam_carve_width. I was wondering how to initialize a seam variable to pass into the find_minimal_vertical_seam function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
According to
<a href="https://piazza.com/class/l7548zpfvr8yj?cid=768" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a>
<a data-pats="post_ref" href="768" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('768');">@768</a>
, you should just initialize the seam with the maximum value. However, this violates one of the function's required clauses.
<div>If you wish to follow the required clause, you can use the solution I found here: <a href="https://piazza.com/class/l7548zpfvr8yj?cid=1158" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><a href="https://piazza.com/class/l7548zpfvr8yj?cid=1158" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank"></a><a data-pats="post_ref" href="1158" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1158');">@1158</a></div>
<div><br/></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How do I call this in the function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You should just initialize seam in seam_carve_width like so: int seam[MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT]
<div><br/></div>
<div>The pass that to find_minimal_vertical_seam.</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>and how do I initialize seam in find_minimal_vertical_seam</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You dont need to initialize seam in find_minimal_vertical_seam because it is already initialized before it is passed to this function. To edit values of seam though, just write seam[column] = newValue

------------------------@1268-------------------------
fails for public test but works when tested seperately
<p>so I get 2 errors for the public test for two of my functions, the print and the row one, however when I tested them seperately with the same conditions in the int main() of a different cpp file, I get the correct answer. For some reason it is only giving a wrong value when the matrix_public_test.exe file is executed. Can someone say why this is happening?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What is the error code?<br/>For print, there could be a whitespace difference between the answer they want and what your code is printing. Your ppm printing could be "correct" in the sense that it's a valid ppm file, but the tests will test to make sure that it is exactly the same as their formatting. Try opening the Marix_public_test.cpp file to see what exactly your output is being compared to. Space and newline placement must be exact.</p>


<p>Hope this helps.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The root cause is in your <code>Matrix_at</code> implementation. It appears to treat <code>row</code> and <code>column</code> as starting from 1 even though they actually start from 0. When <code>row == 0</code>, and <code>column == 0</code>, we’re referring to the valid top left cell of a matrix.</p>
<p>(How do we find this root cause? Your <code>Matrix_print</code> printed <code>42 1</code>, which suggests that the matrix’s width got set to 42 even though it got initialized to 1. Where could this have come from? Most likely line 49 of Matrix_public_test, where we have the most relevant appearance of 42. How did that end up setting the width instead? You might have stepped before of the <code>data</code> array and ended up overwriting the width instead. <strong>You can verify all of this by setting a breakpoint on that line 49 and stepping into <code>Matrix_at</code> in the debugger.</strong>)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
The matrix row function only prints a number row, when I do it seperately I get the correct answer which is 2 but through the test file they say error 1=! 2. For the print one, again I get what should be printed but on the test file it prints something else entirely for some reason.

<p>When you run your code in XCode, does XCode rebuild it first? Setting XCode to produce "Debug" builds (instead of "Release" ones) might fix this.</p>


<p>In ambiguous situations like this one, I recommend you try building and running your code on CAEN, as that is the closest environment to the autograder's. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1276-------------------------
Check if a file exists in resize.cpp
<p>How are we meant to check if a file exists in resize.cpp? I am currently using the is_open member function but when I try it on an output file that doesn't exist, the file is just created and my function doesn't put out an error.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Your program seems to be working correctly. It is supposed to create/rewrite the output file of specified name. If there doesn't already exist an output file, it should create it with no error.
<div><br/><div>The only way I can think that opening the output file would fail is if there already exists a file with that name and you don't have permission to write to it.</div></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But in the project specification, it says that if the output file cannot be opened, then we are supposed to output an error message and return a nonzero value. My program doesn't fulfill that requirement since the file is created when I call is_open on it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Also, if it's intended for our program to create the output file if it doesn't exist, how are we supposed to test our "file does not exist" error implementation?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From the project spec:</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7pepmm2tsbqm%2Fb7e1578859710a76a290bd2eae4b923173b1c02478da88eb18bdb5606dd858e6%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>I'm not sure what "file does not exist" error implementation you are referencing.</p>


<p>As I said in the answer, the only way I can think that an output file could not be opened is if there already exists a file with that name and you don't have permission to write to it. Your program should only output the error message and return a nonzero value when the file cannot be opened.</p>

------------------------@1279-------------------------
command line args resize
<p>Hello, quick question for the resize.cpp file regarding it accepting the command line arguments and other file reading/writing details. Am I allowed to assume that the arguments will always be passed in the order given by the example? Does the file I am writing to need to be created before resize runs or would resize create the file? How do I account for the directory that the files resize is reading from and writing to? Should I just assume that they are in the same directory as the program? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think you can assume the arguments will always be passed in the order given by the example (I think they would include that in the error checking section if it was necessary).</p>


<p>The file you are writing to does not have to be created before running resize.</p>


<p>Assuming you are using fstream, the directory that you are reading and writing from depends on the input. If the input is a file path, you will read and write to the directory/file specified by the file path. If the input is just a filename, you will read and write to the same directory as the program. You don't have to account for the directory inside of your program.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1280-------------------------
Errors
<p>I keep getting these errors in my Image functions, and I'm not sure how to resolve them. Additionally, I'm not really sure how to implement a pointer traversal, or if I should just do a regular nested for loop.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F9174cd961b02b4fc65690672997f9e6807f987b25392d38b028d39dc193f7ba7%2Fptrerror1.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">ptrerror1.png</a></p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F58c054565ec05fc5e82614a03664305db59f11e25966b54bf97c9f1b72a35110%2Fincompints.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">incompints.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>For the first error, it doesn’t look like you’re using pointer traversal correctly. Your stepper var should be an integer that is added to the pointer to the first element in the array.</p>
<p>You can read more on pages 26 and 27 in lecture 4’s slides <a href="https://drive.google.com/drive/u/2/folders/1k81KJg0yGFnqn9vhZqlykjaMzZ0b2Mok" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here.</a></p>
<p>For your second error, <code>img-›red_channel.data = red</code> isn’t working for a couple of reasons.</p>
<p>One, <code>img-&gt;red_channel</code> gives a pointer to the red_channel matrix. You want to dereference this pointer in order to actually modify anything in that object. Also, I’m assuming <code>red</code> is an integer. <code>red_channel</code> is of course an integer array, and you cannot assign that a value of an integer.</p>
<p>Second, although there are other issues with this line as explained above, you do not want to be accessing the .data array from the channels directly. This is breaking the interface of Matrix since <code>red_channel</code> is a Matrix. You will want to use the Matrix_at() functions to set a particular value in this channel.</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1282-------------------------
Test Cases Involving fstream
<p>I am testing my image_init on fstream. I am able to pass an input file stream to init and output file stream to print. However, how do I compare the two files (i.e., the files created by print and the correct file)? I tried using ASSERT_TRUE(Image_equal(img1, img)) where img is the original file and img1 is what I printed after initializing but it didn't work.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In lecture we were briefly introduced to string streams. Using the std::istringstream and std::ostringstream from the #include &lt;cstdlib&gt; header, we can convert these stream's contents to strings and compare the strings. If you find the slides for lecture 7 <a href="https://drive.google.com/drive/u/2/folders/1k81KJg0yGFnqn9vhZqlykjaMzZ0b2Mok" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>, pages 20-22 show the usage of these streams for testing. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1283-------------------------
Is it possible for an image to have an empty pixel?
<p>For example, a 5x5 image is supposed to have 25 pixels, but the input only provides information about 24 pixels. is that possible? </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1285-------------------------
Seam[] type not allowing for it to be added to
<p>I have written the find_minimal_vertical_seam and when debugging it gets all the right values but when it tries to add those values to the seam array, it doesn't do anything. My debugger says that seam[] is of type int* which is confusing because I thought that seam was just an array of integer column values. Does anyone know how to fix this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Under the hood, an integer array is just a pointer to the address of the first integer in the array. The syntax arr[x] is translated by the compiler to *(arr + x). How are you adding the values to the seam array?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I tried doing *(seam + r) = x and it doesn't show the whole array in my debugger, it instead shows only one value in seam. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Can you not just use seam[r] = x ?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As @fdm said, because this array is itself just a pointer, the debugger only shows the value that this points to (the first integer). That is normal behavior.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
I'm having the exact same problem, I've tried seam[x] and *(seam + x). Neither one has worked. seam always shows up as a const* int and when it's dereferenced it has a value of 0.

------------------------@1286-------------------------
Testing Processing.cpp
<p>How do we actually test our functions in processing so we know where things went wrong? Currently running the processing public tests just tells me that an assertion in image_init has failed but it doesn't tell me what part of processing is wrong, or any other insight. </p>


<p></p>


<p>I know we are supposed to set up CAEN but what does that actually mean? Is it a website that we submit our files too? is it a command that we run that would give us more insight as to where our program went wrong? Thanks so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Setting up CAEN is specifically useful for debugging undefined behavior in an autograder-like enviroment (in cases where your program works on your local machine but not the autograder). See the CAEN setup for more information.</p>


<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>If your functions are not working properly on your local machine, you should try using a visual debugger to help find your bugs.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>CAEN is the computing services team at UMichigan, and they have a platform/environment set up for you to develop on computers and laptops across Michigan. We use that environment as a "ground zero" since we run the autograder using the same environment/configuration.</p>


<p></p>


<p>As for a command to figure out what went wrong, I would highly recommend having your visual debugger on hand, since you can see the variables and objects during the runtime of the program.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1287-------------------------
Matrix_at() Out of Bounds Checking
<p>Do we have to make sure that our Matrix_at function and unit test guard against going out of bounds the scope of the Matrix(width and height, not MAX_WIDTH and MAX_HEIGHT)?</p>


<p></p>


<p>If so, how should we handle the cases in which they do go out of bounds, would we instead return a pointer that points to the closes to valid spot in a matrix?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Take a careful look at the requires clause for <code>Matrix_at</code>. If an input violates the requires clause, you don’t need to worry about handling it at all.</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-comment">// REQUIRES: mat points to a valid Matrix</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= row &amp;&amp; row &lt; Matrix_height(mat)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//           0 &lt;= column &amp;&amp; column &lt; Matrix_width(mat)</span>
<span class="hljs-comment">//</span>
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre></div>

<p>This happens in Xcode if it thinks your <code>.h</code> file is C, rather than C++.</p>

------------------------@1293-------------------------
resize.cpp
<p>I understand that in resize.cpp we open a file, at the first index of argv and read from it into the output file, at the second index of argv. I'm confused about how to read in and write to an Image though. Will main only have two parameters, argv and argc? So do we create a new image object for this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes main will only have two arguments: argv and argc. Yes you need to create a new image object and initialize it using the ifstream. Then, once you have run the processing functions on the image, you can run Image_print with an ofstream to write the image to a file.</p>

<p>The issue with pushing is that your partner is working on a version that is older than the remote repo which makes it so he can't push. Your partner would need to create a new branch in git and push that branch so you can checkout that branch (translation: start working on that new branch rather than the old one). If you are not familiar with how to do that, look up something like "git basics branching", or reach out to an instructor or IA in office hours.</p>

------------------------@1298-------------------------
Image_init: how do I read in a temporary pixel?
<p>I'm trying to read in a temporary pixel after filling it with values, how do I do that without getting an error like this?</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F3214a3e6e260018198000150739b7e64e404c823edd8c916253480511e92cd26%2Ftempixelerror.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">tempixelerror.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Use the set pixel function</p>


<p></p>


<p>Is this in the Image_init() function when reading an image from a file?</p>


<p>You will need to read in the first few chunks and set them as the width and height of the image, then use for loops to iterate through the remaining chunks which represent the r g and b values. Once you get the r, g, and b you can use the set pixel function.</p>

------------------------@1304-------------------------
Runtime error: signed integer overflow
<p></p>


<p>Not sure what is causing this </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7cv1jb97ky4ku%2F9a322b37832e835002d03fcd0e8ea9a1efc5281182eb86c170b5009185ab9aee%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Signed integer overflows are typically caused by getter functions trying to access uninitialized data (unless you have really big numbers in your data) - check that your fill, init, and get functions are all declaring the bounds of data as you expect and getting the correct locations.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Look at line 73 in processing.cpp. What exactly are you trying to do there?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>My partner and I also have the same problem. I was wondering if you found what function was causing the problem. Because line 73 in processing.cpp is provided to us, so something else seems to cause the problem</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For me it was compute_energy_matrix, but check the functions in processing.cpp and make sure that if loops are used, the bounds are constructed with the width and height of the const img and not the one being changed</p>

------------------------@1305-------------------------
Dereferencing pointers
My code is giving an this error "expression must have arithmetic or unscoped enum type". I know we're supposed to dereference the pointer so then we can use the value , but it doesn't like that I'm doing that.
<br/>
<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_1.45.44_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkst4426dpr36ty%2F5ec491dcdfdbac2ccdc461d2d42e8c1d461c36c673f14ff440e3e0e05b7db9fa%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_1.45.44_PM.png"/>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You would have to dereference it exactly where you want to use it, so you would have to delete the first line, then do:</p>


<p></p>


<p>int row = <strong>*ptr </strong>/ matrix_width(mat)</p>

------------------------@1309-------------------------
Wrong output for image_print
<p>After running the image_public_test, I can't seem to get the correct output. <p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F93288b19c8c5905ea30a908f94054ed859ff11abb166c2c3bbf82a10035f93e2%2Fprintyerrors.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">printyerrors.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You do not need to use cout or fout in this function. You should use the provided output stream parameter, "os". For example, you should use it in the following way:</p>


<p></p>


<pre>os &lt;&lt; red &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-string">" "</span> &lt;&lt; green &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-string">" "</span> &lt;&lt; blue &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-string">" "</span> &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('b3MlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjByZWQlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjAlMjIlMjAlMjIlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjBncmVlbiUyMCUzQyUzQyUyMCUyMiUyMCUyMiUyMCUzQyUzQyUyMGJsdWUlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjAlMjIlMjAlMjIlMjAlM0MlM0MlMjBlbmRsOw==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>

------------------------@1312-------------------------
Autograder processing_public_tests horses bad_alloc error
<p>I'm getting a bad_alloc error in the processing_public_tests horses section on autograder. I've seen other Piazza posts where the solution is to make sure that all objects created in dynamic memory with the new keyword are deleted. I've checked this an I'm still getting the error when I submit my code. Is there another source of this error that I should check for?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Based on your autograder submit, it seems like your test_matrix_init function in Matrix_tests.cpp and your test_get_pixel_edge function in Image_tests.cpp are leaking memory. Same goes for your resize.cpp in line 23. Make sure you are reading where the autograder memory leak outputs are directing you towards, the address sanitizer contains useful information in tracking down memory leaks.</p>

------------------------@1313-------------------------
compute_energy_matrix
<p>Just to clarify, for compute_energy_matrix, do we fill each non-border pixel with it's calculated energy, or do we leave the non-border pixels filled with 0, and only calculate the energy to find the max value, which we then use to fill the border-pixels?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You first loop through the non-border pixels and calculate their energies, keeping a variable for the max energy. Then, once your loop is done, you set all of the borders to the max value.

-------------------------------------------------

This means your program is failing to print the image to the output file.

<p>While running our tests for processing.cpp, our debugger showed us that all of our tests passed for the dog image, but when we tested crabster, the seam carve test fails, this is really confusing us because it worked for the first test and we're not sure where how we should continue from this point.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Please let us know!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>👍</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Alright, so apparently, every time you shrink the width by 1, you will have a new (and different) cost and energy matrix every time. I was using the same cost and energy matrix through every iteration, so that was my error.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>THank you! You are my everything!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I found the error, at least in my code. </p>


<p>I suggest going into the makefile and changing the complier flags to include sanitizers (look at the image below). When you run it with the sanitizers AND on a CAEN computer (you can login into CAEN through your computer-&gt; look at the link below and follow the directions) it should give u an indication of what and where things are going wrong (the summary section is the most helpful and should specially tell you the file and line number it fails) In my case it was a indexing error, but it might be different for your. Hope this helps. </p>


<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html</a></p>

------------------------@1325-------------------------
Does a maximum of 50 test cases mean we are allowed 50 test cases or 49 test cases?
<p>Does a maximum of 50 test cases mean we are allowed 50 test cases or 49 test cases?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Idk but just put some test cases in the same “TEST” so you don’t have to worry about it. Went from 41 to 12 without testing anything less than I had been the other day.

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Should be 50. I will say (and i think the spec says) that you shouldn’t need 50 test cases to catch everything - pay attention to <em>what</em> you’re testing more than <em>how much</em> you’re testing.</p></div>

------------------------@1327-------------------------
How to test int* Matrix_at  vs const int* Matrix_at
<p>What is the difference in writing the test cases for these two functions? I wrote test cases for the int* Matrix_at function but I'm not sure how to write test cases for the const int* Matrix_at function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Copy a matrix into a const matrix, like this:
<div><br/></div>
<div>Matrix const *example_name = original_prepared_matrix;</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you! However, that means I cannot delete the matrix at the end of my test function since it is being declared as a const?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe you can delete the matrix, just not change it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
You only need to delete original_prepared_matrix or example_name in this case, since they point to the same thing, the compiler will know that you’ve deleted it. Test it out, it’s quick, easy and free to see for yourself.

------------------------@1335-------------------------
In the autograder it says I timed out.
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_3.54.41_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky3dw9nx8sv3u3%2F32fdb2376b47ef7240a2279a23bd8c504f2b93b045fec83f7d600b830b251fe7%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_3.54.41_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Normally this happens because of too many for loops in matrix.cpp. I think you should try to another way to do Matrix_fill_border specifically. There is no need to have 2 double/nested for loops, all you need is 2 single for loops.</p>


<p></p>


<p>- 1 for loop for filling the first and last column (this can be done in 1 loop)</p>


<p>- 1 for loop for filling the first and last row (this can be done in another separate for loop)</p>


<p></p>


<p>That should fix the issue</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm having a similar issue even after adjusting Matrix_fill_border to use two for loops instead of a nested for loop.  What else should I look into to fix this?</p>

------------------------@1338-------------------------
error message for resize
<p>for resize.cpp</p>


<p>the spec says "If any of these are violated, use the following lines of code (literally) to print an error message."</p>


<p>cout &lt;&lt; "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]\n"<br/>     &lt;&lt; "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" &lt;&lt; endl;</p>


<p></p>


<p>are we supposed to replace IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT] with the actual values or why is height in []?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No you should print the error exactly as you have it. This output statement is describing an example usage of the command to the user. Height is in brackets because it is an optional argument.</p>

------------------------@1339-------------------------
Print having the correct row and column, but not getting the right data
<div>
<div>NEVERMIND, I GOT IT, IT WAS IMAGE_INIT THAT WAS WRONG THIS WHOLE TIME</div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div>int width = img-&gt;width;</div>
<div>int height = img-&gt;height;</div>
<br/>
<div>//cout &lt;&lt; "width = " &lt;&lt; width &lt;&lt; " height = " &lt;&lt; height &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<br/>
<div>int row, col;</div>
<div>int k = 0;</div>
<br/>
<div>os &lt;&lt; "P3" &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; width &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; height &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; "255" &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<br/>
<div>for (int i = 0; i &lt; width*height; i += width)</div>
<div>{</div>
<br/>
<div>//cout &lt;&lt; "i = " &lt;&lt; i &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>for (int j = i; j &lt; width+(k*width); j++)</div>
<div>{</div>
<div></div>
<div>row = (j / (img-&gt;width));</div>
<div>col = (j % (img-&gt;width));</div>
<div></div>
<div>//cout &lt;&lt; "j = " &lt;&lt; j &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>//cout &lt;&lt; "row = " &lt;&lt; row &lt;&lt; " col = " &lt;&lt; col &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<br/>
<div>os &lt;&lt; *(Matrix_at(&amp;(img-&gt;red_channel), row, col)) &lt;&lt; " ";</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; *(Matrix_at(&amp;(img-&gt;green_channel), row, col)) &lt;&lt; " ";</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; *(Matrix_at(&amp;(img-&gt;blue_channel), row, col)) &lt;&lt; " ";</div>
<br/>
<div>}</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>k++;</div>
<div>}</div>
<div></div>
</div>


<div>The rows and columns gone through are correct, (row = 0 col = 0, then row = 0 col = 1, then row = 1 col = 0, then row = 1 col = 1) but the output is wrong and I don't know why. I see there is some sort of error with what Matrix_at is getting, but I can't figure out what</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Resolved</p>

------------------------@1344-------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should not be using for loops in matrix_column, matrix_row, or matrix_at. There is a way to do them without loops, there's just a little math involved. If you use loops your code will time out in the autograder for the processing tests usually</p>

------------------------@1350-------------------------
resize.cpp output
<p>Hi! Our output for resize.cpp is completely wrong and we are not sure where our code went wrong. I have attached a picture of our driver and a picture of the output that it results in.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_6.57.50_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksvrib9jehr52a%2Fa322024b9b8d4297dacb35fd8d316f78ebbe79776582d448d08c4f2c5b4463ea%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_6.57.50_PM.png"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_6.53.51_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksvrib9jehr52a%2F02276058703c7a9b64b7edb0782f8fa29027069b2c1f8cc29c94d2a238c41192%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_6.53.51_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I see 2 issues here. First off, you're reading "int outputHeight = atoi(argv[4])"</p>


<p>without any bounds checking. What if there are only 4 arguments total? Then this will access memory that shouldn't be accessed, and it might crash, or it might run with undefined behavior. You should be checking whether you have enough arguments before reading in the arguments.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Secondly, it looks like you're printing the image before making any modifications to it. You should be printing it after you've done seam_carve_width() (and also seam_carve_height() if it needs to be done).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1351-------------------------
Error with processing.cpp.
<p>Could anyone help me with this error message?<img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktiru6iexyi74p%2Fcdf69fe680d833567965e8bcb0b962da3709c49f6291ee2c985d2712b331bb2e%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>This is the error I get when i run "make processing_public_tests.exe".</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It seems like you may be passing in 3 arguments to the min function. Check processing.cpp line 4, and this line should contain the error. If you are still not able to resolve it, follow up with a private post of your processing.cpp at this line.</p>

<p>Also, please include your uniqname in parentheses after your piazza name so that we may find your autograder submissions.</p>

------------------------@1352-------------------------
runtime error undefined behavior for processing_public_tests
<p><img alt="" height="592" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksurffc3u4m3cr%2F4d2fcd0f31fad045ecdfa365f600ebcb40610261be998164562dd2defa245a1c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_7.02.22_PM.png" width="1914"/>Hello, I'm getting this runtime error when I run my processing public tests.exe. I've checked the bounds of my matrix_at function as well as double checked that my Image_set_pixel function works properly using test cases. I don't know what the issue is, it would be awesome if I could have some input.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It seems like one of your processing functions is indexing out of bounds when it calls image_set_pixel which calls Matrix_at. I would recommend adding asserts in your Matrix_at and Image_set_pixel aligned with the requires clauses to debug and trace back which processing function is indexing out of bounds.</p>

------------------------@1353-------------------------
AddressSanitizer memory leak issue with remove vertical, thank you for helping
<p>Hello, my partner and I are continually running into a sanitizer memory leak issue that we are now stuck on. Below is a photo of the error, but in our vertical remove seam we are deleting any objects made with dynamic memory so we are confused. Thanks again.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_7.28.51_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkz5zttc26lq7nw%2Ff5b83c4fa1da4b70244cb5db2e87fbd1c9ca7467739f5ce4e89540655e5128bd%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_7.28.51_PM.png"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_7.26.54_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkz5zttc26lq7nw%2Ff2d82b81213cf4dc14247adbbb93f5da1918c0e08fcd956106bb492d1b2e4af4%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_7.26.54_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You are setting ptr = img2, meaning that these two pointers point to the same memory address. Then at the end of the function, you delete both ptr and img2 which point to the same memory address, effectively causing a double delete. </p>


<p></p>


<p>I would consider whether you need both ptr and img2 in this function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

Istream not being read in when executing resize.exe

-------------------------------------------------
<p>resolved</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1355-------------------------
How to use my own pictures
<p>How can I use the project to edit my own pictures just like Jon Beaumont in his slides?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can use an online jpg or png to ppm format and save it to your directory, and pass it into resize when you run it.</p>



<div>Beware, most of the online ppm converters use a P6 ppm format. You can use this converter I found to convert the image to the P3 ppm format our program uses: </div>



<p><a href="https://thomasebsmith.github.io/ppm-converter/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://thomasebsmith.github.io/ppm-converter/</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I tried that but all the online convertors I find convert it to ppm P6 which is not quite the format the project is designed to work with</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div><br/></div>
<div>https://thomasebsmith.github.io/ppm-converter/</div>

------------------------@1356-------------------------
How to Find the Original Width and Height of the input image
<p>In resize.cpp, we need to compare the new images width and height to the original image's width and height. How do we find the old images width and height since it is in the file itself?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
After running Image_init with your file input stream on the image object you created, you can use the member functions Image_width and Image_height to access the dimensions of the original image.

------------------------@1361-------------------------
Resize.cpp question
<p>My autograder shows that my code cannot print out anything. What might be the reasons for that? thank you.<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktu3q2uwyl63fl%2F95169a463e50db4ae7b5cbbe6ee85251a2b08b7054c64b6afbf90acde032daa9%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.23.31_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.23.31_PM.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There could be a problem with your if-then statements. When I got this problem, my if-then statement required the width/image arguments to be &lt; Image_width/height instead of &lt;=. You also could not be properly reading/writing the files using your fstreams.</p>


<p>If the input/output is your issue, I would suggest reading the "File I/O" section of the lecture notes: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/05_Strings_Streams_IO.html#strings-streams-io" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/05_Strings_Streams_IO.html#strings-streams-io</a></p>

------------------------@1364-------------------------
remove_vertical_seam unnecessary step
<p>It says in the Project 2 guide that, for remove_vertical_seam() function we should copy pixels into a new image, then copy the new image back to the original one. It seems to me that copying to a new image is an unnecessary extra step.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1365-------------------------
resize errors in autograder
<p>what does this mean? it passes the tests with the given images in my terminal  <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.48.34_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkxw1aad2mu144s%2F623926a16e6b9d99e03cfac2f03f7d6beebacd8d672832026a8c6abe36965021%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.48.34_PM.png"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.48.25_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkxw1aad2mu144s%2Fd65836bb58c5204dbfd8ce02afa41c69f56cd56264eac127b2eb9b153755b789%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_8.48.25_PM.png"/></p>

<p>It seems as though you are returning 1 in all cases of your resize.cpp. Make sure that you only return 1 in scenarios that are meant to be caught in error checking as returning 1 reports an exit status of error.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You do not need a return in the main function if it gets through without error. I believe returning 0 would also work though.</p>

------------------------@1383-------------------------
Test cases and grading
<p>If a few of my functions in the processing.cpp file are not working, do I still have the chance to get the points for the private test cases for matrix and image?</p>


<p><br/>Also, if some of my test cases are wrong (solely due to erroneous test case code), will the program still check the other test cases and even allow full points if I can cover all private test cases? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>1. Sure you do, but don't give up yet, you have a day to do the project still and the project is more than doable in that time frame. Like you could do it even if you had to start from scratch in that time. Don't give up yet.</p>


<p>2. I'm not sure exactly what you mean, but it will tell you which of your test cases are valid, i.e. which ones gave a pass to working code, and which ones are invalid, i.e. gave a failure to working code. Regardless of the number of invalid cases that you have, the autograder will take your valid ones and use them, and not take off points for invalid test cases that you have.</p>

------------------------@1386-------------------------
compute_vertical_cost_matrix
<p>I have completed these steps</p>


<ol><li>Initialize the cost <code>Matrix</code> with the same size as the energy <code>Matrix</code>.</li><li>Fill in costs for the first row (index 0). The cost for these pixels is just the energy.</li></ol>


<p>However, I am confused about filling the rest of the cost matrix. I know that we need the min energy of the three pixels straight above, left, and right. But how do get the energy of those pixels ? Do I have to call square difference or do I have to copy the entire energy matrix onto the cost matrix and then use the energy of those pixels (now in cost) to compute the cost?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, how do I think about staying in bounds?</p>


<p></p>


<p>thank u! </p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>you can use a pointer to the same row and column in the energy matrix</p>


<p></p>


<p>and do some loop and pointer trick with it to set the values of the cost matrix equal to the values of the energy matrix</p>


<p></p>


<p>u need to use the below formula as the spec states</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksuyzte8rtb3ak%2Fabf3faa1754fccf6b406dec178004bf5ab34323fa4fe60836e815a982fe97b66%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>and to stay in bounds, just use some if else statement around your loop and modify the formula in the spec according to your needs</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Omggg thank u! but do I need to copy the entire energy matrix onto the cost ? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>you need to initialize the cost matrix as same size of the energy matrix.. but u can't copy the entire matrix because you will do that eventually by calculating the cost step by step and adding the cost value to the cost matrix. At the end u will have a matrix filled with cost. Feel free to ask again if it doesn't clear up</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1387-------------------------
Couple questions about resize.cpp
<p>For resize, I think I have the first few steps correct, but then I'm a little lost on the rest. I use ifstream and open the file using argv[1], create a new image, and then call Image_init to initialize the height and width. After that I then close the file. Is this the point at which I close the file or do I wait until the very end?</p>


<p></p>


<p>My thought was to create if and else-if statements to initialize the image based on if there are 4 or 5 arguments. And then I called seam_carve, but then the program just seems to stop after that (when I go through it with my debugger), so it never makes it to Image_print. Is there something that I am doing wrong or missing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can close the input file after initializing the image. I don't think whether there are 4 or 5 arguments should change how you initialize the image. What it does change though, is what parameters you call seam_carve with. In the case where there is a height argument, you pass that argument to seam_carve. In the case where there is not a height argument (argc = 4), you pass the Image_height of the input image to seam_carve. I am not sure why your program seems to stop. I would take a careful look at your if-then logic.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Do we have to do anything with ofstream before we get to Image_print?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes. You should open the output file using .open(filename) on your ofstream where filename is the name of the output file (argv[2]).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkst441mrtk46s8%2Fb11467d274be043c6a9574ce04c40d7ee3fca7f2a4632087049b3572791f816d%2Fimage.png"/></p>

<p></p>


<div style="font-weight:normal">
<div>assert(Image_equal(removed_img, removed_img_correct));</div>
</div>



<div>still fails. I used my debugger to see what the two values being compared were, I found that removed_img_correct was a 5x5 file while my result was a 4x5. They seem to be different images? I'm not sure what's going on here. The debugger menu (right before line 78):</div>



<div><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkst441mrtk46s8%2F2a49158dffc894198659e0cde3cef41814cd98382dda3ee76e79700967f32a6e%2Fimage.png"/></div>




<div style="font-weight:normal">
<div>Shouldn't removed_img_correct be a 4x5 size image, since the size shrank? What's wrong with my output here? I saw there was something about this in the FAQ but I just don't know what to do here, my Image_init seems fine. (I made an autograder submission earlier today as well if it helps)</div>
</div>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok so I finally figured this out... after a lot of digging :P Putting this here to explain what I did wrong and maybe someone else did wrong as well.</p>


<p></p>


<p>test_remove_seam creates the correct image struct (through load_image) using YOUR image_init function. Specifically, it uses the version that uses an istream. The issue with my code was there. In my situation, I attempted to directly save a value into img's height and width using (*img).height, instead of using the other image_init function (that inputs height width values) instead.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Anyways hoped this helped anyone else in the same position as me.</p>

<p>segmentation fault means you are indexing out of bounds somewhere in your code. try looking at the error to see if there is a specific file name </p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You just want to call Image_print(img, output)</p>

------------------------@1401-------------------------
accessing width and height of resize input file
<p>Hi, how do I access the width and height of the input image in resize? the file is passed in as a command line argument, so do I need to convert it to a string, which would be the name of the image? do i then access the width and height? thank you</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You do need to initialize the image from the file in <code>resize</code>, and after doing that you can find the height and width of the Image easily using the interface functions (<code>Image_width</code>, <code>Image_height</code>).</p></div>

------------------------@1406-------------------------
Same output but fail ASSERT_EQUAL
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1o1yjcjsv1dj%2F01c067f0b63996738f758e9fb49540525ac9fc39844d8c8280618a5d5a041662%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------

<pre><code>diff &lt;file_name&gt; &lt;correct_file_name&gt;
</code></pre><p>to see character by character differences.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Additionally, try checking your spaces as well as your line breaks (\n) as these are the most common errors when you fail an ASSERT_EQUAL is based off the spacings of the characters. </p>

------------------------@1408-------------------------

<p>are ppm files c++ strings or c strings? I'm testing resize.cpp with dog.ppm file and in my Image_init(Image* img, std::istream&amp; is) function it's giving me a "signal SIGABRT" error when I call the original Image_init function because I used stoi(width) to convert the string input to an integer. If anyone could help that'd be so appreciated!!<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_11.38.24_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksyt38hn3uac1%2F21d804bc93957775d4c219584bbd55c2017083cc5bb2f0c71163653ada949cca%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-27_at_11.38.24_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
What exactly does your terminal input look like?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What do you mean?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Like does it look like this?</p>


<p>./resize.exe dog.ppm dog_5x4.ppm 5 4</p>


<p>Or whatever you want to resize it to?</p>


<p>Also looks like you typed "dogs.ppm" on accident there</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>nevermind I figured it out!!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It could be that you are trying to read the first line of the PPM file as an integer when it cannot be parsed as such (“P3” would not be able to be converted to an integer. To answer your question, though, it does seem like the stream reads the tokens as C++ strings, as you were able to pass it in to <code>stoi</code> without error, which only accepts <code>string</code>s as parameters.</p></div>

------------------------@1412-------------------------
Memory leak when initializing Matrix with 500 * 500
<p>when I try to initialize my matrix at 500 * 500 with Matrix_init, I am getting a memory leak. When I Initialize it at 499 * 499, I do not get a memory leak. Does anyone have an idea why?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo4ooY"><p>Marking as resolved - <code>data</code> does not need to be initialized in <code>Matrix_init</code>, it is already done in the struct.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>What does the terminal say concerning the memory leak?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="" height="750" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7c84hh3kqv3cf%2F742ee443474b6bc83c6eccde917c073c443b0b83a249435b4990f76d4601739e%2F1.png" width="1075"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Are you writing anything to the <code>data</code> array in your <code>Matrix_init</code> function?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>all I am doing in my matrix init function is checking the width and height to see if they are appropriate, setting the width and height of Matrix to the inputted width and height, and I am initializing the array.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>You shouldn’t need to initialize the array, since in the definition of the Matrix struct it already sets the array to the maximum length. If you remove that line, does it fix it?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>yes that fixes it. thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo3ooY"><p>no problem!</p></div>

------------------------@1415-------------------------
resize.cpp
<p>I'm having a problem with the error checking component: </p>


<ul><li>There are 4 or 5 arguments, including the executable name itself (i.e. <code>argv[0]</code>).</li><li>The desired width is greater than 0 and less than or equal to the original width of the input image.</li><li>The desired height is greater than 0 and less than or equal to the original height of the input image.</li></ul>


<p>I'm getting the error when I run it, so I tried commenting out one of them at a time to see which one was the issue, and it's the last one regarding height. The reqs for width and height are exactly the same so I used the same if and || statement parameter, but it fails for height and works for width. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Have you differentiated between input with 4 vs 5 arguments? If the input has 4 arguments, there is no height argument. This will cause an error if you are using the same error checking for both situations.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes I separated between argc = 4 and argc = 5. I put the width error checking if statement within the argc = 4 branch since it would not have a height argument, and the height error checking if statement within the argc = 5 branch, and the error is coming from the argc = 5 branch. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What exactly is the error message? Does it just print the one you made?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, it prints this from the spec:</p>


<p>Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]</p>


<p>WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original</p>

<p>Am I allowed to do this </p>

<p>Okay, I separated it even further into *argv[4] &lt;= 0 and *argv[4] &gt; height, and turns out its the *argv[4] &gt; height causing the issue. But then again I still don't know why</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is comparing argv[4] as a c-string to the int height. You need to call stoi() or atoi() on it to change it to an integer. Also, you don't need to dereference it using *, since the arr[] syntax dereferences the array for you.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Oh I see... Does this mean when I declared a string filename in the beginning to be argv[1], that is also incorrect? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No, I think that is OK. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Okay, so I took your advice and changed my parameter to atoi(argv[4]) &gt; height, and that same parameter is still causing the error message. Is this syntax still incorrect? (changed every instance of *argv[x] to atoi(argv[x])</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I just realized. You have the inequality backwards. Argv[4] should be &lt; height</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ok I changed that and it doesn't give the error anymore, but shouldn't it be &gt;? Since the spec says "less than or equal to the original height of the input image", shouldn't the error be printed when the argument is greater than the height? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is all correct. I am stumped.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think writing ifstream input(filename) is your problem. I don't know what the parenthesis after the variable name would do.</p>


<p>When declaring the ifstream, get rid of the parenthesis and just write ifstream input;</p>
