------------------------@1418-------------------------
Resize output creates new file instead of failing
<p>If I understand the specification correctly, in resize.cpp, we are supposed to print out the message "Error opening file: ..." when you cannot open the input or output file with the given name. However, in my code, instead of having an error and printing out this message, a new file is created with the given name and the output is printed into that file. Is there a way to make this output fail instead of creating a new file so that the error message will be printed?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your code is supposed to create the output file, not throw an error.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When the files cannot be opened or the argc is not the correct numbers, you are supposed to print out error messages and return with the error status (so the program is terminated). If you do not return in time, the program will keep running, and you may create new files.</p>

------------------------@1424-------------------------
resize.cpp error when using argv[n]
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>I’m getting this error when I try to declare an <code>istream</code> or <code>ostream</code> using<code>argv[n]</code></p>
<p>no instance of constructor <code>std::__1::basic_ostream&lt;_CharT, _Traits&gt;::basic_ostream [with _CharT=char, _Traits=std::__1::char_traits&lt;char&gt;]</code> matches the argument list</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You shouldn’t need to decarle streams with anything on their initialization statement. For file streams, you would do:</p>
<pre><code>ifstream file_in;
file_in.open(filename);
</code></pre><p>For string streams, you would just do:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-built_in">ostringstream</span> expected;
expected &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-comment">// data you would feed in to the string stream</span>
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('b3N0cmluZ3N0cmVhbSUyMGV4cGVjdGVkOyUwQWV4cGVjdGVkJTIwJTNDJTNDJTIwLy8lMjBkYXRhJTIweW91JTIwd291bGQlMjBmZWVkJTIwaW4lMjB0byUyMHRoZSUyMHN0cmluZyUyMHN0cmVhbSUwQQ==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>If you put something on that initialization line, the computer will try to pass it to a constructor that may or may not exist and then spit out that error.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div>
<div>How would I use this without using istream/ostream?</div>
</div>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>What are you trying to do?</p></div>

------------------------@1425-------------------------
Matrix_init error
<p>What could the error "Use of deallocated memory" indicate in Matrix_init? My partner and I never got this error until trying to run resize.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From your most recent autograder submission, I would take a look at your seam_carve_width function. It looks like you allocate dynamic memory for energy/cost matrices once at the beginning of the function, but then attempt to deallocate them in every iteration of your while loop. I would suggest moving those deletes to the end of the function (after the while loop). Otherwise, you are trying to reuse these matricies in the next iteration of the while loop, even though they have been deallocated.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>This is just a guess, but perhaps you deleted something and then tried to access it later? For example:</p>
<pre><code>Image *img = new Image;
Image_init(img, 5, 5);
Image_fill(img, {255, 255, 255});
delete img;
Image_set_pixel(img, 0, 0, {0, 0, 0});
</code></pre></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1426-------------------------
My own matrix test failed my code within autograder
<p>"Student Matrix tests on student matrix" somehow failed from me in the autograder, despite the fact that the tests always pass when run on my laptop. I have no idea why this is happening. It is just one test that somehow fails on my code within the autograder but also passes everytime when I run it on my side? How is this even possible?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Have you tried running your code on CAEN? It functions in a similar environment to the autograder and may find bugs in how your code compiles on different setups. The main cause for this problem (at least in project 1) was that VSCode or local compilers on your computer may detect libraries automatically and CAEN/autograder would not. However, it could also be another error, so it doesn’t hurt to check and run it on CAEN.</p>
<p>If you need to know how to set it up, see <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_caen.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this tutorial</a>.</p></div>

------------------------@1433-------------------------
How do you copy pixels into a new image; RemoveVerticalSeam
<p>I understand how to copy the new image back to the original one, but not how to copy pixels into a new image. I am clueless. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can use <code>Image_set_pixel</code> on the new image with the image you got from the old image. For example,</p>
<pre><code>Image* img = new Image;
Image * img2 = new Image;
Image_init(img, 1, 1);
Image_init(img2, 1, 1);
Image_fill(img, {255, 255, 255});
Image_set_pixel(img2, 0, 0, Image_get_pixel(img, 0, 0));
</code></pre></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1435-------------------------
Importance of Respecting the Interface in Private Tests
<p>I was just wondering how much respecting the interface mattered in terms of the private tests, because for our processing function we've used a lot of functions with parameters that don't respect the interface and we wanted to know if that would be a significant problem in the private tests. Our code does still run and we're compiling and passing all the public tests.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It was mentioned in lecture that it is normally impractical to check that a program is respecting the interface, but that it is bad practice not to. I don’t know specifically if they will check this in the private tests, but they do have sections in the autograder where they attempt to check this, so I would err towards the careful size and respect the interface more.
<img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7nv0y6f4pf5aa%2F06f8e12bf3d9302cfc7cc56c761e044d53ca5756cb0f6055a6459c518e3d126d%2Fimage.png"/></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1436-------------------------
Make test terminal output confusion
<p>When make test is typed into the terminal, after the horses tests, this shows up. </p>


<p></p>


<p>./resize.exe dog.ppm dog_4x5.out.ppm 4 5<br/>diff dog_4x5.out.ppm dog_4x5.correct.ppm</p>


<p></p>


<p>What does it mean?  dog_4x5.out.ppm &amp; dog_4x5.correct.ppm are identical.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>This is part of the set of commands that <code>make test</code> runs. The first command,</p>
<pre><code>./resize.exe dog.ppm dog_4x5.out.ppm 4 5
</code></pre><p>runs your resize program to make <code>dog_4x5.out.ppm</code>. The second command,</p>
<pre><code>diff dog_4x5.out.ppm dog_4x5.correct.ppm
</code></pre><p>compares the files <code>dog_4x5.out.ppm</code> and <code>dog_4x5.correct.ppm</code> bit by bit to see where they have any difference. If they don’t have any difference, the <code>diff</code> program will print nothing to the terminal. So if that diff command is the last line you see, then <code>dog_4x5.out.ppm</code> and <code>dog_4x5.correct.ppm</code> are identical.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The student's answer is spot on! Just to add on, if there is a difference between the files, it can be hard to go through the differences sometimes using the diff command because of the way it is formatted. The command sdiff (ran the same way as diff) is a bit easier to see but I prefer to use <a href="https://www.diffchecker.com/diff" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this</a> online diff checker.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1437-------------------------
Processing.cpp seam carve runtime error
<p>Hello, </p>


<p>I have a problem of my processing.cpp. When I run the crabster test of processing_public_tests.exe, the terminal shows:</p>


<p>Testing crabster seam carve 50x45…processing.cpp:73:13: runtime error: signed integer overflow: -1094795781 * -1094795781 cannot be represented in type ‘int’ SUMMARY: UndefinedBehaviorSanitizer: undefined-behavior processing.cpp:73:13 in</p>


<p></p>


<p>So, what’s problem of my code?</p>


<p>Thank you!</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Typically when the runtime encounters large numbers like this, you are looking at or trying to use initialized data. Check that your <code>init</code>, <code>get</code>, and <code>fill</code> functions are doing what they are supposed to be doing and defining bounds/values correctly.</p>
<p>It may also help to set up the debugger to see which variable is being assigned the <code>-1094795781 * -1094795781</code> value so you can pinpoint what is causing the problem.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1438-------------------------
Changing MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH/HEIGHT for tests

I was thinking making the maxes smaller in matrix.h in order to make it run faster, or should I just keep it 500x500 since the autograder will use those values? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You should keep it 500 and 500 - I don’t see how changing these would make the program run faster. When the program creates the initial data array in <code>Matrix</code>, it shouldn’t run slower depending on the size of the array, since it isn’t initializing anything in that array yet. It’s just sectioning off an area of memory that’s marked for your to use later. Unless your system is really strapped for memory, initializing a 250000 size array shouldn’t take much more time than a 250 size array.</p>
<p>If you do have an efficiency problem, I would suggest looking into your getter and setter functions (<code>Matrix_at</code>, down the line <code>Image_get_pixel</code>, <code>Image_set_pixel</code>). These functions are used often and need to be fast for every other function to be fast.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1439-------------------------
Height in Seam Carve Functions
<p>getting an infinite loop for height. any suggestions? The width function is working out fine, but after the width is calculated the height is going into a loop</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I pulled up your most recent autograder submission, and I would suggest taking another look at your seam_carve_height function. Is having a while loop necessary? Think about what calling seam_carve_width might already be doing.</p>

------------------------@1443-------------------------
Resize Terminal Output/Checks
<p>Im a little confused on how to tell if resize/the program is actually working. When i run a command like "./resize.exe horses.ppm horses_400x250.ppm 400 250" in the terminal it runs fine with no errors but nothing is printed out to the terminal and im not sure how to check that it actually worked? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you look at the last command in the Makefile for <code>test</code>, the command is <code>diff dog_4x5.out.ppm dog_4x5.correct.ppm</code>. This command compares your output file with the given “correct” file. If you see nothing in the command line after running this command, then the files have the same contents.</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p></div>

------------------------@1444-------------------------
Find veritcal seam issue
<p>IK this is a repost but the op seems to have figured it out but haven't responded how. If anyone knows how to do this I kindly thank you if you share how</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>I cant for the life of me figure out why, but my find_minimal_vertical_seam function reaches out of bounds for its final column to put into the seam array. It works normally until row 0 where it then jumps from column 2 to column 0 (It is supposed to be 1 for the public test) which should not be possible.</p>


<p></p>


<p>It's not an out of bounds error or anything either, I have tested for that. If anyone has faced a similar problem help would be greatly appreciated.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I had the same confusion when I was doing this function as well. By the spec, <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#minimal-vertical-seam" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">right here</a>, the left and right bounds for searching for the minimum must change every time the col for the seam changes. It's possible to have a seam to travel from one corner to the other. The columns that the minimum search is bound to may change every time you move up a row.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I hope this helps.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>marking as resolved</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What you are saying makes sense, I just have 0 clue on how to implement that lmao. Any advice?</p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yeah! Don’t forget about the other helpful functions you’ve programmed in your previous files, namely <code>Matrix.cpp</code>. See if you can find a function that you can use to easily tell where in a row you are.</p></div>

------------------------@1454-------------------------
Here's a tip for using GIMP with vscode
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can drag .ppm files from VSCode’s folder viewer (“Explorer”) to an open GIMP window to immediately open the .ppm file in GIMP. Super useful alongside using gdb for debugging processing.cpp; for example you can compare pixel values from the image using GIMP to pixel values read using your <code>Image_init(img*, filestream)</code> function using the debugger [to see if you swapped the width and height in the for loop in <code>Image_init()</code> like I did] 😉</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1455-------------------------
energy matrix
<p>How do you compute an energy matrix if there is only 1 row or column?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I don't think you can.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Edit: see instructor's answer</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This case shouldn't really even happen because if there's only 1 row or column and you're running a seam carve, the end height/width would be 0, which isn't allowed. However, this isn't part of the requires clause of compute_energy_matrix(), so it's not a bad idea to check for this case.</p>


<p></p>


<p>1. Fill it with zeros. This should give you a 1xn or nx1 matrix with all 0's.</p>


<p></p>


<p>2. Compute the energy for each non-border pixel. All pixels are on the border, so we can skip this.</p>


<p></p>


<p>3. Find the maximum energy so far (which is 0), and use it to fill the border pixels. Again, all of the pixels are on the border, so we set them to 0.</p>


<p></p>


<p>In the end, the energy matrix should just be filled with 0's.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy53m7szmg6j0%2F6da649b6edaa7c5390317b11f1e47831500c792cf7e1c55866e4dd2f11ee7d0e%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-28_at_10.42.26_AM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-09-28_at_10.42.26_AM.png</a></p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>In the <code>program</code> field, it should be the name of the compiled exe file, not a cpp file. This is telling your debugger which file to execute, not compile. It should run the program once it’s the exe.</p></div>

------------------------@1463-------------------------
Conceptual confusion Vert Cost Matrix
<p><img alt="" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky0sj45wn5t2w5%2F6299cba936912eb51c1f5afa382a0844991e6b96dfffe710f1406bb9a18eb959%2FIMG_0020.jpg"/></p>


<p>Right now I am having issues with computing the vertical cost matrix. When</p>


<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">When I do Matrix_min_value_in_row(mat, row above, left column (inclusive), right column (exclusive) )</div>
</div>
</div>


<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">I want to include that right (green, 2940) column so I end my bound at the next one over (blue square) because of exclusivity</div>
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">However, because of that correction that means Matrix_at goes OOB (assertion flag) because I add one additional to column_end</div>
<div style="font-weight:inherit;font-style:inherit">I don't really understand why min_value_in_row is exclusive at the end nor how I would fix it</div>
</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your understanding the vertical cost  function is correct, in that you need to have bounds i-1 and i+2. However, when you are on the left edge of the matrix, you’re bound i-1 will OOB and on the right side i+w2 will too. Try using logic to determine if you are at a first or last column and adjusting the bounds accordingly. You will need to do this every time you compute a cost.</p>
<p>I hope this helps!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1464-------------------------
Print test basic fails
<p>Each time I run the test the numbers that should be pixel color values change. I think this has to do with my second image init function but can not figure out where the problem is. Am I correct in assuming this is the problem because it prints the correctly? <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-09-28_at_11.32.29_AM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkyalmvpm9y23o0%2F57af6795ae6464bbcfad53ea4afb8607a5b8d5f6a2c9801f19ce1f200c1fca1c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-28_at_11.32.29_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your intuition on where the issue is possible. It seems like the numbers being outputted are not even close to the integers (0 or 255) that we expect them to be, however they are not pointers (these will print starting with 0x). This seems like the image’s r, g, and b channel matrices are never properly being set.</p>
<p>Make sure that when you transfer <code>is</code> stream values to the matrices, you are dereferencing the <code>Matrix_at()</code> value. <code>Matrix_at()</code> returns a pointer to the integer you want to change, so just performing <code>is &gt;&gt; Matrix_at(r_channel, x, y)</code> will not change the actual value associated with the matrix cell at row x and column y.</p>
<p>I also recommend placing a breakpoint in your image_init() and image_print() functions so you can follow the program flow line by line and monitor where variable values are not what you expect.</p>
<p>Hope this helps.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I tried doing something along the lines of</p>


<div>
<div>is &gt;&gt; *Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;red_channel, x, y)</div>
<div>In a loop after name, width, height, and max value are read in. Would this be the wrong approach?</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1469-------------------------
how to fix timed out error
<p>my test keeps timing out on horses_cost and i'm not sure why, i went through and commented out all of my asserts for the functions i call in cost to see if that was the problem but it still timed out. i have been looking through my code and i'm doing exactly what the spec says to do, i don't think i'm looping through anything unnecessary, if anyone has any other suggestions i would appreciate it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I was having the same problem. I had deep nesting in my Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row function and fixing this solved my timed out error. From my understanding, it times out if a function is taking too long to execute, and having too many for loops, if statements, etc. causes it to take too long.</p>

------------------------@1472-------------------------
crabster find seam
<p>Hi! <br/>I am failing the crabster find_seam test. I went through the code 1000 times now, but I can´t find any bugs etc. Does anyone have an advice what I should be looking out for? Common mistakes, edge cases etc.</p>


<p><br/>Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you’ve already followed your code through the debugger and it does what you expect (which ends up being wrong), then perhaps your understanding of the seam function’s intended behavior is wrong.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I misunderstood this function at first as well. As detailed in the spec <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#minimal-vertical-seam" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>, the bounds for finding the minimum cost actually change depending on which column the minimum was in for the previously parsed row. Although the diagram in the spec does not deviate much from the initial minimum being in the 3rd column, it would be possible to have a minimum seam cross in a diagonal direction across an image.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Here is another diagram illustrating this: </p>


<p>The circles are the minimum value found in the inclusive bounds, and the boxes are the corresponding new bounds for the next row's analysis.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Another common mistake is not using bounds that span from n-1 to n+2 to account for the fact that the matrix minimum column function has an inclusive lower bound and and exclusive upper bound. <br/><br/></p>


<p>I hope this helps!</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="1176" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7e8alqn6rj6u0%2Fe46447c6f1a8e4979bae7123ce5456eb572166b3862bf1cfcb9d537691a7cd1a%2FScreen_Shot_2022-09-28_at_12.40.42_PM.jpg" width="2811"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1473-------------------------
Seam_carve test for crabster & horses
<p>Hello,</p>


<p></p>


<p>I am having an issue where I run the processing_public_tests and seam_carve() is failing for crabster. This is confusing, not really sure how to debug because the pixels are only compared at the end when they've all been printed. Super weird that all the other functions work on crabster, but it fails at seam_carve(). I did use sdiff to compare my output of crabster to the correct output and it does seem like the numbers are off. I'm not sure why that is but please let me know what I should check for or look for!!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks!!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The one big thing I see is that you're using the min() function with 3 arguments, which doesn't actually work since it only works with 2 arguments to take the minimum of. If you include a third argument, it actually has to be a comparator (more on what that is later this semester).</p>


<p></p>


<p>To fix this, see if you can use the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() function.</p>

------------------------@1477-------------------------
how does filling border work for a 1x1 matrix

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Every pixel in the 1x1 matrix is part of the border, so fill it.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>are 2x2 and 2x1 all filled when calling fill_border</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yes, anything on the first or last row, or first or last column is considered the border.

------------------------@1478-------------------------
horse test time
<p>Hi! </p>


<p>My horse public_tests have been running for at least 10-15 minutes now. Should I stop it and troubleshoot why or is it normal?<br/><br/>It is the seam_carve 300x382 test that I am stuck on.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, you should troubleshoot it because the autograder only allows 30-60 seconds per test. Horse typically takes longer than other tests but it shouldn’t be that long.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Sometimes you might be calling helper functions meant to "respect the interface" within the actually interface they are meant to protect, which is not the use for then. This can really take up a ton of time if the function is called a bunch - think about how much longer it takes for your computer to access a value of class through a function then just by directly calling it (it can be around 2-3x slower!) That being said, do NOT go and replace these functions by just calling the values in places you aren't supposed to (eg other interfaces) to just save time. It's poor practice and the autograder will complain.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What could be common issues for long runtimes? because all my horse tests actually need at least 1 minute to get processed - even the very simple ones like rotating</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Does it take this long the CAEN system? If your computer is slow then that may be the cause. Double check the time it takes on the same system the AG runs on.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

Image get pixel and matrix at should both not use any iteration.

<p>It might not even be that Image_get_pixel() is taking that long. It could be that you're calling it too often by iterating over pixels that you don't have to iterate over, or you're iterating over a bunch of pixels multiple times.</p>


<p></p>


<p>I also don't recommend removing the assert statements, since that is likely not the issue, and it should help in debugging.</p>

------------------------@1491-------------------------
Running into an error with processing find_minimal_vertical_seam
<p>find seam...processing_public_tests.exe: processing_public_tests.cpp:162: void test_find_seam(const int*, int, std::string): Assertion `array_equal(seam, seam_correct, n)' failed.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Anyone else running into this error? No clue on how to fix this</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This means that your find_minimal_vertical_seam function is not working properly. The assertion `array_equal(seam, seam_correct, n)' failed because the seam array edited by your function does not match the correct seam array. I would recommend either using a visual debugger or printing out the arrays in order to view the differences between your array and the expected one.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1492-------------------------
Autograder error "a function-definition is not allowed here before '{' token"
<p>Wha<img alt="" height="1401" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkefowk7y6q04s4%2F29c4dc723f2f0c1ecfdd3cc204660cbf980dfdce0c92ddca36f8bd98a4adc40a%2FAGError.PNG" width="2907"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>What does this mean/how can I fix it? Also, no, I'm not missing any semicolons in Matrix.cpp</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Are you returning values from each non-void function? Are you missing any curly braces? You also may be missing a semicolon. Just look out for syntax errors that you may have missed.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Very likely you missed some curly braces. If you use clean indentation, it should be easier for you to find out where you missed the curly braces.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1493-------------------------
mutation test suites
<p>Hello, </p>


<p></p>


<p>About the tests we write for the mutation tests suites, are we also supposed to intentionally write test cases that would fail on proper code, but work for the buggy implementation? </p>


<p></p>


<p>Say for example something like declaring a matrix with an invalid width/height value?</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You are supposed to write tests using valid input and compare the output of the functions to the expected output using assert statments. If the output of the functions is not what it should be, the assert statments should fail, successfully flagging a buggy program as being inaccurate.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1494-------------------------
Remove_seam function correct until it is passed back
Hello.  When I compute remove_seam in the debugger, it shows the correct answer inside the function remove_seam. However, as soon as I am out of the function, the Image removed_img is not correct. It goes back to its old width, even though the width was correct inside the function. It looks completely correct other than copying one more column of pixels than it should. It even includes 4 as the width at the top of the PPM file. Does anyone know what might be going on?

-------------------------------------------------
Are you copying the removed image back to the original image using *img = *removed_img ?
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
Yes, I am.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When you are out of the function, it doesn't matter whether removed_img is correct because it was only a temporary image created for the function. It should even be deleted at the end of the function. What matters is if the image passed to the function has the seam properly removed. Does this answer your question?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The function removes the seam from img. img can not be passed to the function with the seam already removed so I'm not sure what you mean.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I am confused what you mean by "img can not be passed to the function with the seam already removed" I'm not sure what that is in reference to. If you want to remove more than one seam, like you need to in your seam carve functions, the image will be passed to the function after the previous seam has been removed. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Nvm i got it.</p>

------------------------@1495-------------------------
How to test rgb channels are initialized in image_tests.cpp

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>When respecting the interface, you can’t really check the results of <code>Image_init</code> independently. You will likely have to use other Image functions to test this - e.g. fill, get_pixel, set_pixel, etc.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>undefined reference to typically means you created a function stub and called the function however never implemented it! For more information check out the P3 Commonly Asked Errors post </p>

------------------------@1502-------------------------
Test cases
<p>Do we need to write test cases for every function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your test cases will be used on known faulty programs to see if your test cases catch the bugs of the programs. If the faulty programs have a bug with a specific function that you don’t test, you may get points off for your test cases.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1503-------------------------
Long Lines
Does just pressing enter and breaking a line up into 2 get rid of the long line error in autograder?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes. In C++ you can break up lines anywhere you can put a space.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes you can, but you may notice that this will increase the length of the function (so you may have long functions). If you cannot fix it by simply splitting it into 2 lines, think if it is reasonable to take some code out from the function and make the code another helper function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
If I click enter to make a new line within the parameters, should i make the new line before or after the comma?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think both work. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Generally, it makes more sense to put the new line after the comma, since a comma signifiies a natural pause in English, and starting a line with a pause is unnatural (granted, this isn’t exactly English, but it has similar rationale). The <a href="https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Function_Declarations_and_Definitions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">google style guide</a> also suggests putting the new line after the comma.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1506-------------------------
What does this processing error mean?

------------------------@1520-------------------------
I think the style checks in the Makefile and in the autograder are different
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Basically, in the autograder the <code>cpd</code> command is</p>
<pre><code>pmd.sh cpd --minimum-tokens 100 --language cpp --failOnViolation true --files Matrix.cpp processing.cpp Image.cpp resize.cpp
</code></pre><p>Whereas in the Makefile the <code>$FILES</code> variable also includes the test files.</p>
<p>Just in case anyone was running into something similar.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>I'm just at a bit of a loss as to how to even approach debugging this. Does anyone have any sort of idea what could be wrong/ how to try and debug this?</p>


<p></p>


<p>I know the FAQ says Crabster catches more edge cases but I've been working on this for hours with no progress or even a clue as to what is going wrong. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks, sorry for the late frantic post.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>(assuming your matrix and image functions work) You should look very closely on how you are handling the seam carving of your image. Very carefully. Take another look at the spec example of how carving works and double check all processing functions to prove to yourself that the functions are handling each edge case exactly as it is supposed to. Draw it out, may seem tedious but for some bugs this is the only way to find them.</p>

<p>img-&gt;red_channel breaks the interface? </p>

------------------------@1532-------------------------
Getting very large image for seam removal.
<div>
<div>void remove_vertical_seam(Image* img, const int seam[]) {</div>
<div>  Image* aux = new Image;</div>
<div>  Image_init(aux, MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH, MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT);</div>
<div>  for (int i = 0; i &lt; Image_height(img); ++i) {</div>
<div>    for (int j = 0; j &lt; Image_width(img); ++j) {</div>
<div>      if (j &lt; seam[i]){</div>
<div>        Image_set_pixel(aux, i, j, Image_get_pixel(img, i, j));</div>
<div>      }</div>
<div>      if (j &gt; seam[i]) {</div>
<div>        Image_set_pixel(aux, i, j-1, Image_get_pixel(img, i, j));</div>
<div>      }</div>
<br/>
<div>  }</div>
<div>  *img = *aux;</div><br/><div>  delete aux;</div>
<div>}</div>
<div>}</div>
<div></div>
<div>So we are trying to remove the seam of our image, but we seem to be getting an infinitely large image filled with 0 0 0 pixels. We aren't quite sure why we are getting such a large image, so any help would be appreciated.</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think the problem is here: Image_init(aux, MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH, MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT); You would have to initialize aux to be the same height as the image and width should be 1 less than the image width since your taking out a seam</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div>
<div>void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {</div>
<br/>
<div>  int* red = Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;red_channel, row, column);</div>
<div>  int* green = Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;green_channel, row, column);</div>
<div>  int* blue = Matrix_at(&amp;img-&gt;blue_channel, row, column);  </div>
<div>  *red = color.r;</div>
<div>  *green = color.g;</div>
<div>  *blue = color.b;</div>
</div>


<p>This is what our image_set_pixel looks like for reference, but I am not sure if this is what is causing the error. Any hint or assistance would be of great use to us.</p>

------------------------@1536-------------------------
Question about projects
<p>Generally how should we approach doing projects so that we aren't stuck with a bunch of bugs and errors in the end of the program? Any advice?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Pretend the due date is a week before it actually is. Debug each program step by step, and sometimes you have to start testing with one function at a time, or even one block of code. If you aren’t sure what your loop or function will do, it doesn’t hurt to isolate that, put it into the main function, and let it run to see before you bury it with the rest of your code.</p>
<p>Also, read through the specs <strong>carefully</strong>. Make sure that you are programming for the right behaviors, and it may help to even grab a pen and paper and <em>be the computer</em>. Feel how the procedure will run, and then you can catch weird behaviors/edge cases you may think of along the way.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I agree 100%, you should never plan to finish a project the day before it's due, plan to finish at least a few days before. No matter how fast you code, you'll never really know how many bugs you have and how long they will take to fix, so your best bet is to start early (as early as the first day a project is released even) and best part is if you get stuck chances are someone in OH can help as supposed to the last couple days before a project is due.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You'd be surprised how much easier it is to code and how many bugs you'll avoid if you write and test code little by little :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1537-------------------------
write test cases for checking the REQUIRES clause.
<p>Hi, I want ask how we could test the REQUIRES clause in our test.cpp. For example, I want to assert that the code will fail to compile in this case. How to assert that? Should I write assert (false)? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can write an assert statement at the beginning of the function if you want, but basically, as long as you don't use test inputs that would validate the requires clause, you don't need to write test cases for it.</p>

------------------------@1544-------------------------
P3 FAQ
<p>Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions on Project 3. Project 3 <strong>CHECKPOINT</strong> will be due on <strong>Monday, October 10 at 8pm EST</strong>. Project 3 (full project) will be due on <strong>Friday, October 21 at 8pm EST</strong>. The spec can be found <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>


<h1>From the FAQ:</h1>


<p><strong>Q: I’ve never played Euchre before, how do I learn the rules of the game?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>A: Pages 2-5 of the spec detail the rules of “EECS 280 Euchre”. Also, a staff member from prior semesters made a video tutorial a few years ago that may be helpful: <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc</a></p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=33s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">0:33</a> Dealing</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=115s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">1:55</a> The Upcard / Making Trump Round 1</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=335s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">5:35</a> Making Trump Round 2</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=440s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">7:20</a> Leading the First Trick</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=500s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">8:20</a> The Other Players Play Cards in the First Trick</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=658s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">10:58</a> Deciding who Wins the First Trick</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=684s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">11:24</a> Leading the Second Trick</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=720s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">12:00</a> Playing the Rest of the Hand</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=1230s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">20:30</a> Scoring</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0jGJ0NRcrc&amp;t=1283s" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">21:23</a> Determining Whether Another Hand should be Played - Ending</p>


<p></p>


<p>There will also be a euchre social on <strong>October 1st from 12 - 2 pm</strong> where you can get one-on-one help from IAs to learn euchre.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: What do I have to submit to pass the checkpoint?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>The checkpoint includes all the files except the driver (<code>Card.cpp</code>, <code>Card_tests.cpp</code>, <code>Pack.cpp</code>, <code>Player.cpp</code>, <code>Player_tests.cpp</code>). It will make up 0.5% of your overall course grade.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Can I add helper functions while implementing the Player classes?</strong></p>


<p><strong></strong></p>


<p>You are allowed to use helper functions, but these helper functions should not change the interface of the class. So within your implementations of the class’s member functions, feel free to call helpers. But in your test files, you should not assume that these functions exist (because you should not alter the interface for the classes). This also applies in your euchre driver as well! e.g. If you add a helper function to the simple player class, you can use it within that class, but you can’t use it in the driver since it won’t be part of the Player interface!</p>


<p></p>


<p>This is especially important because when we run your test cases against an intentionally buggy solution, that solution will not have your specially defined helper functions! So just use the interfaces of each class when you test them.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Why am I getting a compiler error for calling sort?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>Note that the sort function modifies the hand. You cannot modify member variables in a const function, so you’ll receive a compiler error you call sort in a const member function.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You shouldn’t need to sort using card less. When you print the hand in order it should be sorted using the &lt; operator. You could sort with card less when determining what action to take, but you should be able to find the min/max card in the hand without sorting. You could use a functor to sort using card less, but those are only covered later in the course. Generally: if you need to use sort, just the default one will be fine.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Similarly: <strong>Q: I’m getting a compiler error related to swap?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>This is the same question as the one above.  Use <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1781" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1781');">@1781</a> to direct students</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Why am I passing euchre public test, but failing euchre public test with solution card, pack, and player?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>This means that when your euchre.cpp is run with the instructor solution implementations of card, pack, and player you produce incorrect output. This likely means that you’re making an incorrect assumption about what functionality should go in card/pack/player versus in the game of euchre. For example, make sure that you’re not printing output in player.cpp that should be printed in euchre.cpp.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Why won’t pack.in open in pack public tests when running on Xcode?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>Click on the name of your scheme in the toolbar at the top left, Edit Scheme &gt; Options &gt; Enable “Custom Working Directory” and press the little folder icon. Pick the folder that contains your code along with pack.in. This will ensure that the file is visible to your executable. This is usually not a problem, and we are investigating the issue.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: How do I debug and add in command line arguments with XCode/VSCode/VS?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>Follow <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup.html#visual-debugger" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this link</a>  and click on your specific IDE, then click on the “Arguments and options” subsection.</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Should I be printing the incoming arguments from the command line?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>Yes, according to the spec: “First, print the executable and all arguments on the first line. Print a single space at the end, which makes it easier to print an array.”</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>Q: Do I need to worry about the human player doing (insert illegal move) during the game?</strong></p>


<p></p>


<p>No, in accordance with the spec you can assume that a human player will follow the rules of the game and will not attempt to cheat.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1562-------------------------
Question about the address and ->
<div>
<div>Hi, I want to get the address of the color of the Car struct, but I am not sure whether to put parentheses around them, for instance, like this: &amp;(Car-&gt;color ). Thank you!</div>
</div>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>-&gt;</code> is equivalent to dereferencing <code>*</code> and then using the dot operator <code>.</code> to access the attribute of the object. Thus, you use <code>-&gt;</code> on a pointer to a struct or class object. If your car object is not a pointer, then you access simply by doing <code>&amp;car.color</code>, there is no need to reference.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

Matrix_print failing and propagating

<p>When I run Matrix_print the output looks to me to be identical, but it still fails on the public test. I really don't know why this is!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Currently, mine looks like this:</p>


<div>
<div>void Matrix_print(const Matrix* mat, std::ostream&amp; os) {</div>
<br/><br/>
<div>os &lt;&lt; mat -&gt; width &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; mat -&gt; height &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>for (int i = 0; i &lt; mat -&gt; height; i++) {</div>
<div>for (int j = 0; j &lt; mat -&gt; width; j++) {</div>
<div>os &lt;&lt; *Matrix_at(mat, i, j) &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<div>}</div>
<br/>
<div>os &lt;&lt; '\n' &lt;&lt; endl;</div>
<br/>
<div>}</div>
</div>

<div>** Test case "test_matrix_print": FAIL<br/>In ASSERT_EQUAL(expected.str(), actual.str()), line 55:<br/>1 1<br/>42 <br/> != 1 1<br/>42 </div>



<div>We are pretty behind so we would appreciate all of the help we can get!</div>



<div>Thank you so much!</div>


<div></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Looks like a whitespace or endl issue, mostly likely this:</p>


<p></p>


<p>os &lt;&lt; *Matrix_at(mat, i, j) &lt;&lt; " " &lt;&lt; endl;</p>


<p></p>


<p>should actually be this: os &lt;&lt; *Matrix_at(mat, i, j) &lt;&lt; " ";</p>

------------------------@1568-------------------------
"Does not consider trump"
<p>I'm confused about how to ignore the trump suit when there is no member variable that tells us which suit is the trump.</p>


<p>For instance, how do we determine which suit to return in Card::get_suit(const std::string &amp;trump) when we don't have a pre-set value for trump?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think what your asking about is Card::get_suit(), not Card::get_suit(const std::string &amp;trump). In the example of Card::get_suit(), we don't want to consider trump, meaning that whatever the suit the card is, that is what we want to return. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Now say we have Card::get_suit(const std::string &amp;trump), where &amp;trump is passed in and we <strong>do</strong> want to consider trump, then there is 1 case where we don't want to return the "exact" suit of the card.</p>


<p></p>


<p>This 1 case is when we are looking at the left bower. </p>


<p></p>


<p>Let's say the trump suit is Hearts, in this case, the left-bower would be Jack-of-Diamonds.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Technically, what is the suit of Jack-of-Diamonds? (The suit is Diamonds)</p>


<p></p>


<p>buttttt since this is the left bower, we want to consider the suit to be hearts, so that's what Card::get_suit(const std::string &amp;trump) would return.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Again, in the case when we call the function Card::get_suit() on the left bower (Jack-of-Diamonds), then we'll just return Diamonds since we're not considering trump for this function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>That makes total sense. Thanks so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In this case, would you modify the left bower of the card to change to the trump suit, or would you simply return the trump suit for this card?</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1569-------------------------
How many bugs are there to expose?
<p>In <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1107" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1107');">@1107</a>, someone asked the same question for project 2. Now, for project 3, how many possible bugs can we expose in <kbd>Card_tests</kbd> and <kbd>Player_tests</kbd> (so we can build more comprehensive test suites)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Good question, I don't know the exact number, but, I know that when you submit test cases to the autograder, it tells you how many bugs you caught and how many points you got, so that should probably help know how many test cases to write. Specifically for this project, you should have at least a few test cases for every function.</p>

------------------------@1574-------------------------
clangd
<p>I'm using clangd to catch errors in my code but when I'm trying to compile card cpp it's giving me these errors: In included file: unknown type name 'constexpr' &amp; Unknown type name 'constexpr'. When I disable clangd it doesn't give me this error but it also doesn't catch errors in my code at all if I disable it. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Sounds like clangd might be using an older C++ standard - as constexpr was added to the language in C++11, which is the version this class uses. You would probably need to look into getting clangd to use C++11 if you want to keep using it.</p>

------------------------@1575-------------------------
include more libraries than neccessary.
<p>Hi, I want to know whether it is legal to include all allowed libraries in each cpp file. I know that my cpp won't need them all in some case. I am not sure whether I would lose points by including all. Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, but it is typically bad practice to do so - possible conflicting names down the line and/or possible bugs. I don’t believe that the style checker checks for extra libraries.</p></div>

------------------------@1576-------------------------
Card_Less function
<p>For this function, are we allowed to assume that the 2 cards passed into this function won't be the same card, its not in the RME's for this function but for the program that we're making, it wouldn't make sense if we passed the exact same card twice to this function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No, you cannot assume that. Note that you cannot assume this for the less-than operator (<kbd>&lt;</kbd>) that we implemented—that is, the less than operator can take in two cards of the same value. If you remember this, the fact that the cards can be the same should not be prohibitive.</p>

For our test cases, should we only write tests for the 2 operator functions that we made originally or should we write test cases for the other 4 operators that are derived from the first 2</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1580-------------------------
For the pack constructor, does it need to pull cards from the deck in any suit order?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>For the default constructor, the suit order must be Spades -&gt; Hearts -&gt; Clubs -&gt; Diamonds. For the non-default constructor, you cannot assume anything about the order of suits in the given input file.</p></div>

Is this an issue with my IDE/Debugger, or is there any way the autograder didn't grade my files / submission correctly? And if the autograder didn't grade me correctly, could me and my partner get the style points we deserve for our code?</p>


<p><img alt="" height="146" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktn26xubdxh2m7%2F545ce37f15341fdec75ff37b196648722fed8d957653b5dbb1c0a3245e05558f%2FStyle_Check.jpg" width="308"/><img alt="" height="135" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktn26xubdxh2m7%2F4f8877d7fb8199040e3cd13f4a27414ef9b8755f5e4ee99d1540fa70ca9495cf%2FAutograder.jpg" width="370"/></p>

------------------------@1582-------------------------
Card.cpp modifier
<p>Card.cpp file does not contain any modifiers. I wonder if I am allowed to construct a modifier for instances of Card, allowing me to use brute force test methods for Card.cpp functions</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No. Check the requirements and restrictions section. In the second entry of the table, it says that while you may "Write helper functions in <kbd>Card.cpp</kbd> and <kbd>Pack.cpp</kbd> as non-member functions in the <kbd>.cpp</kbd> files and declare them <kbd>static</kbd>," you may not "modify <kbd>.h</kbd> files." If you want a modifier on Card to be useful at all, you will need to modify <kbd>Card.h</kbd>, but this is strictly forbidden. (And violating this rule will not get you anywhere). That said, you should not need to modify <kbd>Card</kbd> objects via an explicit modifier to test all of the functions completely.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I’m not entirely sure you what you mean. Can you elaborate? (Putting this as a followup since it doesn’t answer the student question.)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe the issue has been resolved. It turns out for the brute force test cases, a vector of size 52 works perfectly</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1583-------------------------
Are the constants in below rank nine supposed to be used in the program for euchre?
<p>Are the constants in below rank nine supposed to be used in the program for euchre? Just not seeing the point of them. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You won’t be using cards of rank 8 or lower outside of the Card-based files. The purpose of including them in here is to give a “fuller” sense of what a Card ADT would look like. For instance, if we later wanted to make a game of Poker in C++, we would have to reimplement a lot of our code if we didn’t already have the other ranks present.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1584-------------------------
operator overload question
When we implement operator overload, can we use the functions to get the rank and suit of the two cards and compare them directly (like lhs.get_rank() < rhs.get_rank()), or we need to compare them based on their position and size in the array?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The issue with the first method is that rank and suit are both strings, so doing a “&lt;” comparison wouldn’t give you the desired result (e.g. even though 2 &lt; 3, the string “two” is greater than the string “three”). So the key is to use their positions in the arrays.</p>
<p>As a hint though, you can call other operator overloads within each other (assuming you don’t have a recursive loop, like having == call != and vice versa)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
Thanks! Also, if I want to check if lhs is smaller than rhs and their ranks are equal, then I need to check their suits?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes. Suits break ties of rank.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Can you use the . operator to find the position of lhs in the array?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Unfortunately, you will have to do this manually. To find the position of the lhs &amp; rhs rank/suit in the arrays, you would have to perform element-wise comparison to determine what indices they exist at.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1585-------------------------
P3 Partnership
<p>If I submit to the Autograder choosing to work alone at first, can I change it after finding a partner before the checkpoint deadline? Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1588-------------------------
Can a struct have constructor?
<p>Can a struct have a constructor? If so, why do we use Matrix_init() instead of a constructor? Thank you.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
I don’t think structs have a constructor while classes do

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ditto Ethan's response below. Structs can have member functions, including constructors. In real-world C++ code though, we don't see structs with member functions all that often; they're mostly used for organizing multiple pieces of data into one type.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Structs are completely allowed to have a constructor - in fact, structs and classes are effectively identical to the compiler! (I believe the only actual difference is structs have public fields by default, classes have private fields)</p>


<p></p>


<p>The reason project 2 used something like <strong>Matrix_init()</strong> rather than a constructor was to teach about "old styled" C constructs rather than something more "modern" like C++ classes. All things considered - nothing was stopping you from implementing a constructor for the matrix struct - but that wasn't the purpose of the assignment.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>Those variables are arrays, so you need to access values using square brackets ([]) instead of parenthesis.</p>

<p>Here is my complete error message.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The compiler is interpreting your declaration of Card a to be the declaration of a new function named "a". To declare a card with the default constructor, you should use the following syntax:</p>


<p></p>


<div>
<pre>Card a = Card();</pre></div>


<p></p>

Pack Question

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Note that the <kbd>Pack.h</kbd> file defines three private member variables: </p>


<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">private</span>:
  <span class="hljs-keyword">static</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> PACK_SIZE = <span class="hljs-number">24</span>;
  <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">array</span>&lt;Card, PACK_SIZE&gt; cards;
  <span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> next; <span class="hljs-comment">//index of next card to be dealt</span><div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('cHJpdmF0ZTolMEElQzIlQTAlMjBzdGF0aWMlMjBjb25zdCUyMGludCUyMFBBQ0tfU0laRSUyMD0lMjAyNDslMEElQzIlQTAlMjBzdGQ6OmFycmF5JTNDQ2FyZCwlMjBQQUNLX1NJWkUlM0UlMjBjYXJkczslMEElQzIlQTAlMjBpbnQlMjBuZXh0OyUyMC8vaW5kZXglMjBvZiUyMG5leHQlMjBjYXJkJTIwdG8lMjBiZSUyMGRlYWx0');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>
<p>Use these member variables in your <kbd>deal_one()</kbd> function (and other functions with <kbd>Pack.cpp</kbd>). <kbd>deal_one()</kbd> will not need any inputs.</p>

------------------------@1594-------------------------
Shuffle problem
<p>I was wondering whether I have the logic correct for the shuffle function. I read the wikipedia article and I wrote the following code. First I split the deck in half. I do this by creating 2, 12 card arrays. I then refill the original array of cards by interchanging the 2 decks. For some reason, my tests fail and I am picking the wrong card at the top. Are there any holes in my logic that could be leading to this error? <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-01_at_4.37.43_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksy86i95wko132%2F37ab8e670d668194ba1648503a2f7a134659b2224ca43e411cc1ea2a8bf4a640%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-01_at_4.37.43_PM.png"/></p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Without looking too deeply at your code, my recommendation is to annotate your code with print statements that run throughout each iteration of the shuffle function, purely for debugging purposes. For example, you can <code>cout</code> “shuffle 1” followed by the state of your deck. Then, I think you’ll find that its much easier to see which iteration the function is failing on.</p></div>

------------------------@1595-------------------------
trump card in card
<p>since we assumed the trump suit is the suit of the left_bower in get_suit(trump) do we also assume that for the rest of the function in card like is_right_bower()?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, we treat the left_bower as if it were the trump suit for every function.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If we treat the suit of the left bower as the trump suit in is_right_bower(), wouldn't it return true for two cards? This would cause the bowers to be of equal value, no?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Sorry, that was my bad for giving a slightly inaccurate. In <code>is_right_bower()</code>, <code>is_left_bower()</code>, and all functions that state “does not consider trump” will use the suit assigned at initialization.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So if we use is_left_bower(trump) to be the trump suit for the implementation of function is_trump, is it wrong to then use is_trump in the implementation of is_left_bower? Thinking about it they would both just be calling each other. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>If you were to do this, then there’s a very high chance that you will infinite loop. One of the two functions has to not call the other.</p></div>

------------------------@1597-------------------------
Euchre led suit
What is the led suit?

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It is the suit of the first card played in the trick. The led suit will change from trick to trick. </p>


<p></p>


<p>For example, let say after making trump, the person left of the dealer will lead with a card. If they lead with the king of spades, spades is the led suit. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1598-------------------------
card operator test
<p>I am trying to test for operators. At first, I am thinking about using a for loop to create every card to test, but when it goes to two cards, I will have to use four for loops to compare between two cards, and I think that might be a problem as deep nesting, so I feel like I am in the wrong direction, maybe I should test individual cases?</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>I think the more realistic way will be testing edge cases? because if I want to test all cases, I will need to run (4*13)**2 times and even more for having trump, is that correct?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Well of course, you can’t test everything and it would be a waste to try to - as you said you should focus on your edge cases. This applies to all projects - for example in p1-stats there is no way to test every single vector of doubles against your functions - instead you just test some general cases and some edge cases.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your intuition is correct that using edge cases to test your operators will be a more efficient way of catching bugs than brute force for all combinations. You could still try to loop through a subset of cases for the operators as a way to try more possibilities in one test case than one at a time.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Wayne He (waning) is right to point out that best practice is to test some general cases and <em>(at least one of every distinct)</em> edge case you can think of.</p>


<p></p>


<p>That said, it is actually incorrect that you would need to run a for-loop <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="0" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c28"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c34"></mjx-c></mjx-mn><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2217"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" space="3"><mjx-c class="mjx-c31"></mjx-c><mjx-c class="mjx-c33"></mjx-c></mjx-mn><mjx-msup><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c29"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-script style="vertical-align: 0.363em;"><mjx-mn class="mjx-n" size="s"><mjx-c class="mjx-c32"></mjx-c></mjx-mn></mjx-script></mjx-msup></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>∗</mo><mn>13</mn><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> times to test every possible comparison. We can do it in far fewer. Remember the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transitive_relation" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">transitive relation</a>, which states that if <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="1" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D44E TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3C"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mi class="mjx-i" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D44F TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>&lt;</mo><mi>b</mi></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> and <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="2" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D44F TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3C"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mi class="mjx-i" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D450 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2C"></mjx-c></mjx-mo></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>b</mi><mo>&lt;</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>,</mo></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> then <mjx-container class="MathJax CtxtMenu_Attached_0" ctxtmenu_counter="3" jax="CHTML" role="presentation" style="font-size: 116.9%; position: relative;" tabindex="0"><mjx-math aria-hidden="true" class="MJX-TEX"><mjx-mi class="mjx-i"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D44E TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c3C"></mjx-c></mjx-mo><mjx-mi class="mjx-i" space="4"><mjx-c class="mjx-c1D450 TEX-I"></mjx-c></mjx-mi><mjx-mo class="mjx-n"><mjx-c class="mjx-c2E"></mjx-c></mjx-mo></mjx-math><mjx-assistive-mml display="inline" role="presentation" unselectable="on"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>&lt;</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>.</mo></math></mjx-assistive-mml></mjx-container> If you can prove this is true (we'll return to this in a moment), then you only need 51 distinct tests. To write all 51 of these lines succinctly, you can put them together in assert statements using the <kbd>and</kbd> operator: <kbd>ASSERT_TRUE(c1&lt;c2 &amp;&amp; c2&lt;c3 &amp;&amp; c3&lt;c4)</kbd>. Now, of course, you need to prove that the function holds the transitive relation, which, if your function properly holds the less-than relation, will apply. First, think through how your function works to see if you think it should hold the transitive relation, and second, in your tests, write the transitive relation explicitly: <kbd>ASSERT_TRUE(c1&lt;c2 &amp;&amp; c2&lt;c3 &amp;&amp; c1&lt;c3)</kbd>.</p>


<p></p>


<p>It's also not a bad idea to check whether it will return false when provoked with a false result.</p>

------------------------@1600-------------------------
get_suit (HINT: left_bower is considered trump)
<p>Hi! <br/>I am confused about the hint (&amp; question <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1599" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1599');">@1599</a>) about the get_suit function that takes trump as input. <br/><br/>It is expected to return the suit ... of what exactly? Of the trump input? Or of the suit of the card in question (private variable suit whatever it was initialized as)</p>


<p></p>

<p></p>


<p>Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1601-------------------------
20 Shuffles to restore deck
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you want to test <code>shuffle()</code> in <code>pack.cpp</code>, note that it takes 20 in-shuffles to restore a deck of 24 cards. If you call <code>shuffle()</code> 20 times, your deck should be the same as what it started as.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1602-------------------------
Can I call the same function in itself with different parameters
<p>Can I call the &lt; function within the Card_less functions with trump and led_card parameters, or will this result in an error? Similarly, can I call Card_less with just the trump parameter within Card_less with both trump and led_card parameters?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, you can call the <code>&lt;</code> function within the <code>Card_less</code> function, but be careful with your logic since there are cases where the <code>Card_less</code> output will differ from the <code>&lt;</code> output. You can also call the first overload (the one with three parameters) of <code>Card_less</code> from the other overload with four parameters.</p>
<p>More extensively, this applies to any function you’ll ever write - you can even call a function from itself. This is called recursion and you have to be really careful with the logic here or you can easily infinite loop. However, this isn’t relevant for right now - as far as I know Euchre doesn’t require this.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1603-------------------------
Simple Player
<p>are we supposed to create our own private variables when making the derived class for Simple Player. For example, should we create an empty vector with each players hand? Otherwise, where do we add the card in the add_card function?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thanks</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, create your own private member variables for the classes derived from Player.</p>

------------------------@1604-------------------------
bool operators
<p>For the bool operators do we need to consider all cards or just the cards in the deck (ie2s through aces) for euchre (ie 9s through aces)? And if we need to consider all cards how should we rank them?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I don’t know what range exactly, but I would assume the entire deck. The rankings for the cards are detailed in the spec under the section <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">value of cards</a>. In summary,</p>
<pre><code>Diamonds &gt; Clubs &gt; Hearts &gt; Spades
</code></pre><p>and</p>
<pre><code>Ace &gt; King &gt; Queen &gt; Jack &gt; Ten &gt; Nine &gt; ... &gt; Three &gt; Two
</code></pre><p>(The order is also in the constants <code>RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> and <code>SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> in <code>Card.h</code>)</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Student answer is right: the overloaded operators should work on the entire deck. Utilize the RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT and SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT arrays to code the overloaded operators.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, you can call any function from any other function, as long as it is declared before its call.</p></div>

------------------------@1608-------------------------

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>For the <code>add_and_discard</code> function in Simple Player, do we assume that the suit of <code>upcard</code> is the trump when comparing Cards to determine the lowest card? Or do we use the boolean operators to compare the Cards?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, you may assume that. The RME says "Note that at this point, the trump suit is the suit of the upcard."</p>

------------------------@1609-------------------------
P3 FAQ Helper function clarification
<p>I just had a question regarding this excerpt from the Q&amp;A:</p>


<p></p>


<p>"But in your test files, you should not assume that these functions exist (because you should not alter the interface for the classes). This also applies in your euchre driver as well! e.g. If you add a helper function to the simple player class, you can use it within that class, but you can’t use it in the driver since it won’t be part of the Player interface!"</p>


<p></p>


<p>I've never used helper functions in this course yet, so if I make a helper function and put it in say Card_less(), does that mean I can't call/test Card_less() in Card_tests.cpp because it has a helper function that isn't part of the interface? If so how do I test any function with a helper function in it?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you for clearing this up.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you made a helper function that you will use in <code>Card_less()</code>, you can still use <code>Card_less()</code> in <code>Card_tests.cpp</code> - it won’t be breaking the interface. What the Q&amp;A is warning about is that you can’t call the helper function you made for <code>Card_less()</code> inside of <code>Card_tests.cpp</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1610-------------------------
index of a given rank/suit from array
<p>So I know that we are supposed to use the RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT and SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT arrays in the overloaded operator functions but I am not quite sure how.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Is there a way to get the index of a given rank/suit from the array?</p>


<p></p>


<p>For example can I get the index "0" by calling some built in function and giving it the array RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT and "Card::SUIT_SPADES" (a string in the array)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><ol><li>You can call <code>RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> and <code>SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> by simply typing the keyword associated with the rank/suit you want, preceded by the Card scope resolution operator.</li></ol>
<pre><code>Card::SUIT_CLUBS
</code></pre><ol start="2"><li>You are free to do whatever you want with the <code>constexpr</code> strings, except directly modify them. If you want to create an array filled with those ranks and suits, I think its a great idea that could be implemented properly.</li></ol></div>

<p>Project 3 has officially been released... which means we're having another overview live-session!</p>


<p></p>


<p>Staff will be hosting a P3 overview Zoom call on <strong>Monday Night</strong> <strong>@ 8PM EST </strong>to go over the basic structure of this project and answer any questions you might have. Please note that we will <strong>not</strong> be explicitly teaching you how to play Euchre, so it would be helpful to come to this session with a basic understanding of the game.</p>
