------------------------@1698-------------------------
Weights in overloaded operators.
<p>Not sure how to use RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT and SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT arrays to code the overloaded operators. I am thinking of seeing what indexes each card's rank/suit is at to compare, but unsure how to find the index of the arrays. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can use the == operator to compare your card’s suit/rank to every element in RANK_NAMES / SUIT_NAMES. Remember we have the size of these arrays defined as constants in card.h (NUM_SUITS and NUM_RANKS).
Also, make sure to read the operator tutorial. You only need to code 2 operators. The rest can be derived from just those two.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1699-------------------------
Operator Functions
My approach is to iterate through the RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT array for the lhs and res to determine the value, however I am unsure of the syntax? I've tried passing by reference but I'm not sure how to access the array index?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><pre><code>RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT[0] == "Two";

RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT[12] == "Ace";
RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT[13] // oob error
</code></pre><p>It’s just an array of strings, put the index you want in the brackets to access the element. You can iterate it just like iterating a vector:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> (<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> i = <span class="hljs-number">0</span>; i &lt; <span class="hljs-number">13</span>; i++) {
	<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT[i] &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;
}
<span class="hljs-comment">// or</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">for</span> (<span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">string</span> r : RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT) {
	<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; r &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>;
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre></div>

<pre>  <span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">virtual</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">void</span> <span class="hljs-title">add_and_discard</span>(<span class="hljs-params"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> Card &amp;upcard</span>)</span> = <span class="hljs-number">0</span>;

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>See this section of the notes: <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/10_Polymorphism.html#abstract-classes-and-interfaces" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Abstract Classes and Interfaces</a>. It explains that these functions equaling zero denote them as “pure virtual” functions and can’t be implemented in the base class, they <strong>must</strong> be overridden in derived classes.</p></div>

------------------------@1705-------------------------
How to check cards in Player's hand after function call?
<p>If we're testing the Player functions and want to check the player's hand or hand.size() after a function call, what would be the best way to do it? Since print_hand() is a private function, I'm confused on how we can assert different expectations for what should be in the player's hand after a Player function is called.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I don't believe there's a way to directly check the player's hand after a function call since the corresponding functions and variables are all private. What you can do is after calling a function that edits hand, like <kbd>add_and_discard()</kbd>, you can then call functions such as <kbd>lead_card()</kbd> repeatedly to check if the rest of the cards are what you expect.</p>


<p></p>

<p>. <img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-05_at_2.44.43_PM.pngNaN" height="282" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky0sfdd2vr188%2Fb0fa27b4f47c32b2bede408749bd45ab8aa5b215596db051468ab7b125c32de2%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-05_at_2.44.43_PM.png" width="507"/></p>

------------------------@1709-------------------------
confused about ranking
<p>what is the ranking between, regular trump, the led card, the left bower card and the right bower card?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards</a></p>


<p>This link explains the value of the cards pretty well. Essentially, right bower &gt; left bower &gt; trump suit cards &gt; led suit cards &gt; all non-trump-suit non-led-suit cards. Additionally, keep in mind that the suits have a defined order as well, which are considered if the ranks are the same, and neither trump or led suit applies.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1710-------------------------
Pack Constructor
<p>I am confused as to what the pack constructor is actually supposed to do. I understand that one implementation of Pack needs to be done without input and the other is done by reading a file, but what I don't understand is how the actual card information is supposed to be stored. My guess is that Pack is an array, but I couldn't find anywhere that said that explicitly. Is pack supposed to generate an array?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>In the <code>Pack.h</code> file, one of the private variables for the <code>Pack</code> class is the <code>cards</code> array. You are to put the cards in the pack in this array.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Pack is a class, and it does have an array as its private member variable <code>std::array&lt;Card, PACK_SIZE&gt; cards</code>. So. you do not want to "generate" an array, but think about how you want to initialize it (and maybe other member variables) in the constructors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1711-------------------------
Picking trump
<p>The first time around the table what are we supposed to do if a human player tries to input a suit that does not match the upcard?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think when it says that we can assume that the human player's input will be accurate, it also means that the human player's input will follow the rules of the game. So, I don't think we need to account for this specific case. I also believe similar logic should apply if the human player can follow the led suit, but chooses to not anyways.</p>

------------------------@1713-------------------------
Initializing the two of spades
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkejgw934y4m2le%2Fe55f8ca3cbe55e9a29ff6dfd5139e3f83620b438fad56565aafb2b136632fb83%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>We were having trouble initializing the two of spades and we keep failing the public test. Was there something that we were missing?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So what you’re doing here is calling the constructor in the code of your constructor, essentially doing a recursive construction call which is illegal. If you intend to use an initializer list - which you should be doing - touch up on the syntax of an initializer list <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/08_ADTs_in_C++.html?highlight=constructor#constructors" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>.</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1728-------------------------
Why I have to use std::string instead of string in cpp at class
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl54xl3kzaz8jg%2F983a687a5aa70b0b970e88b8057bbf6b056020fce49fce5273b46579d664ae71%2F__2022-10-06___12.53.01.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">__2022-10-06___12.53.01.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You don’t have if you include <kbd>using namespace std;</kbd> at the top of your .cpp file. <kbd>std::</kbd> just signifies that <kbd>string</kbd> is from <kbd>std</kbd> (the C++ Standard Library).</p>

------------------------@1729-------------------------

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If using a temporary array makes the most sense to you, that is a perfectly fine way to go about shuffle. My opinion is that this is also the approach that is least likely to lead to logic mistakes.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1730-------------------------
The comparing operator<
<p>According to the requirements,</p>


<div>
<div>//EFFECTS Returns true if lhs is lower value than rhs.</div>
<div>// Does not consider trump.</div>
<div>But we need to think of the suit color even if two values are equal. Am I overthinking for this function? Should I consider that situation?</div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
If the ranks are equal then you consider suit color. Else, rank decides which is higher.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But what is the purpose of writing &lt;= operator for the next function? Each poker card is unique and they cannot be equal. Thx!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Possibly to show the ability of the class to be adapted to other games? Also keep in mind you only really have to implement two of the operator overrides and the rest can be combinations or negations of each other.

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You are correct that in the context of euchre, we won’t have duplicates of a card. This is more-so for completeness of the <code>Card</code> class.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1731-------------------------
Can I change the suit in class private to trump directly?
<p>For example, it satisfies the requirement of left bower, and I assign trump to suit. Then I return suit. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I assume you are thinking in terms of the <code>get_suit()</code> function here. Technically speaking, the compiler is not going to prevent you from changing the suit of a card anywhere in the <code>Card</code> class. However, I would caution against this. If you changes the rank/suit of a card in the game, you no longer have that card for use. For example, if you were to change the <code>Jack of Hearts</code> to be <code>Diamonds</code> when it is the left bower, you’d be left with a pack that has two <code>Jack of Diamonds</code> and no <code>Jack of Hearts</code>. I would instead just return the trump suit if you realize you are looking at the left bower.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1732-------------------------
Shuffle()
<p>resolved</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>resolved</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>**oops, first_half and second_half should be instantiated outside of the inner for loop</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1733-------------------------
All Pack_public_tests error
<p>Each of the tests in Pack_public_test.exe result in the same error when I run it. The error is:</p>


<p></p>


<p>"Uncaught std::logic_error in test "test": basic_string::_M_construct null not valid"</p>


<p></p>


<p>I'm not sure what this error is or why it is happening, nor how to fix it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It's tough to tell without seeing the code, (you can make a private post if you are still having trouble), but you can read more about that error here: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54429231/how-to-fix-stdlogic-error-what-basic-string-m-construct-null-not-valid" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54429231/how-to-fix-stdlogic-error-what-basic-string-m-construct-null-not-valid</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This error can happen for a variety of reasons, though it typically arises when you try to use a non-string value as a string. Say, initializing a string with a <kbd>char*</kbd> null pointer or using an integer where you're meant to use a string. Without seeing your code (which you shouldn't share), I can't say much else. Maybe this will help, or if not consider a private Piazza post.</p>

------------------------@1734-------------------------
Ranking if trump suit == led suit
<p>If the trump suit and led suit are the same, would the card values be the same as this ranking?</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1735-------------------------
pack_input
<p>for istream pack_input can I read in two string for the suit and the rank and then put them in the cards array? I am getting a segmentation fault error when running the public test cases. and my pack() is working well I wanted to loop through the array as well for my pack_input.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>From looking at your current autograder submission, I think you might just be missing accounting for the “of” in the input of a card. The format of any card in the input is “<strong>rank</strong> of <strong>suit</strong>” (ie. “King of Clubs”). Just make sure to read the “of”.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>I don’t think having all these loops nested is exactly what you want. I would suggest a slightly different approach that just utilizes the outer two loops and a temporary card array. What if you iterated through the pack once (using x) and moved cards into your temporary array based on the value of x.</p>
<p>For example, we know that the card that ends up at index 0 came from index 12 (first card, second half) and the card that ends up at index 1 came from index 0 (first card, first half). How could you relate the indices the cards start at to x (where they end up)?</p></div>

------------------------@1738-------------------------
Why am I failing autograder Player public tests?
<p>I'm confused why I'm failing the Player public tests on autograder. I pass all of them on my computer and on CAEN. The error output states there's no output, but I don't really understand what that means in context of the insertion test, since we're just creating a simple and human player. Any advice would be really appreciated.</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7fig8ilv8x9v%2F32c310465275389c1d3d2c1e4454c92f2468221a3bbc7f1b5e81f135f13dbbd1%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7fig8ilv8x9v%2F837dac3be5ee18ad7433eb7cc83561a6dc44bd353de86fa23ab7506ab95315a1%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From James:</p>


<p>"The issue is that your human player name member variable is declared as a reference. But, that means it ends up getting bound to the temporary std::string materialized from the string literal in the test. That temporary only lives until the end of its enclosing full expression (basically just for that one line of code) and after that the human player's name is a reference to a dead object."</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1742-------------------------
add_and_discard
<p>I'm trying to call make_trump in add_and_discard, but it is giving me this error when trying to pass in the suit of the upward (aka the trump). How do I fix this?<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktx702ju4fk7jj%2F54c349ae6a218a4bdc1e0b48477ea3a41977c42bf444bc7cb48ea9890503d78b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_2.12.30_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_2.12.30_PM.png</a><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktx702ju4fk7jj%2F07826f7c616b9f0c0f8405c50555495cd7de75175b14b9fda11537aa86936638%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_2.12.38_PM.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-10-06_at_2.12.38_PM.png</a></p>

<p>You may not want to call make_trump in add_and_discard (check the RME of each functions) because you do not need to.</p>


<p>The expression upcard.get_suit() should be correct.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>in the spec it says for the add_and_discard "If the trump suit is ordered up during round one, the dealer picks up the upcard." How do you check if this is true if you don't call the function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When the function add_and_discard() is called, you should have known that you want to pick up the upcard. In other words, whether the round is the first round or the second round should be checked outside the function add_and_discard().</p>

------------------------@1743-------------------------
Don't understand how default constructor works
<p>I'm trying to test the default constructor of card Card() but i keep getting this error</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2F70e4cccfb274e532361a4a3979b2217f4937c825b9c28a1ad3c5ec525cdc7fa5%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2F0caa4ebf39c1611776f6e47f9b216eb7a0b33a6d85f4d82d9770a4597f303fc0%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>This is what I wrote in Card()</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxpu49nau04mz%2Fb612af4f9e75fd67e599de44ffe6745ae0ee9575e866cbea922f21e57f045246%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>My other constructor works fine and passes its test</p>


<p>I get the same error if I just use the regular constructor in the default one</p>


<p></p>


<p>I just don't understand how writing a default constructor works when we write the implementation separate from the header.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When you want to call the default constructor (and initialize an instance of your Card class), you do not need to put the () after your object name, in this case c.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Try replacing your declaration with:</p>


<p><kbd>Card c;</kbd></p>


<p></p>


<p>Right now, I think your compiler is reading this as if you were trying to declare a new function called <kbd>c</kbd> which returns a Card and takes no parameters, but by getting rid of the parenthesis you will actually create a Card instance called c by implicitly calling the default constructor.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1744-------------------------
Identical Issue as @1694
<p>Hello, I am receiving the same error as the student in question <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1694" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1694');">@1694</a>. I have verified that my pack ctor initializes the cards in the correct order, and as the code shows below, the in-shuffle is completed 7 times. I was wondering if you could take a look and help me understand where I might be going wrong. Thank you.</p>


<p></p>


<p><code>    void Pack::shuffle(){<br/>  next = 0;<br/>  std::array&lt;Card, PACK_SIZE / 2&gt; firstHalf;<br/>  std::array&lt;Card, PACK_SIZE / 2&gt; secondHalf;<br/>  std::array&lt;Card, PACK_SIZE&gt; inShuffled;<br/><br/>  //Outer for loop ensures the in shuffle is done 7 times.<br/>  for(int doSeven = 0; doSeven &lt; 7; doSeven++){<br/><br/>    //split into half decks<br/>    for(int i = 0; i &lt; PACK_SIZE / 2; i++){<br/>      firstHalf[i] = cards[i];<br/>      secondHalf[i] = cards[i + 12];<br/>    }<br/><br/>    //copy them into an aux array, in correct order.<br/>    for(int i = 0; i &lt; PACK_SIZE; i++){<br/><br/>      //If index of aux is even, take from second half.<br/>      if(i % 2 == 0){<br/>        inShuffled[i] = secondHalf[i / 2];<br/>      }<br/>      <br/>      //If index of aux is odd, take from first half.<br/>      else{<br/>        inShuffled[i] = firstHalf[i / 2];<br/>      }<br/>    }<br/><br/>    //Copys from inShuffled into cards.<br/>    std::copy(begin(inShuffled), end(inShuffled), begin(cards));<br/>  }<br/>}<br/></code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>From your autograder submission, I think the issue may be coming from your <code>Pack</code> constructor rather than the shuffle function. Per the RME for the default <code>Pack</code> constructor:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><em>Initializes the Pack to be in the following standard order: <br/> the cards of the lowest suit arranged from lowest rank to highest rank, followed by the cards of the next lowest suit in order from lowest to highest rank, and so on.</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>It seems like your Pack is initialized with all of the nines followed by all of the tens, etc. Instead, you want all of the Spades followed by all of the Hearts, etc.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1745-------------------------

<p>In my card.cpp I declared some static non-member helper functions and I didn't modify card.h, and I called the helper functions in my card functions. I thought I followed the protocol properly, if anyone can tell me what is wrong with the helper functions I would really appreciate it. Thank you. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You need to declare those helper functions before your class. I noticed that in you cpp files, those functions are declare after class Card.</p>

------------------------@1750-------------------------
How to set the rank and suit of a card in a pack?
<p>I understand how to create the pack constructor except for how I am supposed to set the rank and suit of each card in the pack. It seems like the only function that allows you to do that that's available for a Card is the constructor, but the Cards already exist if they are in the array already, right? It also doesn't seem to be allowing me to use the constructor for this purpose. Are we supposed to create our own functions to set rank and suit or am I missing something?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You're right that you need to use the Card constructor to make cards, since it explicitly sets the rank and suit. You need to make Cards then put them in the "cards" array. Hint: Use a loop to make it more efficient!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I guess what I'm confused about there is that I can't create cards within a loop, because it would try to remake the same card over and over again, right? Is there another way to do this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can call the Card constructor whenever you want to create a new card. For example:</p>


<p></p>


<p>Card c1(Card::RANK_JACK, Card::SUIT_HEARTS);</p>


<p>c1 = Card(Card::RANK_NINE, Card::SUIT_CLUBS);</p>


<p></p>


<p>This would set c1 to a Jack of Hearts, then the next line sets it to a Nine of Clubs.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ohh, thank you so much! I completely missed that you could do that with constructors.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1751-------------------------
Trouble getting full points on Player_tests

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Based on an instructor response on a similar question, the autograder is only checking for SimplePlayer tests, not Human.  As for tests, a piece of advice given during the SI lecture was to go through and play games (against either friends or online) and use that as a basis for your tests.  Otherwise just keep searching for edge cases.  One place I found helpful to reference when checking for those is the card hierarchy diagram in the spec.  Hope that helps!  </p>


<p></p>


<p>Also double check by clicking on your tests in the autograder that you don't have any false positives.  </p>

------------------------@1754-------------------------
Card_less
<p>//REQUIRES trump is a valid suit</p>


<p>//EFFECTS Returns true if a is lower value than b.  Uses trump to determine</p>


<p>// order, as described in the spec.</p>


<p><b>bool</b> Card_less(<b>const</b> Card &amp;a, <b>const</b> Card &amp;b, <b>const</b> std::string &amp;trump);</p>


<p></p>


<p>For this function are we only considering the trump suit as the determining factor in whether a &lt; b or vice versa? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>As I understand it, you should make use of the boolean operator functions in addition to trump in order for Card_less to function as intended.  To get an idea of what this means you can check the middle diagram in the card hierarchy image in the project spec under "scoring".  </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Consider trump alongside the rank and suit (similar to what you did in <code>operator&lt;</code>, hint hint!).</p></div>

------------------------@1757-------------------------
My code for assertion of cards remain in the Pack
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl54xl3kzaz8jg%2Fdc09c9bf9c71610959c4d4ecd4c2fc03e313533da282cca106bcfe78abe84421%2F__2022-10-06___8.55.12.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">__2022-10-06___8.55.12.png</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In the Pack function deal_one(), the assert (empty() == false) is failing, which means empty() is returning true. Either your constructor isn't initializing the Pack to have any cards, or your empty() function has a bug, and is returning true when it should be returning false. Hope this helps!</p>

------------------------@1763-------------------------
Retaking but scored low on Checkpoint
<p>I'm retaking the course with an almost-finished p3 at hand.</p>

------------------------@1764-------------------------
In operator<= interpretation of "card"
<p>Does the "Returns true if lhs is lower value than rhs or the same <strong>card</strong> as rhs" refer to the rank only, or rank AND suit (within the operator&lt;= function of card.cpp)? For example, does it mean a 10 of hearts is the same as a 10 of diamonds, OR is a 10 of hearts the same as a 10 of diamonds.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It should consider both rank and suit. A 10 of hearts is only equal to a 10 of hearts.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You never have 2 of the same cards in a pack though, so in what what cases would that be applied to?</p>

------------------------@1768-------------------------
Static const int
I see that the data type of PACK_SIZE is static const int. What does static mean?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It’s described in detail in the notes <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/11_Container_ADTs.html#static-data-members" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>, but it essentially means that the variable isn’t associated with any specific <code>Pack</code> that you create but the class as a whole. You don’t need to make a <code>Pack</code> member to use <code>PACK_SIZE</code>. It’s kind of similar to global variables in that they just exist not tied to a specific function’s scope or lifetime.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1771-------------------------
simple player, make_trump, what does it mean by same color?
<p>"During round two, a Simple Player considers ordering up the suit with the same color as the upcard, which would make that suit trump. They will order up if that would mean they have one or more cards that are either face or ace cards of the trump suit in their hand (the right and left bowers, and Q, K, A of the order-up suit)."</p>


<p></p>


<p>The description is a little bit confusing here. For example, if the upcard is Dimond, and the player has King of Dimond, he will order up Dimond? And if he has King of Hear, he will order Heart? "Same" color implies that he has two choices?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>"Same" color implies that he only has 1 choice, which is the suit that is not the upcard.</p>


<p></p>


<p>So in your example, if the upcard is Diamond, only Hearts will be considered during the 2nd round</p>

------------------------@1773-------------------------
Deal one
<p>In the deal one function, I should assume that I should be able to deal from wherever I am in the pack correct? If so, how can I keep track of where I am in the deck? Or whenever we deal one, will we always be at the beginning of the pack and the first card will always be the nine of spades? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Per the <code>deal_one()</code> RME:</p>
<p>// REQUIRES: cards remain in the Pack <br/>
// EFFECTS: Returns the next card in the pack and increments the next index <br/>
Card deal_one();</p>
<p>So, you should be dealing from wherever you are in the pack. It is your job to use the <code>Pack</code> private member variables as a means of tracking where to deal from.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1774-------------------------
Concise Coding
<p>Hiya! </p>


<p>I'm not the best at all with C++, but I feel like I have way too many if/else statements and for loops in my code. I checked my pseudocode in office hours and they said it was fine, but I was wondering if there is a more simple way to do this? This screenshot is make_trump from my derived class Simple : public Player in Player.ccp. </p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-07_at_10.50.51_AM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fktax57imt3ldr%2F738a80819e85c1d8e2485bf36edeead561815577ff730045954d2fa6ea6ab76e%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-07_at_10.50.51_AM.png"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A lot of this kinda stuff you just get better at the more you program. At the end of the day, complex software has a lot of nested conditions you need to evaluate. There's no real way to get around that. But some strategies I use to try and reduce to "compact-tify" code are:</p>


<ol><li>Move chunks of code like "for" loops into a separate helper function</li><li>Move if-blocks outside the if-statement</li></ol>


<p></p>


<p>For the 2nd point, and example would be converting:</p>


<pre>for() {
  if(cond) {
    block
  }
}</pre>
<p>to:</p>


<pre>for() {
  if(!cond) continue;
  block
}</pre>
<p>There's a lot of little tricks like that which you'll pick up over time. I wouldn't stress about it too much, but be on the lookout for opportunities like that and you'll improve gradually. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1775-------------------------
Do simple players automatically reject taking the upcard when making Trump?
<p>If a simple player is dealer and a player orders up during the first round, does the simple player automatically reject taking the upcard and keep their hand as is?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From the spec, under Adding the Upcard and Discarding a Card for a Simple Player:</p>


<p></p>


<p>If the trump suit is ordered up during round one, the dealer PICKS UP the upcard. The dealer then discards the lowest card in their hand, <em>even if this is the upcard</em>, for a final total of five cards. (Note that at this point, the trump suit is the suit of the upcard.)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1776-------------------------
How to use next private variable
<p>What exactly is the purpose of "next" private var in Pack? I understand we're supposed to reset the this var and increment it at some point, but should we be using it in our logic for shuffle and/or empty or is it something we'll end up using later down the line instead?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><kbd>next</kbd> stores the index of the next card to be dealt, which you can also think of as the card currently at the top of the deck. When you want to deal a card, you can use <kbd>next</kbd> to figure out which card should be dealt. You can also increment it after to store the index of the next card at the top of the deck (which would then be dealt next). Hopefully this makes a little more sense as to what the purpose of <kbd>next</kbd> is in the scope of the rest of the project.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The student response to question <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1619" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1619');">@1619</a> explains what one shuffle should do to the deck pretty well</p>

------------------------@1778-------------------------
Error with sort function
<p>I am getting this error with the sort function, I know the P3 FAQ has something about this but I do know know if it relates to mine or if I am implementing it wrong<img alt="" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkvfx5ao61zw37e%2F94fca6d06748ae109b5aae57c47a2ff2db4534cec5e54fde544edf7ba68b2f2b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-07_at_12.47.50_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your error is because sort expects the parameters to be iterators instead of direct card objects. I would refer to the cpp reference for <code>std::sort</code> <a href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/sort" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a> for some examples of how to use sort.</p></div>

------------------------@1779-------------------------
How primitive type is default-initialized.
<p>For example, let's say there is a private int type member and a private char type member in a class, and they are not initialized in the constructor. What value will they be default-initialized to? Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You cannot expect a default type to initialize to any certain value once it's declared. Depending on the computer, it may initialize to 0/false or it may just assume the value that was last in its place in memory. Working with an uninitiliazed primitive variable would therefore create unknown behavior. Always initialize your primitives when you can, and don't work with them until they are initialized.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1780-------------------------
Code not running on Xcode but on terminal its fine
<p><img alt="" height="104" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxikn2v41x5ja%2F177a4a827ca7841f781da94c1c7e30c974a4098130c31d9f4b04c81b04ab4a2c%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-07_at_1.55.25_PM.png" width="282"/></p>


<p>I am getting this error whenever I try to run my code on xcode. I have made sure I have the correct compile sources (card.cpp, card_tests.cpp, card_public_test.cpp, pack.cpp, pack_tests.cpp, pack_public_tests.cpp, player.cpp, player_tests.cpp, player_public_tests.cpp, euchre.cpp, and makefile).</p>


<p></p>


<p>I can compile fine on my terminal command line but not xcode and I am not able to use my debugger on xcode until I can run it on the IDE.</p>


<p>I have looked at other similar posts on piazza and have done everything that people have said to do and nothing is working still. Any advice?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You need to modify the compile sources you use depending on what you are trying to run. If you include <code>card_tests.cpp</code>, <code>card_public_tests.cpp</code>, <code>pack_tests.cpp</code>, <code>pack_public_tests.cpp</code>, <code>player_tests.cpp</code>, <code>player_public_tests.cp</code>, and <code>euchre.cpp</code>, XCode doesn’t know which one to run (all of these have main functions). As a rule of thumb, the compile sources should include <code>Card.cpp</code>, <code>Pack.cpp</code>, <code>Player.cpp</code> and one file with a <code>main()</code> depending on what you want to run. I would also recommend removing your Makefile from the compile sources - this sometimes causes other issues.</p></div>

------------------------@1783-------------------------
Player Factory
<p>Right now, I'm having a hard time trying to make player_factory in that I'm getting an error when trying to return a new Simple or Human player with a specified name. I believe that the error is caused because I haven't set up the actual classes for both Simple and Human players but thats where I am confused and don't really know how to proceed with making those classes. What would be the best way to start with making Simple / Human Player and is there any notes that could help me understand what I am trying to do here?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>This project is unique in that it’s passing more of the reins to us, and that we have to figure out how we want to design the structure of this project (you’ll get even more freedom in <code>euchre.cpp</code>. A great place to start is to copy the <code>Player.h</code> class declartion into the <code>Player.cpp</code> file and remove the <code>virtual</code> and <code>= 0</code> parts, since both <code>SimplePlayer</code> and <code>HumanPlayer</code> will be overriding and inheriting this class.</p>
<p>As for any notes, you may want to look at the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/notes/09_Inheritance.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Derived Classes and Inheritance</a> section of the lecture notes. Other than that, the only specification you are given on how to implement the functions are the (short) sections in the project spec and the RMEs.</p></div>

------------------------@1784-------------------------
No instance of constructor SimplePlayer : SimplePlayer (or HumanPlayer) matches the argument list
<p>Right now, I'm currently stuck on player_factory and I don't really know what to do to fix this error. I'm confused on what it means by no instance of constructor since I thought that the class SimplePlayer : public Player was the constructor. What am I doing wrong and what should I do to fix it?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswarsphpxp48a%2Faa960999c44386629cf2415d5f426b50fc061bd7ff6a0d2090581aade9a5e66d%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswarsphpxp48a%2Ff2edd71c6d2ea7206224f4b5e4bacc73e91551886750388db6a884c8dcde01b8%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
Your idea in player factory is right. The error is showing since you haven't implemented a constructor that takes in the "name" as argument. Here, you would need to add a SimplePlayer(...) { Assign name } constructor in order to achieve that. In the line class SimplePlayer: public Player, all that is happening is that SimplePlayer inherits the Player class, so in our case, we need a constructor of our own implemented for SimplePlayer specifically, in addition to all the other functions that needs to be there. The same would be the case for a Human player.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1786-------------------------

------------------------@1787-------------------------
get_name() not working
<p><img alt="" height="150" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksurffc3u4m3cr%2F899a197b4c0119319f0ce052c81a80beefe582613ad1e268f2b91390df27ce46%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-07_at_4.17.21_PM.png" width="490"/></p>


<p>Hi, I'm having an error saying that I'm unable to use "this" in my get_name() function because it can only be used inside a nonstatic member function. I do not know what this means. I have created a variable "name" in each of my classes (Player, Human, Simple), and am unsure as to why this isn't working. Let me know, thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I would double check that your function signature aligns with what is in the <code>Player.h</code> file. <br/>
Here’s the signature: <code>virtual const std::string &amp; get_name() const = 0;</code> <br/>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>In general, the <code>this</code> keyword is implicit when you are writing a function within a class. As long as you have separate <code>SimplePlayer</code> and <code>HumanPlayer</code> classes, there is no need to do anything extra to differentiate between them within their member functions.</p></div>

------------------------@1790-------------------------
Deal_one
I’m having a hard time understanding the deal_one function in the pack. cpp.What does it mean by returning the next card in the pack? Does the next card mean the card to be dealt? And what does it mean that it increments the next index? Does it mean that the dealing starts with cards[0] and if cards[0] is dealt then the dealing starts with cards[1]?

-------------------------------------------------
You basically have it down. You have 24 cards with indexes 0-23. You deal starting at 0 and increment some value that tracks index, which would then become 1. Next time deal is called, it will deal cards[1] and increment.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1791-------------------------
How to test add_card
<p>How are we supposed to test add_card function in Player_tests.cpp? The function is void and we also can't access the member variables of the player's array/vector of cards.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You would have to later call <code>play_card</code> or some function which depends on the cards in the hand to see that the card is actually in the hand and influencing decisions. As you said, there is no direct way to access cards so we can only test them indirectly.</p></div>

------------------------@1793-------------------------
Question on Visual Studio debugger
<p>Hi, I have implemented functions for Card.cpp and Pack.cpp and are passing all the tests through the terminal (except for shuffle()). However, my local windows debugger does not seem to be working and a "unable to start program" warning pops out every time I try to debug it. I attached a screenshot of the warning and error messages. (The Chinese characters just say: Unable to find the files)</p>


<p></p>

------------------------@1795-------------------------
meaning of char *argv[]
<p>argv is an array of arguments. And char **argv is an equivalent way to write it. So, I think argv should be a pointer points to pointer. Is it like argv is a pointer that points to the things in it and the things in it are pointers points to some characters? Does argv here decay from an array to a pointer? If that's true, since argv contains many pointers that point to different characters, argv is pointing at different pointers at the same time or it points to the first pointer in the array.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Recall that a <code>char *</code> is a c-string. This means that <code>argv</code> is an array of cstrings, but you would also not be wrong in saying that it is an array of pointers. The reason <code>char **argv</code> is also <code>char *argv[]</code> is because arrays will decay into a pointer to the first element, and since we don’t know what the size of <code>argv</code> will be, its easier to just keep a pointer to the first element. As an example, this is what the memory addresses would look like for a sample <code>euchre.exe</code> call:</p>
<pre>./euchre.exe pack.<span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> noshuffle <span class="hljs-number">3</span> Ivan Human Judea Human Kunle Human Liskov Human
<span class="hljs-number">0x0218</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of argv
<span class="hljs-number">0x0218</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">0</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12a6</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'./euchre.exe'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0220</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">1</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12b3</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'pack.in'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0228</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">2</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12bb</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'noshuffle'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0230</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">3</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12c5</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'3'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0238</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">4</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12c7</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Ivan'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0240</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">5</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12cc</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Human'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0248</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">6</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12d2</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Judea'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0250</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">7</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12d8</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Human'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0258</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">8</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12de</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Kunle'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0260</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">9</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12e4</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Human'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0268</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">10</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12ea</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Liskov'</span>
<span class="hljs-number">0x0270</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">is</span> the address of the pointer at argv[<span class="hljs-number">11</span>] = <span class="hljs-number">0x12f1</span> which points to the cstring <span class="hljs-string">'Human'</span>
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>The addresses on the far left are the addresses of the elements in argv, namely <code>char**</code> since they point to a pointer to a cstring. The address in the middle is the actual pointer to the cstring which you can see are located in a different place than the values in <code>argv</code> (the memory address starts with a different value).</p>
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7nv0y6f4pf5aa%2F406c56781681280264ea6fef0046b99c00aaed49cf3024f49571490381c15dd3%2Fimage.png"/></p>
<p>Hopefully this clears things up!</p>
<p>If you want to run this little test I spent too much time making, I made a gist <a href="https://gist.github.com/Ecpii/d92d4ac8e14b16667f1770a9633af85d" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>. It shouldn’t be an honor code violation since you don’t need any of this for the actual euchre program but if if breaks any rules please let me know.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1796-------------------------
Screw the dealer and make_trump for simple player
<p>In the spec for simple player it says "(A Simple Player does not consider whether they are the dealer and could gain an additional trump by picking up the upcard.)" in the paragraph about round 1.</p>


<p></p>


<p>However, in the paragraph about round 2 it says "If making reaches the dealer during the second round, we invoke <em>screw the dealer</em>, where the dealer is forced to order up. In the case of screw the dealer, the dealer will always order up the suit with the same color as the upcard."</p>


<p></p>


<p>This is confusing because it says a simple player does not consider whether they are the dealer but then asks us to invoke screw the dealer. Can I please have some general clarification about this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In the first round, the player only considers the cards in their hand. If you are the dealer and have two trumps in your hand, ordering up the suit would give you a third. The spec says to ignore this fact, and run your strategy as if you only have two trumps in your hand.</p>


<p>In the second round, the dealer is stuck (screwed), and must call a suit. They aren't allowed to call the suit that was just turned over, so the Simple strategy insists that you order up the same color suit.</p>


<p></p>


<p>i.e. don't consider dealer status in round one, but do consider it in round two if stuck.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p></p>

------------------------@1799-------------------------
Human player make_trump()
<p>"When making trump reaches a Human Player, first print the Player’s hand. Then, prompt the user for their decision to pass or order up. The user will then enter one of the following: “Spades”, “Hearts”, “Clubs”, “Diamonds”, or “pass” to either order up the specified suit or pass. This procedure is the same for both rounds of making trump."</p>


<p></p>


<p>^pasted from the spec</p>


<p></p>


<p>This makes it sound like the user can order up any suit in the first round, but in the rules it says the players can only order up the suit that the upcard is. What one is true for this assignment?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I believe that you assume the human player will only make a valid decision here.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We will assume that the human player will always make valid decisions that do not violate the game rules.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Then why not simplify the input to either "pass" or "make?" I'm also confused as to why there are four possible input choices.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>For the second round, the human should be able to pick whatever suit they want as trump (as long as it wasn’t the upcard’s suit). This is different from the Simple player.</p></div>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>To reiterate the student follow-up answer, double check that you have a <code>delete</code> for every <code>new</code>. The autograder shows errors coming from lines 362 and 497 in <code>Player_tests.cpp</code>. It looks like you aren’t deallocating the dynamic memory reserved for the cards allocated on those lines.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
Some general advice would be to make sure wherever you use new you use delete. Also, in many cases you don’t have to use dynamic memory and you can avoid these sort of errors.

------------------------@1803-------------------------
get_suit(trump)
<p>I'm very confused about the functionality of this method. If I'm returning the value of the suit of the card in the end, why is the suit of the trump needed in this method call? Why not just use the get_suit() with no parameters to get the suit of the card? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes. As per <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1599" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1599');">@1599</a>, it is identical to `get_suit()` except it also considers the left bower as trump.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I guess I'm still not understanding, if all you want is the suit of the card, why does it even matter what the trump suit is</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The left bower is considered the trump suit instead of its original suit when using this function, so you need to know the trump suit to deal with this.

------------------------@1806-------------------------
Why does address sanitizer work differently on CAEN computers vs my laptop?
<p>Hey! Quick question:</p>


<p></p>


<p>On every project now, I've had code that works beautifully on my laptop but inexplicably blows up on the CAEN computers, usually due to some address sanitizer issue. I know the address sanitizer on my laptop works because I've triggered it quite a few times, but how come it doesn't raise an issue sometimes despite CAEN machines finding one?</p>


<p></p>


<p>I'm on an M1 MacBook - do I need to install some latest version of a package, or something? It makes it <em>really </em>annoying to try to debug when I can't use the visual debugger and have to go off line numbers and error tracing from terminal output.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, and this is the very weird part, sometimes code that passes on the CAEN computers AND my laptop will fail on the autograder. I don't see how... is there some catch-all setting I can enable to get all these errors without having to check my code in 3 places?</p>


<p></p>


<p>Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>From the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_asan.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">address sanitizer tutorial</a>:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>WARNING:</strong> The address sanitizer will not work on heavily resource limited system such as CAEN Linux.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>The system is configured to not use address sanitizer. Remember to remove those flags when you compile on CAEN. Additionally, the debugger is not compatible with the address sanitizer.</p>
<p>As for the autograder/CAEN/home setup issue, I wouldn’t know why something would fail on the autograder if it passes on CAEN - everything I’ve run on CAEN works the same as AG. I believe others have had similar issues so it would be best if an instructor could take a look at your submissions.</p>
<p>Hope this helps!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>In this case, I'm also getting a <em>completely </em>different output in the CAEN machine vs on my laptop - one of my tests fails there despite working locally.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I found <em>an issue </em>- VSCode will default-initialize variables to 0 or 1 or something when you try and use them without initializing them yourself first. CAEN and the other systems won't. I asked a couple friends and they haven't run into that issue, probably some Mac thing.</p>


<p></p>


<p>How do I turn that off?? That's a horrible feature and I can't believe it would ever be on by default.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I believe that this is not VSCode strictly but likely the compiler that is shipped with Apple devices. From the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup.html#macos" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">main setup tutorial</a>:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>Notice that this compiler is really Apple LLVM pretending to be <code>g++.</code></p>
</blockquote>
<pre>$ g++ --version
Configured <span class="hljs-keyword">with</span>: --prefix=<span class="hljs-regexp">/Library/</span>Developer/CommandLineTools/usr --<span class="hljs-keyword">with</span>-gxx-include-dir=<span class="hljs-regexp">/usr/i</span>nclude/c++/<span class="hljs-number">4.2</span><span class="hljs-number">.1</span>
...
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('JCUyMGcrKyUyMC0tdmVyc2lvbiUwQUNvbmZpZ3VyZWQlMjB3aXRoOiUyMC0tcHJlZml4PS9MaWJyYXJ5L0RldmVsb3Blci9Db21tYW5kTGluZVRvb2xzL3VzciUyMC0td2l0aC1neHgtaW5jbHVkZS1kaXI9L3Vzci9pbmNsdWRlL2MrKy80LjIuMSUwQS4uLiUwQQ==');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>Perhaps <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17705880/gcc-failing-to-warn-of-uninitialized-variable" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">this thread</a> has some answers for you on how to avoid this issue.</p></div>

------------------------@1807-------------------------
Player tests
When we write our own tests for Player.cpp, are those tests need to follow the rules as well? If I want to use add and discard card function, does this mean I need to have at least two ace or face cards of the trump suits? It can’t be I have no cards of trump suit  in hand?

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can (and probably should, for completeness) test the functions outside of the practical scope of the game, like you mentioned. It is possible that private test cases will test functions individually like this. The context of the functions will however always follow what is specified in the “REQUIRED” section of the RME.</p></div>

------------------------@1808-------------------------
Test Function for Card_less (with led_card and trump suit), False Positive
<p>This is the implementation of our Card_less:</p>


<p></p>


<p><b>bool</b> Card_less(<b>const</b> Card &amp;a, <b>const</b> Card &amp;b, <b>const</b> Card &amp;led_card,</p>


<p>               <b>const</b> std::string &amp;trump) {</p>


<p>    std::string ledSuit = led_card.get_suit();</p>


<p>    <b>if</b> (led_card.get_suit() == trump) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> Card_less(a, b, trump);</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a == b) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>false</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.is_right_bower(trump)) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>false</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (b.is_right_bower(trump)) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>true</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.is_left_bower(trump)) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>false</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (b.is_left_bower(trump)) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>true</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.get_suit() == trump &amp;&amp; b.get_suit() != trump) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>false</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.get_suit() != trump &amp;&amp; b.get_suit() == trump) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>true</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.get_suit() == ledSuit &amp;&amp; b.get_suit() != ledSuit) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>false</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> <b>if</b> (a.get_suit() != ledSuit &amp;&amp; b.get_suit() == ledSuit) {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> <b>true</b>;</p>


<p>    } <b>else</b> {</p>


<p>        <b>return</b> a &lt; b;</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>}</p>


<p></p>


<p>The function passed autograder tests. Here's the corresponding test function</p>


<p></p>


<p>TEST(test_card_less_led_trump) {</p>


<p>    vector&lt;Card&gt; cards;</p>


<p>    </p>


<p>    <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> k = 0; k &lt; 4; k++) {</p>


<p>        <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> l = 0; l &lt; 4; l++) {</p>


<p>            <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> i = 0; i &lt; 13; i++) {</p>


<p>                <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> j = 0; j &lt; 4; j++) {</p>


<p>                    cards.push_back(Card(ranks[i], suits[j]));</p>


<p>                    <b>if</b> (suits[j] == suits[l] ||</p>


<p>                        cards[cards.size() - 1].is_trump(suits[k])) {</p>


<p>                        cards.pop_back();</p>


<p>                    }</p>


<p>                }</p>


<p>            }</p>


<p>            <b>if</b> (k != l) {</p>


<p>                <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> i = 0; i &lt; 13; i++) {</p>


<p>                    cards.push_back(Card(ranks[i], suits[l]));</p>


<p>                }</p>


<p>            }</p>


<p>            <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> i = 0; i &lt; 13; i++) {</p>


<p>                cards.push_back(Card(ranks[i], suits[k]));</p>


<p>            }</p>


<p>            <b>for</b> (vector&lt;Card&gt;::iterator it = cards.begin();</p>


<p>                 it != cards.end();) {</p>


<p>                <b>if</b> (it-&gt;is_left_bower(suits[k]) ||</p>


<p>                    it-&gt;is_right_bower(suits[k])) {</p>


<p>                    it = cards.erase(it);</p>


<p>                } <b>else</b> it++;</p>


<p>            }</p>


<p>            cards.push_back(Card(Card::RANK_JACK, Suit_next(suits[k])));</p>


<p>            cards.push_back(Card(Card::RANK_JACK, suits[k]));</p>


<p>        </p>


<p>            <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> i = 0; i &lt; 52; i++) {</p>


<p>                <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> u = 0; u &lt; 13; u++) {</p>


<p>                    ASSERT_FALSE(Card_less(cards[i], cards[i],</p>


<p>                                           Card(ranks[u], suits[l]), suits[k]));</p>


<p>                    <b>for</b> (<b>int</b> j = 0; j &lt; i; j++) {</p>


<p>                        ASSERT_TRUE(Card_less(cards[j], cards[i],</p>


<p>                                        Card(ranks[u], suits[l]), suits[k]));</p>


<p>                        ASSERT_FALSE(Card_less(cards[i], cards[j],</p>


<p>                                        Card(ranks[u], suits[l]), suits[k]));</p>


<p>                    }</p>


<p>                }</p>


<p>            }</p>


<p>            cards.clear();</p>


<p>        }</p>


<p>    }</p>


<p>}</p>


<p></p>


<p>The test function for Card_less yielded no error in terminal/command line, but the autograder throws a false positive (check unique name billyin)</p>


<p></p>


<p>In short, we used brute force method to list all possible combinations and test scenarios. For each of the led suit and trump suit combinations (1 out of 16), we arrange the 52 cards from least to highest, then call Card_less on each element and itself, then with every element prior. </p>


<p></p>


<p>We've manually confirmed each card sequence, the nested for-loops and all the assert functions, and we have so far been unsuccessful at debugging the problem. Assistance is direly needed and much appreciated</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Your test case seems almost unnecessarily complicated. When writing test cases for this class, we don’t want to test every possible card case in one test, rather split up these cases in smaller test cases. You definitely don’t need to test all 52 card lesses, and you’re not going to catch any more bugs this way either. I would recommend testing card_less with individual sets of 3-5 cards. I think your false positive will go away if you do it this way.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1809-------------------------
value question
<p>if the lead card and trump suit are the same then are all cards of that suit (besides the left and right bower) depend on ranks for ranking?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, but also there is a secondary ranking system among the suits. Rank does take priority (10 of spades &gt; 9 of diamonds), but among the same rank, the suit order is</p>
<pre><code>Diamonds &gt; Clubs &gt; Hearts &gt; Spades
</code></pre><p>Therefore, a 10 of spades is less than a 10 of diamonds (assuming neither is trump). See <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Value of Cards</a> for more information.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1814-------------------------

<p>If I have a vector of type card can I overwrite it with a new vector?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
As long as the vector is not declared as `const` and the function that is changing it is not declared as `const` (assuming the vector is a member variable)

------------------------@1815-------------------------
std::bad_alloc error on lead_card test in player
<p>** Test case "test_simple_player_lead_card": ERROR<br/>Uncaught std::bad_alloc in test "test_simple_player_lead_card": std::bad_alloc</p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>std::bad_alloc</code> is an indication of an out of bounds memory write. Check that you aren’t looping out of bounds on any arrays or objects. Address sanitizer may help more with pinpointing this - learn how to set it up <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_asan.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>.</p></div>

------------------------@1816-------------------------
Human Player parameters
<p>Do we need to change the parameters the functions in Player.cpp for human players? For example, for</p>


<p> <b>bool</b> make_trump(<b>const</b> Card &amp;upcard, <b>bool</b> is_dealer,</p>


<p>                    <b>int</b> round, std::string &amp;order_up_suit)</p>


<p>should we be taking in an istream instead of all these parameters?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Nope. You shouldn’t change function signatures since you need them to be the same in order to override the function in the <code>Player</code> class. You can program it to read from <code>cin</code>.</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>tl;dr</strong> just put <code>&lt; file_name</code> at the end of your command to read from a file for human player input</p>
</blockquote>
<p>A little lesson on the terminal and input streams:</p>
<p>There are three main input/output streams to every program:</p>
<ul><li><code>STDIN</code>, which is console input (what you type into the terminal when the program prompts you to)</li><li><code>STDOUT</code>, which is console output (what the program prints out to the terminal after you run it</li><li><code>STDERR</code>, which is another console output stream for error messages (but we won’t use this)</li></ul>
<p>When you refer to <code>cin</code> or <code>cout</code> in a C++ program, you are referring to <code>STDIN</code> and <code>STDOUT</code> respectively. As defined above, these are normally just given from terminal input and output. However, when we are executing programs, we can <strong>redirect</strong> these inputs and outputs to come from somewhere else.</p>
<ul><li>If we use <code>&lt; file_name</code> after a program name, the program will instead take the contents of <code>file_name</code> to be <code>STDIN</code>.</li><li>Similarly, if we use <code>&gt; file_name</code> after a program name, the program will print to the file (and overwrite everything in the file) instead of the terminal when we write it.</li></ul>
<p>In the tests of <code>euchre.exe</code> we will simply feed in human input through the command line using these redirects. For example, the command you would use to test <code>euchre_test50.out.correct</code> would be</p>
<pre><code>./euchre.exe pack.in noshuffle 3 Ivan Human Judea Human Kunle Human Liskov Human &lt; euchre_test50.in &gt; euchre_test50.out
</code></pre><p>(which is also given in the Makefile).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

You are to implement these strategies in the Simple Player overrides and the Human Player overrides.</p></div>

------------------------@1820-------------------------
Errors with overriding virtual functions
<p>What do these errors mean for my derived SimplePlayer class?</p>


<div>
<div><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-08_at_12.44.01_AM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky330it8gsm70t%2F85e18e189429fe5b76330dd1fc8c5316f481ad869829856aaee7f7250b4c0b3a%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-08_at_12.44.01_AM.png"/></div>

<p>Do your functions overriden in Player.cpp end with the <em>override</em> keyword? The compiler probably believes you are trying to over<strong>load</strong> which is not intended.</p>

<pre><span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-built_in">int</span> <span class="hljs-title">function1</span>(<span class="hljs-params"><span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> <span class="hljs-built_in">int</span> parameter1</span>) <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">override</span></span> {<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('aW50JTIwZnVuY3Rpb24xKGNvbnN0JTIwaW50JTIwcGFyYW1ldGVyMSklMjBjb25zdCUyMG92ZXJyaWRlJTIwJTdC');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre>

------------------------@1821-------------------------
Player.cpp sort clarification
<p>I just wanted to make sure, but this hint means we can call sort() on a vector and it will sort the hand from least to greatest according to the operator&lt;() function we wrote in Card.cpp right? We don't need to write any extra code? Or am I misunderstanding something? </p>


<p></p>


<p>Also in the add_and_discard function, are we supposed to call sort after we add the upcard to the hand and then call print(), since it says it should always print the cards sorted? Because wouldn't that impact the indexing for -1 if the Human wanted to discard the upcard immediately?</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw3s00pegt2cu%2F8c0236899b42b86135243e1901dce05799e2fef5b44b11b42be538821fc60bad%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Simply using the code provided for sort should use the comparison code you've written, so you'll be just fine there. You should be sorting the hand any time it changes, or the first time it's set up. Before any print, it should be sorted, and since this modifies the original vector itself, you can use the new indices that the user inputs. The -1 should probably be a special check, as calling hand[-1] will crash.</p>


<p>When prompting the user, you should be displaying the 5 cards in their hand, and the -1 is giving them the option to ignore the upcard. You shouldn't put the upcard into their hand and then expect them to discard it, that isn't how the grader expects it to be.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>But doesn't this mean that they do have the option to discard the upcard? If I sort before printing and the player does want to discard the upcard then we would have to iterate throughout the vector to find the card that matches the upcard and discard it, is that right? </p>


<p></p>


<p>But then how does that work, if I sort the vector and the upcard is at position 3, is the Human supposed to input 3 or -1 to discard the upcard then? </p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkw3s00pegt2cu%2Fef3fc2e4953e473f7c86f26820baf9eed0fe43199495fd32cc471b01b22ab333%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
You should display the five cards in the dealer’s hand, and that’s all. Don’t pick up the upcard into the hand first, let the user pick which card they want to discard (0-4) and if it’s -1, don’t do any swap. If they pick a card, switch out the one they chose for the upcard.

------------------------@1823-------------------------
Operators do the opposite.
<p>Hi! </p>


<p></p>


<p>I am posting this because I am really unable to find the error after a long time of debugging. What I have found so far is that my program is not able to identify that Ace &gt; King &gt; Queen etc.. , but it seems like it is doing the opposite even though my code could not be more explicit. I hope that I am not just missing a very simple logic error. Thank you for looking over it, I really appreciate your help.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk9ud4ux46t53yf%2Fc99e1bcb9e3c622a6089acb14f435208882feb931f15358947527a643e5f1471%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fk9ud4ux46t53yf%2F47bce1818c21b76e14989c083c9d92e2ca911582f80b7f06277c5763ca546d27%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>While you seem to have the right idea of first comparing ranks to determine which card is greater, the way you need to go about this is a little more complex. <br/></p>
<p>Suppose we have two cards (lhs = jack of clubs, rhs = ace of clubs):<br/>
Your implementation currently would first check <code>if("jack" &lt; "ace")</code>, doing a comparison between the two strings. This fails to consider the actual ordering of ranks that we define. I would check out the <code>SUIT_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> and <code>RANK_NAMES_BY_WEIGHT</code> arrays in <code>Card.h</code> and see if you could use those to determine which ranks/suits are greater than one another.</p>
<p>If you are still unsure of how to do this, I would try searching piazza since it is definitely a pretty common question!</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1824-------------------------
Sort Function Error
<p>For player.cpp in the derived HumanPlayer class, I am getting a lot of errors when using the sort function. </p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkjopqhk8h1r5ly%2Feb28f63bcbdc0425951808354742d3332a57831151ee2af02c97ad896fbf5c6a%2Fimage.png"/>I used the sort function just as it was shown in the spec, "std::sort(hand.begin(), hand.end());" so I am not sure where all these errors and warnings are coming from. When I remove the sort functions, the public test compiles and runs. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>From the P3 FAQ <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1544" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1544');">@1544</a>:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Q: Why am I getting a compiler error for calling sort?</strong><br/><br/>
Note that the sort function modifies the hand. You cannot modify member variables in a const function, so you’ll receive a compiler error if you call sort in a const member function.<br/><br/>
You shouldn’t need to sort using card less. When you print the hand in order it should be sorted using the &lt; operator. You could sort with card less when determining what action to take, but you should be able to find the min/max card in the hand without sorting. You could use a functor to sort using card less, but those are only covered later in the course. Generally: if you need to use sort, just the default one will be fine.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Feel free to follow-up if you have any questions, or this doesn’t seem like the issue you’re having.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yeah, that helped a bit. For the make_trump function, how are we supposed to sort the hand before it is printed since it is a const function? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>I would try to think of it in terms of when a player’s hand would be changed such that it needs to be sorted. If you sort the hand wherever it is modified, is it necessary to sort in <code>make_trump</code>? This also resolves the issue of const vs. non-const functions; if a hand is being modified somewhere, it can also be sorted.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1825-------------------------
Add_and_discard. seeing if suit is ordered up during round 1
<p>the spec for add_and_discard depends on whether or not the trump suit is ordered up during round 1. How do we figure out if this happened since the trump suit is ordered in round 1 or 2 in the function make_trump?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If the trump suit was ordered up in round 1, call <code>add_and_discard</code>. If it wasn’t ordered up in round 1, don’t call <code>add_and_discard</code>. This logic should be in <code>euchre.cpp</code>, the driver file.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1826-------------------------
Using sort in Simple Player
<p>Are we allowed to use std::sort in Simple Player? Additionally, how exactly is it sorting the cards?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, we are allowed to use <code>std::sort</code> - though I don’t believe that it is checked and needs to be  an invariant like Human Player. Calling</p>
<pre><code>std::sort(hand.begin(), hand.end());
</code></pre><p>will just sort <code>hand</code> using the <code>&lt;</code> operator, which does not consider trump or the led card. If you want to sort with a different function, there is the overload</p>
<pre><code>void sort( RandomIt first, RandomIt last, Compare comp );
</code></pre><p>Where <code>comp</code> is simply a function that takes in two arguments and returns true if the first argument is less than the second argument. More details <a href="https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/sort" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">here</a>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1827-------------------------
Version Control Git Push Errors
<p><img alt="Screenshot_2022-10-08_at_6.58.59_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkf1zfarlhrh4b8%2F1539c1871284fd38392c6499bfc0e5c8d86fd15ca501318dd60a93048a893411%2FScreenshot_2022-10-08_at_6.58.59_PM.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I was trying to set up this version control. However, when I connected my remote repo with my local repo and git push. Does anyone who knows how to solve this problem? Thanks. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>This error means that your remote repository has code that your local machine doesn’t, therefore you’re not allowed to push your code to the remote repository. To fix this, your objective should be to pull the code from the remote repository to your local machine using <code>git pull</code> but this might have some added complexities. If that command doesn’t work, go to office hours and we’ll fix it for you.</p></div>
