------------------------@1966-------------------------
False positive on make_trump() tests in Player_tests
<p>My partner and I are confused on why this trump test is getting a false positive. It seems to make sense with the way making trump is described in the spec for the simple player strategy. Thanks!</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_8.42.38_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky330it8gsm70t%2F39dc25a1f0979df2ab3a9ab85cf571972c77abbf79ba8272d9b4d5cde5550449%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_8.42.38_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It's possible this is a false positive because trump is uninitialized when passed in. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm still getting a false positive in autograder. To my understanding from the spec, since it's round 2 and the player is not the dealer, they should order up suit of spades because trump is clubs (and they have a spade in their hand, which is the opposite color of the upcard. Am I just not understanding the logic of the spec for making trump when it's round 2 and the player is not the dealer?</p>


<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_6.45.38_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky330it8gsm70t%2Fb1a0af907b0ce2ff367790c0309dc97504e8fb37d0dc27e1e8a4cbb8b6d46440%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_6.45.38_PM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is a false positive because they only call up spades if they have one or more face or ace cards. This means a King, Queen, Jack, or Ace of Spades. This also includes the left bower (Jack of Clubs). In your test case, you call it up on a nine of spades, which is not a face card.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1967-------------------------
Implementing Sort function for Human
<p>Hello! I'm just wondering how I can implement a sort function from into my Human_Player derived class. Should I create a new operator overload function in my Human_Player derived class? Also, will the sort function change the vector &lt;Card&gt; hand?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can use the <code>sort()</code> function from the <code>&lt;algorithm&gt;</code> library, as described in <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#requirements-and-restrictions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">the spec</a>.</p>
<p>The third argument for <code>sort()</code> should be the operator you want to use for sorting. Pick one of the ones you wrote in <code>Card.cpp</code>.</p>
<p>You can read more and see examples in the documentation here: <a href="https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/sort/" target="_blank">https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/sort/</a></p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2Ffddb5f90a1262381cd67845fa3c439d654a5f022508c5e7bd0727df0ba1aa7c4%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>So something like this would work to sort my hand from least to greatest?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I think sort(hand.begin(), hand.end()); should suffice. Since you've already implemented a &lt; operator for cards, C++ knows to use this operator when sorting Card objects.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F6be5973e74c08ad797f895f101e7f17e1f29353e311ede6a3683aa2054516284%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I'm getting this error whenever I call the sort function. Any ideas?</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F664f2310ea9dc9043a622b096b2718c2d3a52528aa8a890f70beabaa1e93f5b3%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>See <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1814" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1814');">@1814</a>, the issue is that you are likely modifying the member in a <code>const</code> function (<code>sort</code> modifies <code>hand</code>, which is part of the class member).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1968-------------------------
Using assert() to check that RME is fulfilled
<p>I was wondering if we are expected/required to use assert() statements to check that the RMEs are followed in our functions.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>It is not required, since the RMEs are meant to never be violated. However it is good practice to add <code>assert()</code> statements, especially since they can be helpful while debugging.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1970-------------------------
Comparison confusion
<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt0q37ubhfu3t3%2Fb2cff0946943fba6b26dbc81b55aa3677c13e875b64f82074ee7df35680ca38a%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p>I have run all of these assertions and they all run correctly except the last one. I am unsure why the last assertion would not work given that all the others do. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you think about it, get_rank() returns a string. Technically in your mind, you know which rank should be smaller, but the computer doesn't know what makes one string bigger than the other, so it can't really compare ranks for you.</p>

<p> Thank you!</p>

------------------------@1971-------------------------
player factory error
<p>I copied the prototype code for player factory and I'm getting this error. SimplePlayer is highlighted in red. I don't know what is wrong, I don't know if I should put it before or after the classes or if that even matters. I have no overrides in my functions, but when I add them I get a different error saying the function does not override a base class member.</p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt02uj5j6zj60n%2Fd73722ae978694fda8ce81ef6bc06e681836ac0f4d2093f40dd3b1feb986d859%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>If you haven’t at least added a function stub for all of the functions inherited from <code>Player</code>, then you will get an error because trying to instantiate a <code>HumanPlayer</code> would require inheriting functions that have no implementation – “pure virtual functions” – and then trying to instantiate an object with them, which is impossible.</p>
<p>You can comment out the part of <code>Player_factory()</code> that instantiates a <code>HumanPlayer</code> if you’re just trying to test your <code>SimplePlayer</code>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The issue was I didn't see the const at the end of the function declarations</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@1974-------------------------
Do I need to implement ~Player function?
<p> Do I need to implement the below function for Player? It seems to be a constructor but it has a ~ in front of it</p>


<p></p>


<p>// Needed to avoid some compiler errors</p>


<p>  <b>virtual</b> ~Player() {}</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is called a destructor, you will learn more about them later in the semester, but for now you don't have to implement it or include it in player.cpp :)</p>

------------------------@1975-------------------------
./Player.h:51:32: error: unknown type name 'Card'
<p>I am getting a bunch of errors similar to the one in the title, it was working before and I included Card.h in all the nessacery files, any ideas? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You shouldn't need to include Card.h in any of the files we're modifying. It is already in all the necessary header files. You probably added a header file where it wasn't needed. Card, Pack, and Player should only have their respective .h files included, no others (eg Card.cpp only has Card.h, etc)</p>

------------------------@1978-------------------------
order_up_suit and make_trump() testing
<p>I am confused about how to test if order_up_suit has (not) changed to the correct suit when make_trump() is run. I believe it is not possible to access order_up_suit from the testing file, is there a function that is in Player.h I could use to compare the actual string value of order_up_suit before and after make_trump() is run?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Because <code>make_trump()</code> takes <code>std::string &amp;order_up_suit</code> as a reference variable, the function will change the actual value of the string passed into <code>make_trump()</code>.</p>
<p>You can see the <code>Player_public_test.cpp</code> file’s <code>test_simple_player_make_trump</code> for an example.</p></div>

------------------------@1980-------------------------
Lead card and play card are working but not working
<p>For both the lead card function and the play card function, in the public tests, I am not sure why it says they are not equal to each other. both parameters of ASSERT_EQUAL are of card type so I don't know how these two cannot be equal (not a difference in white space?)</p>


<p>This is also happening for a few functions in my Pack.cpp public tests.</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="173" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxikn2v41x5ja%2Fb408d74520b832f35363c3eae1165f2e35608bcacc4661bb394159f0f7e0319b%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_10.22.37_PM.png" width="453"/></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You should check that your <code>bool operator==()</code> function in <code>Card.cpp</code> is working correctly. It may be the case that while the <code>Card</code> objects being compared have the same <code>rank</code> and <code>suit</code> values, the comparison is actually seeing if they are at the same address.</p>
<p>Check <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/operator_overloading.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">the spec’s description on operator overloading</a>.</p></div>

------------------------@1983-------------------------
Calling sort function error
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F264c5be20677f74c4dd4e19b55d595c8f2622add3bb45a3c863f8e053b544b39%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="image.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F664f2310ea9dc9043a622b096b2718c2d3a52528aa8a890f70beabaa1e93f5b3%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Whenever I call this sort function, I get a really nasty error. Any tips or ideas?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
It’s a const issue. Watching Dr. Juett’s 12pm Lecture 8 around the 56:00 mark might help.

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>From the P3 FAQ:</p>
<blockquote>
<p><strong>Q: Why am I getting a compiler error for calling sort?</strong><br/>
Note that the sort function modifies the hand. You cannot modify member variables in a const function, so you’ll receive a compiler error if you call sort in a const member function.<br/></p>
</blockquote>
<p>If this isn’t the issue you’re having, feel free to follow-up!</p></div>

------------------------@1985-------------------------
Error with player
<p>I keep getting this error.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_11.05.10_PM.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkvzu6bn6plqol%2F05dcc941e736ddef6c269d3d29802c316868d18e6f99f29de1200cc56fcfb497%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_11.05.10_PM.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>I saw post 1962 so i changed my code to the following.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_11.05.29_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkvzu6bn6plqol%2F6b60b17ef74ec08e5029a8e6db065612e64730fd6b5ee452bf763a8331e074e9%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-09_at_11.05.29_PM.png"/> but i still get the same error. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Another approach you can take to ensuring your hand is sorted in make_trump is calling sort on your hand each time that you modify the hand in other non-const functions. For example, if you sort each time you either add or remove a card from your hand, you will know that the hand is sorted at all times.</p>

------------------------@1989-------------------------
Do you have to stub the class in the Player.h file?
<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky1p65245ra4by%2F2370d749630b49c70ee506eba7325611da672746f7c2edeacf1b4390cef828d9%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You shouldn’t modify the <code>.h</code> files at all in this project, it’s listed in the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#requirements-and-restrictions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Requirements and Restrictions</a> section of the project spec. You can just define the class in the <code>.cpp</code> file.</p></div>

<p>If you haven't created a constructor in both of those derived classes, this means you should! Specifically you should make a non-default constructor that takes in a name.</p>

------------------------@1996-------------------------
false positive for add_discard for simple players
<p>Hi,</p>


<p>my uniquename is angelalz. after I turned in Autotrader, my add_discard tests are shown to be having false positive cases. I tried the debugger and can't find where this error could come from. I am wondering whether this is an edge case error or if i am understanding the spec incorrectly. Could anyone please help take a look at my test and my code for add_discard and give me some clues on how to solve this?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Your add_discard test is a false positive, meaning it failed when run on a correct implementation of SimplePlayer. It looks like your assertion ASSERT_EQUAL(cardPlayed2, KS) is where the test failed: The correct solution played King of Clubs, but your test expects a King of Spades. I would review the game rules in the spec to see why your test shouldn't expect a King of Spades here. Hope this helps!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you! The problem is now solved. </p>

------------------------@1999-------------------------
vtable
<p>Getting error with vtable... What is the error here? I initialized every virtual function in the derived ones.<img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.24.01_AM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2Fb2bb529ce5dc4c9ee6a5ff2bd3af1e2ade417c32c16a1a7309bf2dd96fc858cc%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.24.01_AM.png"/><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.24.20_AM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt2b9bbjewsbt%2Fc9656dafe235ce70d00c403f57a8c19ca3c9104083f88bab9b5e9f6408c819fb%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.24.20_AM.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you've implemented some member functions in SimplePlayer (like the constructor and get_name()), but not all of them (add_card(), make_trump(), etc.). Are you implementing those functions anywhere else in Player.cpp? If not, you'll get this error until the compiler can find implementations for all of SimplePlayer's functions. Once you've finished implementing SimplePlayer, the error should go away.</p>

------------------------@2000-------------------------
How are pack.cpp and player.cpp related?
<p>Are we allowed/should we be using Pack in the Player classes for the derived functions to work? For the add_card (for example) would we need a Pack to represent the Player's Hand(?)</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If I am correct, you shouldn't call any constructors/functions from pack inside of player.cpp. You will call pack functions/constructors in euchre.cpp. In order to represent the player's hand, I would advise creating a private member variable inside of the player subclasses that is a vector.  Then you should be able to figure out how to add cards to that vector inside of your add_card function. You can also represent hand as an array, but it will be harder to add and remove cards from it. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2001-------------------------
Shuffle
<p><img alt="Screenshot_2022-10-10_at_8.05.11_PM.png" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkf1zfarlhrh4b8%2Ff6fc191aeec05e45e7ffd9fe467e4e46c3f4c1998f5532725dd9a4cbef4f73a3%2FScreenshot_2022-10-10_at_8.05.11_PM.png"/></p>

You could start by looking at how the pack looks after the each shuffle, and if needed put a break point in the inner for loops. If the pack seems to be fine after 7 shuffles, I'd set a break point for the deal one function, because maybe there could be an error there.</p>

------------------------@2004-------------------------
testing error and pop_back
<p>Hi, two questions. What does this error mean? How can I delete a player after creating it in the PlayerFactory and can I use pop_back() to remove a card from the vector even though we haven't learned it in class, the erase() wasn't working.(<a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk2z87jli277iw%2Fb730e82c891b29caf63df4c2f2e9f48bf440462ae89b5260330ebf22013aff99%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_09.41.52.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_09.41.52.png</a></p>

<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The error means that the output you gave was not equal to what you expected (the two arguments weren’t equal in <code>ASSERT_EQUAL</code>). For your other questions, you shouldn’t delete a player in the <code>PlayerFactory</code> function but instead in the game when you’re done with the player. Yes you can use <code>pop_back()</code> as well as any other functions we haven’t learned as long as the module is listed in the <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#requirements-and-restrictions" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Requirements and Restrictions</a> section of the spec.</p></div>

------------------------@2007-------------------------
Question about std::string Card:: get_suit(const std::string &trump) const
<div>
<div>For the std::string Card:: get_suit(const std::string &amp;trump) const function, are we supposed to check what suit the trump is and set it to the opposite suit of same color and return that suit? I keep getting errors with this function when setting suit equal to a string. Any strategies on approaching this would be very helpful.</div>
</div>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There are two get_suit functions, the first should just return the suit of the card. The second takes in the parameter trump, and returns the suit as well (we need trump to check for bowers). The second function's only purpose it to be able to make sure the left bower is considered the same suit as trump</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>After finding the suit of the left bower, I'm confused on how we make sure the left bower is considered the same suit of the trump?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The <code>get_suit()</code> function gets the suit of the card that it was assigned at initialization. The <code>get_suit(trump)</code> does the same thing, but with the sole exception that this function will consider the jack of the next suit of the trump to be trump. i.e., if this function is called on the Jack of Clubs and the trump suit is Spades, the function will return spades.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2008-------------------------
player testing
<p>I am unsure as to how I am supposed to run tests with the player class's add_card if I am not able to see the player's hand outside of its class implementation.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can't see the player's whole hand, but you can see cards in the players hand one at a time. When you lead or play a card, that card comes from the player's hand. So, you should test what gets added to a player's hand by understanding that playing a card or leading a card has an expected card output.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2010-------------------------
Deleting card from hand
<p>How can I delete a card from the array hand. I understand you can use erase if hand was a vector but in my Class, hand is an array. Is it possible to remove a specific indexed element from the array?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes it's possible, it just way more of a hassle than using vectors. You'll have to keep track of the size of the array, and basically shift each element left once you remove one. There's a couple ways to do it, I'll leave a link below.</p>


<p></p>


<p><a href="https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/delete-an-element-from-array-using-two-traversals-and-one-traversal/" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/delete-an-element-from-array-using-two-traversals-and-one-traversal/</a></p>


<p></p>


<p>*This honestly might take you longer than just switching from an array to a vector in your code, but up to you</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I would recommend switching your hand to be represented as a vector. As the student answer states, you can “remove” cards from an array, but this tends to be a lot trickier to keep track of. Using a vector should help you implicitly avoid some of the errors that might come with using an array.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2012-------------------------
Attempt to erase from container error
<p>Hello! My roommate and I have this undefined behavior showing up and we are unsure what it means. Any input would be appreciated. <img alt="3.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxzjz9knc269v%2Fdeb2c018b2c6d9aaa297191ba4cca28b141838835e4f2330a8c807380c8f2ca8%2F3.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It’s likely that you are passing an out of bounds index to the <code>erase()</code> function. Remember that the hand is not always of size 5, and make sure your index that you pass in is smaller than the size of the vector.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Tip: It's much easier to create an iterator for the card you're wanting to delete like such</p>


<p><code>auto card = (something)</code></p>


<p>and then you can just call</p>


<p><code>hand.erase(card);</code><code></code></p>


<p>Then you don't have to worry about bounds, assuming you get the iterator correct.<code></code></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Could you specify what you mean by an iterator? Just slightly confused what "auto card = (something)" means. Thanks!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>When you use a <code>vector</code>’s erase function, the syntax is:</p>
<pre><code>vector_name.erase(vector_name.begin() + index);
</code></pre><p>To be honest I don’t know the guts of how it works and what an iterator technically is but we abstract that away for now. I think that the student answer means to have you store the index/iterator of the card (<code>vector_name.begin() + index</code>) in that variable and then use it.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>To tack on, for reference in c++ auto lets the compiler figure out what the variable type is.</p>

------------------------@2017-------------------------
Play_card scenario for Simple Player
<p>If the trump suit is Spades and the Led suit is Diamonds, and the simple player has a hand consisting of a Jack of Spades(right bower) and Ace of Diamonds, would the simple player play ace of diamonds first because according to the specification, "Simple Players use a simple strategy that considers only the suit that was led"?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A simple player plays the highest card that follows suit if they can, lowest card otherwise. In this case, the player would play the Ace. Playing the right bower would be invalid since you're not following suit.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>marking as resolved</p>

out of bounds error

    <span class="hljs-keyword">with</span> out-<span class="hljs-keyword">of</span>-bounds index <span class="hljs-number">24</span>, but container only holds <span class="hljs-number">24</span> elements.

Objects involved <span class="hljs-keyword">in</span> the operation:
sequence <span class="hljs-string">"this"</span> @ 0x0x7fffcbf966a0 {

<p></p>


<p>arrayName( {item1, item2, item3} )</p>


<p></p>


<p>Adjust this to work with cards and that might solve your issue.</p>

------------------------@2028-------------------------
No matching function to call swap error
<p>I keep getting this error message and I have no idea how to fix.</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkt05rt9dco53is%2Fd4c7c69a46fcbff08b05b1799329d996b41cfd4dda7dbbe9a78014f32df6e2c2%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_3.21.24_PM.jpeg" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_3.21.24_PM.jpeg</a></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>This is likely because you are calling sort in a const function. Remember that sort modifies private member variables, and thus violates the promise made by a const modifier.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>So, the provided print hand function uses the hand private vector; if we can't sort the hand, the how do we call print hand on a temp hand we created?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p><code>print_hand</code> is not defined in the <code>.h</code> file, so you can change its function signature - you can just remove the <code>const</code> at the end of the function if you want to sort the hand in the <code>print_hand</code> function or you can make a separate function to enforce this invariant and call it at the end of every non-<code>const</code> function.</p></div>

------------------------@2031-------------------------
Can left bower be considered as lead suit?
<p>I'm a bit confused about whether the left bower is still considered a part of its original suit or not. After reading questions <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1913" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1913');">@1913</a> and <a data-pats="post_ref" href="1878" onclick="return PE.gotoPost('1878');">@1878</a>, I'm unsure if you can play the left bower if there are no cards of the lead suit.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
The left bower is no longer considered the original suit, instead it is considered the trump suit. If the trump is spades, the jack of clubs is taken as a spade.
<div>If there are no cards of the lead suit, a Simple player strategy requires you to choose the lowest card you have. If that is a left bower, then you can play it. As a Human player too, you have the liberty to play the same as long as you don't have any cards of the lead suit. </div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2036-------------------------
SimplePlayer lead card and play card seg faults
<p>Whenever I try to run the public test for player I get a segmentation fault for lead card and play card. I tried fixing lead card but it still returns a seg fault. Could you lead me on the right track for what I need to fix?</p>


<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkswmvh3nmaebm%2F3b4b8ac8a0308ec5c6c59dfe190e4534ad3f22bbbef03fa1de8bafaf35fed159%2FPlayer.cpp" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Player.cpp</a></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It looks like you're iterating from 0 to MAX_HAND_SIZE in your for loops of SimplePlayer::lead_card(). Remember that there won't always be MAX_HAND_SIZE cards in the player's hand. After at least 1 trick is played, there will be fewer than MAX_HAND_SIZE cards.</p>


<p></p>


<p>One other thing I'm noticing is that your lead_card() function counts the number of trump cards by comparing trump to Card::get_suit(). What if you encounter the Left Bower? Card::get_suit() would return the next suit instead of trump. To fix this, make sure you use Card::get_suit(trump).</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2039-------------------------
play_card question
<p>If the trump suit and the led suit are the same, and we call the function play card, is the Left Bower considered to be following suit?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yes, the left bower is considered to be the trump suit in any circumstance.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Also, if you were to pass in the Left Bower as the led card, would following suit mean a card with the same suit as the Left Bower or the same suit as the trump card?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Same suit as trump.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2040-------------------------
calling sort in a const function
<p>If the provided print hand function uses the hand private vector in player.cpp and we can't sort the hand, then how do we call print hand on a temp hand we created?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What do you mean by temp hand? The only way to access private variables of a class is with a private member function. Your print function should be declared in HumanPlayer, not Player. Then it will have access to the vector to print it. When you go to define your print function, you'll then do something like</p>


<p></p>


<p>void HumanPlayer::print_hand() const {}</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>You can change the signature of <code>print_hand()</code> to be non-<code>const</code>, and thus you can sort the hand in <code>print_hand</code>. I would avoid making a separate hand as it would make things more complicated and you may run into more bugs.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Does this mean we can remove const from the make_trump function as well?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No, that function is declared as const and should be const. The print_hand function is a function you made, and you can declare it as whatever you want. As said above, making another hand is more difficult, so the best way to do this is just to make a regular function without const so that the function has the ability to modify hand. We declare functions as const when we don't want them to modify attributes of the class. We want the hand to be sorted, so it's fine declaring it without const. For functions that are already declared const in the given project files, do not modify their signatures.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>but if you declare print_hand to be not const, then you can't use print_hand in a const func right? Then how should you use it in make_trump function?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Good question - you could make a separate helper function to print the hand in the `make_trump` function or you could make the hand being sorted a data invariant - every time you change the hand you sort it right after (since those functions are already non-const). In the latter, you can actually keep print_hand as const.

-------------------------------------------------

<p>From the spec, you shouldn't be modifying the .h file, but if you want a helper function, it should be a <em>non-member function</em> and declared as static.</p>


<p></p>


<p>As stated in the follow-up, making it a non-member function would make the private member hand inaccessible. Do you really need to have this function available though, if all it does is return the player's hand (I'm guessing)? You can just directly reference the hand variable.</p>

<p>If declared outside of the simpleplayer class, hand becomes inaccessible as it is a private variable.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>See below; unfortunately, you cannot use get_hand() in your test cases. For a hint, look toward the functions that return cards and see how you can use them to validate that the function you called previously performed correctly.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2050-------------------------

------------------------@2051-------------------------
Bus error
<p>What does this mean?  Test_simple_play_card1 is testing for when a player has all trump cards and a trump which player doesn't have was led. They should be playing the highest card in their hand but I am getting a bus error.</p>


<p><img alt="" height="156" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fksxikn2v41x5ja%2F2c6fd2b023e33916bd5146a8bde7450bc56b44825f6f1160bed0a4c89540cdaa%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_5.00.01_PM.png" width="308"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>A bus error is extremely uncommon, first of all. While seg faults can occur from trying to access memory outside your process(things like pointing to things that are deallocated, using a nullptr, overflowing a buffer) bus errors occur when your processor literally can't even attempt the memory access requested (not a valid address).</p>


<p></p>


<p>As for how to fix it, double check things like bounds, memory allocation and deallocation</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>Source: <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/212466/what-is-a-bus-error-is-it-different-from-a-segmentation-fault" target="_blank">https://stackoverflow.com/questions/212466/what-is-a-bus-error-is-it-different-from-a-segmentation-fault</a></p>

------------------------@2053-------------------------
including cpp files
<p>Are we allowed to include cpp files in other cpp files. For example, I want to use a static helper function from Card.cpp in Pack.cpp to make the empty() function easier, but I'm not sure if that is allowed.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>No, you should never include .cpp files in other .cpp files as it leads to compilation issues. That's why header files (.h) exists. Unfortunately, since we aren't allowed to modify the header files, we don't have a way of accessing that function :(</p>


<p>If it's possible, you would just have to redefine the function in Pack.cpp</p>

-------------------------------------------------

<p>Just for human player, but it may be helpful for when you are debugging.</p>

------------------------@2057-------------------------
Pack istream
<p>How would I read in the strings from the input stream? Right now I have a while loop but it's giving me a segmentation error and it seems like I'm not correctly reading in the rank, "of" and suit separately. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What are the parameters of your while loop first of all? You have a PACK_SIZE variable, so you should definitely be utilizing that. The strings are conveniently separated by spaces, so like in our image project, you can just use the &gt;&gt; operator to grab the words. You mentioned having trouble reading them separately, more than likely because of that word "of" in there. You have 2 options:</p>


<p></p>


<p>1.) Read in all the words on the line, with a garbage string for "of"</p>


<p></p>


<p>2.) istream has a function .ignore(count), where count is the number of characters to ignore. Maybe you could utilize that...</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I decided to change to a for loop until i &lt; PACK_SIZE, with 3 std::string variables rank, garbage, and suit. Would I be able to just read each word separately using these 3 varibles (becuase of the convenient spacing) and then create a card (a), and add it to the "cards" array by using cards.push_back(a)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You got it! Just remember there's no push_back for arrays, that's for vectors. You have to put each card in at some index</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>thank you so much!</p>

------------------------@2059-------------------------
lead card meaning
<p>I want to clarify the meaning of the lead card. The specs and the piazza post contradict each other when it says to play the lowest non trump card or the highest non trump card. Which is correct?<br/><br/>If a player has all spades in his hand and the trump suit is diamonds, would the player lead in with Ace of Spades or Nine of Spades?</p>


<p></p>


<p><img alt="" height="163" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7qk9gbyzzx6he%2F599c6383dcb8cbb32539b65d8f75241d272cdcc52b5c82e004d78ef62230f24f%2FScreenshot_100.png" width="1430"/></p>


<p><img alt="" height="286" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7qk9gbyzzx6he%2F1c5fffaef14723717a051652d415686b21058f9537a634647e7298caad1c47d8%2FScreenshot_101.png" width="1309"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There are two situations here, neither result in the simple player playing their lowest card, trump or not.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Situation one: Simple player has all trump -&gt; Play the highest one trump</p>


<p>Situation two: Simple player does not have all trump (either no trump or at least one trump) -&gt; Play the highest card that is not trump (note that highest also has to do with suit, eg diamonds are higher than spades)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2062-------------------------
Tests with false positives:
<p>I write some correct tests and my code past all of them. However, the autograder gives me errors back like this for one unit test. What does that mean?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It means that the test case that you wrote ran on a completely correct implementation, but the test case still failed. This implies that there is something wrong with your assert statements in the test case (it has nothing to do with your player.cpp, card.cpp, etc.). Check the logic that you are asserting in that particular test case and ensure that it follows the euchre rules.</p>

------------------------@2066-------------------------
sort
<p>If sort is sorting the hand in the wrong order, which functions are the errors to debug?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>std::sort uses the less than operator (&lt;) to compare cards, so your issue is most likely there. Remember, though, that operator&lt; shouldn't consider either trump or the led card, only suit (doesn't care about Left Bower) and rank.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How can I get it to consider trump and led suit then? Because the sort using a function only accepts functions with exactly 2 inputs, unlike our Card_less function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You shouldn't need to use Card_less with any instance of std::sort. You said sorting is resulted in incorrect order. Go back and see if it is actually not sorted properly, remembering that it shouldn't consider trump or a led card.</p>

------------------------@2068-------------------------
Is it safe to assume that there will be no impossible hands?
<p>Like the question says. Does our test need to deal with impossible hands? For example, having two of the same cards, or two identical cards, one in hand and the other as a lead card or upcard.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It doesn't hurt to test for those hands as the RMEs of the functions don't explicitly state the hands need to be valid. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
As the student mentioned, the only assumptions about input you can make are based on the RMEs. So when it comes to how players operate in different situations you should test on any edge cases you think are relavent or could arise if a, let's say, other developer tries to use your player implementations, card implementation, or pack implementations.

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2069-------------------------
in play card
<p>what if the lead card and the trump are the same? do you return the highest trump card?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Per the spec:</p>


<blockquote>
<p>If a Simple Player can follow suit, they play the highest card that follows suit. Otherwise, they play the lowest card in their hand.</p>
</blockquote>


<p><br/>So, you would play the highest card that is the same suit of the led card. If the trump suit is the same suit, then you play your highest card which would be the highest trump card.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Follow up on that: </p>


<p></p>


<p>if my lead_card is HEARTS, and trump is also HEARTS, is the highest card that follows suit ACE_HEARTS or JACK_HEARTS (simple player)?</p>


<p>I believe that it is the first, since simple player doesn´t consider trump suits. I am asking because ever since I added this private test case, I am getting false positive error feedback. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Jack of Hearts is the highest card. The simple player does consider trump suit when playing. </p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2077-------------------------
Who is the dealer in the next round?
<p>After one hand is played, we have to assign a new dealer. Does the eldest hand of the last round become the dealer of the next round? It is not specified in the specification. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Pretty sure the new dealer is the player sitting to the left of the previous dealer</p>


<p></p>


<p>*The above is correct</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>From the spec, "In each hand, one player is designated as the dealer (if humans were playing the game, the one who passes out the cards). In our game, player 0 deals during the first hand. Each subsequent hand, the role of dealer moves one player to the left."</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2078-------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I'm not sure why that would make it any easier, its just an extra step. We're told there will be exactly 12 arguments. To access the values of argv is just like any other array:</p>


<p></p>


<p>argv[index]</p>

This fails on the style guide and says there is code duplication. How should I solve this problem since I can't add the function the the player.h file (which is what I think would solve this problem)?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You could create the function outside of the classes, and pass in a player* object to the function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Alternatively, if the helper function performs some task like "find the card from this vector according to X criteria", you might restructure it so that it's a non-member function that doesn't know about "players" at all and just operates on the collection of cards.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>wouldn't I still have to declare this function in the header file though? Or can I just define it in the .cpp </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You can just define it in the .cpp as a free static function</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2085-------------------------
player function not accounting for trump.
<p>For add_and_discard, I am unsure how to account for trump. I am just using the &lt; operator, which follows the generic ranking system. I was thinking to use Card_less, but I cannot implement it correctly. Not sure if that is the right idea.</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes, you should be using <code>Card_less</code> to compare with the context of the game. It should be used in a similar manner to the <code>&lt;</code> operator:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-function">Card <span class="hljs-title">c1</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span></span>;
<span class="hljs-function">Card <span class="hljs-title">c2</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span></span>;
<span class="hljs-function">Card <span class="hljs-title">led_card</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span></span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (c1 &lt; c2) {
	<span class="hljs-comment">/* code */</span>
}
<span class="hljs-keyword">if</span> (Card_less(c1, c2, led_card, Card::SUIT_SPADES)) {
	<span class="hljs-comment">/* code */</span>
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('Q2FyZCUyMGMxKCk7JTBBQ2FyZCUyMGMyKCk7JTBBQ2FyZCUyMGxlZF9jYXJkKCk7JTBBaWYlMjAoYzElMjAlM0MlMjBjMiklMjAlN0IlMEElMDkvKiUyMGNvZGUlMjAqLyUwQSU3RCUwQWlmJTIwKENhcmRfbGVzcyhjMSwlMjBjMiwlMjBsZWRfY2FyZCwlMjBDYXJkOjpTVUlUX1NQQURFUykpJTIwJTdCJTBBJTA5LyolMjBjb2RlJTIwKi8lMEElN0QlMEE=');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2086-------------------------
Pack_tests
<p>How extensively should we test pack outside of the public tests?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>As extensively as you think you’ll need. Remember that the purpose of tests is to catch bugs that you wouldn’t normally think of. Since the pack tests aren’t graded, this is the only reason to test. If you’re <strong>confident</strong> that your code won’t trip up on an edge case or general use then you won’t need to test as much, but if you’re not you should write more.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You should test it as we have tested other ADT's in this class even if it is not graded: test all functions and try to come up with edge cases and normal cases for each. You want to be confident that your card and pack ADT's do not have bugs when you are writing Player and Euchre as those bugs will be harder to track down.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Can I test with pack sizes other than 24 to make testing easier? Or would that go against the ADT? I’m thinking about shuffle specifically in this context. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Since the pack tests aren’t graded, you can use whatever you want for your tests. In theory, testing with a small input should expose the same bugs that a larger input would.</p>
<p>Just make sure that you remember to change <code>PACK_SIZE</code> back to 24 outside of your smaller pack size tests.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2087-------------------------
Midterm Exam Logistics and Practice Material
<p dir="ltr">Hi everyone! The mid-term exam is coming up. Here’s some key information.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Where To Take The Exam</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">You have three options for taking the exam:</p>


<ol><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">On a personal laptop, remotely from a location of your choice.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">On a personal laptop, in a North Campus classroom with power outlets at each seat.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">On a CAEN lab computer, in a North Campus computer lab. (This option is only available to students who do not have access to an adequate personal laptop.)</p>
</li></ol>


<p dir="ltr">If you would like to or feel that you need to take your exam in a classroom or CAEN lab please fill out the form below so that we can make sure that we have enough space. We will email you the room location confirmation a week before the exam. If you do not want us to reserve a space for you to take the exam, you don't need to fill out this form.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdNpuknbVlS0rminWRkfrAuR59giz66N7LKM35YqA7dToFP7Q/viewform?usp=sf_link" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Exam Room Registration</a></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr">If you have any questions please email eecs280exams@umich.edu</p>


<p dir="ltr">--EECS 280 Exam Team</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>When To Take The Exam</strong></p>


<ul><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">At the regular time, unless you have made arrangements with us to take the exam at an alternate time.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">If you have an extended time accommodation through the SSD office, your electronic exam and deadline on Canvas will be configured accordingly.</p>
</li></ul>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Exam Format</strong></p>


<ul><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">The exam is administered online; you take it in your web browser.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">The exam is "open everything". You may use any resources, including online resources. You may not collaborate with others.</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">You’ve got two hours to take the exam. Turn in your answers to Canvas before time is up.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">Each student receives a random set of questions drawn from a large question bank.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">Each student’s exam is “individually curved”. If you happen to get a harder set of questions, you’ll have a more generous curve.</p>
</li></ul>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>How To Take The Exam</strong></p>


<ol><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">An <strong>individualized exam link</strong> is emailed to you a couple days before the exam. When the exam starts, you can access your exam through that link (before the start of the exam, you’ll get a “404 not found” error for the link).</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">You take the exam in your web browser.</p>
</li><li dir="ltr">
<p dir="ltr">When you finish, click a button to download an <strong>answers file</strong>, which you must <strong>submit to Canvas</strong> before time is up.</p>
</li></ol>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Exam Coverage</strong></p>


<ul><li>The midterm exam covers material from lectures 1-10 (up to and including polymorphism).</li><li>Note: Some of the older practice materials include a significant amount of content on “C-Style ADTs” (as you used in project 2). We are transitioning to focus more on “C++ Style ADTs” (as you used in project 3), and these will player a bigger role on our midterm exam.</li></ul>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Live Practice Exam</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">Your link for the live practice exam will be emailed Tuesday evening, 10/11 with subject line "EECS 280 F22 Live Practice Final Exam". This practice exam is hosted using the same system as we will use for the real exam, and we highly recommend you take a chance to get familiar with it and with the question formats.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr">You are welcome to turn in your answers file for the live practice exam on Canvas. This is NOT required. It’s there in case you would like to practice the full exam process, end-to-end.</p>


<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://umich.instructure.com/courses/547703/assignments/1778548" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://umich.instructure.com/courses/547703/assignments/1778548</a></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr">The <strong>solutions</strong> for the live practice exam are available at:</p>


<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://lobster.eecs.umich.edu/exam-distribution/exams/eecs280f22practice-midterm/sample-solution.html" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://lobster.eecs.umich.edu/exam-distribution/exams/eecs280f22practice-midterm/sample-solution.html</a></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Additional Practice Exams and Other Materials</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">Additional practice materials, including copies of old paper exams, are available on our Google Drive:</p>


<p dir="ltr"><a href="https://drive.google.com/drive/u/1/folders/1Cewr2sAr_b_8FYD9pQRxc08JkK7txk4T" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">https://drive.google.com/drive/u/1/folders/1Cewr2sAr_b_8FYD9pQRxc08JkK7txk4T</a></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Exam Interface:</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">When you open the exam, you should get a welcome pop-up. If you don't see this (on either the practice exam or real exam), it means something went wrong and the page hasn't loaded correctly. Let us know if this happens.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr">The exam interface should look generally like this in your web browser. If it doesn’t, please let us know. (Especially if page elements like the “Answers File” button are misplaced, or if you didn't get the welcome popup mentioned above.)</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Feedback/Issues</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">Please use the follow-ups below to report any bugs/issues or other feedback.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>FAQ:</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Q: Do I have to take the exam through my link?</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">A: Yes. Each student’s exam is randomized, and we keep a record of who was assigned each question. If a student takes the exam through the wrong link, their questions won’t match up and they won’t receive credit. Please do not share your link with anyone.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Q: How can I ask questions during the exam?</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">A: You may ask questions on Piazza or join a Zoom call with staff. We're happy to answer questions about the questions, but we can't provide any information that assists in coming up with a solution.</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Q: Is the exam proctored? Do I need to join a zoom call or install proctoring software?</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">A: No, but staff are available on a zoom call linked from the exam page in case you have questions.</p>


<p dir="ltr">Troubleshooting:</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"><strong>Q: What should I do if I open the exam and I don't see the "popup" with the honor code info where I click "I understand"?</strong></p>


<p dir="ltr">A: This most likely means one of the 3rd part libraries used by the site didn't load correctly from its CDN. This can happen due to an unreliable internet connection or restrictions by your ISP or internet provider. Try refreshing the page a few times to see if it loads correctly. As long as it loads correctly once, you're all set (the exam application doesn't need to contact a server at all once it's started). If you have issues, please join our zoom call and we can help!</p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>


<p dir="ltr"></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When I ask questions on piazza during the exam, will I create a private question addressed to only instructors or will I post a piazza post?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yep, we'll change the settings on Piazza during the exam so that only private posts to instructors are allowed.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I tested positive for Covid today. Am I expected to still take the exam as normal on Wednesday?</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Since the exam is remote, you can take it at the normal time if you like. But if you're not feeling reasonably well enough to take the exam, we can get you set up with an alternate, later time once you're doing better. Please send us an email or fill out the extension request form on eecs280.org.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>What time will the Live Practice Exam be opened and closed?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>It’s called “live”, but you can actually take it whenever you’d like. I think by live they simply mean it’s got a timer and is in the same web format that you’ll encounter on the real exam.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>How many of the questions will be multiple choice or short answers? How many total questions will there be?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>We don't provide any specific details, but we generally try to make sure the format of the exam will not be surprising given the practice materials that we've given. The most notable difference is that there are some formats on the electronic exams (e.g. drag/drop code blocks) that just don't exist on the old paper exams.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>for coding problems, will we be graded on how efficient our code is? for instance, if we come up with an inefficient solution for a problem will we get points off even if it produces the correct output?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo2ooY"><p>Likely not, we’ve only barely touched on time efficiency and it hasn’t been counted against us or enforced before.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>For the midterm, we generally aren't going to ask you to write code with a particular efficiency. That might be a bit more relevant for the final exam and could show up in a minor way there, since we cover efficiency and complexity at an intro level in the 2nd half of the course.</p>


<p></p>


<p>However, one notable exception is that you should make sure to use best practices w.r.t. e.g. passing parameters correctly. For example, a string that you're not intending to modify should generally be passed by const reference, not by value.</p>

------------------------@2088-------------------------
Shuffle question ( correct output after 7 shuffle )
<p>After shuffling the cards seven times with the in-shuffle, do I return to the same order as PacK.in ?? When I asserted the first three cards I got the same result as pack.in order. </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Nope, you will return to the same order you started after 20 shuffles. 7 shuffles should make the pack different.</p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Is there any place where I can find the correct order after seven shuffles so that I can match it with my own shuffle output?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I believe the public case only tests the first card after 7 shuffles. Meaning it calls shuffle once and checks the first card. I would make a test that checks if the pack is the same as when you started. You can do this by creating 2 packs. Calling shuffle 20 times(meaning 140 individiual shuffles) on one pack, and checking if each card is equal in both packs. I also checked first if my cards were correct after 1 out of the 7 shuffles. I wrote out by hand what they would be after 1 shuffle(of 7), then printed out the hand and compared the results. </p>

------------------------@2091-------------------------
Deal order
<p>Would the deal order be player 1, player 2, player 3, player 0 or would it be player 3, player 2, player 1, player 0?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Player 0 deals first, followed by 1, 2, and 3 and then back to 0</p>

------------------------@2092-------------------------
Problem reading in from argv
<p>For some reason my argv is taking in the file location as well.  Note that the junk variable below is initialized to argv[0]. Therefore everything is one off. How do I fix this?</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky342nr86vr4or%2F69319ff38841bbe28c9f581a45b2e37af4d629ab6bef66713ef5b4ca40d1e4bb%2Fimage.png"/></p>

------------------------@2094-------------------------

From a design perspective, your game logic shouldn't discriminate between the player types; since the details of each player is abstracted away into Player.cpp, euchre.cpp shouldn't worry about it.</p>

------------------------@2096-------------------------
error from public tests
<p><a href="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fkk2z87jli277iw%2Fb730e82c891b29caf63df4c2f2e9f48bf440462ae89b5260330ebf22013aff99%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_09.41.52.png" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">Screen_Shot_2022-10-10_at_09.41.52.png</a></p>

------------------------@2097-------------------------
#includes in euchre.cpp
<p>Do we #include "Player.h" or #include "Player.cpp" in euchre.cpp? Just wondering because Player.h doesn't have overrides of SimplePlayer and HumanPlayer that were written in the player cpp file</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>You always want to include the header file, never the cpp file. Because your Simple Player and Human Player were written in the Player.cpp file which *includes* the Player.h file itself, the compiler is smart enough to bundle it all together. You'll learn more about this concept in EECS 370 if you end up taking it.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2098-------------------------
My code works when complied with address sanitizer but doesnt when compiled without it
<p>With Address Sanitizer: <img alt="image.pngNaN" height="247" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky342nr86vr4or%2Fd90ddd2611c16289bd77c39a65c7bdd2878cd28f0eb3c7d40b1f8cfd48870961%2Fimage.png" width="421"/></p>


<p></p>


<p>Without:</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky342nr86vr4or%2Ff89025b99b747d5d7bdd109ffe3d81568832a7333a6e361ec28db850c66a03e3%2Fimage.png"/></p>


<p></p>


<p></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>It's possible there's some undefined behavior in your code the address sanitizer isn't catching. Try re-compiling your code <strong>without</strong> the sanitizer, and then running the program under your debugger. Your debugger will stop on the failed assert, and you'll be able to trace why that assert failed from there.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also, note that the assert "assert(false)" always fails when run. Did you leave this in your Game::findTeam() function by mistake?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>I was able to find that address sanitizer was not running in visual studio, after enabling it I received these Access violation errors.<br/><br/></p>


<p>How do I fix them?</p>


<p><img alt="image.pngNaN" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fky342nr86vr4or%2F7edc4e2abdc40cfef33955fe5d6d1980ea75af6eee391c54a199bffcce99b54f%2Fimage.png"/></p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Access violations occur when you access an invalid memory location; this could be caused by dereferencing a null or freed pointer, indexing out of the bounds of an array/vector, using member variables in a class that haven't been initialized by the constructor, etc. A common bug in P3 is forgetting to initialize member variables in the constructors you write. I would check that each constructor you wrote uses an initializer list, and initializes all of its member variables before reading them. If you don't find anything there, double-check you aren't walking off the end of any vectors/arrays.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Also correct me if I'm wrong, but it looks like you're running your code in Windows without using WSL. To get as close to the autograder's environment as possible, I recommend using WSL (or CAEN) to debug your code; ASan support will probably be better on both of those platforms, too.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2099-------------------------
Adding the Upcard and Discarding a Card
<p>in the Adding the Upcard and Discarding a Card function for the simple player is the upcard considered trump for comparison of card worth? in other words, do we call</p>


<div>
<div>bool Card_less(const Card &amp;a, const Card &amp;b, const std::string &amp;trump) {</div>
</div>


<div>or operator&lt; </div>


<div>
<div></div>
</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>When adding and discarding the upcard, you are at a point in the game where trump has been selected. Therefore you should use the <code>Card_less()</code> function since only it will consider trump when deciding card value.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>so then the upcard's suit is the trump?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2100-------------------------
Reached Player.cpp, what are we supposed to function stubs are we supposed to put in?
<p>I just reached Player.cpp, what exactly do we put in there now? I remember in the setup it said to only put in Player_factory() and operator&lt;&lt;. What is the order we should code Player.cpp in?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The function stubs it instructed for you to include at the beginning were so that the file would compile (but not work). You may now proceed to implement the Player.cpp functions, the order in which you do them doesn’t really matter. If one function requires the use of another one, then of course you would want to implement the used function first.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The two functions you listed are declared in the header file and we want you to implement them in the cpp file. They are not "member" functions.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Note that Player is an abstract class, you may want to implement the SimplePlayer's and HumanPlayer's own versions of functions (like add_card(), make_trump() etc.). You can also add member variables to these two classes.</p>


<p></p>


<p>You may want to add other helper functions if needed, and they might belong to a class (depends on how you want to use them).</p>

------------------------@2103-------------------------
play card question
<p>lets say you have a hand of cards like </p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>queen_hearts</p>


<p>jack_hearts</p>


<p>jack_diamonds</p>


<p>ten_diamonds</p>


<p>ace_spades</p>



<div>if both the trump and lead suit are hearts,</div>


<div>the first card returned is jack of hearts</div>


<div>but the second card returned should be queen of hearts right? not the left bower jack of diamond?</div>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>From the spec:</p>
<blockquote>
<p>If a Simple Player can follow suit, they play the highest card that follows suit. Otherwise, they play the lowest card in their hand.</p>
</blockquote>
<p>Based on this, they would play their highest Hearts first which is Jack of Hearts (right bower). The next round, they follow the same strategy where now the Jack of Diamond (left bower) is the highest card that follows suit of Hearts.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2107-------------------------
euchre_test01.out.correct question
<p>From lines 19-23 in the euchre_test01.out.correct file, the following is listed: (the trump suit is HEARTS)</p>


<p></p>


<p>King of Diamonds led by Edsger<br/>Nine of Spades played by Fran<br/>Nine of Clubs played by Gabriel<br/>Queen of Diamonds played by Herb<br/>Edsger takes the trick</p>


<p></p>


<p>After doing some debugging, I saw that GABRIEL has a Jack of Diamonds. Shouldn't it be expected that Gabriel plays the Jack of Diamonds instead of the Nine of Clubs since Gabriel has a card that allows him to follow suit? Am I misunderstanding the rules of the game? I would appreciate a clarification.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The jack of diamonds is the left bower, so it is treated completely as if it is a heart. Thus, it is not the same suit as the king of diamonds. Even if you were to lead with the jack of diamonds, the led suit should still be hearts.</p>

------------------------@2109-------------------------
shuffle function
<p>I saw the answer below from another question. Do we loop the whole process below seven times? Also are we creating a new container that will hold the shuffled cards and then assign all those values to the initial cards container?</p>


<p></p>


<p><strong>In the shuffle, the deck is split exactly in half. The cards are weaved such that</strong></p>


<ul><li><strong>the top card of the bottom half is now the first card</strong></li><li><strong>the top card of the top half (original top card) is now the second card</strong></li><li><strong>the second card of the bottom half is now the third card</strong></li><li><strong>the second card of the top half is now the fourth card</strong></li><li><strong>…</strong></li><li><strong>the bottom card of the bottom half is now the twenty-third card</strong></li><li><strong>the bottom card of the top half is now the bottom card</strong></li></ul>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>We do loop the whole process seven times. You can implement the shuffling any way you wish (creating an array of the indices, creating a new array with the new order, etc.). Just make sure to assign the new order to the original array/vector storing the cards.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2113-------------------------
question about bad test cases
<p><img alt="Screen_Shot_2022-10-12_at_4.15.16_PM.pngNaN" height="281" src="/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&amp;prefix=paste%2Fl7zih2mbmcf5j%2F6a32a14d0d2ec52338409657d6b21cfac6d40d900e638889a5d5983b9b2ce271%2FScreen_Shot_2022-10-12_at_4.15.16_PM.png" width="367"/></p>


<p>Hi, I want to ask the problem wit this test case is that it access the private data right? If you use *Matrix_at, it would be no problem right? Do we need to not access data directly even if it is a struct not a class? Thank. you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Yes, you could repair this test case by using Matrix_at(). Because structs don't have functions, you cannot implement getter and setter functions that would allow you to respect the interface. This is why a class is optimal in this case.

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Thank you! So since it's a struct, we can only break the interface. But in practice, we could use class to fix this issue right?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>Yes you can make variables private in a class and make getter/setter functions to interact with it.</p>
<p>For this test case, you don’t have to break the interface you can instead call Matrix_at.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Also, we will not get a compile error if we break the interface for struct, but we will get one for class right?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo1ooY"><p>Yes, you aren’t able to access any private members outside of the class (we generally make member variables private).</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2115-------------------------
questions about C struct and C++ class
<p>Hi, I want to know whether c++ class is a better replacement for c struct, which means we could only need to know the c++ class. Or should we also learn about c struct? Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
Both are used for different uses. Structs (for the purpose of this class) cannot hold functions so C++ classes are more versatile in that respect. Structs are typically used when creating objects with a series of member variables, but can always be replaced by a class.
<div><br/></div>
<div>Here's a great page on how to decide when to use a class vs. a struct: </div>
<div><br/></div>
<div>https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/choosing-between-class-and-struct?redirectedfrom=MSDN</div>
<div><br/></div>
<div><br/></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2118-------------------------
Question from Lecture 8 (ADT in C++)
<p>Sorry this might be from a while ago, I'm wondering for composing abstract data types in c++ (nested classes), is it possible for say Class A to be called in Class B, if Class B has also been called in Class A? What about when Class B calls another Class C in its member list, can Class B still be called in Class A's member list? (and so on) Thanks!</p>


<p></p>


<p>For example:</p>


<p></p>


<p>class Professor{</p>


<p>private:</p>


<p>Coffee favcoffee;</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>}</p>


<p></p>


<p>//while also having this</p>


<p>class Coffee{</p>


<p>private:</p>


<p>Professor favprofessor;</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>}</p>


<p></p>


<p></p>


<p>//what about this</p>


<p>class Coffee{</p>


<p>private:</p>


<p>Flavor allflavors[6];</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>}</p>


<p></p>


<p>class Flavor{</p>


<p>private:</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>public:</p>


<p>//define "allflavors"</p>


<p>...</p>


<p>}</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>I would say this might not be allowed due to an infinite cycle occurring. Each member variable of a class will be instantiated either with a default value or a custom constructor. So since Coffee has a Professor object inside it, that Professor object will have its own Coffee object, and that Coffee object will then have its own Professor object, etc…</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2121-------------------------
void play();

------------------------@2124-------------------------
Card_less
<p>Let's say I have two cards, one is diamonds and the second one is spades. The lead suit is diamonds but the trump is spades. Which card would be considered smaller? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The diamond. Trump beats every non-trump card, unconditionally - trump will only lose to a higher trump card. The led suit then beats every non led suit and non trump card. Then, the cards follow the order described in <a href="https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards" rel="noreferrer" target="_blank">value of cards</a>.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2125-------------------------
