------------------------@2126-------------------------
Question about Pack Constructor number 2
<p>For the second Pack constructor, I'm reading in each line into rank, garbage, and suit but since this will only read in the rank and suit without the CARD:: in front, do I have to change each rank and suit to do this? Even after I do this, my test case is still skipping over the constructor and going on to the next function.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The "Card::" is just a namespace qualifier for the variable that comes after. For example, Card::RANK_TWO refers to the RANK_TWO variable inside the Card class (you can see this in Card.h). Card::RANK_TWO has a value of "Two", and Card::SUIT_SPADES has a value of "Spades", etc. So you shouldn't have to modify the input from the istream object in the Pack constructor.</p>


<p></p>


<p>Could you elaborate on what you mean by "skipping over" the constructor in your test, please?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>When I was debugging the debugger skipped over the second pack constructor but now I got it to run but the test case fails. I think I'm reading in the pack.in wrong. When I read in, it's reading in the whole line. I'm not sure how I can make the program stop at every whitespace and then set the values of suit and rank appropriately to initialize each card.</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you're reading input into a string using the &gt;&gt; operator, the istream object should separate by whitespace by default. If you're using something like getline(), it will get the whole line of input, so I recommend the former approach.</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2127-------------------------
euchre.cpp length
<p>approximately how many lines is euchre.cpp supposed to be when done? </p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>There is no length euchre.cpp is "supposed" to be, as each implementation will be of slightly different length. For reference, my solution is about 300 lines, but yours could definitely be more or less, due to a range of both trivial factors (like newlines and how you format your code) and important decisions (like how well you re-use your code).</p>


<p></p>


<p>It sounds like you're more interested in the question "how much effort will euchre.cpp take?" Line count is not an accurate indicator of effort, but I'll say this: Most students (myself included) spend way more time debugging euchre than writing it. This is true not just for EECS 280, but for complex projects in general. If you work consistently on P3 now so you give yourself ample time to debug later, you'll set yourself up nicely for success. :)</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2128-------------------------
reference and pointer
<p>Hi, I want to ask the difference between a pointer * to a variable and the reference &amp; of a variable. So, the reference does't take memory and we don't really create anything and the reference can't change right? Can an object have more than one reference? On the other hand, the pointer takes memory and can point to other object right? When we should use reference and when we should use pointer? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<blockquote>
<p>So, the reference doesn't take memory and we don't really create anything</p>
</blockquote>


<p>The details of how references use memory are a bit complicated, and definitely aren't needed in 280. But in a nutshell, in some cases (like if you have a local variable and a reference to it in a function), the compiler can treat a reference exactly as an "alias" for the original variable, and just replace all uses of the reference with the original variable -- this means the reference takes no additional memory. In other cases (like if you have a function that takes references as input), the compiler might implement the reference with a pointer, which does take memory. But you don't have to worry about these details.</p>


<p>You are correct that the reference does not create any new data, but instead becomes another name for an object. at runtime.</p>


<p></p>


<blockquote>
<p>and the reference can't change, right?</p>
</blockquote>


<p>Yes, you're correct. When creating a reference, you must set it equal to a variable, and after the reference has been set to alias another variable, it cannot be set to a different variable. For example, "int &amp;a;" is a compiler error because you declared a reference, but didn't set it to a variable. Also, "int &amp;a = x; a = y" does not set a to alias y, but instead sets x to be the same value as y.</p>


<p></p>


<blockquote>
<p>Can an object have more than one reference?</p>
</blockquote>


<p></p>


<p>Yes, you can have multiple references to the same object.</p>


<p></p>


<blockquote>
<p>On the other hand, the pointer takes memory and can point to other object right?</p>
</blockquote>


<p></p>


<p>Yes, once a non-const pointer is set to point to an object, it can be set to point to a different object. However, you don't want to lose track of the first object, because if it was dynamically allocated (i.e. with the "new" keyword), you're responsible for deleting it, which requires a pointer to it.</p>


<p></p>


<blockquote>
<p>When we should use reference and when we should use pointer?</p>
</blockquote>


<p></p>


<p>In general, pointers can do everything references can do, but references cannot do everything pointers can do. For example, if you want to pass an object to a function without making a copy of it, you can write the function to take a reference as input, or a pointer as input. However, if you want to keep track of an object in dynamic memory, you must use a pointer. Also, references cannot do pointer arithmetic, which is sometimes useful. Overall, pointers are more powerful, but arguably harder to use correctly -- they introduce an entire class of errors, like null pointer dereferences and dereferencing de-allocated/invalid memory.</p>


<p></p>


<p>If you can use references to implement something (like a function that is pass-by-reference), I recommend you use them instead!</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2129-------------------------
question about const
<p>Hi, I just want to double check whether the const function can only call a const object, but the const object can be called by non-const functions? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>A function that has the <code>const</code> tag at the end of it means that you can’t modify the member variables of the class. You can still create and edit local variables, but you can only read member variables, not edit them. For example:</p>
<pre><span class="hljs-class"><span class="hljs-keyword">class</span> <span class="hljs-title">A</span> {</span>
<span class="hljs-function"><span class="hljs-keyword">void</span> <span class="hljs-title">my_function</span><span class="hljs-params">()</span> <span class="hljs-keyword">const</span> </span>{
	<span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">cout</span> &lt;&lt; a &lt;&lt; <span class="hljs-built_in">std</span>::<span class="hljs-built_in">endl</span>; <span class="hljs-comment">// works!</span>
	a = b; <span class="hljs-comment">// doesn't work! you can't modify class variables in a const func</span>
}
<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> a = <span class="hljs-number">9</span>;
<span class="hljs-keyword">int</span> b = <span class="hljs-number">10</span>;
}
<div class="compile_code"><button class="compile_code_button" data-id="compileCodeBtnId" onclick="return PE.openCodeRunner('');">run code snippet</button><div class="code_runner_notify">Visit Manage Class to disable runnable code snippets<button onclick="return PE.dismissCodeRunnerNotice();">×</button></div></div></pre><p>Under the hood, how it works is that the <code>this</code> pointer passed to the function is passed as a <code>const</code> pointer.</p></div>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Ditto the student's answer. This means you are allowed to call const member functions on non-const objects.</p>

------------------------@2130-------------------------
use of the helper functions in game class
<p>if I wanted to use the helper functions in the game class, what would that look like? I am confused on how one would use the helper functions in the game class when we have already implemented these same functions?</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>If you have implemented these helper functions as member functions in the Game class, you can simply call them where necessary in play().</p>


<p></p>


<blockquote>
<p>how one would use the helper functions in the game class when we have already implemented these same functions?</p>
</blockquote>


<p>Just to clarify, the shuffle/deal/make_trump/etc. helper functions in the Game class mentioned in the spec aren't the same functions as those in Pack/Player/etc. (even though they have the same names -- sorry about the confusion there!). The idea here is that the Game functions use those functions in Player/Pack/etc. as necessary to implement a part of the game's logic. For example, each Player has their own make_trump() function; how can you put their individual functionality together to make trump for an actual round of Euchre?</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2132-------------------------
lead card when there's a left-bower
<p>Hi, I want to ask if a player has a left-bower, will he/she lead the left-bower? Or the left-bower is a trump card in every situation? Thank you so much!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>Yes, the left bower is always considered a trump suit</p>

-------------------------------------------------

------------------------@2133-------------------------
order of the card
<p>Hi, I want to ask that whether the order of cards if D&gt;C&gt;H&gt;S, since it's different from the traditional order. Thank you!</p>

-------------------------------------------------
<p>The order of the cards is A &gt; K &gt; Q &gt; J &gt; 10 &gt; 9 (this is by rank), in the case of ties, the order for suits is D &gt; C &gt; H &gt; S</p>

-------------------------------------------------

-------------------------------------------------
<div class="markdown" id="q38kRj58oo0ooY"><p>The autograder will not test cards outside of the Euchre range (9 to A).</p></div>
